reviews.review: 10/10 recommend . This was my favorite part of my Cape Town visit. Go up to the light house and then down to the Cape of Good Hope. It is extra windy but fun to explore the rocks and watch the waves crash.

What a place!. This was another outstanding adventure on our trip to Cape Town. The park is huge and breathtaking. Makes a lovely day trip. When we actually arrived at the Point, the wind was so strong we could hardly open the car door so watch your hats! A thrill to be there.
Amzing. Amazing views!!! Could spend endless amount of time looking at the ocean. Bamboos in area beware, also saw ostriches.
Absolutely a must go . We went here yesterday. The view is seriously amazing. From this point you can also walk to Cape of the good hope. Loved it!

Great Day . Visited here on our day trip from Cape Town.
The views are magnificent went up to the lighthouse some great views from the top.
Well worth a visit.

Views Views Views. Drive yourself, Hire a driver or take a tour.The views all along the way are spectacular.In the reserve we saw an ostrich pair with 8 chicks just hanging out by the roadside.Needless to say every car stopped to take a closer look and photos.The views at Cape Point lighthouse are really something to see. The ocean is clear and blue the beaches white sand.You can walk up or take a funicular for a small fee which is good for the less mobile.There are warning signs about Baboons but we didn't see any. Return to Cape Town via the penguin colony.....must do this as well
BREATHTAKING VIEWS. The long walk was definitely worth it when we saw the joining of the two oceans. Very windy up at the top. Views were breathtaking.

Great experience!. Be ready to walk... it is a bit of a long drive from Cape Town but make sure you drive through the coast as the landscape is extremely beautiful!You make a stop on your way there at Simon's Town and watch the African penguins. The restaurant up there is pretty nice with great views to the ocean!
The end of the world that I loved :). It's great to stand at the end of the world, especially if you walk there - I recommend walking from the lighthouse to the point. Wear windproof & warm clothes.
Worth the drive. Fantastic vistas, and super cool to be at the tip of Africa. Walk up to light house if you can. Bring water

lovley beach quiet experience. it was wonderful lots of tourist so beautiful walking on the beach at night..my family really had a lovely experience in cape town, strongly recommend it for other people.

Popular tourist spot. Sadly National Parks cannot cope with the crowds visiting this attraction. Long queues to get into the park, very unpleasant gate staff and then the restaurants and shop are incredibly busy. Take your own food and drinks and it will save you a lot of time.
Gorgeous Place. Absolutely Stunning views. Well worth the drive to view. Would recommend to see if visiting Capetown

Saw ostrich!. Visited the Cape Point Lighthouse which was a bit of a let-down - the visit up to the top was more interesting than arriving at the top. However there are excellent gift shops (at the top and bottom, both selling different items). Was delighted to see wild ostrich - a male, female and their chicks! The area with the Cape Hope sign is touristy but worth a visit.

Beautiful scenery and everything works efficiently. The trip up to the Lighthouse is really great, and the views stretch far and wide. they have a shop at the bottom and at the top, and a restaurant. The drive to cape of Good Hope also fantastic, really great, just can be crowded on weekends.
Amazing. Amazing, I mean; THIS is Africa with all its power. You MUST go! Be careful with the local Baboons which will try to enter to your cart and still your food if your aren't careful!

An Amazing visit!. This stop should not be considered for just those who love nature. It was actually an amazing place to see. We came across many beautiful spring blooming plants, saw the world famous record sized South African surfing waves and MANY wildlife animals in the park.

Long drive enjoy the view. Also cape of Good hope, truly the most SW point of South Africa, take a looong walk to the top of one of the hills, soak in the breeze and think of how lucky you are to make it there...

Many look outs. Beautiful scenery.. A long time from Cape Town to there but so worth it. You have to arrive early to get decent parking and to miss the crowds. Take your own snacks because te restuarant is a bit pricey.

A subtle but spectacular hidden gem. Some of the attractions of the Cape Point Nature Reserve are visually stunning but some are more subtle, requiring a little more time to appreciate. Dias Beach provides a visual feast, as does the view from the Point itself. It isn't the actual southernmost tip of Africa, nor is it the meeting of two oceans, but it should be! It's a spectacularly dramatic meeting point, particularly in slightly stormy weather, of two mighty ocean currents, and to view the roiling ocean from the lofty viewpoint above is unforgettable. There is a good restaurant at the base of the funicular which provides a superb view across the bay. Just be careful of the baboons stealing your lunch if you decide to have a packed lunch outside.Take time to drive down as many of the side roads as you find time for, particularly Buffels Baai and Olifanstsbos. There are many beautiful and secluded beaches, some with designated picnic spots, where one can braai. Again, beware of those crafty baboons, who will stare soulfully out at the ocean whilst timing their raiding sorties on your picnic!There are truly wonderful hikes, where one can see all manner of bird life, an explosion of flowering fynbos in Spring, plus an assortment of antelope. One of the extraordinary things one can experience is to look up from one's beach picnic, to see ostriches pecking away amidst the kelp!I have yet to do so, but one can also stay overnight or longer in one of the SANPark self-catering cottages.

Overcrowded. We visited in a tour group as part of an African holiday. It includes Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope. In contrast with a free visit I made here in the mid 90s, this attraction now charges entry, is as commercial as they can make it and is overcrowded with tourists (like us) so that there is no longer any sense of being wild or unique.

Ausome nature reserve with some fantastic viewing sights.. you must make time for visiting this place as there is so much to see, beautiful nature reserve, awesome sea views. you can even picnic at some of the many spots within the reserve. there is a fantastic restaurant at the most southerly point of the reserve, with an tram to take you up to the top if you so wish. you have to drive down to cape Point to get there, so a car is essential. you also need to choose a nice sunny day as this will be preferable.

Good day trip. The funicular was a good slow trip to the top of Cape Point Lighthouse to see the magnificent views of False Bay. The sheer cliffs were magical, and the history of the area is immense. The drive down to Cape Point itself is great and to actually be at the south western most point of Africa

a place where you can reconnect with nature in its truest form. Experience a taste of the world as it once was. apart from boasting some of the planets most scenic beaches, what strikes me the most is the absolute serenity of a world gone by - a place free from the chaotic impact of humanity that surrounds us on a permanent basis. go and have the breathe of fresh air. let the cold atlantic clear out your lungs. let your eyes feast on the breath taking scenery. let the cool wind rustle your hair. watch the 7-gill sharks frolic in azure blue waters. hike to your hearts content. find peace in the silence of grazing bucks or surf the fiesty ocean. two key things: watch out for baboons. do not eat anywhere but inside your car. DO NOT FEED THE WILD LIFE - a fed baboon is a dead baboon. choose a windless day

Explore du cape. As what most people always refer to as the end of our continent, of course Agulhas Point is really but us locals just feel its closer. This was an awesome day if sightseeing and driving through the fynbos cant wait to do it again with my wife next year. Definitely a have to see.

The Cape on a lovely day. Choose your day carefully if you can to travel south. Sun is a must for the spectacular photographs that are available. The cable car up to the top is a great experience and once at the top the views are wonderful. We ate at the restaurant to the left of the cable car before we boarded and it was excellent. Service, food and views set the day apart. There is another kiosk at the top which looked very good but very busy. The scenery and colour of the water made for stunning photographs. We didn't go all the way down to the beach end of South Africa as the day changed and became overcast and cold.
The Ultimate Hike. The most amazing hike I ever did Our beautiful country right here in our backyard . An experience that will last a lifetime .

A must see.. Hired a car for 2 days. Day one to Hermanus and the whales. Day2, Cape Point. I chose a car rental instead of a tour as we were 3 and would save money and I didn't want my time limited as is on a tour. I also started from central Cape Town and drove around Sea Point and Clifton before driving Chapman's Peak and onto Cape Point. Coming back to Cape Town via Simon's Town , Boulders Beach and Muizenburg.Instead of taking the funicular we hiked up to the top station and onto the lighthouse..Coming down again on foot we walked to the older lighthouse on the right hand side all the time admiring the fauna and flora as well as the cliffs and ocean of this beautiful area.

Always impressive. Get there early to avoid the crowds, preferably for breakfast. On the restaurant food its ok but as is the want with tourist attractions, can be a wee bit pricy. But then you are not here for gourmet food but for the views. Spectacular especially from the lighthouse at the top. If you are fit take a walk up otherwise a very good funicular to take you up. Also on the way out visit the most South westerly point of Africa were you will more than likely have baboons trying to get at any food you have in the car ( take care) and may see ostriches wandering around on the seashore. The picture included was taken from the sea looking back at Cape Point towards Cape Town with Table Mountain in the back ground.

Great Day Out for Spectacular views, exercise and Fresh Air. It was rather busier than I expected but not overly crowded. There were many tracks and look outs to explore which gives you different angles of the landscape which included the lighthouse and Cape of Good Hope and many of the surrounding mountains and oceans. The gondular was a nice touch as a method of getting to the top but another short walk of some 50 steps or so steps are required to get to the lighthouse. Get there a little early if you want to do the Cape of Good Hope walk as that takes 1.5 hours, and the other short tracks can have you walking around for at least an hour ( and more time if you head into the shop)
Cape Point. Good place to go. Very scenic. Only an hour's drive. Touristy -- but that was to be expected. A must see.

a beautiful drive down the cape point.. We enjoyed the drive down to Cape Point. A beautiful drive along the coast --very much like the California coastline. At the National Park we saw baboons, ostriches and a few antelope type things. Cape of Good Hope is a lovely scenic spot. One can take a tram car --or the lovely paved walk. Incredible views. Kind of a major tourist parking lot, though.

A SIGHT TO SEE. Amazing views from the top a bit windy so hold on to your hat.take the funicular tram up to the to save a long walk .there is an old lighthouse at the top.It is well worth the visit to see the Indian and Atlantic oceans meeting.

Stunning scenery. If you are staying in Cape Town and have a car, take a nice drive down to the cape along the coast road for stunning views. Allow around 2 hours to get to the reserve and be prepared to queue to get in - they are not very fast taking money! Once through, you can drive around the various viewpoints, watching out for the ostriches holding up the traffic! The lighthouse gest very busy for parking so expect to park on the road and walk up, people do leave regularly so don't give up, there are nice views from the top.

Beautiful Fynbos landscapes. If you love nature, you will enjoy visiting the Cape Point Nature Reserve. Try and get there early to avoid the coach loads of tourists that arrive from about 11 am. We did the walk from the car park by the lighthouse to the Cape Point - stunning!
Atmospheric. This is a must. Not the most southern point but such an evocative place. It's a fair walk over to Cape Point but well worth it if only to see the wild ostriches!

Beautiful view from the top. It's amazing to see in person this creation of God. Beautiful landscape and unspoiled turquoise water. We were surprised to see a family of ostrich walking at the middle of the road and a turtle crossing the street. There is a fee to ride the funicular to see the top. Wear your hiking shoes and be ready for the walk!

Absolutely stunning area well worth a visit. Wear good strong shoes or boots and go for a decent hike in this stunningly beautiful area. You will not be disappointed. The wild flowers (fynbos) were absolutely beautiful. Take care on the footpaths.

Beautiful nature reserve . At the most Southern West tip of Africa lies the Cape Point nature reserve. A fee of about R125 ($9) gets you inside the reserve per person. Take a slow drive around the reserve and take in the natural vegetation and typography of the area. Home to a wide variety of fynbos. The park has beautiful beaches and sites and the odd animal. We saw a few ostrichs. Take the cable car to the lighthouse and walk around there. It's really beautiful up there and you're right on the edge of the cliffs. There's also a little bit of history regarding the early Dutch settlers to the Cape for those history buffs. There's a decent restaurant in the reserve where you can have a good lunch and beer or some quality local Cape Town wine. We spent about 7 hours in the reserve walking, driving and exploring. It's really so picturesque and beautiful. Keep an eye on the time though because you get a big fine if you arrive too late back at the exit gates!

Imposant views . Easy to get there. You have to walk a bit (or use the flying dutchman) to get to the old lighthouse - it is windy there! It's a great idea to walk to the old lighthouse around: only 25 minutes and even less people there. ;-)On your way out make a left and stop at the stony beach unbeneath the hill - great waves.

You gotta go and see it!. This offers a good half day trip, longer if you do some of the great walks too. Amazing countryside, great views across the oceans and to Table Mountain, busy at weekends but not that bad really when compared to the UK. Well worth the trip

A great experience.. We were fortunate to visit it on a brilliantly clear day. The views of the two oceans meeting at the point was thrilling to sea, as was the surge of the ocean breaking on the rocks below A rather longish drive from the City, but more than worth it.

To be seen but nothing that special. We drove from Cape Town. Quite a long, but very nice drive via Camps bay /the Atlantic coast. We didn't see any baboons (while friends told me there are plenty ), but we saw the at Simon's town. There is a small funicular so perfect for all ages /fitness levels. You can hike, take nice pictures of a cormorans colony and THE meeting of the 2 oceans. At the end have lunch at the restaurant (not the fast food) located next to the funicular station. Great staff and fresh fish/seafood !

Unbelievable Views, Un-spoilt Beaches. I visited Cape Point many years ago on my first trip to South Africa - one of the highlights of my 3 month trip then was trekking up to the point to experience the amazing views and feeling like I was standing on the end of the earth! This year I went back as a "local" (I've now been living in SA for 7 years) and it didn't disappoint. We didn't make the trip to "the point" as it was holiday time and extremely busy but we took a picnic and explored the beautiful beaches, surfed in the quiet bays and spent the day in the sunshine. A timeless treat in Cape Town. The entry fee can get expensive if you're taking the whole family!

Read up, and then decide if you want to go. You might have different expectations and be disappointed. Okay, this nature reserve is incredibly popular. When you go, there could be dozens of buses and hundreds cars per hour, but really this is an extremely lite version of a South African nature reserve.The pros- Cape Point is stunning, huge cliffs, good viewpoints, crashing waves, a lighthouse. Spectacular. And this is often sold as the southernmost tip of Africa, where the Indian and Atlantic oceans meet. It is neither, but far more spectacular than the true southernmost point Cape Agulhas.- try a few smaller roads to get down to the sea The cons- pretty boring vegetation. Fynbos. Sanparks rangers get terribly excited by fynbos, and probably have wet dreams about it, but in truth it is not very exciting and if you drive from Cape Town in any direction you will see hundreds of kilometres of various types of fynbos. Now all sing, to the tune of "I joined the Navy to see the world"..."I went to Cape Town to see the (insert appropriate word) , but all that we saw, we saw the fynbos"- very few birds. Really, you struggle to find any- animals. Now here's the thing. Dont get confused by the name Nature Reserve and dont have any illusions about there being ANY animals, let alone any exciting African animals. I have been to Cape Point many many times. On the best, the absolute best, animal spotting occasions, and excluding the baboons at Cape Point which are pesky AND dangerous (do not under any circumstances try to picnic) I think I have seen about 10, including maybe 3 ostriches and 6 or 7 buck or zebra. When I visit, I visit to see Cape Point which as I said is spectacular and sometimes take side roads to get to quieter more scenic spots, for the rest I just drive straight through.
Nothing from here to Antartica!. The scenery is amazing, the waves are incredible and we found it difficult to believe we were actually standing at the Cape of Good Hope!

Perfect picture taking opportunity. We took the tramway up to the top for the views and then down again, but you can walk either way if you want the exercise. Then it was down the road to the sign (Cape of Good Hope) and lined up to get our picture taken (no official picture taking company, either by your friends, tour guide, or anybody else in line who is willing to oblige.) On the way there we saw baboons and ostriches which were a pleasant surprise.
Beautiful and rugged. This is a beautiful placd but very rugganimals are evrywhere.ed and if yo don't lie a windy place you should avoid it. Birdlife is prevalent and small
Views, beaches and wildlife. Well worth a visit when the weather is good. The views are amazing and the trip was rounded off when we saw a family of ostriches walking down the road!

Best views yet!. The most beautiful reserve we have yet to experience! The sights will not easily be forgotten! The funicular was just such fun!The views were breathtaking from just about any viewing point we walked to.An absolute MUST for ANYONE visiting Cape Town
Worth the drive from Cape Town. A beautiful drive from Cape Town, Enjoy the coastal views, Be respectful of any wildlife you may see, and the wildlife will vie respectful of you.
A must. What to say? Breath-taking views, nice wildlife, perfect walks. Be sure you get your camera ready, because the views are incredible. Cannot wait to be back :)

Amazing sights. Just the drive to the Cape is beautiful and makes you appreciate the amazing countryside around Cape Town. While our guide told us it would take 20-30 minutes to walk, we took our time and took lots of pictures, walking down to the beach and just soaking up the atmosphere. We even saw some seals playing in the surf. It took us a little under 2 hours to fully take the walk then saw ostriches and baboons on the drive out. A trip to Cape Town is not compete unless you visit this then stop at Boulder Beach on the way back (or there)!

Rugged Seaside Beauty. We visited Cape Point as part of a Penninsula Tour. As beautiful as it was, we found it pricey to gain admission for our group of eight for just a couple of hours. We visited the lighthouse and took in the beautiful views from up top. We enjoyed the antics of the many baboons in the area, although we understand they have become a huge nusiance. The wild ostrich by the road was a big treat. And of course we had to take our photo by the sign depicting the spot as the most south West Point in Africa.

Wondrous Site, yet REALLY Windy. We were looking for where the Atlantic intersects with the Indian, but turned out, we were in the wrong place. Oh well, it's still a beautiful sight. It was REALLY windy. I think this was the windiest place I've ever been. In spite of that, this is a cannot miss, in Cape Town.

Fun day trip from Cape Town. Nice to say we were at the south-western most point on the African continent. But this is not the most southern point. That's a couple hundred km east. Baboons (some aggressive if you have food) all over the place.
Breathtaking views. Beautiful area, very efficient service to the top on the funicular railway. Could have spent hours admiring the views.

A MUST DO !. We were on a full day tour of the Cape and only had a couple of hours here. It was enough to get to Cape point and down the walkway to the cliffs however it did leave me wanting more. The view from Cape Point is amazing
take a heli to have a good aerial view... it's awesome. nice view up there. It can get crowded and foggy on land. a must point to see.take a heli to have a good aerial view... it's awesome

Marvellous. A full day is needed - start in Cape Town, head out along Camps Bay onto Houtbay & Chapman Peak. Once in Cape Nature reserve look out for turn off to Cape of Good Hope. Scenic ride next to the ocean & you might just see ostriches. For the adventurous you can hike up from Cape of Good Hope to parking area near lighthouse - Stunning views. But you'll have to nominate a driver to drive car to main attraction - the lighthouse. For those interested the Funicular is R48 up only & R58 return (prices valid October 2016) Stunning views of False Bay & Atlantic ocean. But please note - very busy with tour buses & big coaches.Drive back to Cape Town via Simonstown (Boulders beach with the penguins) Kalkbay & Muizenberg - all these little bit a side towns ideal to stop at for late lunch

Not to be missed. I visited Cape Point on a recent trip to South Africa and would really recommend it. You do need a car and the better part of a day if you are staying in Cape Town. I would recommend getting an early start. This will help with entry into the area (the lines get long as the day goes on). The Cape Point area is beautiful, with interesting vegetation and birds and sea life. I can't really imagine a visit to this part of South Africa being complete without visiting. It is important to take you time and enjoy the scenery.
So beautiful. This is a must stop visit. We were able to hike/climb the stairs to amazing views and it was so worth it!

Beautiful place. Went with my family this week and enjoyed this place. It's better to arrive in the morning when it's less crowded. When we got out of the reserve we saw a lot of cars getting in.It was quite cold at that time of the year so bring a coat.
Amazing views and scenery!. We drove to Cape Point and was so very glad we made the trip! If is spectacular and is a definate for a South African experience!

Best day trip. We hired a car and drove round the east side first and came back up the west. This avoids the buses but some of the views in the afternoon on the west are somewhat impaired by the sunset glare. However, watching sunset from the beach is always fun. If you choose to drive the alternate direction, I would start early to beat the buses.Don't miss the Penguins at Boulder beach.

Visiting nature at the tip of Africa. Visited Cape Point Nature Reserve as part of a day-long tour. It was well worth the stop. Awe-inspiring view. Saw many animals on the way to the Point, while driving through the Reserve. Well worth the trip to get there.
Beautiful Place. We drove down here because of a recommendation and it was all he said it would be and more. It is a spectacular place and the views are incredible.

Great scenery and walks. As with other of the Cape Town area scenic hotshots, expect quite a few tourists to be heading here. This especially holds true for the South African summer periods. However, there are some great views and the walk to the light house is not too taxing. You can also catch a shuttle to the top so it's suitable for all.

Good day with lots to see. Did this day trip with Ilios tours and was just one other couple in van so had a personal experience .. Scenery great and guide was friendly and very chatty .. Lots of knowledge there Lucky with weather so enhanced experienceLunch not so great in Smithton .. Very overpriced and obviously for tourists and tourist companies Crayfish was a 'special of the day'For 650 rand or 65 Australian dollarsRubbish price as double what you would pay at upmarket restaurants in capetownTourist trap really That aside was a good trip and penguins are do interesting at boulders beach too

Best Part of SA tour . Must visit place Cape point and cape of good hopes . Really the best place to shoot movies . One cant even dream of beauty of mountains and speed of winds on cape point . Its 1.5 Hrs walk from parking of cape point to cape of good hopes . Its really a thrill and adventure to visit cape of good hope . A cable train takes you to top of mountain and to reach upto light house , You need to step around 75 stairs .

Where Two Oceans meet..... ...except they don't!
The oceans meeting is a myth, but it is still worth visiting the Point if only to see the baboons! There is a funicular to the top, but still a little bit of a walk up to the lighthouse, so prepare for a little exertion.

A Must Do. We were a small group and our guide drove us down from Cape Town to Cape Point via the ocean drive. What a spectacular drive and fabulous destination.We visited in school holidays so the car park was very full. It was a cool day and quite windy so I was glad to have a jacket with me.Having a bad knee I decided to go up on the Flying Dutchman funicular which takes you about three quarters of the way up to the top of the old lighthouse. From there is a walkway with steps to the viewing area at the light. The views are spectacular and we were lucky enough to see a Southern Right Whale .There are also a number of walks you can do including walking to the Cape of Good Hope.After coming back down we decided to have a bite to eat. There is a nice looking take away but we opted to dine at the Two Oceans Restaurant which was outstanding.
End of the World :). I took a small group guided day tour around the reserve and it was a beautiful experience. The coast, rocks and sea, the animals you see while walking. Unforgettable.
Amazing place. one of the best rides , from any side of the peninsula. you can really the two oceans meet each other .
Great view and very windy!. This place is unique and the the view at the lighthouse is great. Just be sure to bring a warm jacket because it is very windy up there.

Great trip down to Cape Point from Cape Town!. We were visiting Cape Town and chose to do a tour down the cape to Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope. Beautiful drive and great views once we got to Cape Point. There are trails you can walk there, so if you can leave some time for seeing the area.
The sea and the mountain together. A fabulous landscape where we have a mixture of sea and mountain. Very good, deserve the visit. Don't miss it.

Great experience. It was a nice sunny day when we visited the reserve with breathtaking and awesome views where the Atlantic meets the Indian ocean. We went up to the lighthouse and we use cable car down. A small hidden restaurant with average meals. Plenty wildlife and baboons. Watch out for your meals.
Not to be Missed. How can you go this far and not see Cape Point? Expect wind, great views and animals....baboons, ostrich and more.

Spectacular Views at Cape Point. Traveled via the coast from Cape Town which in itself a very pretty Journey. Upon reaching the cape the views exceeded all my expectations. Would recommend this trip without hesitation

Morning Sunrise. This is such a beautiful view of the ocean, cliffs, mountains and nature! There are spots to hike in the surrounding areas so hiking shoes or trainers are a must if you wish to get a better view of the surrounding area! It is quite a drive but once you get there it is worth it! Make it a day trip as there are TONS of little towns and attractions along the way! If you are young or old, in a group or alone... Cape Point Nature Reserve is the best place to be

Mind baboons!. We have visited this park at the end of September, it was a bit windy and cold day, a lot of buses and cars entered park, so Cape of Good Hope was overcrouded by tourists waiting for pictures and selfies at mark "Cape of Good Hope". But if You will drive slow and look around, You can see a lot of animals! There is dangerous and silly to eat Your snake or drink coffee on open air - baboons are very quick, impudent and excelent thiefs and danger! Do not show them Your meal! And for baboons could be Your irresponsible behavior very danger, too. For many tourists it is very funny, but if some baboon use to stole eat, he will be soon destroyed because he will become very agresive!
Beautiful. A must do. Great views, spring is best to avoid the crowds. Food at the Point isn't bad either and prices are fair, try the Ostrich Pizza.

Get a car, or a driver and go. I had a car and driver (it wasn't that expensive) take me for a private tour... how often are you going to go? do you want to be on a bus on someone else's schedule? Spend a few extra dollars and take a private car. Some breath taking views and sights!
Another day out. Not too busy when we went, as you would expect a bit breezy; awesome views East & West to infinity and beyond

Gorgeous!!!!!!!. Where Indian Ocean meets the Atlantic. I hiked up and took cable car down. You can go up and down so long as you allow enough time and you have enough water if it is a hot day. Go early to avoid large groups who can dominate the trails and photo spots - although there are many perfect spots for photos. you can also do a second hike from near the parking lot down to the beach. GREAT cafe with takeaway food. Had a tomatoe and mozzarella sandwich and it was very fresh! Bread was fantastic. If I had had more time, I would have had lunch in the restaurant. Great views!
Great Views. It is worth doing the short hike up to the lighthouse for the views and being there at sunrise is definitely worth it but it does not open until 0700.

The End. We had the most amazing day here, saw the tip of land diving into the sea, the waves crashing over the rocks in such an incredible way that you have to see it to believe it. Lots of wildlife to see to if you keep your eyes peeled. Don't worry the baboons will find you, but please don't try to touch them or feed them, just watch and enjoy.

Get there early in the morning. Awesome bit of nature at the (seemingly) world's end. Get up early and arrive as the gates open as it's less crowded. The walk to the lighthouse takes about an hour (return) if you take it easy. Take some pictures and rest up a little. The sandwiches that can be bought at the restaurant here are very good so have breakfast here or reward yourself with a bit of lunch after you've explored the area.

Amazing views at every turn!. What more could you ask for? There was so much scenery that every place we looked was a feast for the eyes. We took the funicular to the steps to get to the lighthouse. We were there in August, so there were no lines. We then ate at the restaurant, which is very well hidden. The food was just mediocre, but with the view, along with the whales cavorting below us in the water, it was well worth the price. If you are in that area it is just a must do. Period. Don't miss it!
Most beautiful place on earth. If you want to see the proof that we live in the most beautiful country in the world you should visit this breathtaking reserve!

I would not go here to see game. En route to the Cape of Good Hope you drive through this reserve. Some tourists got excited on seeing baboons but that was about it! it is a scenic route to the Cape, but that is about it.

most magical romantic place ive ever seen. where to begin, youve driven through national park its so beautiful, just before you reach the giftshop, cafe etc turn right into cape point. the view and the photo opportunity with the sign is something to behold. then the giftshop and restaurant with ocean views is stupendously wonderful. you must visit put it on your bucket list
Fabulous views. Great scenic trip to get to the reserve and the views when you get there are gorgeous. Small charge to get in but definitely worth it.

Amazing ! A must do !. It was a great trip we did it with a group and was organized by our guest house , costed 950 R ppVisited seal island ( you have to pay for the ticket)Cape pointCape of good hopePenguins colonyBotanical gardenMy advice for couples is to rent a car and do it by yourself , you will save a lot and have your own pace

Picture Perfect Beauty. Just a drive within this reserve introduced us to turtles crossing the road, trying to find their way into the sea says it all. Scenic beauty all through the drive will keep you mesmerized.

Ga eens van de gebaande paden!. Cape Point is a lovely place where you can enjoy fresh air and enjoy scenic vistas. The downside is that it can be quite busy here. It is the tourist hotspot. To avoid the crowds we did a couple of hikes here. If you are just off the beaten path, you experience the tranquility and nature that make the park so beautiful.

A tip which is not really the southernmost tip.... The drive to Cape point is lovely with history galore going back to Vasco da Gama. Scenery is beautiful with cerulean blue Atlantic waters, ostriches, baboons, and penguins along the way. Of course, the real southernmost point is some miles away across False Bay, but who cares?

worth the trip. The sea is such a wonderful aquamarine colour and to hear the waves breaking on the rocks is magical. The fynbos is also a treat; it's not dissimilar to the Scottish Highlands units vastness.

A Must Visit. This was a bucket list item for me and it did not disappoint. Go ll the way out to the tip and prepare to be in awe. Just spectacular. bring layers of clothes a head cover as the weather can vary greatly & even within short distances of time. Binoculars are a plus as well.

Something unusual. Rugged and barren. Be aware of the roadworks happening at the moment. There is stop-go traffic for quite a long section of the main road so things take longer. Get there as early as possible in the morning as it gets incredibly busy once all the tour buses arrive.
impressive. Lunar landscapes, dramatic sea views, good walks. Can't ask for much more than this in a reserve. Watch out for baboons on the roads!

Mixed feelings. It's a rather long but very scenic drive from cape town to cape point. There are various small towns on the way which seem like beautiful places to stop and look around (if you go Friday, stop at Bay Harbour Market on the way back or Saturday on the way to the Cape). At our arrival to the Nature Reserve, there was a long car queue of vehicles looking to enter the reserve. It took us around 45 minutes of waiting. After paying the fee, we followed the line of cars to the cape point car park. From there it's a ten minute walk past hordes of tourists to the light house and another twenty minutes to the actual Cape Point. There are also others places in the park where to take scenic stops. If you're doing the garden route and you're looking for a bit of a hike and nature, I recommend Robberg Nature Reserve compared to this!Conclusion: the various small towns between Cape Town and Cape Point look a lot more intriguing than Cape Point itself.

Fabulous Views, Great Scenery. We walked up to the Lighthouse at Cape Point and were rewarded with spectacular views of the Atlantic and Indian Oceans (there also is a funicular for those who don't want to hike up). We also saw wildlife, including Baboons and wild Ostrich. You can walk from Cape Point over to the Cape of Good Hope to enjoy even more scenery.

Incredible Scenery. This place is something else when it comes to scenery. It's just spectacular, even the drive there was amazing. we purposely left so the sun would be rising as we did Chapmans Peak (advised btw), so when we arrived a thin layer of cloud was covering a surrounding peaks and it was that 'fresh', sunny morning feeling.The touristy bits are pretty busy. But it's mainly busy because of all the coach tours which only spend a short amount of time at each 'attraction'. so just wait for them to take their photos and get back on their coach and you're good! The most SW point in Africa sign and cape point itself had a lot of people around, but if you venture off the beaten track, there is an abundance of wildlife, ranging from small reptiles and snakes to ostriches. A must if you visit Cape Town.
Wonder of Africa. This nature reserve has one of the best views i have seen. The rocky bottom with  The waves crashing are a sight to witness. Words wont do justice. Highly recommend.
END OF AFRICA. What more can you say, it's the end of the continent! The drive down is good and on our way we saw ostrich, hyrax, fur seal and many birds.
beautiful. this is another must see spot in Cape Town. breath taking views, beautiful landscapes, very dramatic.
Amazing. An amazing place to visit the breathtaking view of the ocean from all corners and natural scenic beauty.y

Breath taking views. We walked all the way to the top but there is a bus that can take you up. The walk was rough but tolerable. The views were amazing and indescribable. We saw our first wild baboons here and they were docile except when one chased a lady with food in her bag. The view from the top was gorgeous!

Watch out for the baboons. The Cape Point Nature Reserve is a beautiful stretch along the Cape Coast. You encounter all types of wildlife along the way, including ostrich, baboons, cape penguins, and various birds. Watch out for the baboons as you climb to the top of one of the view points. They will snatch your food if you are not careful.
Beautiful!. This is a really beautiful area with a lighthouse that you can take a funicular to and then walk up about another 50 steps to get to the top. Beautiful sweeping views of Cape Point.

Get there early before the crowds. We didn't really know what to expect from this place other than going to the southernmost tip of Africa. It is so much more than that with excellent walks, stunning scenery and on the day we went whales to see.
There are good amenities there and a reasonably priced cafe and restaurant

Great day excersion. Good way to see where the oceans meet. Take a walk to the light house.
Look at the weather as the wind can get quite strong.

Beautiful views!. I wish we had allotted more time to hike the trails here. We took the funicular to Cape Point and walked up to the lighthouse where whales frolicking just off the coast. We could have spent an entire day here! The souvenir shop at the top had Cape Point specific items that were not available (that I saw) at the shop at the entrance.

Wonderful views at the tip of Africa. Amazing views in a very rugged terrain. It is worthwhile taking the funicular up to the lighthouse and walking back down the very steep stairs, if you knees can handle it. Curios available at the small shop. Remember to take a hat and sunscreen.
A must see. Amazing view from the light house and one of the places you have to go to when visiting south africa. Go during the week as the place gets crowded on weekends.

You can't really visit the Cape without a photo from Cape Point. Very busy, loads of tourists. Nice walking trails along the point. It can be quite crowed on the actual point with everyone wanting to take photos.

Stunning landscape. This place is amazing. You can see stunning landscapes, and you feel like at the end of the world. I went in the park with a car, and drove both to Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope. If you go to Cape Town you can't miss this reserve. You will see also baboons and ostriches on the road. Really amazing.

Wow!. This was a beautiful, historic spot to visit. The wind and waves were strong, which made it easy to understand its first European name of "Cape of Storms." Definitely a must to visit if you have the time!

Cape Point Reserve. A bit of a drive from Cape Town, but well worth it. The drive to get here from cape town is scenic and offers many overlooks to stop and take photos. The Reserve itself is beautiful, with large numbers of birds and seals along the shore. Definitely recommended.

Obviously you HAVE to visit Cape point but..... ...we were really surprised at the entrance fees to the National Park. As a tourist you just suck it up as something that you simply must do (and you must!) but if I were local, I'd be pretty darned annoyed at the cost of entry! (Maybe locals have annual passes or discount rates, who knows?) Anyway, it is a must see event. Don't bother with the funicular railway, use your legs and walk up to the old lighthouse (interesting that it was too high and too often in the fog that it was deemed ineffective in preventing shipwrecks, so it was moved!). Lovely views from the top, made all the more lovely because you walked! Then go down to Cape of Good Hope for a picture by the sign.

Amazing views and scenery but we ran out of time. We wanted to squeeze this into our Cape Town trip but having been to this park you need a full day or at the minimum 3-4 hours so appreciate everything within the park. We saw cape point and the cape of good hope and walked up to the light house but there is sooo much more we could have done with our time here! We will definitely be coming back to explore some more. Arrive early as this was very popular with tourists and buses of them arrive at once.
Stunning. Walk up the steep incline to the light house and ride down. G2-Oceans great restaurant. Go in off season so it is not crowded. September is ideal.

Spectacular scenery! . We walked up to the lighthouse and were so glad we did as it was a chance to really take in the views and avoid the crowds. Stunning views from the top - definitely worth the effort.
Lovely nature reserve. We came during a beautiful sunny day ( we had rain and clouds the 2 days before ). It was sooooo beautiful. We saw some ostriches, some antelope, birds, flowers but no baboons!

fantastic scenic tour. We took a private tour which covered cape point and it was fantastic. Views were incredible, and we learned about the lighthouses, flora, fauna, wildlife, etc. There is a small museum which is quaint and actually very informative showing the animals which live in the nature reserve as well as the rare flowers. Well worth a visit

Excellent, but unneccessary queue. This is a fabulous drive, walk and we didn't want to miss a visit ot the Cape of Good Hope, but we had to queue for 20 minutes to get into the Park, which appears to be entirely due to inability to dispense tickets quickly. All it would take is somebody walking down the line taking money for tickets as well as the two booths to double the capacity.

Nice vegetation and great experience. If you are going to see Cape Point Nature Reserve from Cape Town, then it's important to realize that this can only be done by renting a car or paying for a guided tour (I recommend the latter). Allocate at least half a day, as it is quite far from Cape Town. The area has a unique vegetation, a lot of baboons and birds. Our experience was basically a drive through the park on the way to Cape Point.

Stunning Penninsula, a must do. Make sure to take a day driving the Cape Penninsula from Cape Town (down the east side first, back up the west side to catch the sunset) through Simons Town, Penguin Boulder Bay, to the Reserve and the spectacular lookout and Cape Good Hope, then back up the west coast to Cape Town. Take the day, hike and picnic. One of the most beautiful drives I have done anywhere

Ostrich, Baboon & Fynbos. Lots & Lots of vegetation to see. In terms of wildlife, we spotted a troop of baboons and 2 pairs of Ostrich... One of them had 16 ostrich chicks with them as well.At the most south-western point there is a sign board which most people take pictures at, if you look out toward the rock outcrops a little way out from the shore line, you may spot seals if you lucky. Other interesting spot is the trip up to the lighthouse, either by Cable Car or on foot, one you get to the top ... You still need to navigate about 100 stairs to get to the lighthouse. Wear comfortable shoes if you plan on going to the top, there is also a path to walk around the mountain the lighthouse is on... Lovely sea view from all sides.

Awesome Views!. This was one of our favorite spots in Capetown as the views were gorgeous and breathtaking. The waves clashing on the rocks at the bottom and the breeze going by makes it unusual and awesome. A must do while in Capetown!

The end of the world is stunningly beautiful and wild. We hired a car to drive us down from Cape Town which took about an hour and a half and climbed up to the lighthouse at Cape Point and also climbed to the top of the Cape of Good Hope. You can take a cable car to the lighthouse, and the climb is relatively easy - again, depending on your level of fitness. Surreally beautiful landscapes, ostriches, baboons, and relatively few crowds as we were there in the low season. Definitely the highlight of my trip to Cape Town!
Absolute awe!. Words cannot describe the beauty of Cape Point. One can also see baboons and ostrichs near the light house.

Beautiful, but blown away !. Cape Point was just beautiful ! If you go to the very top of the lighthouse the views are amazing and worth it. I did find it quite expensive at R125 per person. If you're walking to the top of the lighthouse be prepared for a very steep walk. The top of the lighthouse is extremely windy so be sure to wear lots of clothes!!
Amazing view. It was a nice visit.we took the hard way for the further light,it was so dangerous for kids.very nice view.on our way,we went to whale watching and we saw 2.

Cape Point & Cape of Good Hope. Entry to Cape Point was R125. We rode the funicular up to the upper light house. It departs every 3 minutes and costs R48 one-way & R58 round-trip.From there you can take in the view, and continue to walk uphill to higher lookout points.On the way down, we also did other walks which were very scenic, where we saw whales.It was a beautiful, sunny day. However, it can be windy at the Point. The Cape of Good Hope (and sign) is in the vicinity. But you can drive to it.It is not the tip of Africa. The southernmost point is Cape Agulhas, about 150 kilometres (90 mi) to the east-southeast. The currents of the two oceans meet at the point where the warm-water Agulhas current meets the cold water Benguela current and turns back on itself—a point that fluctuates between Cape Agulhas and Cape Point which is about 1.2 kilometers east of the Cape of Good Hope.
Beautiful to explore. Cape Point is a lovely attraction. Animals are roaming freely ( think baboons and ostrich). The lighthouse view was beautiful on a nice day.

Views for Africa. We been at cape point a number of times previously and it never fails to impress. The views are fantastic from the lighthouse and also from the other viewing platforms. A must if you in Cape Town

Fantastic views.. We drove from Cape Town along the M62 and then along the M6 and through Simons Town ( you might want to check the penguin colony at Boulders Beach here).There is a toll to pay of R42.00 when you drive through Chapmans Peak but its worth doing this for the great views along the road.There was quiet a queue of cars at the park entrance and then its another 15 minute drive till you get to the parking area. There are detours you can take along the way to view other parts of the reserve.We bought tickets for the Funicular train (R58.00 for an adult). Seemed a lot easier than walking up.Once at the top there is a short stepped walk to the lighthouse for views across the seas. In fact there are many viewing point around the lighthouse for great views.There are 2 restaurants at the entrance for the train - a fast food pizza (avoid) and Two Oceans Restaurant. If you have the time have a meal here, the food and especially the seafood was amazing, freshly caught and cooked and amazing desserts too.After this we drove down to the beach where the Cape Point sign is for the obligatory photo shoot.This is well worth a day trip from Cape Town especially if you incorporate the stops along the way.

Bonus view of breaching southern right whales!. The scenery was breathtaking. Great hiking. Lots of baboons. Just happened to be at an overlook when some whales surfaced!! Interesting visitor information. Can't imagine how they got that lighthouse up there in 1860!

Heritage drive. I've always wanted to see the point where the Indian ocean and Atlantic meet. Enjoyed the drive through the fynbos, which is quite long but for me was worth it. Unfortunately there is only one restaurant at the end of a long drive, and one take away pizza spot, so the line was quite long - and the restaurant full, a good idea to take your own picnic perhaps. Beautiful views

Great!!!. You feel like you are reaching the "end of the world" when you enter this Reserve! We used bicycles to go around and it was pretty great. It is a pretty calm place and lovely for walking or bicycle!

Good trip. We had a car and drove out to this area. There is a tourist centre and restaurant with some items (I liked the giraffe table mats they had). The climb up to the light house is easy for anyone without mobility challenges. There is a lift. The day we went was cloudy so views were limited, however, later you can drive down to the ocean and spend sometime on the rocky beach. There is parking there (free). Parking up top is free. But there is a park entry fee (moderate).All in all worth the drive out and time spent. If I remember correctly 3-5 hours round trip and viewing/activity time.
Total bliss. No words can do this place justice. It is a must see, take the short hike up the long stairs from the cable car for an unmatched view. Then lunch with a seeview.

EXCELLENT VIEW OF THE TWO OCEANS. The place offers a spectacular view of the nature. The ideal time to visit the point would be 2pm because the park closes by 5 pm and the penalise if you are returning after the closing hours. The cape of good hope offers a hiking tour for 2 hours. Do not take the cable car to the Lighthouse as it is not a value for money.

Cold but incredible. It is an experience to visit the southernmost tip of Africa. Like most of the Western Cape, the area is tourism-friendly, clean and well- organized. When visiting do remember to take a warm jacket as it can get very cold with the south-easter blowing, even in summer. Flat walking shoes are recommended.

Amazing views. This a must do visit when in Cape Town. Still quite a drive once you get to entrance of park but great to go through the fynbos ecosystem. Can either walk to the point & lighthouse or make use of the funicular which is quite an experience. Restaurant seems to be used a lot by tour groups so only other option is a 'fast food' option which for food appeared to be quite slow but where quick with drinks.

Cape Point. Great Scenery, lots of wild flowers and small wildlife. Please do not feed Baboons, they are dangerous animals and may become aggressive if you are carrying food in your hands. Please please please do not pick the flowers, heavy fines by the parks authority.

Reall bad road. I don't understand why Cape Point gets so many visitors. It's overpriced, and the road is in a very poor state. They've been working on it for as long as I can remember, but they still have a long way to go. The stop/go system means long delays. Be warned, there are no toilet facilities at Cape of Good Hope!

Mother Nature in the Mother City. A beautiful, unspoilt part of the Cape. Instead of rushing to the commercialised Cape Point itself we drove around the back roads, exploring BuffelsBaai, Platboom &the Diaz Cross. We were rewarded with baboons, dassies & ostriches - as well as a beautiful white sand beach without another soul in sight. Be careful of bluebottles though - the water was choked with them. The flora was in full bloom too - enormous bushes of blossoming pincushions & other indigenous flowers. Needed a whole day there, but it was still an afternoon well spent.

Dramatic landscape. Spend as much time as you want and walk around to see all the sights.Tramway to the top where the lighthouse is if you dont want to climb the small hill.Food a little overpriced and the quality not that great

Visit to the most southerly point of the Peninsula. This should not be confused with the most southerly point of the continent which is Cape Agulhas about 190km to the south east as the crow flies or 360 km by road!The Cape of Good Hope has glorious views over False Bay on a clear day but it can be quite windy at times.There are a number of animals in the reserve and the ones which one is most likely to see are the chacma baboons which are resident in the reserve or often can be seen on the coastal road to the Cape Point nature reserve.There is a funicular up to the viewpoint at the point, or one can walk up the incline.There are a number of walks and one should give yourself enough time to discover the beaches in the reserve although the water could be quite chilly!
Of Saturday escapades. Set out with my friends on Saturday 10th for a drive. This trip blew our minds away I tell you. The beauty around RSA is amazing. I'm in awe.

Amazing and Splendid views. A must see when in Cape Town - South Africa. Lots to see - fauna, flora, lots of animals. Best 360 degree views. lots of amenities etc.Swimming spots galore - braai facilities - walking trials and many more. Baboons to be seen, be carefull.

Captivating Cape Point. This almost Southern Tip of Africa is a place of unspoilt beauty with the wild South Atlantic waves crashing into the rocky coast throwing up sheets of spume. The park has wide plains, mountains, steep cliffs overlooking False Bay and many discrete trails to explore. A must for nature lovers.

Cape Point nature reserve . Beautiful scenery, fauna and flora across a vast area on the Cape's south peninsula. Plenty of areas to explore and perfect if you want to go for a long walk on spectacular white sand beaches. The food at the restaurant might be deemed pricy by locals but well worth the treat. We had a special day out.

One walks "up" to Cape point, not down. One of the best aspects of touring Cape point is the drive from Cape Town to the nature reserve. It really is one of the most panoramic drives I've taken over the years. So, if possible, hire or take your own car...its worth it. There is a restaurant with point and sea views. There is a mini cable car that takes you up the mountain to cape point. However, I recommend walking. Indeed one walks "up" to Cape point and not down but walk allows better views and of course that "wind in your experience".The advertisements list mountain zebra and baboons. I saw only baboons. Beware of baboons they are not to be trifled with.In short, if it is untrammelled sea and mountain views you seek, then cape point is the destination without a doubt.On a side note. The wind is stronger down there and colder. So take a jacket if you are prone to the "coldies ".

spend the whole day exploring. incredible peninsula, you can get off the beaten track and walk among animals. A local private guide is the way to go as the weather, swell and numerous species of deadly snakes can make you a bit edgy. Local guide from Scarborough took us to beautiful spots , we saw so much and felt relaxed and on holiday. Our guides number 0826657232. Our favourite spot in Cape Town

Spectacular Scenery. Having rented a minivan taxi to take us to this Nature Reserve, our group of five enjoyed the drive as much as the destination, taking in all the beautiful vistas of a South African Spring. Please note: one has to pay to get into the reserve, then pay to take the lift which drops visitors off roughtly halfway to the top. Good walking shoes are a must. If the climb up to the lighthouse is too much, there are intermediate lookout spots on the side which offer a splendid view. I saw visitors with binoculars, which I thought was a good idea, to spot marine birds whirling about and to try perhaps to see the whales which frequent the oceans in the area. At the lighthouse, one is looking over two oceans and the view is breathtaking. Or maybe that was me trying to catch my breath... In any case, not to be missed. On the way to the Cape of Good Hope, our party spotted three ostriches and a couple of springboks near the beach.

Beautiful place!. Here you're going to see some ostrich and although there was a sign of warning us about baboons, I did not see any. This is actually a good thing ha ha. Otherwise you have to really watch your belongings.The Cape point nature reserve is absolutely stunning at the top. Here you are at the most southwestern part of the continent of Africa. If you really like nature and oceans, you'll love it here. There's a place for public restrooms and a tram that takes you up to the top for beautiful views.

Nice walk. Once near the shop there is a sign as you head out to the point that is misleading making you think it is another 1.5 hours but it only took us 30 minutes. Such a view, baboons too as long as you keep moving they don't bother you.

Undisturbed View of Nature at Cape Point. Cape Point Nature Reserve has been preserved to see the land and nature just as it has been for centuries, unspoiled and beautiful. It is certainly worth the time (approximate 1 hour from Cape Town) to visit the reserve and see the animals and the sheer natural beauty of this Nature Reserve.

Very touristy. One of our must visit stops were definitely Cape Point, but we were very annoyed with the tour busses speeding past us and the multitudes of tourist not caring about the people around them. Once again tourist were ignoring the signs requesting them to stay in paths and were taking very risky pictures on edges of rocks. Maybe a Ranger or two must be around to keep them in check? The area around the Cape Point Lighthouse was full of litter, but this is once again blamed on careless tourists.We had a bit of a fright as the Funicular had a short breakdown on the rails, but no explanation was provided by the operator. We still do not know what happened...But otherwise, the view was amazing and I would definitely go back to do the hike down to Cape of Good Hope.
Scenic. Love it here. Looking out over the oceans. Spotting the wild animals. Truly wonderful.Very picturesque, lots of pictures to be taken, and memories to be made.

Flying Dutchman Funicular | Cape Point. Visiting Cape Point specifically with the aim of visiting the Flying Dutchman Funicular today. Well kept and maintained, friendly staff, good service. The wind nearly blew us off the top, but even that didn't take away the beautiful experience and view. For people who can't negotiate the steep climb to the top at the lighthouse - you can still make use of the Funicular, and at the top level where it stops, you will still get breath taking views. You don't have to climb right up. One of the most beautiful views the Cape offers. As a Tourist Guide - I can definitely recommend a visit - its just about one of the places you have to see! Entrance to Cape Point was less pleasant - the card machine appeared to give problems and this delayed entrance to the Park. I believe the entry system can be improved on. But once you are inside - there is much to see. If you are interested in Fynbos, stop as much as possible as you will see more species that you thought possible.
Oceans and cliffs. Take the funicular train up to Cape Point, Stand at the tip where you could gaze out to the South Atlantic Ocean meets Indian Ocean at the Lighthouse.

A must see when visiting Cape Town!. Wildlife, views and a wonderful restaurant. There are several hikes in the reserve with great views. Hikes can range from 30 minutes to 5 hours. There are several to choose from. The two oceans restaurant has very good food and wine, not what you would expect from a nature reserve. We saw whales frolicking in the sea right from our table!
Rugged natural beauty and ostriches. Stunning reserve - you must do the short hike to fully appreciate the beauty. Bonus: on our way in - ostrich were roaming freely.

At africas end. Its quite a long drive from cape town - over an hour - and the charge for going in was one of the more expensive entry fees we paid. But you get to experience the amazing feeling of being at the sw tip of Africa. Even on a calm day elsewhere the sea was boiling and you could hardly stand up in the wind. You could only imagine what sailors a hundred years ago had to endure. Lots of tour buses!

Awesome views of the sea, cliffs and nature.. A very popular attraction on the tour bus circuit but away from the tourist hotspots this is a fabulous place. We sat on a deserted beach of white sand watching fur seals playing in the waves!
Beautiful place. The view is unbelievably beautiful while you are watching the wild waves of the oceans. There is a weird feeling if you think where you are standing when you are there!
kaap die goede hoop. so close to cape town a wonderful place to take pictures of the most southern place in Africa. we even climbed to the top of the cliff(ten minutes climbing up the stairs)

Amazing scenery. This reserve has some wonderful scenery. I would suggest going here on a clear day to see and take everything in. There are multiple spots to check out with one of my favorites being the Cape Point stop (the ocean below is amazing). Also be on the lookout for ostriches, mongooses, and baboons.
Cape Point Nature Reserve. Very nice family friendly excursion or with friends. Actually any person will enjoy this outing ! Nice restaurant to visit. Scenery exquisite all around the whole area.
Tranquil view. My wife and I hired a driver through our hotel (Blackheath Lodge) and drove to Cape Point. A beautiful drive and very cool to see where the two oceans meet.
Cape Point & Cape of Good Hope. We not only enjoyed the spectacular views, but also were lucky to see baboons and ostriches. A great day at the south western tip of Africa.

Well worth a visit but spoilt by baboons. Lovely scenery and drive to get there. One there you can take the funicular to the top where there is a lighthouse or you can walk up to the lighthouse. Allow 30 minutes for the walk each way. The only down side about walking is the baboons that roam wild. They are dangerous and aggressive and are looking for food so if you are carrying bags there is a change they will try to get them off you. This happened to us and we had no food only a picture of two Zulus in our bag. Keep car doors and windows closed as they are roaming in the car park also.
beautiful, breathtaking. Interesting attraction for all ages. my family loved coming here, we had lunch and went up to the lighthouse.If you go to cape town do not miss this place, it was amazing!

Great fun. Bit of a drive but you can stop off at some lovely locations on the way. The view is incredible especially when you walk to the top. Most people walked up to the first lighthouse which ended in a lovely view however you could also walk round to the tip, by the second lighthouse, where a lot of people didn't go. The second lighthouse felt like the edge of the world and was beautiful. Cape point was also very nice. You can either drive to it or walk it.
What a view. This was our second time there and it was just spectacular both times. Bring your walking shoes if you plan to walk to the lighthouse.. It's well worth it!!

"SUPERB LOCATION AND GREAT SCENERY". The drive around the park is great,with all different wildlife to see.
The walk to the point and lighthouse is great,with fantastic views,then you make your way over to the Cape of good hope which is a great photo opportunity.
Overall a great day out with lots to see

A whale of an adventure. A full day adventure beginning with a stop in Kalk Bay for shopping and a snack, then onto Simon town to learn the history of the famous dog that joined the British Navy, then on to Boulder beach for Penguins, then into the park itself with the wonderful hike to the two lighthouses and then a stop at Cape point to have your picture taken with the famous sign, finally on the way back Chapmans peak drive for some awesome views and a return to Cape Town.

STUNNING LOCATION RIGHT NEXT TO CAPE OF GOOD HOPE. Our guide took us here after Cape of Good Hope and stopped in several places where tour buses don't stop. An empty beach with running baboons was beautiful. The Cape Point is very busy with tourists but well worth it. We took the tram to see the Lighthouse up close and the gorgeous beaches, a real stunner.
Great Day out. Walk from Cape of Good Hope to Cape Points is worth it, great views. If you can make time for lunch at the Two Oceans restaurant, great views and seafood.

A Gem of South Africa. Very well managed and run. The roads are undergoing repaving but this was no problem, the short hold up. Very friendly staff from the pay kiosks to the funicular and shop attendants.

Beautiful nature. Cape Point Nature Reserve is a beautiful national park including Cape of Good Hope. Although it is not the most southern tip of Africa (that is Cape Agulhas 150 km. to the east) it is worth a visit. It is very touristic and beware the baboons.
Nothing much. Its a place you need to go when you are in Capetown but to be honest not so fun...beware the baboons.. You should other things to do on that day. A place to visit rapidly

Seeing the 2 waters... awesome. I dont do well with heights but this one.. I went all the way to the lighthouse.. And the view from there cannot be explained by words. The "blue" of the waters.. were different. The Atlantic was crazy, turbulent and the Indian was calm. All the noise came from the Atlantic. ..

Another must-see when in Cape Town. There are 2 main spots in the Nature Reserve - Cape Point itself which is rocky and dramatic, and the old lighthouse which provides excellent views. To get there & back from Cape Town, take a loop drive including Chapman's Peak drive - the scenery is magnificent.Please be aware of horrible road works in Kalk Bay at the moment - we were delayed by over 20 minutes.

Beautifull rugged mountains and coast scenery. Take the drive or tour to cape of good hope and cape point lighthouse from capetown through chapmans peak road. Magnificent scenery. A fee for chapmans peak road but worth it.

Great!. A great experience to hike from Cape of good hope to Cape point.Great views, easy going, a lot of animals and birds.There are some parts which need extra care but not something really dangerous (we made the hike with our 6 1/2 y.o.son),1 1/2 hours each way.
Excellent day out. This is a must on your list when visiting the cape. Get lunch at the two oceans and take a drive around the reserve, breath taking.

Most magical views. This must be one of the best sights to take in when in Cape Town
It is absolutely unprecedented and for me, even prettier than the cable car

Superb views!. We visited here on a hiking and bike ride day. It was very windy but that just added to the adventure! Stunning views all the way up to the lighthouse, very peaceful as well. Not to be missed if you are in the Cape Town area.
Cape Point. Cape Point, Cape Town in South Africa. Please see my first impression photos. Thank you very much indeed.:-)

Definitely a must see. The Nature Reserve is part of the SAN Parks and one can access it if free of charge if you are in possession of a valid Wild card. For those who dont have a wild card, there is quite a hefty entry fee into the reserve. The reserve has a detailed map, information centre and curio shops at both the information centre and near the Wild Dutchman funicular. There is plenty to explore and do which makes this a great day out for the family. The funicular has its own fee and tickets are only obtainable from the ticket office at the funicualr.
Fantastic place. Great place to visit. Cape of good hope is wonderful and more if there's a good weather. It's one of the places we enjoyed more during our stay!

A must when visiting Cape Town. The drive itself is beautiful and rewarding. When you get there, the natural beauty is breathtaking. THINGS TO CONSIDER- research the trip getting there and back. The favourite is driving in from the East Coast side and going back to Cape Town on West Coast side (which means you get a front row sea view and places to stop on the 'Houtbay' cliffs).- timing and day of the week determines how big the crowd is going to be. This place is popular. So the obvious times are best avoided if you don't like big crowds or queues.- if you perfer to walk a tiny bit and then have lunch, it's on offer. If you like to hike a lot and do very active things, it's on offer.- even if it's sweltering hot in the city, its always good to bring a jacket for the sometimes very strong winds and a hat for the sun.

You forget about the busy life and drink in the beauty that surrounds you.. Went early so did not wait long to enter. It is worth every cent. We did not drive around the off beaten tracks but headed for the point. Plenty parking. And although there are crowds you dont feel crowded because of the wide open spaces. I took a slow stroll to the top! It is well kept and a must see. The vegetation and sea views let one escape to that happy place.
Mesmerizing. I could barley believe my eyes. It was so so so beautiful and the hike to the two different viewing points was fairly easy!

Stunning!. We had a really lovely drive down to Cape Point. We left Cape Town in the morning and stopped via the penguins at Boulders Beach. The scenery was stunning the whole way down. Im glad we got to Cape Point early as all the tourist buses started showing up which slightly tainted the serenity of it all, but was still beautiful. We drove back to Cape Town via the west coast which was amazing!! A definite must.
Amazing Diversity at tip of Africa. Traveling from Cape Town down to Cape Point Nature Reserve should not be missed. The landscape, flora and fauna are unlike any other in the world.
Stunning location. Not too busy, stunning views - well worth the drive. Beware the birds in the cafe that pinch your lunch given the chance (worse than the baboons)

Stunning. Cape Point Nature Reserve is an amazing and terrific place.To live in the best way your day, you have to wear comfy or trekking shoes.Entrance fee is quite high. It is 120R but it is worthy! Cape point will give you breathtaking views and the feeling to be very small in this amazing world.If you do not feel to do the walk until the top (15 minutes) you could take a cable up which is an additional cost namely 60R.

Just stunning. A beautiful location that should not be missed. The scenery is fantastic with a huge diversity ranging from dramatic mountains to beautiful bays. The restaurant is good, just be careful of the birds if dining outside, they are organised and quick at stealing food.Just be patient at the Cape of Good Hope it is a little busy for photo ops however the general vibe is nice and chilled.
Stunning!. Get yourself here!! It is stunning. The walks and nature and ocean views are out of this world gorgeous. There is an entry fee and it can get very windy.
Beautiful. A must visit if you're in Cape Town. The last last point before the south Pole and where the Atlantic and Pacific oceans meet.

exceptional views from the restaurant overlooking the ocean and also from the Cape Point at the end of the funicular. An amazing experience showing where the two oceans meet - the Indian and Atlantic. Incredible views and beautiful park with lovely walks and drives.
Amazin place. Perfect option ir you are visiting Cape Town. Rent a cheap car and go there. During the way, you'll find amazing places, beaches and aninals!

Beautiful and stunning - beware of the baboons. Great experience and a Cape Town "must do." One word of warning would be to avoid baboons. Unfortunately if you put anything down the baboons don't mess around getting it. Some tourists think it funny to take pictures directly in the baboons faces.
Definitely Visit. We have visited numerous times with visiting family. Great way to spend the day. Baboons, Ostriches and sometimes whales all in one visit
Fantastic views. Great drive from Cape Town with spectacular views all the way (if the mist/fog allows) Watch out for the baboons in the car par!
Spectacular. We spent a full day exploring the Cape. The walks are great and well worth it! Make sure you visit the highlights early in the morning, before the busses arrive!
Really cool. Abundance of wildlife, Beautiful views, nice drive through the park. I would highly recommend a trip here.

Spectacular. Spectacular place at the south-western most point of the continent. Has a lot of history including Bartholomew Diaz and Vasco Da Gama route maps. There is also some whimsy with the story of the sleeping giant dooming the flying dutchman to sail his waters forever taking shape in the form of a funicular ride to the light house. You can spend hours on end just watching the waves crash against the rocks on Cape of Good Hope. The walk up to the the different view points is spectacular. Be ready for sharp winds and glorious photos :) There are various tour companies that take you on a trip to the reserve, or you can rent a car and drive from Cape Town (about 1 hr with not stops). You can also take the train Metroplus upto simons town and then rent bikes to the reserve. We took an uber from Cape town to the reserve and back. About 700 rand one way including all stops. We stopped at Hout Bay, drove through Chapman's Peak drive, via Kommetjie and return via Simons Town and the penguin colony. I highly recommend this method of travel to all those not comfortable driving by themselves on strange roads. It is convenient, can be personalized and cheaper alternative to tour buses. If we had the time I would have done the train/bike option.

Breathtaking views. Pretty as a picture. Its a beautiful drive for local or tourist. Cape town has spectacular drives. Plan this activity for the whole day. I suggest exploring the reserve to the full potential. You can pack a picnic or enjoy the fine dining restaurant that is there. Wear comfy shoes that you can walk in and a jacket as teh wind can pick up there in the winter months.Entrance fee and you can hike up to the light house or take a cable up which is an additional cost.

Cape Point. The Cape Point nature reserve is well worth a visit. The wildlife in the reserve is amazing and has some rare and once endangered species in it. The view across the oceans from the point is quite spectacular and worth the entrance fee.
Go to the edge. Even if you have always lived in Cape Town, a visit to Cape Point should be something you do every 2-3 years. It is just so beautiful and the restaurant is good on the catering.

One of the most beautiful places in South Africa. A must visit for all tourists and locals. It's a beautiful drive to the reserve. The reserve has lots of fauna and flore on offer. A visit to Cape Town will be incomplete without a visit to Cape Point.

Nice place.. Awesome views. Had been to this place on a particularly hot day which didn't result in a pleasant atmosphere. However, the views are breathtaking and you can stay in that serene atmosphere as long as you wish to. If lucky, you can get a glimpse of some whales as well. A one-of-a-kind experience with you being on top and the ocean all around you.A must visit if you are anywhere nearby.

You just got to go!. Definitely plan to hike when you get there. We saw lots of different wild life and were amazed about how different the ocean was -- in some places very very calm and in others places waves pounding the beach. Plan to stop at the exhibit at the entrance which helps set the context for what you will see.

Definitely go, but not with a tour. I've been to the Cape Point Nature Reserve many times over the years. Best advice I can give is to drive there yourself, don't plan to go with a huge group or a tour. Sure, go on the hike up to the lighthouse and follow the crowds for a bit, but the beauty of this park is found elsewhere. It is a treasure of natural space and a photographer's dream. Go down to Diaz Beach! The steps are daunting, but so worth it. Drive out to both the east seaside where you can spend time by the beaches and rock pools, and go to the west side where you can hike around and enjoy incredible views up and down the coast. A special treat on the west side is the low clouds and fog rolling up the mountain during much of the year. Take a lunch, and plenty of water! Neither are available in the park unless you want to go to the pricey restaurant and shoppe. Plan a whole day. The entry tickets are about R110 last time I checked, which is a lot of money locally. Use common sense and don't go off the trails, pick flowers, collect anything, or feed wildlife!!!

Tranquil drive. Driving through looking at three different type of fynbos was lovely. It was raining so we only saw ostrich but it was a lovely drive. We parked for lunch and walked around the souvenir shops but when we left the car park was full and busy. Glad we missed the lunchtime rush!
Smme great views. Great place to visit and see some amazing views. We took the 'Flying Dutchman' funicular up to the lighthouse and we blown away by the 360 degree vistas.

Spectacular . What a beautiful place to spend time enjoying the spectacular scenery. We also cycle around the area . Simply love the beauty it has to offer. Also stop by the restaurant for breakfast or lunch. We are never disappointed .

Great nature reserve. The ocean views were wonderful and we were surprised at the variety of wildlife (various antelopes, ostriches, baboons, birds, etc,) that we encountered. This was the highlight of our trip to Cape Town

Highlight of SA tour. Visit Cape point in January 16, and it was well worth the vist. We climbed to the top rather than taking the tram and were rewarded with fantastic view of the Indian and the Atlantic Ocean's. It was one of my must do's on this trip to South Africa and i would recommend it to everyone.
