A great place to visit even when cloudy. We visited Cape Point but it was misty so the visibility on the point was poor. There are however lots of other things to see and do at the Nature Reserve. We stopped at a beach and spent time exploring the rock pools and beach. The plant life is also outstanding. You pay an entrance fee at the Nature Reserve and can walk up to the top of the point. A funicular is also available but at an extra cost. The point also has a restaurant and toilets at the base of the point.

A must. It is bit of a drive from Cape Town, if you want to do the journey in a day as there are so many sights and beautifyl views on the way. It was very windy that day, but still we walked all they way up to the lighthouse. Dont miss that!

Beautiful. We had a great time. The scenery is breathtaking. Saw ostriches and baboons too. Also the hike to the top was worth the view. Plan extra time as it took a while to get in (everyone paying by credit card?) and also there is some road construction in the park.

Touristy but worth it. The drive down to Cape Point is beautiful and if the weather is clear its amazing all that you can see. We were there in winter and there wasn't too much wildlife though we did happen upon baboons and ostriches. There was a line for the photo op in from of the Cape of Good Hope signage, however I imagine its always like that, and most people were courteous enough to wait in line. If you make it all the way down to South Africa, then this is a must.
Capt Point. Wonderful views. Weather not too windy and sky blue most of the time. Was worth the walk to see the view. However, the tour didn't allow quite enough time to get right to the top.

Southern end of the continent!. We had time to visit Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope - both are great landmarks. The scenery is breathtaking and sitting on the shore near Cape of Good Hope - watching the waves crash in! - glorious sunset too.

Family trip with grandparents and kids. We spent all day driving down from Camps Bay to Cape Point passing through Hout bay, seal island, fish hoek, penguin colony etc. When we got to cape point, as it was a public holiday, there was a long queue - we waited about 20 minutes before reaching the gate for payment. Then driving in they have road works going on now, not sure when it's ending, delay was about 5-10 min. The funicular was good. The view is amazing. Been here several times and always love the view! We had lunch at Two Oceans restaurant. The food was very good. But they don't have kids menu. They had just few stuff that they can do as half portions.

We're West and East meet. Beautiful scenery. Saw some wild animals. Access management effective and speedy. Ample parking and a nice climb to the top, can also use the cable cart. Small but nice curio shop. A decimate visit on a day tout via cape point. Road in good condition.

For all the tourist but never the less worthwhile the visit. Of course you can not avoid the busses full of tourist but anyway it remains on of the sites with a spectacular view.Enjoy it as it is and erase the others from the view

look around. Cape point is famous for being the shipwreck point of old times ships, the most dangerous point of Africa's continent, and that's why most people go there, to feel like they are almost touching the end of the world. It's quite summed up by the signage near the lighthouse that indicates where all the other continents over the ocean are. But going there look carefully around the road inside the national park, you might spot ostriches, baboons, turtles, snakes, and huge antelopes. The landscape is so beautiful it's worth a quick walk in a 15/20 min walk trail near the road, and the bushes in the early morning have a unique african wonderful perfume.
Unbelievable 360 degree views!. Would definitely recommend taking a guided tour to Cape Point! The drive from the harbour was spectacular!

Fun to walk up to the lighthouse and check out the stunning views from there.. A perfect sunny day in winter! We took the flying dutchman which was so quick. Handy for south african pensioners as they only pay R15 return and with The my Green Card, you only pay R30 return.
Not southernmost, but fabulous anyway!. The drive to cape point is as wonderful as being at the point. Scenery is fabulous. Windy, however, so hold on to your hat!

WHEN ALMOST AT THE TIP OF AFRICA. Travelling from Cape Town, along the coastal road, one passes some of the most beautiful vistas featuring Mountain Ranges, Valleys, Sun soaked beaches, Quaint villages, and the AWESOME MERGING OF THE ATLANTIC and INDIAN OCEANS.The Cape Point Nature Reserve, in real terms it should be referred to as The Cape Point Natural Reserve, in as much, that everything you see, in terms of the vegetation, is as natural as it was on the day it was created.The reserve has an abundance of Flora and Fauna and the views across the scraggy cliffs are simply awe inspiring. Where else on Earth can you stand and watch the merging of two huge oceans. Wildlife is a rarity, except for the many TROOPS OF BABOONS that roam this sanctuary freely. Bontebok, Ostrich, and Bird life are also to be found, but difficult to spot. The Da Gama cross also stands proudly within the reserve, this has a history all of its own. Great fishing spots abound along the shoreline and the beach at the Cape of Good Hope is a MUST visit. The rugged coastline on the Indian Ocean side of the reserve is dotted with beaches that are not crowded and ideal to enjoy because the water is warmer than on the Atlantic Ocean side of the Reserve. Rock pools and Tidal pools also abound the coastline. Enjoy, you can't go much further South without getting your feet wet.

Another must from Cape Town. There were 11 of us and we had arranged a peninsula tour with Ilios Travel. Part of the trip was a visit to the Cape of Good Hope and Cape Point, part of Table Mountain National Park. The Cape of Good Hope is somewhat touristy with people falling over themselves to be photographed by the sign. This may be the most southwesterly point on the continent but it is not the most southerly and does not mark the meeting of the Atlantic and Indian Oceans so I can't understand the fuss. Cape Point is a little further east and is not so gimmicky. There is a funicular railway to the top or you can walk up. At the top there is the obligatory signpost with distances to Paris, Sydney and New York but it is otherwise fairly unspoilt. There is plenty of wildlife including baboons and ostriches in the park. There is a very good restaurant at the car park for Cape Point. The sea views are excellent.

Nice views. Enjoyed the nature,fynbos,sea,ostrich etc...Had a good feeling about the whole park.Didnt like some tourist pushing each other around the cape of good hope sign.The route should be fixed soon

Adults like it, kids don't.. I have always liked this spot, for the views, the history, and the possibility of spotting whales. However I always find that kids are unimpressed by it, and are totally indifferent to its being the south-western most point in Africa. The beautiful scenery also seems to leave them unmoved, but I think for the discerning adult that and the history of the place are fascinating. watch out for baboons - don't carry anything they might snatch.
Very cool!. Part of an all day bus tour. This was an amazing stop! Hard to believe you are almost at the bottom of the earth!
Beautiful place to visit . Great energy, fresh wind, beautiful place to visit, Ocean , rocks, air, birds, monkeys)Old light house. Many tourist in the summer time( December)
Unforgettable experience. Gorgeous views of the two oceans and stunning cliffs. Less crowded than expected, pleasant route from Cape Town with several places to stop and visit. You can't miss it.

Not to be missed!. We hired a car and did a self-drive from Cape Town. Pretty easy as the peninsula is pretty easy to navigate and the road signs are clear. The day was made more enjoyable as we experienced beautiful, winter weather of +23 degrees Celsius with brilliant sun and blue skies. Wear comfortable shoes and once you're a up at the top of the Point, allow time to hike to the furthest most point (the Lighthouse Trail) which takes less than an hour for a moderately fit person. There is one part is that is elevated but one can just take it slowly along this part. The rest is flat. To get up to the peak, you have the option of walking or taking the funicular. Food and drink available.

Even in bad weather it has a WOW factor. It was raining very hard when we visited but this only added to our appreciation of how strong nature is with the driving rain and crashing waves, however that did, pardon the pun, put a bit of a dampener on the trip. There is a vernacular to take you up to the lighthouse and great views as well as baboons ready to pinch any exposed food so watch out
Take the hike out- it is pretty gradual and absolutely beautiful!. Take the hike out- it is pretty gradual and absolutely beautiful! Well worth your time and a nice hike as well- so beautiful!

WINDYYYY BUT FUN. talk about windy. the boys had a bunch of fun and I have to say I myself was overwhelmed with the beauty of Cape point. It was a bit crowed but fun non the less. Seem December isn't the best time if you want it all to yourself.

Worth the Trip. So you have to make the effort to get to Cape Point, but it is worth the trip. The historic lighthouse is well worth the trip and a decent hike. The baboons are fun to watch but you cannot interact with them as they have been known to be aggressive and attack people and cars, so please respect the signs that ask you not to feed them or interact with them and lock your cars.There is a popular misconception that Cape Point (and the Cape of Good Hope where it is located) is the southern tip of Africa. It is not - that is Cape Agulhas about 150km to the east-southeast. That should not stop you from having your photo taken at the sign which says 'Cape of Good Hope - the most south-western point of the African Continent.'

wonderful views. The coastal drive from Cape Town city was beautiful, and the view from the old light house was very pretty. The visit to Cape of Good Hope was a bit shorter than what I expected though - it was basically just a photo stop in front of the sign post that says it is the Cape of Good Hope.

Spectacular geology and views. The reserve gives access to the old lighthouse and the spectacular scenery that surrounds it in the reserve. We did a day circuit from Cape Town and this was one of the highlights. Easy access up in the funicular railway and then an energetic walk up the many steps to the lighthouse for great views of the coastline and Southern Ocean. The buildings were well preserved and walks well signed.

Breath-taking views where ever you look. Cape Point had to be the highlight of my trip to Cape Town. The drive to Cape Point along the coast is beautiful. As you enter the nature reserve there are wild apes and their young along the road. It is truly beautiful. The drive to the actual point is beautiful and unexpectedly flat. You do need an entire day and its best to go early as there are a few hiking trails which offer amazing views. My favourite was the 5 minute walk to the tip. Definitely worth the trip and my favourite part of Cape Town.

The Best of Nature. We toured the Cape on a windy, cloudy, drizzly winter day. In spite of this, I adored the vews and all the wildlife we saw. We saw the most adorable penguins and baboons. I was just as captivated by the wildlife here, as I was on my safari in Kruger; and the views of the Cape were indescribable. This is a must do activity while in South Africa.
Well worth the trip. After seeing it from the air the road trip was also fantastic. A really stunning bit of coast. Well worth the trip down.

Beautiful views!. Beautiful views, really a place you have to visit when in the Cape. Well worth the time spent there admiring the beauty. Only the bathrooms were disappointing as they are a bit old and were not very clean

Beautiful . Everyone if there must say the have been to the Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope. Very Beautiful, drive and you see wildlife as well as scenery. This with Boulder Beach can be done in 1/2 day.

The beauty of Cape Point!. I never knew what to expect going to this tourist attraction, driving through Simonstown was an amazing experience as is...especially travelling with a partner who knew the place very well. Finally walking up the mountain was exhausting but a beautiful experience. The view from the lighthouse is beyond words, creation at its best!
The no. 1 must see South-African attraction. With its truly breathtaking view, the Cape Point trip felt like travelling back in time, way back when its first explorers set foot on this land.

You cannot believe the beauty of this place. Looking down at the point from the vantage high above, one is humbled by the sheer beauty of such a place. Mysterious, dangerous and beautiful all at once. the Vernacular rail car was also a stunning experience. this is a well priced excursion.

Short visit from Cape Town. While in Cape Town I took a local tour to Cape Point. The light house on the point is a 20 min climb from the car park but once there the views of the oceans meet are brilliant. (There is a cable car for the least able) The wind can be strong to be prepared.
A Must. I was hesitant because it's so far out side of Cape Town but it's really a must, we took a guided tour out but it could also be done though a hired car.

Amazing landscapes!. The area is amazing. You have to drive for quite a while until you get there but then there are also lots walkways. You should arrive in the morning because there is so much to see.

Beautiful. We were here as a group during the rains.
The place felt secluded and not crowded like other spots we visited (could be the weather)
This place is perfect to spend an entire day with the number of spots to see.
Should not miss this place.

Beautiful, with unexpected zebras!. We visited the Cape Point Nature Reserve in driving rain, and were worried we wouldn't see anything at all. However, as we headed further south, the rain cleared up, and the beauty of the area became apparent. Soon afterwards, we saw a zebra, which we were not expecting! The road winds down to the funicular railway up to the old lighthouse, where we were able to take some awesome photographs and see some amazing views. We also walked part of the way to the new lighthouse, which provided the opportunity to view some interesting seabirds. Finally, we drove back inland a short way before turning down to the Cape of Good Hope proper, which has a good plaque for selfies, and lots of ostriches. This is definitely a cool place to visit if you're in Cape Town, as the road down has many other great stopping places.

Cape point . Great views from the Cape. On my last visit I did the walk down to the beach but didn't have the time on this return visit but if you do it's worth it. Great shots if your into photography
Wow just wow!. I went on a solo road trip and wow I find it hard to explain in words. If you get an opportunity to do this drive then go for it as it is magnificent!
Great side trip if you have timw. We hired a private driver to take us to Cape Point. The trip to and from Cape Town was a leisurely all-day drive, but it was well worth it. Fantastic scenery.

Beautiful walks and cycling. If you are into spending the day cycling or walking through beautiful surroundings next to the sea then this is for you. There are many different paths to walk including from the Cape of good hope to the cape point lighthouse
Rugged and beautiful, seaside towns. Take a full day to tour. We did an extended half-day tour (5+ hours) and it felt a bit rushed. Terrific guide, Lou from African Eagle Tours.
cape point. experiencing nature from a different point of view, a different perspective of beauty, that is wonderful

Just for the beauty of it. Walk up the steep path to the lighthouse from where amazing views unfold or take the funicular at a fee. Well laid out viewpoints and walks. Dias Beach is a real gem. Great walks and picnic spots in the rest of the park. Visitor`s Centre with interesting information and displays. This reserve is highly recommended and not to be missed.

Great day out, we self drove.. Couldn't believe how busy this was, but not in a bad way, plenty of space for everyone.
Obviously a steep climb, but the rail car makes it accessible for most.
Good info and history and sensational restaurant too.

Where 2 oceans meet cape point is probably the most beautiful place in the world. take the cable car up to the point and walk back down. if you lucky you can als do whale spotting.. not much animal life besides monkeys, ostriches .....lovely trails.
beaches are very cold so not much swimming.
entrance fee when entering.
Cape Point. Here you can witness the best sunset you could ever see on the earth. So you should set your timing accordingly
Must visit. Absolutely beautiful drive to this place and equally beautiful once you are there. There is construction in SimonTown at the moment so I would travel the other way to get here.

beautiful day trip. definitely worth while the short trip from Cape town (about an hour) but be warned as at the funicular it get's very touristy with tourists amass. Whilst the nature is breath-taking the shanty towns on the way there are not. Quite sad and a bit of a damper as one feels the injustice of it.

Stunning views and Whale Watching. Cape Point was not only brilliant for the stunning views but we were also lucky enough to see a breaching Southern Right Whale which was simply amazing. It is a short hill walk to reach Cape Point but there is also a cable train if you do not wish to walk to the lighthouse. At this point you can also see the meeting of two oceans which is another incredible experience. If you enjoy scenery and wildlife then Cape Point is a must.

Most beautiful view ever. The view from the lighthouse at Cape Point is magnificent! We were blessed with a clear, sunny day where the Atlantic and Indian Oceans meet. It's a 10 minute climb on a paved trail with some steps from the parking lot to the lighthouse. For those not interested in walking the whole way, the Flying Dutchman Funicular runs on a track about halfway up. I'm telling you, the I view is absolutely spectacular from the top! The Reserve also includes the fine Two Oceans Restaurant. There is a letter box outside the restaurant but apparently it's not a Cape Of Good Hope Postmark.

Ocean views. As part of you SA tour we visited the light house. It was 45 degrees with misting rain. We rode the funicular to the lighthouse base and then spent several minutes looking at the ocean views. Unfortunately the wind and mist did not make for pleasant viewing and we spent more time in the gift shop.Staff was friendly and pleasant.

The meeting of two ocean currents. My family and I went to Cape Point today. It was wonderful. We hired a private driver so we were able to spend plenty of time there enjoying all that mother nature had to show us. We arrived at the national park, had lunch and then we walked to the summit of the mountain. There is a train that you can take but we decided to walk. If you have small children or if you have mobility issues then the cable car/train is the best way to go. For the walkers, the climb is pretty steep however there are places to sit and rest along the way. The view at the top from the light house is spectacular. We took some great photos. You should be warned that there are plenty of baboons in the park and they can be aggressive if they think you have food. Just be smart. Do not feed the animals. Overall we had a wonderful time.

Simply breath taking. Did self-drive and left a day to explore. The park itself is vast with many roads off the main to explore. Wildlife everywhere if you drive slowly and keep an eye out. The scenery is breathtaking from every corner and sea spectacular. Recommend a visit and take your camera and binoculars!

MOST SOUTH WESTERLY POINT OF AFRICA. Magnificent Scenery of Romantically the Two Oceans Meeting Place although that is actually Cape Agulhas but well worth the walk to the Cape Point Lighthouse and to the Sign at the Cape of Good Hope

Breathtaking experience. There are many tours that take you to cape point. The one we had took a scenic route which was breathtaking. Once you reach cape point there is a reataurant and small shops. You can either choose to walk up to the light house or use their cable car. It was really fun. And the view from the top shouldnt be missed

Very scenic and enjoyable drive . I went on a full day tour sadly it was overcast and rained for most of the day however still enjoyed the incredible scenery on the way.Many lookouts to stop and take great photos on both side of the ocean you can go down one side and come back the other side so that you can enjoy different scenery. A sign is located before the lighthouse indicating that it's the most s/w part of Africa.Lighthouse is also very good it has a restaurant, pizza place and gift shop to enjoy then it's a 10 minute walk up to lighthouse or you can catch like a cable car train up for 58 rand return.If in Cape Town this trip should be in the top 3 things to do.
Fabuos and very intresting fauna,. Traveling to this area, for trekking. Buteful walking fr.o.m. Capetown to the cape. Absolute fabolus with a lot of flowers and animals

A Must Do. We did a tour of the Cape as part of our trip to South Africa. We stopped at the Cape of Good Hope - a good photo opportunity- and continued on to Cape Point where we walked up to the lighthouse for some fantastic views. The lazy ones among us took the funicular. There are some good tourist shops here also. On the way back to Capetown we stopped off at Boulders Beach to see the Penguins. A really good day out, lots to see with interesting scenery - the views across the ocean are particularly stunning.
Nature surrounds in total abundance. Here it is possible to absorb creation the way it originated. No interference by unnecessary human inventions.
ENDLESS BEAUTY. From Zebras, Baboons, Dassies, Bokkies to hiking, Fishing , Diving - the odd ostrich who will visit you to the amazing scenic views across the ocean. A must for your entire family

cape. Very cool place I loved it extremely must remain there for a long time
Fantastically ocean view and causing waves enchanting

Really interesting visit. Really interesting visit to the furthest South point in Africa. A huge nature reserve which we only wished we had allowed more time to explore. Would recommend a while day to explore the area and book dinner in the two oceans restaurant with fabulous views and high quality food

Many pay points so come prepared. Visiting Cape Point is well worth the trip but be prepared for entrance fee - R100+ and an additional R50+ if you have not prepared to walk up to the light house and views.Make the most of the day - wear hiking shoes (save the funicular fee) and enjoy the walk right down to the point - only 45minutes or so on good path but proper walking shoes are needed.Pack a picnic and drive around the park a little - some historic points to view. Spend the morning and make the most of the entrance fees.As with all San Parks, everything is well kept, beat, tidy and clean. Staff are friendly and helpful.Even a pod shopping spot for international tourists - prices here the same as in the city.

Beautiful scenery at Cape Point. Cape Point and the journey thereto via Chapmans has got to offer some of the most stunning coastal scenery in the world. It comes complete with baboons dotted about that although dangerous and not to be approached offer amusement to passers by.
Beautiful!. A beautiful nature reserve! and a breathtaking view. This is a must to anyone visiting Cape Town, hope to go again soon!

Windy but spectacular!. Great views, some wildlife, a bit of walking but not too much (Funicular option for the less able). The views of the ocean and the rocks are just to die for. Expect high winds!

Historical and Interesting site. Spectacular views of the ocean and is the southwestern point in South Africa. We traveled during Winter and it was a stormy day but the views were still very good. You can pay a small fee to travel up to the lighthouse by a small train. It made for a great half day trip as you can also walk to the southwestern point (which is away from the lighthouse itself) and also view the monuments of the Spanish explorers in times past.

Stunning view from Light House. We have visited Cape Point Nature Reserve during our Peninsula trip organized by Cape Town agency Shark & Safaris.We took the cable car to get to the top of the mountain and walked up to the Light House.The view from up there is excellent, took nice shots. There are many naughty monkeys so it is not advisable to eat any food or to keep your belongings anywhere. Beside the Cable Car starting point is a nice restaurant and souvenir shops selling wide variety of nice souvenirs.
Beautiful!. Can't go to Capetown and not visit the cape point nature reserve! Lots of nice view, baboons, and ostriches to see in their natural habitat! Very cold, so bring a nice sweater!
Cape Point Reserve. Very interesting. Wonderful views of the oceans Atlantic and Indian meeting. Center of the earth!!!! A must visit
Quick day trip needs to be longer. We. Only had two days but this was one highlight ! A must see beautiful beautiful place . Our guide was great and it was her first day
Beautiful day trip out of Cape Town. Beautiful trip out side Cape Town and the saw lots of Baboons along the way. The coastal highway is a magnificent drive.

Need to Visit!. So many facts around Cape Point and although you need to climb steps even after taking the cable car up the mountain, it was worth all the effort to get the beautiful scenery. To see where Indian and Atlantic oceans meet is something else. Our guide warned us and it was true that there are many baboons in the area although not as aggressive as I thought they would be.
Nature at its best. Took helicopter ride to Cape Point Nature Reserve, what an adventure, like being in National Geographic.

Breath taking sight. Bit of a climb to the light house viewing point, but the effort once you at the top. Stunning views to behold of the sea.2 Curio shops at the top of the point as well as at the starting point. There is a cafeteria is available. One could use the funicular if the walking is tiresome.

A must-do. One of the "must-dos" whilst in Capetown - a visit to Cape Point and the reserve. Plenty of bird life, including ostrich, only problem is popularity of the Cape Point, which may require a queue for a photo of the sign at Cape Point !
Vacation in South Africa. A mesmerizing view worth the travel. The wonderful ocean water splashing against the rocks are a breath taking experience. Water lovers should definitely go.

Family day out.. We took the "Flying Dutchman" to the top to see the Lighthouse. The views are spectacular. We walked back down which is highly recommended. There are baboons walking about so be aware. Don't have any open handbags for food around as they will snatch it from you. There were people taunting the baboons which is NOT clever. These are wild animals after all. We packed a picnic and after driving around jn the Reserve found a nice spot next to the beach.
Breath Taking sights. Seen some of the most beautiful views and amazing wild animals that one can only dream about. A Must see!

Go on a day with fewer tourists. We were lucky to visit this part of south Africa during the winter. There were fewer tourists, and the weather was nice and cool.The only frustrating moment during our visit was fighting with 100 other tourists who all wanted their picture in front of the "Cape of good hope" sign. If one of those mega tour buses had arrived, this would have been a nonstop battle and we never would have had a moment to ourselves (and the sign). A great stop if you're down that way... Not a must see, but it was a great flash back to world history, remembering how Magellan and Diaz and others came that way once upon and time.
Great Views at Cape Point. The views from Cape Point were great. A visit to Simonstown was a highlight - especially seeing the penguins. The buildings in Simonstown also worth a look.
Another Must see in Capetown. There is so much to see at Capetown and this is another one of them. Walk through the trails and you will see families of different kinds of monkeys.

Scenery is phenomenal!. We spent the day hiking in the park at various waterfront locations and the lighthouse. The scenery is magnificent! Don't miss the cliff views at the lighthouse. We also saw many species of birds, eland, baboons, lizards and ostrich. Lovely waves, water and sand beaches.
Beautiful!!. Must-see, take the tourist crowd for granted... Take the walk to the old light-house, worth it! Go up with the cable car, take the stairs down and enjoy the fantastic views.

Last point of Africa where two oceans meet. One of the major attraction in SA. 2 hour journey from Cape Town takes you to this amazing place. See the meeting g point of Indian ocean and Pacific ocean having two distinct colors. Beautiful view from the cliff. See the point where a board indicates straight line directions and distance of world's famous cities. Have good lunch in Cape View restaurant. But some memento in the souvenir shop. You can sight some wild life like wild baboons. Don't feed them which is strictly no no. Do not go close to them since they can attack human beings easily. Great place for day tour.
Exquisite views. Had a blast visiting this area yesterday. Was a tad windy, as you'd expect but the views were absolutely amazing :) definitely worth the drive down!
Reasonable priced.. Very Nice Area.lots of things to see here. Not overcrowded when we went there. Take the Walk to the top. And then descent with the cable trolley.
Nice walk and beautiful location. A must do, and would recommend making a half day of it to take advantage of the hiking around the reserve.

Cape Point. By visiting the Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope area is a must.. Travelling from your hotel along the Helen Suzman drive towards Beach Road is an amazing experience. From there journey along Clifton with the four beaches. Stop at a place called Maidens Cove where you can take pictures of Camps bay. From there your journey take you towards Houtbay then onwards to Chapman's Peak drive. You will then travel towards Noordhoek on your way to Cape Point. Cape Point is between the two oceans mainly the Atlantic and the Indian Oceans. Cape of Good Hope is the South Westerly Point of the African Continent. Many believe this is where the two oceans meet, but it is another 200 plus kilometres away. A visit to this beautiful part of Cape Town is a must for each visitor. Many
Incredible piece of nature. Gorgeous views are to be found here. Do NOT miss! Either walk or take the funicular up to the lighthouse. Lots of birdwatching to be done as well.

Long trip. Worth the long drive to know you have been to the point. Only saw a few wildlife in the park, but great views from the point. Windy, go on a fine day, went on an organised trip visiting the Penguins enroute
Terrific Place!. You have not been to this side of the world until you visit the Cape Point! Makes you appreciate God's wonderful works! Awesome!

Beautiful views. Not to be missed. Views are wonderful and for the hearty a walk up to the lighthouse. Can be crowded in the month of January. Lots of steps to the top. Hand rails provided. Has to be a non rainy day to enjoy.

Stunning views. Unfortunately we visited here on the last day of our holiday so we were a bit rushed. Of note we had our own car so I'm not sure what if any public transport there is,I only saw tour buses. We chose to take the funicular up to the top as we were under time pressure but I would have preferred to walk. The cost was 58 rand return for an adult and 24 for a scholar. The views up the top are spectacular. Worth a visit but allow time to explore.
Stunning views at Cape Point. This was a great day trip from Cape Town, good scenery and we had a good day. Also went on to the penguin colony at Simon's Town
Untouched Nature at its best. This was a place where nature is untouched and whilst the beautiful views are amazing, animals such as Baboons , Ostriches and others even complement the place.
Stunning scenery here.. Cold and windy but well worth the visit, with some terrific photo opportunities of the rugged and wild coastline.
Breathtaking!. Wonderfully maintained and highly enjoyable hiking. An experience to be savored and relived for many years.

Beautiful place with variety of attractions. That is a place for people loving nature with great cliffs and vast savanna. You can meet baboons, ostrich and many birds. There are many tracks for hikers.
Nice view and wild animals. We saw ostrichs and baboons here. The views were very nice. We didn't go up to the highest point so I can't speak about that part but the park is worth a visit.

Mind the Baboons. Sensational views from Cape Point with a drive through the wildlife nature reserve before you reach the restaurant and lighthouse. You will see Kudu, zebra, tortoises, and a variety of buck including the Red Hartebeest. The restaurant itself serves a nice variety of food with a great wine list, and has sensational views. BUT BE WARNED....the baboons are extremely bold and will get into your car quick as a wink, steal your handbag, and run off into the brush with it. There are guards armed with water guns who will scare them off your car if they are sitting on top of it on your return. DO NOT EVER FEED THEM !

Incredible hikes at the edge of the world. We came for a day to hike and see the sights. We ended up doing the hike up to Cape Point (~20-30 min round trip) and the hike from Cape Point to the Cape of Good Hope (~1 hour 15 min roundtrip). We would highly recommend both.

Beautiful scenery but an expensive destination.. It is one of those must-do destinations in the Cape but, by local standards, it is very expensive. The restaurant is hugely overpriced for what you get. However, the scenery is dramatic.
Beautiful. Amazingly beautiful place. Very windy so be prepared - windbreaker/jackets recommended even on summer days
Fantastic but costly. Like many things in SA you pay, constantly and all over, which after a while is annoying even if you expect it.But the price paid is worth it!

Wow. We started a self drive tour to Cape point and followed the Atlantic ocean down to the cape, spent a few hours looking around and followed the Indian ocean back to Cape Town. What an extraordinary experience. It was very cold and very windy but that didn't stop us enjoying every part of this trip. Well worth the effort to get there.

Breathtaking views. I always go here when in Cape Town for a break. It is a bit of a drive but the road there is good and very scenic.It offers the most incredible views of the Cape peninsula. Take the tram to the top and spend some time taking in the scenery and you can walk around at the top for hours. It is quite exposed so take something warm. There is a good restaurant on site and an interesting gift shop with lots of souvenirs on offer.An absolute must if you are visiting the city.
Cape Point is beautiful!. You MUST have your picture taken at the Cape of Good Hope latitude and longitude sign! The whole area is gorgeous...we saw ostriches on the beach!
Stunning. Well worth visiting stunning scenery and lovely was to spend a day or more exploring the Cape Point Nature Reserve

Amazing visit, superb nature and views around the cape point!. The drive to Cape Point is legendary, using the 2 oceans road. Upon arrival incredible views can be seen from the lighthouse over the impressive cliffs!
Must visit.

Incredible views and the awesome raw power of nature. Great site seeing location. There are two points (Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope). I remembering learning about he Cape of Good Hope in school, but never heard of Cape Point - interesting that Cape Point is where all the action is. It was a very windy day when we visited (which the park staff said was normal).You can walk or take a tram from the parking area to the top (to the lighthouse). There are lots of trails for walking - so you should spend hours here, just walking around. On our winter visit (on a cold day), the baboons were not out, and the place was not packed. Make sure you visit the light house at the top, and if you're up to it, consider walking out the the far point. But, have a jacket, and hold on to stuff so it doesn't get blown away.
Cape Point is stunning!. Never miss this on a sunny day!Best views with cute penguins to boot. Best sunset views from Signal Hill Great photo shots of Table Mountain from top of Signal Hill.
Beautiful. It was fun to stand at the southwest most point of Africa. If you are not in good shape take the trolley up the mountain. Breathtaking views! Watch out for the baboons!

Cold and rainy day.. We went with the car to this Cape of good hope park. On the way there were some baboons on the road(keep your windows closed) once up there the view was stunning, the left side the indian ocean and the right the atlantic. Went at a very cold day, so was a bit freezing.

Worth the visit. The Point is a natural touristic attraction. I was in the low season and there were plenty of people, so must be very crowded on peak season.The place is very good for a stroll and going up the lighthouse is a must.The food courts on the base are small and not a big deal. When you get to the top (I took funicular) and after the walk, there is a much nicer wi-fi spot, great views and great coffee & muffins.

An incredible experience seeing the Atlantic and Indian Ocean at the same time.. Roads need major repairs and I don't think a tour is a great way of getting here. I would suggest great walking boots or shoes. Driving thru the park I saw several varieties of wild life - Ostriches and Antelopes. Never saw any Zebra but supposedly they are here.
Spectacular Views. This is the tip of the African continent where the Indian ocean meets Atlantic. Its said many ships and sailors lost their lives there and a priest renamed it Cape of Good Hope.

Stunning views of the Ocean. If you are not fit enough or you don't exercise regularly, I STRONGLY advice you to reach the top using the funicular -which runs from the car park level-. On the way down, you can easily walk the pathway and admire the beautiful cliffs and landscapes :-) The views from the old lighthouse are truly speechless! FYI: Cape Point is often mistakenly as the place where Indian and Atlantic Ocean meets!

Worth the drive. We enjoyed the drive through the reserve. Difinitely worth driving to. There are places to stop and stretch your legs. Look out for baboons and don't carry food in your car! The views are breathtaking!
Amazing view . This place had an amazing view in all directions! I prefer Cape Point in stead of Cape of Good Hope..! Good weather is preferable, but as long as it doesn't rain it's beautiful;)

Amazing view from the platforms and lighthouse. I arrived immediately before it started raining on Cape Point but I got some amazing views from the platforms. I would recommend hiking up the the top instead of taking the funicular if you are healthy enough. Watch out for baboons!
Beautiful and scenic. Drove from Cape Town. Spectacular scenery despite the light rain. Stopped at tourist office (coffee and bathroom). Enjoyable day trip,

One of the worlds amazing places. One of the most naturally beautiful places on the planet. Awe inspiring, amazing, beautiful - one gets lost for words. Great walking location. On most popular tourist route. Charge for entry.

Excellent. This is a bit away from Cale town but worth the visit. The main attractions are flying Dutchman and cape of good hope. The flying Dutchman is OK nothing great specially if you have gone to Switzerland or the peak in Hong Kong. However the view from the top are amazing. There are some animals in the park and the cape of good hope is in the park.

Gorgeous and worth the drive. It looks like the end of the earth with the dramatic scenery and it almost is. I would reccomend a visit, but if you can spend the money do it with a private tour guide and combine it with a trip to see the penguins.
Stunningly beautiful nature reserve. Although the iconic sign is worth a visit, the entire reserve is worth seeing. This area of Cape Town is gorgeous with the cliffs and water.

End of Africa . Who doesn't want to say they have been to the end of Africa? Well, I never get tired of it. I look forward to seeing some wild life while I am there as well. But, the views are amazing. The rolling mountains in the distance are so exilherarting. I am so amazed with God's creation. I love taking a photo at the top of the light house that shows how far it is to New York City. Maybe it makes me fill like a child again!

SPECTACULAR!. Wonderful area to take a slow drive and see the rugged landscape, beautiful fynbos and spectacular views of the ocean. A fairly steep walk up rocky steps at Cape Point will take you to the vantage point at the light house; there is also the option of taking a funicular ride to the top. One can stop for a coffee or meal at the restaurant below the light house…just watch out for the birds who swoop down to take some of your bread!
Awesomeness day . Cheap to enter with amazing hiking trails and lots to see against the beautiful backdrop of the mountain range

Beautiful. Beautiful, but a little busy. Some lovely walks to do.
We combined this with a day trip to Simonstown, Boulders Beach and Kalk Bay.

Exceptional edge of the World!. Great trip well worth doing. Cheap entrance and well priced all round day out. Exceptional views and of great natural interest. Nice walk if you wan to avoid the funicular and beautiful beach if you head down to bay

Hiking trails. Wonderful hiking trails ( choice of different routes). me and my son took the one from the parking lot down to Cape of Good Hope (for about 1hr45). Wonderful views of the ocean and the blue waters
Cape of Good Hope. There is Cape of Good Hope at Cape Point Nature reserve, it's very fantastic to see this board-sign overthere.

Back to Nature. A beautiful part of the Cape where one can ride in the coach (forgotten the correct name - sorry) to the top and have the world at your feet. Supposedly the two oceans meet at this point but, in actual fact, the two oceans actually meet at Arniston. Some beautiful picnic spots though and the dassies and baboons are interesting to watch from a distance.

where the 2 oceans meet. nice nature walks, good restaurant, on the way to the point do not have windows open for the baboons although parks board are keeping them at bay. choose a clear day and can be a bit windy. nature is beautiful down there.
Amazing natural beauty. Its a great drive down to Cape Point along the coast. Keep a full day to explore this place entirely.
Jewels of Africa. Standing on the edge of Africa staring into the openness of ocean all round , no words can explain. experience an explosion of various feelings and emotions
Beautiful. If you love water, mountains, birds, and a good walk, this is the right place. It is hard to stop taking pictures....

Amazing scenery. Well worth a visit. The natural place to go is the lighthouse at the top/end, but could easily make a day of a combination of driving and walking around the park, exploring all the different parts of the coastline.

Great day trip with Cape Extreme. We used Cape Xtreme (info@cape-xtreme.com) to visit Cape Point and were more than happy with our choice.Collected from our hostel at 8am and dropped back at 5.30pm the day was full of variety which included visiting the Bo Kaap district, stopping at Camps Bay, driving over Chapman's Peak from Houts Bay, photo opportunities at both the Cape of Good Hope and Cape Point, a simple lunch of fish and chips followed by a visit to Boulders beach to see the penguins before heading back towards Cape Town and our final stop at a winery for a wine tasting. The day cost $800 R per person and was we'll worth it. Jimmy our guide was full of information and even spotted a whale for us.

''LOvely drive and breatht aking view''. On of the main attraction of cape town. you start early and it takes couple of hrs. t reach to that place on the way one can stop by to see the ostrich park from couple of feet away. one can see many species of flora and fauna.once you are in cape point it is like heaven, vast expense of sea blue in colour and one gets intoxicated with the enormity of the view.it has long an d great history read before going and look for a good driver and guide.

Just to say you have been. Many of these places are hot on the list of places to go when you are in CapeTown. Well the Cape Point Nature Reserve is truly a place to visit. The views, the landscape and the feeling you get being one with nature is stupendous. Go for the pictures!! You won't regret it.
OUTSTANDING!!!. Breathtaking views! I went down to the water and braved the sharks. MUST SEE!!!! Can get a little crowded at the lookout.

One of the must beautiful drives in the world. The drive form Cape Town to Cape Point is incredible gourgeous, the mountains, the oceans (on one side the Atlantic and on the other the Indian) plus you get baboons and ostrichs crosing the road!
Must see. Beautiful seascapes and the most south-westerly point in SA. Whole drive there and back from Capetown is rich in scenery and history. A great day out.

Feels like you are in another world. great place to spend an entire day, lots of hikes and wildlife as well as beaches to choose from. Braai areas available at buffers bay beach, just watch out for crafty baboons and do not feed or leave car door/windows open. Diaz beach is amazing to spend the day picnicking, be careful when swimming though as it is a bit dangerous. It can get very busy in peak tourist season so best to start off early.

Amazing scenery - coastline & mountains.. A great day trip from Cape Town with magnificent scenery and lots of history.If its open, take the Chapman's Peak Drive for great scenery and engineering.We did the trip on an American Eagle full day tour of the Peninsula
Beautiful and Wild. Really worth exploring. If you have hired a car it is a must do. Some many beautiful views with a rugged coastline.
Amaizing view. Really was of going, and combining together with Pinguin and botanical gardens. Was amazing day, we had private guide, so he can stop were we decided :)

Two oceans coming togather.. This is the Southern point/tip of the Africa as a continent, this where Indian and Atlantic oceans meet, you get to walk up the mountain until you rich the top of the mountain, the site of the two oceans coming togather and the waves mixing togather is amazing,
Nature's wonder. Nice place to visit. It's a heaven for nature lovers. You have an option to explore this place by foot. If you are good Walker then do it.
Amazing Place to visit. The Cape Point and the Reserve are places not to miss during the Cape Town experience..... The Light house point and the Cape Point is amazing....
Drive to Cape Point via Chapmans Peak Drive. Nice drive along Chapmans Peak, great views form the top. Getting there was half the fun. Very scenic drive.

Worth the Trip. We loved the drive from Cape Town down to the Cape Point Nature Reserve. You pass through ritzy suburbs and quaint little fishing towns on the way. The Cape is wild and we saw several animals as we drove. The light house is worth the climb!!
Must See Point. It is one of the must see point. It is very impressive. It is not really close to Cape Town center however it is worth to go there!

Visit to Cape. After several days of rain we finally got here... it rained on and off but it was OK to hike up to Cape point. Watch out for baboon...one jumped in the car next to us as they were getting out and stole their popcorn. Funny but scary too. This time of year there were not a lot of people so that was nice. Made it back to car in time for the rain again. Nice site to visit.

Fascinating oceanic and mountain views! too beautiful!. awesome panoramic mountain and oceanic views especially from the old lighthouse...... if you are lucky you could see a whale on the south easterly side of the light house... i saw one! on my drive within the nature reserve i came across wild such as the Eland-very big and beautiful, wild ostrich and some baboons. Thanks to Mille a Mille tour guide !
Beautiful. Lovely. Could cater more for young kids. Stunning views. Could cater more for locals with ZAR as opposed to £££'s. Restaurant although beautiful, a let down in its variety of offerings.
Beautiful Views. The coastal views were absolutely beautiful! The pictures taken from the top were some of our favorite!

Beautiful views, great hiking. We took the day to drive from Cape Town to Cape Point, and it was worth it! The drive was fairly easy and the hiking and views at Cape Point were well worth the trip. Cape Point Nature Reserve has many hiking paths and outlook points other than the most popular lighthouse spot, and we are so glad that we took a local's advice to check out some of these less touristy spots. That being said, we did really enjoy the lighthouse at the point as well, but hiking down the trail to the very tip was probably our favorite part of our stop at the point. If you love nature and hiking, this spot is for you. But, do beware of the baboons. They are definitely not afraid of people!
Well worth a day trip!. No visit to CPT isn't complete without a visit to here. The sights, sounds, and sheer stunning beauty of the place is worth the drive out...
gorgeous views. this is one of the most beautiful places I've ever been! Basically you will see everything in nature that you are expecting for, white beaches, cliffs, wild animals, plants....

Great place for half a day - but take a picnic. This is not where the two seas meet!I didn't know this until I got there, but it was still a great place to visit, some nice walks, plenty to do and see. It is also said, during summer you can see whales and dolphins, which I sadly missed. Make sure you take a picnic so that you can relax and enjoy the great scenery.

Simply beautiful.... Cape Point Nature Reserve is a wonderful place to simply be...outdoor options like having a picnic with the family, visiting the tip of Africa and some great walks for the whole family.

Beautiful drive and view. Cape point Nature Reserve is a must visit when you are in cape town. Its a huge national reserve and has no commercial buildings. you need to drive through the reserve to see the cape point and cape of good hope.
Beautiful Place! A Must-Do!. My girlfriend and I hiked all over Cape Point while on our trip to Cape Town! The scenery will absolutely take your breath away!
A 'must see' - breathtaking!. A highlight was walking out to the point so we recommend wearing decent walking sandals/shoes ie. not flip flops.

Great views with ostriches on the trail. Lovely drive and short hike 40 minute from the car up to the car park which felt far away from the road. Baboons playing by the entrance, down to the penguin beach below full of beautiful nature and hikes.

Stunning views and delightful meal. This is a great experience, the walk is beautiful and the majesty of the oceans colliding is awe-inspiring. The wildlife and native fauna on the road through the Nature Reserve is beautiful and if you are adventurous, the climb down to some of the secluded beaches is amazing. We stayed for lunch on the deck overlooking the ocean - stunning!

Well Worth the trip down if you can make it!. Breathtaking scenery and if you time it right you may see some whales from cape point!
A very beautiful place and highly recommended!
Sunrise in paradise. Beautiful ! We went there to see the sunrise and it was so peaceful, calm and breathtaking. We loved it. Definitely a must go place !!!!
Stupendous view. we were lucky could see the view in clear day. we took excellent photograph. It is quite easy to access for climbing, walking or just chilling. Beautiful place
Cold windy cloudy but still beautiful. The weather was disappointing on the day we toured the Cape. It was still beautiful - rugged coastline and would have been amazing in the sunshine.

The Beauty of Cape Point. It is such an awesome experience traveling to Cape Point.
Such natural beauty and amazing views. Simply a Must see for anyone
Visiting Capetown.
The end of Africa. Stunningly beautiful with great views of the ocean from different vantage points. Not much in the way of animals, mostly ostriches, but rich with flora and breathtaking seascapes.
Nice half day trip. Well worth the trip down. We enjoyed the funicular up to the lighthouse. Great vistas. Stop at Boulders beach to see the penguins.

Awesome. Great drive down, wonderful views at the end. Well worth it.
Learnt that Cape Point and The Cape of Good Hope are two different places.
Wholeheartedly recommended.

We were all over South Africa and Zambia and this is the ONLY place we saw Eland. Great place to spend a day - just do NOT feed the baboons - we saw some foolish people doing this. Being from Florida and having the same problem with tourists feeding alligators we understand how this can become a BIG problem.

A view for Africa. The reserve is well cared for and the sites are amazing. Was there on business for telecommunications requirements and had to ensure that the natural sites were taken into consideration for the infrastructure

Not Worth a Second Look. The Nature Reserve touts the "joining of the Atlantic and Indian Oceans" - which doesn't happen here. Be prepared for a good hike up to the lookout point or pay extra to take the "tram" up. Oh, the baboons are free to roam all over and they certainly aren't afraid of anyone! We certainly wouldn't return for another look; if you have time stop here, but don't go out of your way.

Stunning views. We had a lovely walk up to the old lighthouse, seeing so many birds and an Eland on the way.The views are stunning, especially down to the new lighthouse.Easy to drive to from Cape Town.

Breathtaking views. This is an amazing place. about 3 hr ride from the heart of Cape Town, this is a must go place if you are visiting. A walk upto the old Light House with sea on one side is brilliant.
nice peninsular view of cape. should not miss this tourist place as its awesome to be a part in mother natures creation.bit costly trip but worth.
Cape of Good Hope- beautiful the tip of the continent. Lovely drive, lovely scenery- the tip of the continent not to be missed. Had a good and not very overpriced meal at the restaurant.
Open Water as far as you can see!. WOW! This was amazing! It was so pretty to witness the light house and Baboons and the open ocean! Do not miss this beautiful place!

Not to Be Missed. This is a visit to another landmark not to be missed if you are in South Africa. It is easy to get to by car, nicely laid out and organised and offers some breath taking and unique sea views. It is best to allow time to visit here and Cape of Good Hope so perhaps set aside most of one day and a time for a picnic in the middle. A fantastic place and one I would highly recommend.
Very rugged coastline. Take a tour since our driver provided great history and political lessons of south Africa. What a great view from the Cape. Saw a few ostriches

Amazing Place. This is a must do for people coming to South Africa. The park is amazing. it's a very easy drive from Cape Town and i would highly recommend driving yourself. You pass many towns on the way to stop and grab food before you get to the park. The park is not commercialized so bring water and eat food before arriving if you plan to spend a lot of time in the park. The park can get crowded near the lighthouse during the day but the other areas had amble parking. Great place to see wildlife including seals, baboons, birds, and other lager animals.

Nature at its best. This is a beautiful day out with stunning drives to Cape Point Nature Reserve and once inside the park more beautiful scenery, with added wild life and views of amazing seas. Depending on the time of year and weather, you can see some really rough wave activity. Careful of the baboons, keep your food hidden away and your vehicle doors locked at all times. And please do not feed the baboons. There are also walks for the more active visitors that are well kept and beautiful to hike.
Great hiking. Stunning views and fun hiking - make sure to take water. Access deserted beaches and fairly empty trails. Two oceans restaurant is misnamed but the food was good.

Cape point. What a nice place to be! It is absolutely worth to visit. You can walk there by your own. Well landscaped walkways. Beautiful cliffs views and things like that. I can't describe it very well, you have to see it by yourself.

Well worth the visit. Try to get off the beaten track and do a short hike or two so you can drink in the atmosphere. Cape Point particularly gets overwhelmed with bus loads to pic snapping tourists especially on weekends, and it can seriously degrade your experience. Take your time on the side roads and you could get lucky and see some of the animals in their natural state.

Great day outing. I have been here three times already and do not get tired of visiting. With each and every visit, I am amazed at the splendor. You can explore the nature reserve and various beaches for hours. Absolutely beautiful.
Cape Point. We did a full day tour Cape Point that included also Penguin colony, Cape of Good Hope etc. This tour is a must for a first time visitor to Capetown.

A thrill of a lifetime. To travel to the end of Africa with the Atlantic on one side and Indian on the other is breathtaking. Also, the drive there through the lunar landscape is amazing with all he wildlife.

Lovely!. The Cape Point Nature Reserve is a protected area that leads up to the Cape of Good Hope. Nice natural scenery, scenic views and some wild animals (I like the ostriches!) can be enjoyed here. Lovely!

Beautiful. We took a half day trip to the Cape Point Nature Reserve. We saw animals and beautiful views, be aware of the closing times, they are quite strict about the gate closures and the fees if you run late.

Simply GREAT!!!!!. For all my life I had a dream (cit) :) ... See the Cape of Good Hope area and Cape Point LIght... The Park is vast and you need of a lot of hours to visit. You can see a lot of animals also, Baboons, Ostrichs, Cobras, Turtles and so on.... A very magic place.....

The Tip of the Cape. Cape Point is a beautiful reserve with some great trails, a lighthouse with cable car to the top (or you can hike), and simply stunning views of the powerful ocean. Take the day to hike around, pack a lunch or dine at the Two Oceans restaurant (it is fabulous). This is a lovely spot to visit.

To the End of the World!. What a magnificent place to go...it's a national park so entry fees are payable but there is enough to see and do to fill a day....most tourists go straight to the tip and take the cablecar up for the views, usually followed by something to eat in the restaurant...as a result it's usually absolutely packed....but, there are lots of roads leading off both sides of the main road that will take you to lovely beaches and/or picnic areas...you can also go for walks and could be lucky enough to see a bit of wildlife (not the dangerous variety)..did I just say not the dangerous variety? Well, baboons can be if not treated with caution and respect...I lost my picnic lunch to a troop of them that appeared out of nowhere it seemed to me....I let them eat their fill I hasten to add....Another Must Do for visitors to Cape Town
Windy and Wild. When we were there, it was blustery (cold) and windy--but really exhilarating! Loved it! Be sure to take your picture with signs in both languages at the point.

Breathtaking Sea Cliffs, Amazing Scenery and lunch !. Be prepared for some walking, but it is well worth the effort. If you are prepared to spend a bit more, take the Funicular Tram to the top of Cape point and enjoy the views. Those with a Green Nature Conservation Access card get into the Cape Point Nature reserve free :) There are also a myriad of side trips within the reserve that can fascinate and awe with some really beautiful scenery and the occasional wildlife. A day outing well worth the time and very rewarding.
nature at one. this was one of the best place i have ever been to you may have to walk but you can ride bike to on my tour we had to ride bike, walk, take the most amazing photos, but just enjoy it
Monterrey. If you've ever visited California wineries then Cape Town is a good place to start to toe address homesickness,

A must see when you are in Cape Town. We drove there ourselves so my advice is based on our flexibility. Go early it's a long trip. I think it took us almost 2 hours to get there from downtown. Don't miss the penguins! You don't have to go to tourist center and pay money to see them. On the left from the parking lot there is an entrance to the beach and there is plenty of them there. And they let you get very close.There are a few locations at Cape Point. If want to hike one day will not be enough. 2 locations are a must see - the Cape Point itself and the lighthouse on top of the mountain. We took a cable car to get up and then walked down. The views are spectacular. There is a very nice restaurant right by the cable car station. Get a table on the deck and watch out for monkeys.

Beautiful!!. Cape Point is one of those places that you absolutely must see if you go visiting Cape Town. We had the priviledge of staying over in a cottage in the park. This is a very popular place for tourists to go and it can get very crowded. Best to go and visit during the week and especially early morning. The earlier you can go, the more you will have the park to yourself.

Must do!. This should definitely be on everybody's list while visiting Cape Town. On the way to the reserve, we visited penguins in Simon's town and then off to the Cape Point. We have used the furnicular up to the top to see the new lighthouse and then we walked the path to the old lighthouse (around 40 mins round trip) which had beautiful views of the ocean and mountains - defnitely recommend that.After that, we got sandwiches (very tasty) from the cafe and walked the cliff path to the Cape of Good Hope- I believe you can drive there as well but I would defnitely recommended walking the path (from where the furnicular is)! On the way, you can admire beutiful Diaz beach and you can also opt for climbing the stairs down and back up (great exercise:-)) and enjoy the beach. When we were there (late afternoon in January), we had the beach to ourselves!!The path to the Cape of Good Hope is fairly easy, only at the end, you have to climb a little - but the ocean views are definitely worth it.
Beautiful sceneries. We spent the whole day driving around the peninsula. We saw antilopes, baboons, seals, ostriches and kudus. amazing

Duiker cottage, Baboons and Braai. Very quiet. We stayed with 2 persons in the cottage, but there is space for6.Ostriches (with young ones) near cottage and bonteboks.Of course there were baboons were around and they watched us closely untilsomeone (presumably a ranger nearby) made a sound that made them go away.Outside shower was nice (there was an indoor shower as well...).There is a large braai area.Book with a lot of information, including the walks.

Cape Point. One of the most spectacular trips to Cape Point, is the surrounding landscape and the scenic view. It is suitable for all ages and has many pathways that will lead to stunning beaches and adventure walks.

Simply fantastic. This is worth a visit - it is possible to do a one-day trip (either rented car or with an agency). entering the reserve you have access to both Cape of good Hope an Cape Point (anda lot of other beautiful nature spots). The areas have wild baboons, dassies and ostrich. Originally it was thought that this was were the Atlantic Ocean and the Indian Ocean meet, and even though that is in l'Agulhas, this is still worth a visit - beautiful scenery. Had lunch at Cape Point, which was also fantastic - very fresh and delicious seafood at descent prices.
We spotted Bonteboks of onl 3000 left. Beautiful park with indigenous plants and the famous Bontebok. Nice views of nearby mountains and sea. Easy to follow roads and easy to follow the directions.

Gorgeous views. Just a day trip to Cape Point (my second one in ten years). Cost is about R150 Justpp entry into park. The hike up to the lighthouse is beautiful and a good bit of exercise. The views are amazing. A must for the first time traveller to Cape Town.
Wowwww. Exellent landscape and panoramic views,this is a place one can spend the entire day just enjoying the views
Do Not Miss!. Cape Point was the main stop on our private peninsula (tour). We took the tram up to the top and had the most spectacular views. Well worth the trip.

Two Lighthouses @ Cape point. The Cape Point Nature Reserve opens up a nice 6am for the early birds like myself. Unfortunately the same cannot be said for the restaurant and the funicular which really work on "Africa" Time. Further they allow motorcycles. The Reserve is well kept. Views from the original, now non-functional, lighthouse are absolutely breathtaking. There are many secondary roads that makes for a whole day outing if planned well.
It can be very windy up there.... never mind the heavy winds (even on a clear and sunny day), just get up there! The view you get is astonishing!
Amazind place. Stunning view in the Cape Point. Lot of baboons, antelopes and birds. The dramatic intersection of two oceans with rocks reef give a special feelings.

Something Momentous about standing at the Tip of Africa. Next stop Antarctica! When you look out from the old lighthouse at Cape Point you can almost see the curve of the earth on the watery horizon. It's quite something. But the reserve is not only that, it's the beautiful triangle of coastline at the furthest south west you can go on the continent, full of antelopes, tortoises, bike and hiking trails and some fantastic beaches. But beware of baboons who will steal your lunch if you aren't careful and sit on your picnic blanket eating it! But don't let that stop you taking the side roads off the main drag leading you to Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope as you'll find some wild and windy corners worth visiting.

Well worth the drive and climb!. Cape Point can be a bit crowded with buses coming in but you can have an enjoyable time with a little patience. There is a decent walk with slippery, shaking rocks in places to the top of the point so make sure you have a good shoes and water. Once you are up there, the view is absolutely beautiful. It is well worth the time and energy. I would definitely say this is a MUST for your Cape Town trip planning.
A Rare Experience. Not many places in the world can you see or experience two oceans joining. The views are magnificent. I have never been there when it was not windy, but still VERY worthwhile.
Worth the trip. If you are in Cape Town and don't dedicate a full day to visit Cape Point is like throwing money to the sea. Is one of the best things to do (for not saying THE best).

Easy walk with incredible views. My advice is to spend the whole day here. Take a picnic or a braai pack and after experiencing the touristy sights head down to one of the beaches and enjoy what the Cape wildlife has to offer.

Brilliant . Undoubtedly a must-do on a visit to Cape Town. Definitely take the tram up to the top. It's really cheap. The views from the top are incredible. It's quite a drive out of Cape Town, but there are easy stops along the way. Don't skip the whole Chapman's Peak drive. It deserves its reputation. And the folks selling curios at the entrance on the main road before you turn to the Nature Reserve are amazing. Please give them your business.

Fabulous drive to a beautiful place. Everyone should do this even if you don't see any Baboons!Scenery spectacular everywhere. Hike to the Cape of Good Hope a must with sea views all around with the Atlantic and Indian joining together.Funicular available as well for a reasonable fee
Awesome. It's absolutely beautiful to be there. There's all sorts of things to see, we saw birds, flowers, buck, they we're even busy fixing the road inside the reserve. Awesome.
A must destination if you are anywhere near Cape Town.. Breath taking beauty. Gives you a sense of history and what it must have been like to sail and "discover" the Cape. Just raw beauty.

Well worth it!. We went on a perfect day to the lighthouse and had great views. Pay to enter the reserve. Can hike to the lighthouse or pay for the tram. The hike up is moderate in difficulty. There were a lot of tour buses making it crowded and noisy. There is a gift shop and busy restaurant. Plenty of restrooms and parking. Roads were being worked on creating delays. Views are incredible.

Cape Point. A wonderful trip.. Needs a full day itenary. Recommend that one walks up to the lighthouse.. Seniors may be advised to use the Funicular. Eating at the take away restaurant can be a bit hazardous since the birds are extremely aggressive. The views and the scenery are amazing. Choose a good guide to show all the stops along the way, coz there are many the general tours will miss. A MUST visit ..
Fantastic Views and a must visit place in Cape Town. The Cape Point Nature Reserve which is also called the Cape of Good Hope is a rocky headland on the Atlantic coast of the Cape Peninsula.
Amazing Africa Tours . A must for all tourists. Organised Tours are offered. Day well spend with all sightings.Have enough time, camera chips, full batteries and a jacket with you.
Excellent Place. Excellent Place and a must visit place. The view from the Top is amazing and its a different experience altogether. One can enjoy the experience of Shopping as well at the venue.
Top of the world feeling. The place to be to experience and get the best pics of the 2 ocean, the landforms and not forgetting the lighthouse. Superbly windy and awesome.

Breathtaking . Cape point is amazing even for us locals It's quite a drive but once you reach this point it's all worth it... along side the roads there are many stalls selling hand made african art...

Stunning scenery and seascapes. We enjoyed the scenery and seascapes and walked to the top which was shrouded in vapour. We were bold and waited till it cleared and walked back up.Restaurant and coffee shop were a pleasant surprise too.
cape point the tip of the world. that was a lovely trip ostriches ,baboons ,the lighthouse everything was fantastic at the tip of the world

Tour group. Totally surprised to see wild ostriches running alongside our tour bus with the ocean behind them. Also saw elan and baboons. The funicular to the top was great with the choice to catch it or walk back down. The clouds tended to stay around the top lighthouse but we were still able to get good views
A magnificent view of the tip of Africa. Make sure you take the cable carA spectacular view of a national landmark!!A beautiful plece!!!!!Take lots of pictures!!!
Good views. Not a whole lot to do but the views are fantastic. Hope for a good day without a lot of clouds. Lots of wildlife to see, watch out for baboons. They are jerks.

A nature reserve that must not be missed except for the staff! Bad customer service. You should not miss this exceptional destination. However I am here to mention the management of CPNR, first of all there is no mention on their website that dogs are not allowed. Secondly there is no visible customer information on arrival that strictly prohibits dogs. Thirdly the entry fee kiosk girl never told us that the dog we had in the car is not allowed. Next we encounter the most dreadful staff that was threatening us with a fine and a personal escort off the reserve for bringing a dog! He even went so far as to threaten us with being arrested for being difficult and not cooperating. That particular staff ( the manager on duty that day ) was ridiculous to the point of ruining a perfectly good day. Summary ! if you don't accept dogs advertise it. If customers pay to enter with a dog then accept some responsibility. A car escort out of the property was not only unnecessary it was a grande fiasco.

The place to go. There is a beauty and a particular energy to that place that cannot be compared to any other. Every season has its beauty. The light there is incomparable. It s a journey. Almost a mystical one.
Far end of the world. the drive to cape point from Cape Town is absolutely beautiful. The park is great for hiking and Cape Point and the Cape is another world.
Woow i like it. Is a beautful place to see and go to last point in africa wooow and set front of the oeacn .. Cape of good hope ia wonderful place

Wonderful place to visit. Take the tram ride up to the top. Great views, wonderful experience. Don't miss it. Price is very reasonable.. Would also recommend taking the 10 minute drive to the Cape of Good Hope for a photo opp
Wild beautiful place. Super wild reserve after lovely drive down from Cape Town. Fresh and breezy ( take a jacket) - nice to see the Cape of Good Hope

It rains!. One problem about going to any of the various ends of the world or any of the meetings of mighty oceans is that it rains ...a lot! As for Cape Point, no matter how good the weather looks in Cape Town, it can be very different when you finally get here...so be prepared but do not let it put you off going. Cape Point is a "must see" in any travellers list. For a start, there is a wonderful coastal journey (try to sit on the right leaving Cape Town) . It is quite a long journey, but can and should be combined with a return leg via the Indian Ocean side and some of the attractions there. You could easily see wildlife, will certainly view some rugged, almost brutal, coastline waters and will definitely enjoy memorable and unique scenery. Try the funicular, visit the lighthouse (a few more steps involved) and maybe walk back down a good and scenic track before eating or rejoining your transport. However, if you want the photographic experience...avoid the rain!

Spectacular Coast line. Great views of the rugged coastline, along with scenic walks up the mountain, lots of bird life and some wild animals like jackal, and impala and seals. Well worth the trip to see, won't be disappointed.
360 views of Cape Town. Mind-blowing walk which goes around and around and gives the best views of Cape Town. really well spent time.

Fantastic views from top of Fenicular. Amazing sight! Where two sections of the Atlantic Ocean meet! Different types of sea animals, plants and birds live on each side, but mix at this point.
Elands and a few rare bukbeests graze at the bottom.
Beautiful views of the rocky coast, with some small coves and beaches.
Definitely a worthwhile trip!

A must-see. A unique place which you definitely should include in your trip while in Cape Town. The trip down there via St James and Kalk Bay should be part of it - and go back via the Atlantic side, through Misty Cliffs and Scarborough. Beautiful day trip, and you may get lucky and see baboons, too.

A must visit activity in Cape Town. Many uninformed visitors believe that this is the most southerly point of Africa. IN fact it is the most south westerly tip of Africa. The two oceans do not meet here either. The Atlantic and Indian oceans technically meet at cape Agulhas and not Cape Point. A visit to the area is however not only to place a tick in the box, but also for the natural beauty and possible animal and bird sightings. Take you camera along for those postcard pictures to be taken whilst in the park and also en route.
The end of the world. Been here is incredible, you are in one of the southern places on earth, and the southern place on Africa, full of the great white sharks, the feeling is just amazing.
Nice View. Nice view and the way to get there is beautiful. If you are lucky you might see Baboons and other animals.

Stunning!. Another wonderful special place in South Africa. What a paradise this coutry is. The drive here alone is fascinating - for lovers of both landscape and architecture (all sorts of houses in picturesque settlements). Then the whoosh of the freshest air imaginable and the stunning views on arrival. A must for anyone visiting Cape Town.
Breathtaking. Two oceans coming together, wind like hell, rough sea. We loved it. We saw the monkeys (yeees, no monkeys, other name, I forgot) as well.

Nature at it's best. A wondeful experience to see nature and experience the Cape of Good Hope. The most South Westerly piece of land in Africa. Cape Point - when it is storming spare athought for the poor early sailors. Maybe you will see Zebra, Ostriches, Baboons and some of the other animals.

Spectacular!. I went here as part of a tour. Very spectacular but overly chatty guide. After a long, wonderful day, did not care about the prince who was murdered with thorns from a bush in the 1700s! But don't miss this! I'll go back on my own next visit!

Beautiful. Try and get there early to avoid the massive crowds. If you go on a cloudy day you won't see much. Take the Keeper's trail if you are physically able to do so....almost no one does and it's lovely. There's a postbox outside the restaurant if you want to mail your postcards. If you're coming to Cape Town you really have to do this.

Spectacular !. I was stunned by the beauty of this area. WE were on an organized bus tour but the ride in was amazing. WE saw a troop of baboons and several species of antelope as well as 2 puff adders on the road. The scenery is just stunning and the feeling of being at the Cape Of Good Hope will stay with me for a long time. Fantastic day out.

Breathtaking. This is a must see. Quite simply it takes your breath away. Standing on the shore watching the waves crashing in reminds you of the power of nature and reminds you of what a tiny speck in the universe you really are! Beautiful.
Worth the drive there. All the way to the southern tip is a great drive and you get to see the wide expanse of ocean and really wild weather at times. Is a long way, but worth it
Stunning view!. Great view from the Lighthouse. It was worth it after spending about 1,5 hour drive from Cape Town. Entrance fee is expensive (though everything is expensive for a traveler nowdays)
Amazing. Beautiful and amazing view a bit of a walk but worth every step - careful or you will get pooped on by a baboon.

at the tip of africa. Long ride to get there, but worth it. Long hike to the top, and decided not to take the train. I think it is great for people that could not make the hike, but would recommend the 10min hike to the top. Beautiful view. Watch out for the baboon's, we saw them stealing food out or tourists hands, and then trashing cars that windows were open. Without the baboon's scaring my 3 children we would have given it a 5. But hey that is nature. Worth the drive.
Hit & miss . The coast is stunning....if you can see it. It was exceedingly foggy and I couldn't see three feet in front of me.Time it right, otherwise you'll just see quite a nice area of grassland
