You need time to do this. It is a long drive to Cape Point Nature Reserve, but well worth it. Nice walks and trails, three shops to choose from and a restaurant. Good venue for a family.
awesome. Great place to go and see and a lovely walking experience. Well organised , tidy and lots of information. Worth the visit.
Iconic South Africa. Breadth the cool & purest air from the Atlantic seaboard into your face and enjoy one of the oldest and most diverse biosphere ...

Worth the drive. When visiting Cape Town seeing Cape Point is a must. Stunning scenery along the way past Boulders Beach to Cape Point where you can walk to Cape of good hope and the point itself near the lighthouse. Even spotted a pair of ostriches looking their heads out of the bushes.

Great day trip. This is a must for a day trip out of Capetown. Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope are set within a large nature reserve. The views are stupendous and it is great area for walking, climbing or chilling. You can really feel yourself at the end of the continent.

A must see. I rented a car for two days and went driving around the reserve, highly recommended and very easy to do, definitely one of the best trips I did on my own whilst travelling through South Africa. Beautiful beaches and wildlife too!

Skip it if it's Not a Clear Day. I was disappointed that we got to the top and could see nothing below us because the fog was that thick. It would have made for excellent photos if we could see clearly. Regardless, we took the car out to the beach area and was able to see baboons, emus, and ostriches walking around so that was the plus of coming on a gloomy day.

Felt I had to visit, but it blew me away.. This was on the list of things I needed to do in Cape Town, and I went almost with a sense of obligation. The experience was amazing. The drive is beautiful. We saw multiple wild ostrich and a large besbok. The point itself is breathtaking. I have never seen such a violent sea. Well worth the drive down and the minimal cost.

Hike, picnic, savour the views ... and the sushi. Cape Point is a spectacular spot to visit - within an hour of Cape Town and just the drive, above the Atlantic Ocean, getting to the national park is sublime. Then there's the animals, the beaches, the hikes and the sushi! Take a bicycle to experience the park at its best

Beautiful but expensive for no reason. My friends and I wanted to see Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope but we did not want to rent a car on our last full day in Cape Town so we decided to über from the city center. Well, when we got to the entrance, we were told that we also had to pay for our uber driver to enter because the Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope were were a good 20 minute drive from the entrance. We paid and drove into the park. The park was beautiful and had excellent views. Could have easily spent a day there and in Simon's Town. We were short on time but it would have been a very nice hike. Instead, we took the Flying Dutchman Funicular (which is absolutely nothing to write hope about).

Stunning scenery!. Driving through Cape Point Nature reserve you realize just how beautiful this part of South Africa is. The funicular ride up to the light house is a treat. Do not go to the restaurant unless you want to pay exorbitant prices!
A long drive from Cape Town but the view is worth it!. This a quite a drive from Cape Town and would cost a lot in a taxi, however the views were phenomenal.

Make the effort to visit when in Cape Town!. The spectacular views are well worth the drive from Cape Town. Definitely recommend making the effort to jump on a half day tour to take in this beautiful spot, or drive yourself if you like. This mythical place where two oceans meet should be on your must do list when visiting the Western Cape!
Day Trip. Great tour if it is a sunny day. The views of the ocean and mountains are spectacular. the views from the lighthouse are terrific. The penguin colony was also a fun experience.

So so . A beautiful place to visit. Long drive from Cape Town. Be wary of the fee though. R125 PP. once you are there the views make you forget about the entrance fees. Budget a few hours to thoroughly enjoy
Can't say enough about this beautiful place. I absolutely love the Nature Reserve, and the drive there from Capetown is amazing. We do this every time we are in the area.
Cape Point is on point!. It was quite expensive to go in and there were a lot of tourists, but it was a great walk with astonishing views! It was absolutely breathtaking!
A stormy day visit. Wonderful even in 60-70 mph winds! The ocean is magnificent and we enjoyed the climb to the light house.

Excellent!. I highly recommend a trip up to the top at Cape Point. there is a cablecar/"train" from the parking area, but If you can you should walk up as it is well worth it and not so steep. Can be a bit misty, but wait for it - it is soon over :) many baboons on the way, but they will not do bother you if you don't bother them. Do not bring food as they are attracted by the possibility of something to eat.

Cape Point Experience. we live close to Cape Point (in Fish Hoek) and often take our Guests to Cape Point. It is so beautiful, scenic, spectacular views, well managed and an altogether wonderful outing.

A day well spent!. It's neither the southernmost tip of the African continent (that would be Cape Agulhas), neither is it the most spectacular place on the planet, but a visit here will leave a pleasant warmth in your heart for the rest of your life. The drive from the gate to the various lookout points and walks is serene and the fynbos (local shrubbery) is pleasing to the eye. You may encounter ostriches, buck or tortoises along the road. Certainly you will see baboons! Beware, they are cheeky and they are opportunists stealing anything and everything that they can get at!There is a bus and cable car which will take you approximately halfway to the summit - where you can see the lighthouse and feel like you are soaring with the birds. Fancy a snack or an extensive meal with great beer and wines or beverages for the kids? The restaurant here serves everything - from breakfast to wonderful lunches... at tourist prices, of course!
meeting of the waters. wear warm clothes, its cold up here, stunning views, great for photos, its where the two oceans meet,
great views. this is a great place to reach when you visit Cape point and the place is always fully utilized, as this is the most attraction in cape town
Really great drive to Cape Point. Stop off in Simons Town - good restaurants, check out the dog statue. Further on see the penguine colony.

Beautiful Cape Town. Quite a drive to the tip of the peninsula but well worth it. Restaurants up top and lighthouse to visit, maybe you see a troop of baboons enroute, also don't forget about the point that shows you where the 2 Oceans meet just below the lighthouse, the Indian and Atlantic, enjoy!

One of my highlights!. All I can say, is wow. Being at Cape Point where the two oceans meet was incredible! Seeing the straight line of white wash where the two oceans brush up against each other is amazing. It can get quite windy so pack a jacket or windbreaker. But the coastal walk is absolute bliss.
Absolutely stunning place to visit. Stunning views well worth the drive. Did not see any animals in the reserve but Cape Point was worth the drive.

Beautifully executed for touists. What an incredible place. A good 1.5 hr drive from CT, but well worth it.an enormous nat'l park, full of flower and shrubs that are very distinct. So much rock! Lots of walks and hikes, cost $ 250 R / adult. Make sure you also visit the cape of good hope for a pic! We saw lots of baboons, took the funicular( short train ride-$ 50 R/ adult) up to the lighthouse. From the top- you still have to climb a few stairs. Not for handicapped or very elderly. An enjoyable trip on a good day. You can see for miles. Not to be missed. Go early before the bus tours arrive!

Amazing!!!!. It is so surreal to think you are at the tip of the African continent. We loved this experience. Tours can be a little pricey so make sure you search around. We used African Eagle day tours. Our guide was chatty but very annoying to listen to on the bus.
Spend the day. A massive area with beautiful beach areas in addition to the lighthouse. Lots of great walking paths. We went in off season and had the place to ourselves. Plenty of wildlife also.
A must do. A full au trip which included various stops but well worth it.We took the fenicular up and walked down, stopping to admire the stunning views.

Amazing Day Trip. You must go to Cape Point, it is amazing. The scenery is breath taking and you get the most amazing views from the top, you must do the walk to the lighthouse also, that is the most beautiful part.For lunch there is an amazing restaurant there, Two Oceans that serves really good sea food and offers great view of the ocean. I loved this trip and next time i might try also the hiking paths.

we visited Cape Point nature reserve and did the Shipwreck walk on the beach. The Shipwreck Walk in Cape Point nature reserve is fascinating and scenically beautiful. One enters the Reserve at the main gate and then follows the road to Olifantsbos and take the trail marked "Thomas Tucker Shipwreck Trail".. It is a pristine, totally unspoilt beach where one can walk and see remains of shipwrecks as well as a huge Whale's vertebra lying on the beach. There is also the opportunity to see some wonderful birdlife en route, including the rare Oystercatchers and herons. You may also spot some Bontebok in the fynbos area. ,

Breathless views everywhere!. The trip to this nature reserve must not be missed. It leaves me.in awe as i see a very different type of vegetation, i nver imagined succulents with such tiny leaves and yet with colorful flowers no matter how small. The babboons were interesting they seemed.more.intelligent than men! It was great to have spoted an eland and the ostriches by the ocean were splendid! Having studied biogeography in college many years ago i wished i was able to visit this place sooner so i could.have applied my lessons on the different ecosystems. Definitely Cape Point's flora and fauna are unique! The view of the sea and the landscape left me.breathless!

A must see in Cape Town. One of my favourite day trips in Cape Town. Remember to go early. The Cape Point Nature Reserve offers an amazing view from the lighthouse towards the wild Southern Ocean and back towards the north.If you have time explore the park and it's beautiful secluded beaches and antelopes.Important tip: When you stop at the lighthouse reception area do not walk around with food as baboons from time to time might take it. There is a convenient cable car to the top or you can walk and enjoy the views even more.
Very expensive to enter. The entry fee is way over the benefit of the reserve itself.The only other reason to visit the area is to go to the point and visit the lighthouse.
Gorgeous views!. During our tour of the Cape Town region, we toured Cape Point Nature Reserve. Beautiful views! My favorite part was seeing wild Ostriches near the beach!

Stunning. When in SA, we hired a car and drove to Cape Point (make sure you know the opening times as we were almost caught out!). The drive was enjoyable as the views are stunning in that region. Lots of nature to be seen. Plenty of places for great photos and stunning views. Even the baboons trying to break into cars added to the experience.

Epically beautiful. The Nature Reserve is beautiful beyond words. Awesome views. Great outdoors for cycling enthusiasts and hikers - the serious and the novice. The walk to the lighthouse can be a bit trying for the unfit and I would recommend they take the venicular and then walk down if you want to enjoy the scenery. Don't feed the baboons. The restaurant does get rather busy during peak tourist season, so be sure to take some snacks if you have not make a booking.
Spectacular views!. Little bit of a drive from Cape Town but once you get there and look out upon the crystal blue ocean it makes it all worth while. Make sure your camera is ready to go.

Cape point and the Cape of Good hope.. About an hours drive from Capetown,most of the Cape reserve is fairly barren.We did see some baboons and ostriches en route though. Cape point lighthouse involves a funicular ride,very windy at the top! Try walking down though!
Cape point experience. It is an excellent place to visit if in cape town. The scenary in very pretty and a must to do at least once.

Epic Scenery . Cape Point must rate as one of the most beautiful scenic areas in the country. We have the privelege of living close to this nature reserve. The reserve boasts some of the most scenic beaches. Fynbos to delight any botanist. This is a must see for local and international tourists.

Get off the beaten ... road!. Definitely a must-see (for visitors and locals) but try to get off the quick main road to the point/furnicular. Off the sides are roads to beautiful coves and little beaches, chances to see the wildlife other than baboons (e.g. ostriches, bontebok, zebra, hartebees, ...) and wonderful hiking trails. Oh and the restaurant offers really good food and service.

Overwhelming. To the lighthouse, an easy drive on the peninsula roads, in one of the natural wonders of the World. Quiet bays for watching the South Atlantic rollers wash in. Keeping the windows shut while the troop of baboons wanders past, in their own sweet time, thank you very much! Watch it! though - They are quick and greedy and strong and seem to like windscreen wipers. The fynbos stretches over the rocks, the sun glints off the sea and we are in a different world. The complex round the lighthouse has a lot of parking - tip the parking guards a few Rand - but avoid busy weekends when the rest of South Africa wants to visit. Take your time up the steep steps to the lighthouse itself. The facilties are OK. I could have stayed there all day and all night. But don't - always remember: TIA.

Where the ocean currents meet. Being a lover of oceans & sailing, this was a must visit for me. Good view, but nothing spectacular. Baboons a real nuisance, they steal cameras, handbags, food, drinks - be warned

Watch out for the baboons!. I must say, the baboons made the trip. It is too bad that so many people ignore the instructions and give them food. It is probably only a matter of time until someone gets bitten if it hasn't happened already (and it won't be the fault of the animals,but the stupid humans!) The day we were there it was VERY windy but it didn't hurt the spectacular views! Well worth the drive from Cape Town but leave early in the day as I understand it gets VERY busy as the day goes on...(it was already quite busy when we were there and it was 1030AM!)
Beautiful View!. Amazing view point, It's must do if you are in cape Town! Amazing place to do some hiking. Go and try!
Lands end. Far from Cape Town but worth the trip. This is where two oceans meet. Ride the train up and hike the way down. Restaurant was crowded. Must see when in Cape Town.
loved this place. from the moment you arrive, there is so much to see and do, from woodland walks to ocean views, to fine food, time passes to quickly.

Stunning vistas, refreshing weather. This is a definitive most do on your list when visiting Cape Town and surroundings. Its an easy drive with rewarding scenery and views all along the way and the icing on the cake is the cape point and lighthouse. I can highly recommend this part of the cape peninsula.

Breathtaking views of the "bottom" of Africa. An easy drive from Cape Town to visit the Cape of Good Hope and see the southern most point of the African Continent. One can only imagine what the early explorers experienced as the rounded this point.
Beautiful scenery - must do!. The entire Cape Peninsula is beautiful, and worth exploring. The drive has gorgeous views, and you'll see many types of flora and fauna.

Always a worthwhile day out. We always enjoy a day out at Cape Point when we visit Cape Town. Whichever route you take to get there, the scenery is stunning (although there are extensive roadworks on the road via Fish Hoek which delayed us quite a bit, and I suspect these will be in place for some time). Inside the nature reserve itself there is usually plenty of wildlife and fynbos to see, in addition to enjoying further spectacular views of the Cape coast. We highly recommend the reserve's restaurant for lunch: it offers very good value indeed, particularly the seafood platter (although we thought the portions were slightly less than when we last visited, for the same price).

Definitely worth a visit when in Cape Town. Really good day trip from Cape Town. It was a bit tricky to park when we arrived at Cape Point and we had to queue to get into the national park but otherwise a very nice place to visit. Quite busy though.

Must see when you visit Cape town. When you visit Cape Town you have to visit Cape Point Nature Reserve. After a scenic drive from Cape Town you enter the Reserve Park. There is wildlife in the park, beware of baboons, but also austriches en antelopes. The scenery of the coast is really beautiful. Visit Cape of Good Hope the most south west point of the African continent and Cape point with the lighthouse and stunning views.
A must while in Cale Town. Great scenery for driving or biking. Good tourism infrastructure and services. Easy to navigate through park with map given at entrance. Astonishing views.

Do visit the lighthouse. There is a funicular that takes you up to within a few(?) short steps up and back to this old lighthouse, for just ZAR 58.per person. when we visited it was very very windy with a number of hats disappearing off into the wind. Again the views are spectacular

Must visit. This place is amazing in so many ways, historically but also the views. Walk down to the beach, walk up to the top - take time, take in the views. Don't park your car take a pic and leave - that's just sad in such a lovely place.

Who won't go to Cape Point if there's in CT? . I already went there three times as I love Cape Point. Each time I've seen ostriches and baboons. Once seen elands and other time I saw bonteboks. My favorite is walking from cape of good hope to all the way to where the restraunts are. Sunblock and hat are something you must bring and often windy so better prepare warm clothes. I went there in March and April 2016 there's a road work which can cause delays.

Must See. Any trip to Cape Town should include a visit to Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope. As the southern tip of Africa, its historic and beautiful. Wonderful photo ops. And your visit will include a vigorous walk which is appreciated after the 2 hr drive.There's a restaurant with great views and average food. We passed on this option and went to Simons Town for lunch. Better food, better view. For those needing help up, a funicular can help you for about 50 Rand one way.Most walk up to the Cape Point lighthouse. Don't miss the extension to the old lighthouse. It's only 15 minutes more even though the sign says 1.5 hrs.There's a separate trail to the point of Good Hope. The sign also says 1.5 hrs. We thought it was nearly as good, if not better than visiting Table Mountain.

good for history, wildlife, beach, picnic; go early if a holiday. Cape Point is one of my favorite places in Cape town. As a nature reserve it is hard to beat, you can see hills, beaches, and all sorts of vegetation. There are plenty of places to picnic, places to surf and places to swim. The main visitor center is terrific to learn about the history connected with this area and walk on the trails to the lighthouse, etc. There is a smaller visitor center closer to the entrance, which is often less crowded. One can learn a lot there as well. Go early if you are there during a holiday - the line to get through the entrance can be as long as an hour during peak times and peak holiday season.

A must from Cape Town. If you're in Cape Town for more than a few days, its definitely worth spending one of those visiting Cape Point. You can go via a tour company or drive it yourself. After doing a few tours during our week we decided to drive it ourself and it was easy. Car hire for the day was £25 inc. fuel and it was an awesome scenic drive from the city along the coast down to the point. There is a small entry fee to enter and a long drive through the reserve to reach the point.We ate when we arrived at the restaurant (great views) before heading up to the lighthouse to take a few snaps. Be warned the winds are strong enough to blow away small children and annoying wives. The baboons are great to see wandering around and aren't shy of people - just don't feed them and you'll be fine. There's little vehicular train which can take you to the top of the point if you are tired of waking up steps.Definitely worth a day of your time and even more if you plan exploring the beached and the cape of good hope. On the way back we drove via boulders beach and saw the penguins.

Natural beauty!. No trip to Cape Town is complete without a visit to Cape Point. We visited Cape Point as part of a full day out, starting in Cape Town, and arrived here around lunch time. We drove in a rental car, which I highly recommend as there are a lot of great, smaller beaches within the nature reserve to visit. If you're up for it, you can hike up the trails to many view sites. This is of course at your own risk, but totally worth it for the views. I managed fine in a pair on Converse, but it was a dry day, although quite windy. The landscape is rock and wind and water beaten, and there are magnificent views of the ocean. It's a great reminder of the power and beauty of nature!
a breathtaking place. beautiful views after a little walk to the light-house. there's also a shuttle for the those who can't do the walk. a must do in the area of Capetown!

The volume of visitors is expertly managed once inside the Reserve.. From the stunning vistas where one almost sees the Flying Dutchman in the sea mist to the busy fast food restaurant at the point, the visitor experiences South Africa at its best. The staff and facilities are world beating and the setting is perhaps the finest on Earth. However the entrance gate experience can be somewhat soured by the occasional hold-up due to staff being unable to process difficult clients in a professional (fast) manner.
Great place to visit. Make sure you add Cape Point to your trip when visiting Cape Town, well worth the trip. A lovely part of the world

Magnificent!!!. This is a must do trip. The views are with clear weather beautiful and awesome. The place has a great history. You need some endurance for the walk to the light house, but you get a nice reward when you are up. Also Cape of Good Hope is nice and especially through the stories of history. It also has a nice walking trail. Also visit the memorial of Vasco da Gama. Be aware that this NP is very touristic and crowdy, but nevertheless really worth it.

Ocean power.. We drove to Cape Point, paid our entrance fee and completed a form with our details and car registration. Its several miles drive to the point and Cape of Good Hope and were had to queue for quite a while as there were essential road repairs on a 4 way junction, but this didn't matter as it gave us chance to admire the scenery and the baboons. We luckily managed to park near the visitors centre, otherwise it would have been a long walk. The fenicular was not working so for a small fee we were taken up in a minibus. The view from the lighthouse show just how powerful the oceans are, tremendous waves breaking onto rugged rocks and how the lighthouse was so important. There is a restaurant there but we only wanted a snack so gave it a miss. On exiting the park we had to hand in the copy of the form we had completed on entry, this is to ensure no one is lost in the park at night as it's such a huge place and there in not much mobile signal so if you have broken down etc they know that you haven't left the park and can go looking for you. Well worth the entrance fee.

Pleasantly surprised!. We arrived early so as to avoid the crowds of tourists that arrive by bus. A quick trip with the "Flying Dutchman" to the top and then just a few steps to the light house. Wonderful views all round!

Stupendous views and a great walk up. This is one of the 'must do' trips in life. The drive along the coast to get to the reserve is so captivating. Don't take the train to the top as it's a big cheat. Toil to the top - for any half fit person, it's no more than 15 mins of huffing & puffing. When you get to the summit, you will literally be 'blown away' with the views and strong winds. The cliffs and beach views to one side you'll just want to drink them in all day. The views to Hermanus on the other side are glorious depending on the visibility that day. We went towards the end of the afternoon when the crowds were gone so it was that much more solitary and enjoyable. Wow!

Next Stop Antarctica!. We left Cape Town at 9am to get to the Point early, which we were grateful for as we beat the Coach parties there and had a parking spot near to the lighthouse. When we left the queues were a good 20 minute wait to get in.I would park at Cape Point and then do the 45 minute walk to Cape of Good Hope after going up to the lighthouse. The path is part boardwalk and part cobbles and well maintained. If you are fit there is a gorgeous beach between the two points, but access is via a very steep set of steps (over 100).

Definitely worth a visit . To visit Cape Point/Cape of Good Hope (Note: this is not quite the most southerly point of Africa) you should allow at least a half day. There is a very pleasant drive down to the Cape Point Park and once you are through the ticket/entrance gate a very large area to explore and some wonderful scenery, not least at the Cape itself.We would suggest that you arrive early; we arrived shortly after noon and there was already a long queue of cars (at least a 45 minute wait) waiting to get through the small entrance barrier. Be prepared for some walking (take good walking shoes) as you will be going up and down some fairly steep paths if you want to get the best views of the Cape of Good Hope. You should probably bring an extra layer of clothing as it can get quite windy.At the time of our visit (March 2016) there were roadworks within the park which meant some stop-go traffic delays.

Absolutely a high point of any visit to this part of the world. The views of and from this historically significant location are magnificent. We were lucky to have had an early start and we saw all with great, clear skies. It didn't take long for that to change. Lots of cars were arriving as we were leaving and I couldn't help be feel sorry for them as the weather had closed in. Perhaps that changed after a while.

Sunning views and beaches. Fantastic views and beaches and great for wildlife as well. Can easily spend a whole day there. If you drive from Cape Town, take the Chapmans Drive along the coast, it is worth the toll it costs to drive there.

Stunning views!. Lovely drive down from Cape Town, easy to find a car parking space. Got the funicular railway up to almost the top then climbed up the steps to the Lighthouse. We were rewarded with the most stunning, beautiful views. Well worth a visit but do not forget your camera!
Beautiful and scenic....... We spent a couple of hours walking around and enjoyed the penguins and their habitat. Very scenic and well laid out pathways.

Amazing natural beauty. I booked a day trip to tour the Cape Peninsula and this was included in that tour. What a great way to observe the natural beauty of the country and get a lot of great photo opportunities. This is a must if you are in Capetown!

Worth seeing. If you got a car go in early on a nice day. Wind is really bad here so if it's clear but windy take a wind breaker. It's worth going early to avoid bus tours and the hustle and bustle. There is a venicular available. The view is breathtaking but other than that not much there apart from indigenous flora.

THE MOST BEAUTIFUL CAPE IN THE WHOLE WORLD. As Sir Francis Drake said it is the most beautiful Cape in the whole circumference of the world. The tip of the Cape Peninsula is very special with stunning scenery and our own unique flora called "fynbos". down the Peninsula. There are more species (2500) of plants than in the whole of the UK (less than 1500). Ride the funicular (there is a charge) to the Old Lighthouse on top of the hill or sit down for a scrumptious meal. Hike around the area or just sit and watch the waves crash over Bellows Rock. Cape Point in the Cape of Good Hope Reserve is a must when visiting Cape Town - a very mystical place with lots of sea-faring history, flora and a few animals such as Ostrich, Bontebok and Babboons.

A must do day out! . We always include Cape point in a trip to Cape Town.If driving in from town a good circular route is out of town on the M3 then though Kalk bay/Simonstown, then return via Scarborough , makes for a stunning circuit. Take a picnic, try Buffels bay, but watch for baboons. Many people blast straight to the funicular , but would recommend taking some of the other side roads too. There are many walks, most circular, but our favourite is from the funicular car park down to the cape of good hope itself . If you have a non walker in your group a good option is for them to drive round to pick you up. If not it's about 1 hour each way including photo stops. It's also less crowded than the funicular with just as good scenery. Try to allow the whole day if you can. We stop to view the Penguins at Boulders, just past Simonstown on the way in.
Unbeatable. Captured all our imaginations. Beware the 20 minute delay each way for road upgrade. Have lunch at the restaurant, book in advance. The views are staggering.

A wonderful day out. What a beautiful place! The information we were given at the park gates was very useful. The restaurant at the Point was excellent- the best, most imaginative salad I have ever eaten! There is a cable car up to the lighthouse at the top of the point- otherwise it is a very steep path. There are plenty of clean toilets and the obligatory gift shops. Don't stick to the main paths as you drive through the reserve- there are some beautiful bays off the main road, with sort walks and information boards.
Beautiful Scenery! I Love Nature..... Beautiful scenery & nice outing for the entire family. Make sure you have lots of free memory space to take amazing photos.

Spectacular, Unreal Views. We planned this for the last day of our 3-week South African adventure and WOW what a great way to finish our trip and revel in this country's raw and natural beauty. Park on the shoulder of the road and enjoy the walk to the info station, and then get ready to climb stairs! Take plenty of time to explore the many smaller paths and don't forget to get a vanilla ice cream at the food counter for the walk back to your car!

the southwestern most tip of Africa!. This is a beautiful nature reserve! Plan to spend a few hours, and drive back to Cape Town along a different coast (depending upon how you approach the reserve) for new views. The drive is breathtaking! At the reserve, be sure to hike up to the lighthouse. Enjoy the views and the wildlife. We didn't have time to hike down to the beach - next time!! We had a very nice lunch in the restaurant there. Not the sandwich/pizza place but the sit down spot which was surprisingly lovely. Good food and great views!

Beautiful coastal scenery. Loved this area. It's really beautiful! We rented a car for the day from Cape Town and came here. Car rental for the day was 500 rand and it was a great way to do it. The scenery is amazing and it's not far from Cape Town.

The most beautiful corner of the continent. Cape Point is a little bit out of the way but most definitely worth it. When you're there it's hard to believe that there's a massive city just around the corner. It's quite easy to spend the whole day just driving around and taking in the beautiful setting. It's also good for walking or riding if that's your vibe.
well worth a daytrip. Beautiful scenery. Went by private day tour and included a short visit to the Kirstenbosch Gardens . Worth not rushing.

Amazing. This is a must do if you are in Cape Town. When you get to top the views around this area are breathtakingly beautiful. There are lots of trails to explore the area but the highlight for me was the lighthouse and the Cape of Good Hope, where you get a sense of how wild the ocean is.

scenic view. this time we made the trip to cape point. its a bit of a drive from capetown central but its worth the time.scenic views of the oceans, you can take a cable car up to the lighthouse or walk.
Beautiful view. The view at the top is breathtaking. I had a full day outing with an agency and i enjoyed the trip. We walked through the beach to cape point.

One of the most places. A plce for understand the difficulties that our earliest explorer had to cope with to find the passes to another world. A beautifull snd wild place that one have to see and experience. A place you cant miss while you are in south of africa.

Wonderful . I think this place doesn't get the publicity it deserves.
It's very good, refreshing. You need to spend the better time of the day to explore it fully.
If you love nature and pictures, this place is for you
It's some distance from Cape Town, so there is need for proper time management
Cape Point. A must visit place when you are in Cape town. The views are spectacular. I couldn't stop taking videos and pictures

History is here. A must go whether you enjoy History. I read about Cape Point and Cape Good Hope several times on the books. There is a nice restaurant (Two Oceans) for sea food lovers. I suggest to ride the funicular to go on the top, for the old lighthouse, and walk when going down where you can take nice pics of Cape Good Hope. Windy. Bring a good coat.

Great! - but watch out for the baboons. We went there to enjoy the views and have a picnic. It was beautiful and we enjoyed ourselves but were interrupted by a very large baboon who stole our packet of chips. The rest of the troupe followed and started to try and steal food from other picnickers that were trying to braai. Needless to say we ate our lunch locked in the car. The rest of the day was spent enjoying the views outside though.

Gets busier all the time. This year we decided to include some of the side roads in our visit as so many buses at the Point and Cape of Good Hope. We were rewarded with ostriches sitting on their eggs by side of road. Most tourists missed this
Stunning. Amazing views and scenery. Not to be missed on a visit to Cape Town. See where the two oceans meet. Stunning

Must do. We drove in a rental car. It is an hour and a half drive from Cape Town but Camps Bay, Hout Bay and Chapman's Peak makes for great scenery to take in on the way. You will want to stop and take pictures on the way. Allow a full day if taking in Boulders Beach on the same trip. Great views, very fresh air and a bit of a hike - need to be good on your feet. I saw a number of people struggling with the walk up to the lighthouse. No baboons seen on this visit for us - we had seen them on a previous visit - pot luck.

End of the continent!. We drove down to this attraction one day as part of our stay in Cape Town. We actually took a wrong turning thanks to the sat nav so be aware of that, it put us about an hour back by the time we realised and corrected it. Walking around the park and looking out to the ocean knowing you are as south as you can be in the African continent was awe inspiring for us. The weather wasn't great but still made a great day out

Visit to Cape of Good Hope. We drove to Cape Point, but skipped the actual Cape Point lighthouse etc. and instead took a walk to Cape of Good Hope (or above it). Without knowing, we suspected that it would be a view over a lot of water from the Cape Point, and more to experience by the Cape of Good Hope. Dias' Beach is a powerful experience, with heavy waves thundering in. We saw antelopes, ostriches and other animals both wild and farmed). The views from the pathways are also spectacular. I had to "lean inwards", having a notable high anxiety, but it was not too bad. Most of the way is smooth to slightly rough, but the last part is fairly rough and demands walking in more-or-less natural stairs, with quite high steps. No problems for a normally fit, but not recommendable for those with walking problems.
Nice but very windy. Cape Point was very very windy when we visited so we couldn't enjoy the outside as much as we wanted but you will get some nice views from almost everywhere you are.

Glorious - go early. This site completely exceeded by expectations. Everything is laid out quite nice, but parking can be a pain - definitely get the tickets for the funicular and bring a jacket. It is so magical and should not be missed.

nice vibe, good a hike too. Good view, can be a good opportunity for hikers to climb up from cape cape of good hope to foot of lighthouse, nice hour of walk among breathtaking scenary. beware of baboons

Beautiful views but quite a drive. My advice to get the best out of this visit is to make a full day of it. Hike to the beach or out to the lower lighthouse in Cape Point. Make reservations at the Two Oceans Restaurant etc. it is also best for the kids to incorporate the return journey with a stop at Boulders Beach to play with the local friendly penguin colony. N.B not the most southern point in Africa and not the spot where the Atlantic meets the Indian Ocean. That is at Cape Aghulus. Still romantic in the context of early European sailors.
a whole day out. We went on a Cape Peninsula tour to Cape Point and to obviously the Cape of Good Hope. The scenery is stunning, it is very windy but just wonderful

Worth the trip...especially when you get to the lighthouse . I did this trip on a guided tour and I recommend that you do this. Too much to see, learn and do on your own. The highlight is the trip up to the Cape of Good Hope lighthouse and the phenomenal views from there. On a clear day, you literally can see forever! So this is the bottom of Africa!? Hard to believe. Remember that this area is one of 7 ecologically unique ecosystems so really take a close look at the vegetation. Such diversity and beauty.

Gotta Go. This was an incredible experience. I just had to see where the two oceans met. Cape Point was so beautiful. If you go, visit early in the day. It isn't as crowded. There are many warnings regarding baboons, but I never did.

Don't miss it. Stunning view of the ocean, quite windy and a fun place to take selfies / group photos. One can also walk up - will take you just a few minutes more than the ride. The drive from Cape Town to this place is also marvelous.
visit to the point. another fantastic place to visit when in cape town. did not see any baboons but enjoyed the day. lots of great pictures
just because. the point at which the Indian and the Atlantic oceans meet. Wild and beautiful. Be careful of cheeky unafraid baboons.
God's beauty in your face. You cannot see another great destination like this one. It is majestic and beautiful, long or short walks and a great restaurant to recuperate.

Everyone should visit this reserve. The views and wild life are breathtakingly magnificent. The walks were exciting. The baboons are to be observed with the utmost caution. The Funicular was an awesome experience and the restaurant experience was a delicious trteat with incredibly reasonable prices. The Mussel Potjie served in a Falkirk pot proved to be delicious, plentiful and good value for money.The salads were generous and the linefish came fresh from the sea!Eating while enjoying a spectacular view of False Bay was an experience to be repeated often.
Oh my, what a view. . What an amazing view. The preservation of the light house and the cable car was amazing. I thoroughly enjoyed the hike though.

Where were the animals?. Its my second trip in the last few years and the first time we saw loads of animals but this time very little. Wrong season perhaps? The views are magnificent and we too a chance going on a day that started a little misty but it cleared thank goodness. The organisation is good and the place well kept and tidy. If the animals are out then it is a great day's visit.
Must See. For history and nature lovers, Cape Point is a must. The drive from Cape Town is scenic. The views from the cliffs are gorgeous. The air really cleans out your lungs.

Afternoon trip. Line was long to get in but only took 30 minutes to clear the gate. Once in we enjoyed the hikes and trails to the top and new light house. Didn't make it down to the lower cliff as we stopped for food at the two oceans cafe.

Stunning views! . Hi allCape point is amazing Having stunning views , great history , outdoor walking , great with family Tips:Check weather if cloudy avoid itIt's little bit windy Long drive to reach Probably you can spend there 2-3 hours Combo this park with Simons town / seal island CheersT!
Beautiful. Me and my wife visited this place, it was beautiful, we enjoyed our walk to reach the top, cool weather.

Nature. Long drive through the park to reach the point parking area. At the car park there is a fairly steep walk to the point. It's not rushed and there was a variety of age groups walking up. On top you are met with stunning views across the bay .Shop and restaurant facility available at car park are.
Amazing views. We walked to the Cape of Good Hope. It is an easy walk, with steps and boardwalk sections. The sign says it is a 1 1/2 Hour round trip but it took us about 45 minutes.

Go early to get full experience. We visited Cape Point after 26 years. Wow it has transformed into an amazing tourist site. Go early enough - arrive before 14:00 to have enough time to walk down to beach on south western end of main light house. There are two lighthouses. The one at the bottom is a 30 min return walk from the tip tower. Don't use the Funacolor (tram) walk up and down. The regular stop points each has its own magical view. The pathway to second light house at far end (most southern lookout) is on west side behind the ticket office/shop at the top. Called the lighthouse route. DON't take all the effort to the top and not go there. It is clean, easy path ways and spectacular views. The restaurant is on the pricy side.

Go!. The breathtaking view from Cape Point is well worth the trip. There are several points where you can catch your breath while ascending. If you prefer, you can take the funicular. You won't be sorry going to this beautiful spot!

Beautiful view!. Must do. Incredible view of the 2 oceans.
Get there early it gets crowded.
It is always windy. You can walk the stairs or not to get to the top.

Mind blowing . This was absolutely epic!!!! Sadly we were just cramming it in to the end of our day so we only had 2 hours from entering the park to leaving - it's 20 mins drive each way to the main "Cape Point" so we didn't get to go on the funicular or do the cape point drive along the beach and the shop and cafe was closed. You need a whole day really to enjoy it the most. It was immensely windy - which was a really scary experience - we had to hang onto the walls and railing when climbing up to the lighthouse and then when by the light house I was afraid to stand up - the wind was sooooo strong - the view was amazing - I will definitely return. Saw the baboons in the road - generally causing havoc but great to see them and an amazing sunset - a must see if you're in Cape Town - scary driving to the park itself - lots of road close to the edge which normally is fine but in a tiny hire car when it was that windy it was worrying it might actually get blown away... When we stopped it was shaking... Go on a sunny - wind free day!
Anther must when in Cape Town. The nature reserve with ist wonderful rocks and beaches should not be missed when in Cape Town. Not advisable on windy days however.

A Must See. This is where the Atlantic and the Indian Ocean Meet. You can actually see the divide which makes it that more interesting. Go on a warm day. It is about 45mins from Capetown. We hired a driver arranged by the hotel (we spent about 8hrs sightseeing with him that day and is was only $150 us in a brand new Audi!) We were hesitant to eat at the restaurant at the reserve (as we don't like touristy restaurants) but, glad we did as the food was excellent, the service was good and it had a beautiful view. There is a small sandwich take out shop there as well and you can sit at outside tables and eat if you prefer something more casual. From there, where the penguins are located is about a 15min drive so, I would plan to do that in the same day. Oh, and as a bonus, enroute there, we saw lots of wild baboons on the side of the road!

But of course. How can you not visit the Cape when in Capetown? Within a national park there is the drive thru the bushland and the Cable car to the peak and the markpoint at the bottom on the beach. Excellent lunch in the peak restaurant. Go.

Peace close to city centre. Nature at its best. Beautiful fynbos along the tarred roads. There is the lighthouse at Cape point with a steep walk and steps or you could use the shuttle. Cape of Good Hope (the most south-western point in Africa) and various little bays. Make sure to visit Diaz and Da Gama's crosses. Wonderfull views and vistas.

A good activity for nature lovers. We drove to Cape Point via the Penguins at Boulders beach - this made the long ride worthwhile. The walk up to the light house was too much for small kids, but riding up in the funicular was fun. There is still a bit of a walk to the lighthouse, but the view is worth it. At the base is a nice looking restaurant. However, since we have small kids we ate at the take out cafeteria. The food was surprisingly good.

Trip to the end of the world. Stunning, Hire a car, and just go there. The views of False Bay are breath taking, then climb up to the lighthouse at Cape Point and walk down the cliff path to the very end of Africa, there are not many places in the world one can stand between three great oceans.
Amazing!. Its a memory which I will treasure forever. Climbing wasn't easy but the views were stunning. You see nature, animals, fantastic beach and the amazing beauty of both of the oceans.

Amazing trip. We left early from the house rentals and drove around the coast like almost 1 hr 45 minutes , the view remind me to the Pacific Coast Highway, gorgeous and dangerous, but it was worthy, You need to be slightly in shape to get to the Lighthouse, but you need to do it ,so u can see the natural beauty .

A must-do. If you have time, do take the drive to CP nature reserve. It costs R125 per adult and this doesn't include the trolley to take you up. You can walk up to the lighthouse. It's a steep climb, well-paved, with steps along the way. If you have any mobility issues, take the funicular instead. Of course, you get a chance to stop and take photos if you're walking; you'll want to get photos along the way up. Some in out group stopped at the curio shop below the lighthouse; others walked the entire path to the lighthouse. There is a restroom at the curio shops at the base of the mountain and mid-way up. I noticed a few benches along the way, nice to catch a breath. It can be quite windy so layer up accordingly. Also, this isn't the place for cutesy sandals and heels; those ladies looked quite uncomfortable. There is parking and, I think, room for buses. A magnificent view awaits!
Land's end. Beautiful and scenic route all the way to the Point. Spectacular. Mostly windy, but not to be missed! Easy access, well maintained facilities.
Most beautiful coastline I've ever seen. Rocks and sand and water in the Southern Hemisphere is one of those must-see! Take your photo at a marker indicating the latitude and longitude

mystical even if its cloudy/rainy. Watch out for the baboons!. Pros: - it looks like a VERY beautiful place to go when its sunny. even with the mist it was very beautiful in its own way - they just had painted the lighthouse which was cool to check out! - we did the trail to the point and we could watch the boats out in the ocean. some great places to see the lifts - if you get a chance make sure you check out Dias beach! Cons: - watch out for the end of the day around 6:30 pm when the baboons come out to eat trash. its fun to watch them initially but if you are a woman they will come and smack you backpack !

The South-Western Tip of Africa. There are 2 main attractions here, the Cape of Good Hope and Cape Point, both part of the Peninsula. The Cape of Good Hope is marked by a signpost in both Afrikaans and English with latitude and longitude, at beach level. There is parking and it is very exposed with very windy conditions at times, very much a camera opportunity. Cape Point is reached by a funicular and is at a high level with great views around the area. There is a souvenir shop plus the Two Oceans Restaurant as well as parking around the base of the funicular. Well worth a visit in good weather.
Views. Stunning scenery ... Plenty of wildlife.... Be aware of the baboons. When strolling around......also take the cable car to the tip ........ Wow

Stunner. One of the most pleasing and fascinating sites of the world.with the false bay and the atlantic ocean merging and the feeling of standing on the terminl point on earth,the experiance is breath taking.
Good. We took a full day tour; it was good but i would recommend for a half day as the Kristenbush is better to be done alone.You get to see where the two oceans meets and the tip of Africa.
Beautiful. Enjoyed it. Definitely recommended for hikers. Lovely trails to hike and the most beautiful scenery you can imagine.

Beautiful. When it comes to beauty and nature. .. quite breathtaking! The sea views are incredible. I got a photo of 3 different shades of blue and green of the water. You can state at the ocean forever.Don't go to the restaurant though. VERY EXPENSIVE. LOOOOOOOONG QUES. Unfriendly, harried restaurateurs! Entrance fees is reasonable and surrounding slots are equally as beautiful. I don't go often but I do go regularly - even as a local.

Great when the weather is great. On a nice sunny day the views are spectacular and all the tour operators in a 100 km radius know this. I felt like the only South African among the greater part of the population from the US, but the views made up for it when i could find an open spot.

Get there as early as you can and go straight up to the lighthouse. My second trip here on a tour. First time we were the 3rd vehicle in line, this time we went in the afternoon and waited in a queue of traffic to go and and down made worse by stop / go road works. However, while stationary we saw baboons (keep your windows shut!) and ostrich. It's a wonderfully scenic drive, no photo could do it justice. If you can get here early, keep going and get to the top before the crowds, you can then take your time on the way down and appreciate the views and the fynbos. The day we went the funicular wasn't working, those who couldn't walk up could pay to go in a minibus. If you are fit enough do make the effort and climb up to the top of the lighthouse; the views are stunning and look out for the rock hyrax (dassie).

Enjoy the wild nature. Despite the huge number of tourist visiting this place every day you can still enjoy its Wilderness. Great nature, awesome views over 2 oceans: atlantic and indian. The walk to the Lighthouse is not tough but bring water with you as it might be very hot. I recommend to visit Cape of Good Hope and Cape Point in the morning as there are far less tourists

Tourist hotspot. A place you must visit if you are in the region. The park is quite beautiful but no more so than the coastal road to get there. Lots of car parking along the road and who knows how bad it gets at peak times. hardly any seating for the shop selling sandwiches and pizza slices - no more than 10 tables. Restaurant looks good but very busy and like all tourist spots, very noisy.Glad we went as the views are very good, but not worth visiting a second time. And somebody point out to the visitors that this is NOT the most southerly point in Africa !

A "WOW" experience- a must do in South Africa. Pictures cannot do justice to the beauty and amazing experience of Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope. In all out travels, we found this to be one of the most amazing experiences we done.The views- STUNNING!The wildlife- AMAZING!The scenery- AWESOME!Stop reading this and go. Right now! Rent a car, take the hike up and do this right now!!!

Just WOW!. So worth seeing this place! And to make it even better we took the following route: Cape Town - Clifton - Chapmans Peak (you have to pay a toll but so worth it) - Cape Point (direction Kommetjie) - Boulders Beach - Simon's Town - Noordhoek - Constantia - Cape Town centre. You'll get the scenic route down, and you get to swim with penguins on the way back! We drove through the park without a guide, went to Cape Point Lighthouse first (views are amazing/ make sure we keep warm as the wind is very powerful there), and one the way out stopped at Cape of Good Hope. It was a great day and the scenery is amazing!

Amazing. We go every year and always blown away (literally on a windy day!). There is so much to see and do. Take the funicular up to the top. Then be brave and walk the extra to get to the lighthouse. Amazing. We like having lunch in TwoOceans. It can get very crowded with coach parties but that is par for the course. If you haven't been, you must.
2 oceans! . Wauw what a vieuw! We took a Nice trip against mountains. We Also saw baboons for the first time! With a ranger nearby we stoppen to see animals.

The end of the world. Being in Cape Town, you should definetily go to the Cape Point. You will have the most beautiful ride going by Hout bay. At the Cape Point you feel you are at the end of the world, and it feels good!

Stunning views. Visited on a coach tour. Stopped at Cape Point and saw the seals on the rocks. Then went up to the lighthouse on the vernicular tramway. Lots of steps so not good for the less agile but stunning views. Cafe, souvenirs and toilets available.

Edge of the earth. The funicular up the point is awesome called the flying Dutchman named after the Dutch ship the survived the windy shores of cape point impressive museum up there wit the walk up to the light house wit an even more better view

Unparalleled natural beauty. About an hour's drive from City Bowl, the Cape Point Nature Reserve offers unrivaled natural beauty and tranquility. Walk up towards the lighthouse on a sunny day to experience a quintessential Cape Town experience.

Cape Point tour. Fantastic view after a long winding road journey. However its worth the fatigue as we got to see ostrich, deer and babboons along the way. In Feb the weather was cooling and breezy. There was also a 1 hr walking path down to Cape of Good Hope, which is the southern most tip of the African continent. Biew down to the sttep cliff ends at the foothill and widenes further into the meeting point of the Atlantic Ocean and Indian Ocean.

Amazing views and beautiful scenery!. Very beautiful natural park and once you get to the Cape Point the views are breath-taking! For those that don't walk too much or arent as fit, I would recommend to take the tram to the top (what I should have done!) but walking allows you to stop to take some photos of scenery from different angles and views. PS. Watch out for Baboons!

Be careful with the baboons !. Amazing place ! You can have nice shots, Stunning views and a lot of history. Just be careful with the baboons. They're looking for food all the time and they attacked a couple behind us while taking pictures.

South-western most point of Africa. Well worth the trip, it gets busy so go early and start at the point and work your way back up the smaller viewpoints. Likewise for the restaurant, take your own picnic or head to the Cape Farmhouse or on to Simonstown for lunch after your visit.

A Scenic Beauty. The wild windswept beauty of this reserve makes for a very scenic car trip. The rugged landscape stretches for miles and then when you reach the end you can take a funicular up to the top and gaze around the crashing seas from the lighthouse. This is where the two oceans meet. There is a lovely little gift shop up there which a great place to shelter from the howling wind and the merchandise is good too.

Stacking rock displays along the shore and plenty of seals. This was a very nice place to stop. Construction could cause traffic delays, but still worth the wait. Numerous piles of stacked rocks adorned the shore. Nearby seals made for some photo opportunities if you had zoom capability.

Stunning scenery. Spend a whole day to do this trip preferably by hiring your own car. Worth driving there via Chapmans Peak Drive which is spectacular, stopping at Simons Town on the way, seeing the penguins at Boulders Bay and then allowing plenty of time to explore all the tracks in the reserve. The light house area has amazing views and then down at seal level the waves are wonderful to watch crashing ashore. Also explore the little bays such as Buffels Bay. Quiet when we went and great for a walk on the sands. A great day out from the city

Hot, windy, awesome, breathtakingly beautiful summer fun. This visit was both fun and work. I was accompanying my visiting colleague from India to the Global Atmospheric Watch Station at Cape Point, while doing sightseeing on our way there. It can be a long drive, depending from which side of the Peninsula you are driving from.It was hot and windy, but with so many tourists around, you soon forget about the weather and take in all of the spectacular views. There was not enough time to enjoy all of the nature around us. There is a lot to see of the Cape Floral Region and local flowers, such as the Protea flower itself. The unspoilt beaches with its clear sand, allows for hours of brute sun soaking fun.It gets busy with lots of tourists, so find your spot to chill, undisturbed.Lots of picture moments, so take along your camera, hat, sunscreen, lots of water and a picnic basket. There are plenty of hiking routes, so enquire beforehand to get essential information.This is one of those attractions/places that you visit as many times possible, since you find something new to see on every visit. I will be there again.

A beautiful historic site when the weather is nice. It is a rather long trip but the places you go through are all very interesting. This nature reserve itself has its own stories to tell from the first landing, the army quarters and the shipwrecks, not to mention the legends. The light house and the surrounding buildings are part of a well known monument that has much to tell you. The seas too. You appreciate vastness of space, sea and horizons there.
Holiday visit.. Well worth the drive, great views from the lighthouse. Enjoyed the little train journey, saved some energy on a hot day !

Amazing views. Amazing views, a must do when in Cape Town. If you are not so fit, take the cabin up, but don't take the cabin for view cause it's a very packed and hot cabin and the view is better when walking.

Beach and adventure. Great for the nature enthusiast or even those looking for a more private beach experience. The reserve is huge and lots to explore. The restaurants are very pricey but if you bring a Pick Nick lots of great stops and hikes.

You just need to do this while in Cape Town . This is a must see place in Cape Town. If you have traveled there why not go right to the end of the earth-:). The view is amazing. Something to keep in mind is that it is very windy there, do it is recommended for ladies to pull their hair back.

Windy. Visited the nature reserve, Cape Point lighthouse and Cape of Good Hope. All very worthwhile.Very windy when at the lighthouse to the point of blowing people off their feet. But has to be done.

You've got to go.. If you have come all this way you just have to come to the Cape of Good Hope.Hire a car and drive here through some great scenery. I've been wanting to come here since hearing about in my primary school history lessons. The day we were here the skies were blue the sun was out and the wind was blowing around the Cape in full force. hard to stand up at the sign for photos. Fantastic. DO IT.

Heading south to the end of the world. Strange feeling to be heading south the the Cape of Good Hope. Vast areas with low vegetation and sparse trees, baboons, bontebok, eland and mountain zebra here and there, incredible long and wide beaches with the waves of the Atlantic wildly beating them. Hiking trails, interpretation centre, birdwatching, are open options. And at the end ... taratata... the Cape of Good Hope!
Tip of Africa. A must see for visitors. An enjoyable funicular ride. Lots of steps to climb for the best views. But worth it.

historical and informative visit in a beautiful landscape. the cape point is a must on a visit to ZA.we went by car from muisenberg to Simons town where we did our first stop in the center to see the victorian main street and had a beautiful in an art-cafe.after visiting the penguins we continued to the cape point.the passage through the nature reserve was better in november when all the flowers where coloured. but the visit was beautiful and interesting again. we finished our tour by visiting the cape point oustrich farm where we did a guided tour. good explanations and good time for a break with a oustrich burger.we got home via chapmans peak another beautiful point of the tour.

South but not south enough. A longish drive from Cape Town and you enter the park (pay) followed by a shortish drive to the car park (tip parking attendant) followed by a cable car (pay) up to the near summit and then a moderate climb to the lighthouse. You are then much further south than you are likely to get. Except Cape Aguilas is still further south.

To see the most South Westerly point of Africa.. The best approach is via Chapman's Peak. We didn't see the variety of wildlife we expected, only baboons. This could be due to the drought.The cold Atlantic meeting the warm Indian ocean creates choppy waters,which didn't deter the seals catching fish or just sun bathing.

Stunning Views. You are paying for the views, but they are worth it. The queues at the pay point were annoying - think the staff could have processed people far more quickly, but once in you can travel about at your own pace. We stopped at a few different beaches, which were beautiful, walked up to the Lighthouse, went to the Cape of Good Hope etc. Saw plenty of seals and an ostrich.

To fulfill a dream. WOW!To be at Cape Point fulfilled a long had dream, since 5th grade. And I did not get dissapointed. To see the cliffs, feel the air, sense the troublesome waters for the seamen, and experience the baboons first hand. It really made a lot of my trip to the southern part of Africa.

Beautiful. We really enjoyed our trip out to Cape Point. It was a fairly easy walk up and you were rewarded with great views. We continued onto the furtherest point which I'd recommend. On our way down we were met with families of baboons. It was great to see them, although keep your distance as one woman got attacked. She was okay but the baboon was grabbing her dress.

Breathtaking views!!! . I would highly recommend going!! It was one of the highlights of our trip!!We hiked up to the lighthouse and was mesmerized by the beauty and great views!! So worth it!!If you can't hike up there is mechanical means to make it to almost the top. Still a small hike to the very top where the lighthouse is located. All around GREAT experience!! ❤️

High entrancefee - and nothing in return. We had to pay 125 Rand pr. person at the gate.For this we actually got nothing.Of course you get to see a lot of nature (nothing speciel compared to other places in SA), and you can take you piecture at a sign for Cape of Good hope.

The streght and The Power of the nature . My place . where I m going to move hopfully soon or as soon as I can from cape town take The road by The atlantic stop as much as You Can on The way to cape Point there are on The both sides incredible Villages and nice people . one day i ll move there in Scarborough !!!

Again, great views. This point is not to be confused with Good Hope, it is further east and a bit north. The views from the top where the lighthouse stands are commanding. You walk the last bit but ride a cable car most of the way from the parking lot.

Stunning - well worth the drive. It's a long trip to the point, probably further than we realised and the traffic leading into the nature reserve was horrendous, we queued for almost 2 hours to get into the park itself, although once in everything was fine. We had a whole day so we had plenty of time and also planned to stop off en route to see the penguins at Boulders Bay. Unfortunately after driving all the way there, the Reserve had a power cut and the Funicular was not working so I didn't make it to the very top. My husband and son did take the walk up but that's not for the unfit like me and I would have struggled in the heat. By the time they had gone to the top and come back down again there was a huge sea fog that came in and people after us would not have been able to see anything of the views.It is worth taking the longer route via Chapman's Peak and Boulders Bay. It is truly spectacular scenery and I am so pleased we came into the Reserve that way. We then found an alternative way back which was not as stunning but still worth it.

Wonderful drive.... We rented a Harley and spent the entire day driving around the Cape Town area. Cape Point Nature Reserve is beautiful we stopped many times to snap photos and just take in the magnificent views. The wind gets rather fierce in this area so if you do decide to go it is a good idea to bring a jacket and possible something to cover your ears. Definitely must visit here if you are in the area.

One of the most scenic places on earth. An expansive nature reserve nestled at the end of a continent provides ocean and mountain views, beautiful flowers and plants, fantastic scenery, and nice hiking. Spend an afternoon or morning driving from area to area, stopping along the way at as many places as you please to explore more in depth.
Excellent - get there early before the buses. You can take the funicular up or hike up, either way, it's well worth seeing! To the West is the Cape of Good hope.

Beautiful . Highly worth a visit. Plenty of great hikes around the park and many, many beautiful landscapes for viewing and photographing. The beauty is breathtaking!It is expensive to gain entry but you could easily spend the whole day and make it worth your money. You must go down to the beaches and watch the wind surfing, etc. Very relaxing. Just watch out for the monkeys!

Amazing but leave early. . It's a long trip to the point so leave CT early to give you time to get the cart to the top. We left CT too late, stopped in towns along the way like Boulders Bay to see the Penguins and by the time we got to the point, we missed the last cart going up and down. So a big tip, get there early. A great route is from CT to Cape Point via Boulders Bay and the back to CT via Kalk Bay and Hout Bay as there are AMAZING AMAZING VIEWS!
Stunning area. Entrance fee to pay but well worth it.Stunning views of the 2 oceans meeting and can be clearly seen on a good day.Excellent restaurant for refreshments. Good gift shop too.

Bazbus Tour. Doing this tour with a fun yet professional company like Bazbus was a pleasant experience.Hout Bay, Chapmans Peak, Boulders and Cape of Good Hope...Amazing and highly recomnended. Breakfast and lunch in spectacular spots, all entrance fees included in the price of the tour. A tour that was a highlight for me. Thank you Bazbus for this memorable trip.Shaz Smuts

Good Stop and Great Hike from Cape Point to Cape of Good Hope. The funicular to the lighthouse was not operating one the day we were there, but there was a shuttle bus running up and down on a regular basis. There are nice views from the lighthouse. You can also hike down to the new lighthouse which is closer to the Point, but we opted not to do that in the interest of time.Off to the side of the parking lot, near the rest rooms, there is a trailhead for the trail that leads to the Cape of Good Hope. One can also drive there, but this is a worthwhile hike with fabulous views, if you are fit and have sturdy shoes. We hiked to the look-out point above the Cape of Good Hope parking lot, about a 1-1/2 hour round trip. The trail continues down to the parking lot but it is a steep hike back up to return. There is no protection from the sun on this trail, so a hat and sunscreen are necessary.Get to Cape Point early as there was a fairly long line of vehicles waiting to get in as we were leaving.
a must see - simply beautiful. This is a terrific spot, simply beautiful. The views are stunning, the mountains, flora, fauna and the mighty Atlantic Ocean are awesome.

Gorgeous. Stunning.. watch out for the baboons on your car!
If you have reasonable fitness you can walk up to the lighthouse and follow the paths.. but there is a funicular railway too
Two Oceans Restaurant is a beautiful spot for food - formal or casual dining available.
Cape Point. You can't go to Cape Town and not take a trip to Cape Point. Was worth the trip for the amazing views.

Cape of Good Hope Accessibility . Cape of Good Hope is semi wheelchair accessible. The restaurants and shops at the bottom have ramps and separate accessible restrooms. Be aware that you may have to ask an employee to unlock the door. The tram to the light house is accessible and half price for wheelchair users. There's a paved cobblestone path with good views but no way of getting to the lighthouse itself.

It´s the end.. Being fanatic about the continent Africa, visiting the most southern point was a must. The scenery is beautiful and there is so much history connected to Good Hope. Also the magnificent trip from Cape Town makes the journey a must.

Leave the crowds to discover the real Cape Point. Cape Point National Park is one of the must see places when in Cape Town but frankly most people miss the best of it. The park forms the tip of the Cape peninsula with beautiful ocean and mountain views.Through the gate and the vast majority of people hurtle down the central road to the two famous capes, The Cape of Good Hope, the south west tip of Africa for the essential photograph and Cape Point overrun with tourists but with all the facilities including a restaurant with the most fabulous views. From the car park, you can take the expensive funicular up to the old lighthouse and from there admire or even walk down to the new lighthouse. The views are stunning. Some may take the scenic walk between Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope.However following the tourist trail will ensure you miss out on the real beauty of this amazing park. There are four places worth visiting, two on the False Bay side of the peninsula and two on the Atlantic side. On the False Bay side there is Buffels Bay, a beautiful picnic area right on the sea complete with toilets, tidal pool and braai facilities making it popular with South Africans. North of this is Bordjiesrif, another spot right by the sea with tidal pool, picnic areas and loos. However to get right off the beaten track take the left hand turn to Black Rocks and follow the road down past the limestone kiln to the parking area. From there you can walk along the tarmac road to Venus Pool a most unusual coastal feature overshadowed by three enormous peaks. On the other side of the peninsula where the Atlantic waves roll onto the rocky shoreline are two more hidden gems. It is a fairly long drive down to Olifantsbos where there is parking overlooking a beautiful beach and you will almost certainly see bontebok and maybe baboon and ostrich. The baboons here are noted for their seafood diet of shellfish and kelp. From the car park there is a beach walk to the wrecks of the Tommy Tucker and the Nolloth. People will be in very short supply.Another great place is Platboom. The car park is on a low bluff overlooking a wide sand river. After crossing the sand, you can either turn left for a deserted beach walk or turn right and find the coastal path. After an unpromising start, the path wends its way along by the rocky shoreline and there is great variety of birds to be spotted hopping on the rocks including terns, cormorants, sacred ibis, herons and plovers. It is a stunning walk and you will almost certainly see not a soul. In the distance the traffic hammers to the Capes but you walk in splendid isolation. One memorable afternoon, not only did we see the usual array of birds but also bontebok with young, ostriches with young, baboons always with young, Cape seals basking on the rocks and as we turned to return to the car I glanced over my shoulder to see a herd of eland crossing the dunes.The best way to visit Cape Point is to take a car, take a picnic, take your binoculars and take your time. Away from the crowds you will not be disappointed.
Beautiful scenic point!. This is a beautiful point where the two oceans meet. You can walk up to the light house, and there are so many photo opportunities. We also saw baboons!

Worth a day trip!. Really enjoyed our day trip down to Cape Town. It will take about an hour and a half to get down there from Cape Town or perhaps a bit longer depending on the driver and traffic. The national park is stunning and it's well worth going down to Cape Point, the most south westerly point in South Africa I believe. The scenery on a clear day is quite spectacular. It is easy enough to a private tour down there for the day if you don't want to drive. It will likely cost you around 1500 rand for the day.

Most scenic tourist attraction. Being the tip & horn of Africa it must be the second most popular outdoor nature attraction after Table Mountain.Accessible by hiking,cycling but best visited by car.Open all year round.Fees apply or use Wild Car.Well hidden are some of its most natural beaches or bays like "Bordtjies Drift" which in yester years were most famous for local fishing and day campers.This reserve houses many plant,animal,bird & reptile life.Keep those eyes open.The areas sandstone is very rocky ,sharp edged ,mountanous & contains many cliffs.Drive down to the Cape of Good Hope beach beacon to take a must photograph or scale a small cliff area to its right for some stunning sea views.One the other side take the boardwalk down to a bay to feel the ocean breeze on your face.Else take the cable tram to the beacon to see the Indian & Atlantic oceans meet.Fees apply else take the path, a longer steep walk for the fit.Also spend time at the curio shop to buy souvenirs or catch up on the history of the place.This makes it a both educational & enjoyable excursion.Better so why not have lunch there.Cafe & restaurant fully stocked.Restrooms are clean & free.A half a day should be sufficient time for a visit

Amazing place. Take your time here and enjoy the beauty. Get there early to beat the crowds. Take the easy walk to the new lighthouse, it is not as long as the signs will be telling you, definitely not 1.5h.Also you can walk to the Cape of Good hope from the lighthouse, easy 40 minutes walk (if you don´t go down to the gorgeous beach midway) right until the end where you have a slight rocky descend to the cape of good hope. Nothing hard with an average fitness level.
Just SOO beautiful. I loved the Cape Peninsula Tour as you can really see South Africa's beauty, the nature is just so amazing and beautiful.

A visit with crowds of people. At the gate to the park we had to wait for a minimum of 20 minutes to get in. At Cape Point there were crowds if people, walking upstairs - chatting, screaming, shouting - it was allover loud. At the sign of Cape of good Hope there are three busses arriving and everybody wants to take a ave last hours to get to the sign. No thanks, never again. It is a park, I expected nature and quitness.ö

Beautiful Natural Reserve. This is a beautiful location at the tip of the western cape. Essential to walk up the path all the way to the lighthouse at the top for the amazing views across the bays, and the wildlife.
Definitely worth visiting. You can't really visit Cape Town and not visit Cape Point's nature reserve. Go early, the queues do build up. View is amazing and it's so worth visiting

Cape Point South Africa’s most magnificent sightseeing & tourist attractions. Cape Point is beyond doubt one of South Africa’s most magnificent sightseeing & tourist attractions, though most well known as the dramatic point of collision between Africa's surly currents, this renowned geographic phenomenon is worlds more than just towering cliffs &d rocky escarpments that overlook a watery crux. Location shooting for Hollywood’s “Pirates of the Caribbean” is one of the credits to its edge-of-the-world allure astounding enough to render nearby urban civilization almost inconceivable & recognized as a World Heritage Site.
Rent a car to see it all. I was there on a tour, which is not the proper way to go there. Rent a car and walk around, that way you can see the beauty of the place.
Well worth a visit.. The views are stunning. Ensure you visit on a clear an relatively wind free day. Suited for all age groups. Funicular is available, pricey but worth t.

Stunning . Be prepared to spend quite a while in this beautiful place. You pay to drive into the reserve but then you could literally spend all day there. Car parking wasn't great and not very suitable for anyone with walking difficulties. Good variety of souvenirs in the shops. There's a cable car to the top or a good hours walk. Totally worth it for the stunning views though.

The drive from Cape Town by way of Simonstown is amazing. Take your time and do it during daylight to enjoy the views.. The park is a great half-day visit from Cape Town. You can do it quicker but you won't want to. Do the drive via Hout Bay and Chapman's Peak and you will think you are on highway 1 in California. Once you get to the point take the time to walk all the way to the point (down from the lighthouse). The sheer cliffs and stunning views are well worth the time and effort.

Special place. Cape point nature reserve is special because of many things but I believe the most special thing is that it is the point where 2 oceans meet. And if you had the chance of visiting Cape Town you should also go and see this place.

Worthy tourist destination. Truly spectacular view of where the Atlantic and Indian meet. Crazy how clear it is right there at the point, where you can see the two waters clashing and whirling together. The cliffs, beaches, birds, baboons and stunning views are worth weaving through the plentiful amount of tourist. Try going on a weekday for less of a crowd.

Stunning!. A great drive from Cape Town, down one side and back on the other. Lots of amazing song views in the park including wildlife. Do the hike to the lower light house, return in 45 minutes and not the 1.5 hours the sign suggests.

stunning. This Natural World Heritage Site is a must see when in Cape Town.
