Plan in a day trip - and make sure to also view the penguins at Boulder's Beach - and try to be there after 3 pm (that is when most of the tour buses leave). Cape Point is a paradise for nature Lovers: fynbos, antelopes, zebras, ostriches, turtles and birds galore. Pack your hiking shoes (don't forget to bring enough water) and go for one of the scenic hikes there. Cape Point was always a bit tricky for sailors, as gale force storms and rugged rocks made it difficult to navigate and it was rightly named "Cape of Storms" by Bartolomeu Dias. Do hike up to the lighthouse and enjoy the stunning views and snap a pic at the "Cape of Good Hope". The only downer: we were here on a beautiful Sunday afternoon and the Restaurant and Bistro were closed after 4 pm due to stock taking. Erm....seriously? In Season? why not have stock taking done after hours?

It has to be seen to be believed just a stunningly beautiful place. South Africa has so much to offer but the best has to be Cape Town and the whole surrounding area - a must to visit put it on your bucket list

Always something to see and experience. During one months we visited the Cape Point Parc 6 times and hiked more or less all the trails (we did not go to the Point or the Good Hope as we had been there several times in the past).The weather was mainly pleasant with a SE wind cooling you down. Trails are well laid out and we experience, Angular Tortoises, ostriches, Cape Mountain zebras, bonteboks and a few other antelopes but most important walking within 150 metres from a herd of 12 Elands. The stone formations walking i.e. up to Sirkelvlei are impressive and old old. Yes Cape Point and Good Hope are must-see - but the whole area deserves to be experienced while walking..

Needed the photo. Hired a car and drove down the coast road from Cape Town. Stopped off at boulders beach for the Penguins before continuing onto the cape point reserve. Walked up to the Cape Point lighthouse before hiking across to the cape of good Hope which takes around an hour return to the main car park.Fantastic views of the surrounding coves and landscapes , saw an Ostrich wandering but no baboons .

World heritage importance. A great variety of wildlife, vegetation, scenery and a real experience alwáys worth repeating. A whole day out and the abilit to incorporate areas such as Chapman's Peak. First rate and a must!

Worth the drive to view nature at its grandest. Bring a nice pair of sneaker and go for a long walk up the path. Sit and enjoy the best views in Cape Town and the fauna of a completely different area.

Stunning Views. It is a long drive to here but a very scenic and enjoyable one. try not to rush the drive as this also an experience.I was quite disappointed to find that the oceans did not actually meet here but a few hundred kilometers away. I expected to see rough sees clashing and two different colour waters battling for dominance but there was just a lot of wind - extremely windy to hike up the trail to the lighthouse. there is a tram that goes up and down and from the base to the lighthouse, but this is a boring route and would highly recommend the hike instead. the was a lot of hype about the restaurant but this was a huge disappointment. The nature reserve is stunning with breathtaking views when hiking up to the top especially towards the sunset. did not get down to the point itself as this is a long hike. would highly recommend if you have the time to explore but do not go for the restaurant, just for the views.

Plan to spend at least a day here. This is a beautiful park and the visitor centre along the road before getting to Cape Point is lovely. The actual Cape of Good Hope and Cape point attractions are worth the trip alone but you can do some amazing hikes and drive the little roads to the side beaches.Amazing.Wish we could have stayed much longer.
Beautiful views, but no animals. I've been several times over the years, but never seen any animals. Well worth a drive for the views though.

Road works made big delays. For me it was nice to say I have been but not an experience I would repeat. We were stuck in traffic for ages because they are doing the longest stretch of 'road works' that is on a par with the M1 motorway in England in length but has 3 way traffic lights on it!It's pretty when you get to cape point but so is a lot of the rest of the coast in these parts. Due to mobility issues we couldn't do any walking but took the replacement bus up to the lighthouse. We didn't hang around long though as they were repainting it and there were a lot of biting bugs about.
Excellent. Great experience and possibly one of the best places you can visit on this planet. Will come often times back to see this magnificient place.
Simply stunning. Such a wild and diverse natural location, too incredible to put into words so just go and see for yourself!
A stunning part of the world. The drive from Cape Town is spectacular. The reserve is a "must do" for nature lovers and those who want to view stunning scenary.
Hike. Heavely place to visit. Exquisite walks just beyond the gate to the point. Tranquility and peace. Hoerrikwagga trail highly recommended.

Must do activity. Excellent view of Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope. I always regret not planning more time for the visit and take the opportunity to hike on the walking trials. You can easily spend a full day here. Next time I will! If don't like or are able to walk the last part, take the elevator. Plan 90 minutes to drive from Cape Town city bowl to the Cape Point, one-way.
End of the world. Despite many tourists and photo cameras, there is an incredible feeling of being at the end of the world. Just escape the crowds and find your way to the ocean.
Cape Point Nature Reserve. Cape Point Nature Reserve! i must say the drive there is amazing but the point is nothing amazing i think...

Worth a Visit. It was pretty neat being on the southern tip of Africa, The tram is worth taking but it is also worth the walk down to the bottom lot from the bottom of the tram. Be sure to look around as we saw a ver majestic Eland standing on top of a hill

Meeting place of two oceans. Take the cableway to the top and watch the two oceans meet, an excellent area to take a swim, it has tidal pools at the different beaches. Baboons are quite a nuisance at the beaches so be careful, good restaurant inside, overall lots to do, if you a cyclist they have special tours for you at a fee.

Visit the southernmost tip of Cape Town, not South Africa. Allocate one full day or at least half day to explore the beautiful Cape Point Nature Reserve. Take your time to explore each historical spots and places of attraction + the wildlife. Take a hike up and down the lighthouse, even though they offer funicular ride. Take the time to go downhill to feel the chill of the atlantic ocean water. There's a big chance of you meeting ostriches, kudu, springboks and other animals here. Travel slowly in your vehicle and pay attention to the road as there might be turtles or baby turtles passing. Pay attention to closing hours. A visit to the nearby ostrich farm is also a must.

Baboons everywhere!. We traveled through the reserve to get to Cape Point. Really pretty landscape and we were able to see some mountain zebra and a lot of baboons! Be carful if you leave the car that you don't have food on your person!!
Windy bit worth it. It's quite a drive but too see the two oceans come to together is magnificent. ..really amazing veiws.But pack same ice water it is a steep hill to climb to the top

Cape Point Nature - The Jewel in the Capes Crown. This has to be one of the most beautiful, rugged coastlines of Southern Africa. Besides the incredible raw beauty of the rocks + beaches that form one of the most southern most points of South Africa (it is NOT the southern most point please note!), and the breathtaking view from the Lighthouse, there are also stunning and relatively flat/easy hikes and walks to be taken in the nature reserve. Look out for baboons, ostriches, Bontebok, and delicate flowers. From the entry, the roads are well signposted, and you will be given a map on arrival. Drive ALL the side-roads, stop, get out and look at the Diaz crosses, and breath the amazing air. Once you get to the 'touristy' part where you either climb to the Lighthouse or take the Funicular if you're not that fit, don't forget your camera to photograph some of the most breathtaking views in the world. If the wind is blowing, hold on to your everything! Stop at the Restaurant for a meal or coffee, and just know that you're privileged to view one of the most amazing places on earth! Get there early!
"A day out". Did a tour round Cape peninsula visiting here. Very quiet peaceful place with lots of places of interest to see.

Gorgeous nature views and the most attraction of watching union of two oceans!. This is a must to visit. Gorgeous views of the Atlantic and Indian oceans joining at the tip of the peninsula of the African continent. Stunning views of the mountains, cliffs, and scenery!

A Must. The Cape of Good hope; well, how can you miss it. That point, so feared by sailers for hundreds of years, where the oceans meet (oh, I know not geographically, but in realty!). You stand there and see this meeting of forces - go up to the lighthouse and think about the incredible history of all the ships from Europe passing here to go to the far east, months and months at sea ...... but on top of this, the park is a breathtaking area where Fynbos (one of the 6 floral kingdoms) is abundant and is there without the so often found influence of alien vegetation. Once you get off the beaten tracks, you find pristine beaches, landmarks - and you might bump into some exciting wild life. It's such an inspiring place, so full of vibrant life - be it in nature or history. I love it.

It all comes together. This is a beautiful location and the destination of any bus tour of the cape area south of Cape Town. It is not the southernmost point of Africa, but it is the southwestern most point of the continent. If you walk to the lighthouse at the top of cape point, you will see how the Atlantic comes together with the Indian Ocean.
Beauty abounds. Wonderful area of the cape. So much open space and the vegetation and wildlife are plentiful. The walk to the light house will get you in shape.

Absolutely breathtaking!. We hired a driver for half a day to take us to the Cape Point Nature Reserve.. It is huge, much bigger than expected, and you get to view the beauty of the Atlantic and Indian oceans meeting. We took a trip up to the lighthouse (stunning views) and walked along a long stretch of beach which was completely empty and utterly beautiful. We also saw a mother and baby baboon. I highly recommend visiting.

Lovely day trip with Cheryl. Wetookthistrip to go to lower area of peninsula. It was a well guided tour with ,Cheryl giving us a lot of info. She even included the chance to.go on a trip to sea the fur seals and also to Boulders to see the penguin.

A must see, despite all the visitors. The day we did this the road beyond the entrance was under repair. Combined with it being a Sunday afternoon we had a half hour wait in a jam. No problem. Chatted with visitors from the Congo who were also strolling around as we waited. The steps and path up to the old lighthouse are in superb condition. 20 minutes to the top. You can take a shuttle up while the tram is out of action. Best to do this early on a weekday I think.

Not as wonderful as the drive leading up to it, but worth it. Prepare for lots of people taking selfies. Turn your back to them and enjoy the amazing viewing incredibly beautiful vista. If you are lucky you will spot some whales!

A must to do when you are in Cape Town. If you have time use it at this Nature Reserve go off the Main Road, take the small roads to the left an the right and look around if you see some animals or birds in their natural habitat. Obviously you also have to spend time at the southernmost point of the Penisula (Cape Point) and pose at the Cape of Good Hope (that's were coach tourist get driven to)
Cape Point wow!. One of those places you must see if in Cape Town. Stunning views, get there early in the morning as gets very busy, we visited on a Saturday.

For both tourists & nature lovers. If you do go to the touristy part at the tip, i recommend using the funicular for you g children, and doing the walk down to the gunners point & WW2 radar site. But my favourite part of our visit was exploring the quite paths & roads the tourists miss.

Fantastic end of the world feeling. Not the most southern point of the continent as I'd thought but spectacular, windswept and beautiful. Great system of paths to give different views. the way over to the Cape of Good Hope was well worth it. Only issue was the provision of a picnic area- the only place with seating to eat the sandwiches sold on site with attendant baboons. There had been warning elsewhere on site but none that we saw here. The guy with the stick to chase them off arrived just after we're had some of our lunch stolen.
Beautiful. You have to see this place. The environment is wonderful.I coul spend hours just looking at the horizon and the see.

Great Views!. Driving throughout the park you see very picturesque cliffs and waves. They continue as you get to the Cape Point and take the little tram or walk up to get to the light house. I'd try to make it up there earlier in the day because the tour buses will bring crowds. There are a few gift shops and even a little cafe. Hold on to your hats up at the lighthouse because it is windy! There is a sign post down near the water that says Cape of Good Hope.

Visit to Cape Province. You have to come by car to the reserve and their lots of walks, Going all the way to the Cape of Good Hope whit fantastic views.There a lots of animals in the nature reserve, be careful of the monkeys

A good day out. We visited whilst staying in Cape Town. Its a good drive to get there but worth it .
There are some interesting walks around the area but the winds can be very strong.The funicular takes you nearly to the top and there are steps to the ligthouse.

windy visit to the old lighthouse. it's a fair climb up path and stairs to get to the top where the old lighthouse is located. windy all the way!! if you like to wear headgear, get one with strings. nice ride down in the funicular -- nb: one way costs almost as much as round trip.

An excellent day out. When visiting the Cape Province this is a real must. When in the park. It is possible to go to The Cape of Good Hope, Cape Point and many of the places of interest on the way. The views are spectacular. We were lucky enough to see bontebok, ostriches, tortoises, dassies and other antelope whilst there. It is very easy to spend a whole day here.

Nice view !. Good experience at the bottom of no where !A small walk to go to the ligthouse and then you can go behing to go to the top of the cliff.Beautiful view of the cliffs going under a amazing blue clear water.If you are lucky you could also enjoy the antelope around

Great Nature experience. 50 minutes from Cape Town is this amazingly beautiful reserve. We go hiking so park the car and walk in different directions. The ocean surrounding is impressive snd watch out for the small nature experiences. Adders, baboons, tortoises, sea birds and perhaps an ostrich or bontebok . You can take your bicycle and picnic lunch. Watch for Baboons who steal your food. The restaurant up by the vernacular is also good. Can watch whales cruising below and scenery is stunning.
Stunning views!!. Really large area with lots of stop of points. A nice climb at the top to get the amazing views,need the camera another hood place when you have good sunny westher
BEAUTIFUL!!. Enjoyed it tremendously. One of the highlights of our visit. Highly recommend it if you visit this area and have time. The drive there was breath taking.

No other like it !. The Cape Point Nature reserve is an absolute must when visiting Cape Town . The breathtaking views , the African Penguin colony at Boulders beach , the history of the Cape of Good Hope all makes for a magical day out on the Peninsula that is unique , there is none like it !
Breathtaking Views all around. The drive to Cape point is so beautiful but that doesn't even prepare you for the spectacular views when you finally get there.

Not the most Southerly spot in Africa!. Many people mistakenly believe that they are visiting the most southerly place in Africa at Cape Point. This is not correct as the most southerly spot is along the coast at Cape Aghulas where also the Indian and Atlantic Oceans also meet.However, this should not dissuade u from visiting Cape Point, it is a good drive out from Cape Town which also allows you to enjoy the coastline and towns along the way Muizenberg, Kalk Bay, Simonstown. When you arrive at the entrance and pay the entrance fee you will be surprised that Cape Point is still a good 11Kms from there.Once you arrive at Cape Point you have two choices about how you reach the top - you can walk (it is a good walk up) or use the Funicular (unfortunately this was not working on the day we visited). This was a challenge for us as my 80 year old mother was unable to walk up to the top. Once you are up the top the views are fantastic - looking down at the sea, the Cape of Good Hope and indeed if you walk further around the point the little light house at the end of the point.If you are feeling energetic and adventurous and have enough time you can walk from Cape Point to the Cape of Good Hope and back. It is a good walk and takes about 90 minutes for the round trip. Be prepared for strong winds which even on a very hot day will make you feel a little cold!Thee are shops to purchase goods and also a food shop and restaurant which is very popular and busy with great views along the coast.
A must see while in the cape. It's a reasonable drive from Cape Town but worth the trip. The views are great, just watch out for the baboons :)

Beautiful location. During a recent visit to Cape Town we had a fantastic day trip along the coast line to the Cape of Good Hope and Cape Point. Fantastic views - a must see when in the area. On route stop off to see the penguins at Boulders Beach and Camps Bay for lunch, dinner or an ice cream

Visit the south-eastern tip of Africa. Cape Point provides spectacular views from the most south-eastern point of the continent. At Cape Point you can walk up to the lighthouse or catch the funicular railway to enjoy views across False Bay. You can walk 1km along the clifftops from Cape Point to the Cape of Good Hope and look back up the Atlantic coast. The path is well-marked and in good condition but not suited to seniors or very young children.The Two Oceans restaurant at Cape Point offers diners great views across False Bay and a good range of dishes at a reasonable price. Fro more casual food there is a takeaway pizza and sandwich shop next door.I would combine a half-day at Cape Point with a trip to the African Penguin colony at Boulders (near Simonstown).
Spectacular sights. We took a tour to the Cape on such a beautiful sunny day. We took the funicular up to the lighthouse where we got the most magnificent sights of the coast.
Cape Point Review. Cape Point offers time in Nature whilst experiencing the beauty of the Cape. You will see wildlife, beach, sea and birdlife while watching two oceans meet.

nature pure. a visit of this reserve completes a visit to this heavenly place, a wide selection of activities, which can be done here from biking, walking and climbing. enjoy the wind and you can avoid the masses.

Really Disappointed . We arrived at 8:45 in windy horrible weather. The restaurant and coffee kiosk told us that they would be open at 9. At 9:05 we tried to get a cup of coffee only to be told by the restaurant that we had to get it from the kiosk (my opinion is that because we weren't having a full breakfast, they were not interested in our patronage). We then got advised by the kiosk that they would only be able to help us at 9:30 and this after being told that they open at 9:00. Not the customer service one would expect.

Beautiful, but half a day was not enough. As we only had half a day we limited ourselves to vist the Cape of Good Hope and Cape Point itself. The drives to both place were nice, with good views on the ocean. At Cape Point it was too bad you cannot really get close to the point, but from up there you had a great aerial view (almost) on Cape of Good Hope.Take your time if you go here, as there are some nice hikes to do and it's nice to enjoy the fresh air here (apparently the cleanest in the world!).
Spectacular Views. The views are unreal. This place is definitely worth it. The flora is other worldly. It was one of the best attractions of Cape Town for me.
Amazing Cape. Cape point and Cape of good hope, lovely views and beaches. Love to climb Cape of good hope and just breath the air...

This places is worth at least a day of your time... The cape is beautiful, much more breath taking than we expected, even with the crowds. We had about 2 hours to hike, but frankly had we known there were so many hiking trails here we would have given ourselves a whole day to explore the trails and enjoy the stunning views. There's also a sit down restaurant at monument that is excellent. Make sure you allow time for lunch here.

Beautiful scenery!. A lovely drive down the coast to the Cape Point Lighthouse and Cape of Good Hope came with happy surprises like a troop of baboons sitting on the side of the road and an ostrich sauntering down the beach and beautiful antelope grazing in the bush. Enjoyed our visit immensely.

Worth every moment. It was beautiful and it is worth every second and every penny. I loved it and the kids had so much fun. Even tho it's in the mountain it was pretty accessible for a family with kids.

A place to see but too many coaches. It is a must in South Africa but the experience is ruined by coach loads of noisy visitors all fighting for a picture by the sign. Surely that's not the point. Enjoy the stunning scenery.
Wow. Amazing place. Could not believe the natural beauty. A must see on the bucket list. Was with a day tour. Lovely. Beautiful views in every direction.

Beautiful, well-maintained park. It took us quite a long time to get into the park (1+ hour) as we were there in the height of the summer season just before the New Year. But it was worth the wait - lots to see - whether driving or hiking - great hikes to the Cape of Good Hope and views for days. Though it was busy, as soon as we were off the beaten path (ie the lighthouse path), we were mostly to ourselves.

Spectacular views. A wonderful way to appreciate the beauty of the Cape. A visit to the Cape Point Nature Reserve provides breathtaking views of where the Atlantic and Indian Oceans meet and a look into the history of the Portuguese and Dutch who found and ultimately settle this land so remote from their native Europe. A great experience.

Favourite place. Grab a picnic basket and your walking shoes and spend the day in this pristine environment. Breath taking views, clean air and amazing fynbos. There is always something different flowering here. There are many walks you can go on - stop at the info centre on the way in for a map. Beaches galore. Be careful if you swim, this is treacherous water if you don't know what you are doing, rather swim in the tidal pool. If you want to go to the tourist centre at the top it is also worth a walk out to the 'tip of Africa' (which obviously it isn't ) but it feels like it! Not cheap to get in but well worth it. Residents can get 12 free entries pa.

Cape Point. The southern most tip of Africa is a windy windy spot. It is well worth it to walk to the top of the cliff or take the cable car up and walk down. Be sure to stop at the sign for the classic must have photo
One of those places you must see before you die.... Breathtaking, naturally wonderful. Be carefully with the baboons, and check the weather before visiting.

Awesome day out. There is tons to do and see, lots of photo opportunities with various landscape and dramatic seascapes. The cable car was not working when we went which we were looking forward to riding on but the walk ended up being a great alternative with plenty of spectacular views to stop and look at on the way. Nice little beach coves with braai facilities. When we were there the park was in pristine condition and makes us proud to be be South Africans.
Amazing Location & View. Cape Point is one of the must see places in Cape Town. Even the route to the point has got some amazing view points. Quiet serene and peaceful.

No visit to Cape Town complete without going to Cape Point. This is a must visit location on a Cape Town trip.Beautiful scenery long walks by the cliffs edge. Nice restaurants and maybe perhaps a sight of a naughty baboon .Strongly recommended

A must do. Definitely a bucket list experience to sit on the rocks and take it all in - the location, the views, the landscape etc.... Stunning walk from Cape Point to Cape of Good Hope past the most amazing beach/bay. A. It chaotic with works going at present on road in and in car park.

Well Worth It. This is a full day activity and definitely worth it. We hired a private taxi for ZAR 1600 - pick up at 9:30 and return at 6:00. Stopped at boulders for the Penquins and on to the Cape. Took the tram up to the lighthouse and walked out to Dias Point for the spectacular views. It was extremely foggy at the entrance where you paid yours fees, and many people were turning around. We continued on and were rewarded with a sun that broke through, no wind, and just a perfect day. A quick side trip to Cape Horn completes this wonderful and scenic opportunity. Don't miss it.

Service. the most annoying part of this trip was at the entrance gate. The cashier was moody and real very slow in doing her work. We had to wait at least about 8 min before we could get to her window. Very miserable woman cashier and verry expensive for locals to enter. However, the trip to Cape Point made up for her miserability.. beautiful views. Restaurant is very pricey. very expensive for us locals.

Spectacular. We drove from Cape Town stopping at Boulders Beach to see the penguins first. We had a small wait to pay getting into the park. We drove to the point then hiked up to the lighthouse. It was short and a little steep.Would love to have walked around the point but did not have the time. The views were fabulous.

Stunning views!. I'd highly recommend a visit to this wonderful place...you feel like being at the end of the planet...walk up to Cape Point to enjoy the view of the ocean and the incredible surroundings

Awesome little hike to Cape point. Not too expensive and a lot to see and take in. The walk/hike to Cape Point is great, but it can be a challenge on windy days, so watch out for that. If you complete the hike you can scale the rocks and you'll be able to capture some truly amazing photos of surrounding areas or just relax and enjoy the scenery.

Great day out. Drove out from Cape Town and arrived at lunch time. Plenty to do there. Lots of walks for all levels of walkers. The two crosses are interesting and the walk to the point is wonderful. The funicular is a fun way to get part of the way up but walking to the light house was the best. Spectacular views and great photo opportunities. Lots of birds nesting on the cliffs. Worth spending a day here. The restaurant is fine if a little pricy.

Didn't expect to see so much.. On our drive to Cape Point we saw all manner of wildlife including Ostrich and tortoise which was a real pleasure.
The point itself is good and you have to get the customary 'Welcome to Cape Point' sign photo!
Could do with a bit more in terms of facilities but it had everything that you needed really.
Excellet. A must see with spectacular views did this as part of a tour not to be missed really. Wild coast line where many ships came to peril

Wonderful . Friends and I fell in love with this place. It is so beautiful and beautiful scenery. I was amazed how scenic it was. A great stop to spend time and take in nature. It really is interesting and worth a stop. You will be quiet pleased.
A must see. Absolutely worth the walk! Scenic views. Well kept. Good restaurants. The funicular is a must if you are not a keen walker. The drive from the gate to Cape Point is absolutely beautiful.

Beautiful view! . I decided to take the cable car situation up and down, but I'm not opposed to only taking it one way or I visit again. There are plenty of opportunities for great pictures, and the view is amazing. It's a bit of a hike to the lighthouse at the top, but well worth it, if you can manage the stairs. Must see!
Worth the journey. Drive from Cape Town takes in some picturesque places and stunning coastline. Cape Point has a charming funicular and good visitor facilities.

Point of Beauty. This is a must visit for anyone visiting Cape Town. The drive to Cape Point is simply gorgeous. It can become very cold very quickly, so always be sure to take a sunhat and a warm jacket.

Excellent sightseeing. Those who travel to Cape Town must visit the nature reserve. This place has lot to walk so I wont recommend for old people. Scenic view is great throughout .. its where two oceans meet so cant miss it !
Such lovely scenery . Such a pretty area. You must see the penquins colony, you really are close up to them. Highly recommended

Most Southwestern Point in Africa. A must visit place for anyone on holiday in Cape Town. The drive to and from the park is beautiful in and of itself. Be prepared to take your time to get there depending on the traffic. Also be prepared that the weather can change pretty quickly. When we arrived at the gate to the park we were told that conditions were very cloudy and visibility was terrible. We had driven a long way and decided to take a chance. Glad we did as by the time we got to the point, the clouds had moved on. Views were spectacular!We took the funicular to the top as we were in a bit of a time crunch and wanted to see the lighthouse. We may as well have hiked (which we did on the way down) as the funicular decided not to work and an engineer had to walk down from the top to fix it. Make sure you drive down to the point proper and get in line to stand by the sign. You wouldn't want to miss proving to your friends that you stood in the most southwestern point in Africa. Whatever that means.
Always beautiful, whatever the weather. It's quite a distance, but worth the trip when touring the peninsula. Great views from all angles. Restaurant is good (fresh fish)
Beautiful. I really enjoyed this it was not very busy when we went and its a really easy hike around the point.
Great view. The place is just amazing. The view at Cape Point is stunning. But be prepared to have a 20 mins trail walk if you want to go to the south point.
Spectacular sight!. One of the best parts of our trip... It was a day well spent. We opted to walk, which took time but definitely worth every step! A beautiful place.

Nice drive!. Always a favorite get away, just to drive through Simons Town, lunch in Kalk Bay and then a stroll along the Cape Point - what a great reminder that Cape Town offers the best leisure lifestyle!

"Cape Point where South Africa begins". It is always a good feeling to visit the Cape Point when one is in Cape Town. To experience the marvellous creation of God, the view is so refreshing and appealing to the eyes. My youngest daughter was over the moon to experience the height at the light house and to see those points showing how many kilometres it takes to travel by ship to other countries like Rio de Janeiro,London, U.S. etc. One thing I didn't like though is the fact that we pay at the entrance gate and again pay for the cable cars to the light house it is costly! But otherwise the experience was awesome, we even took some walking trips just to view the beauty of nature.There's also a huge rock at the light house were people can write their signatures as a sign that they were there,it's like leaving your footprints so that those who come after you may witness your presence!

Climb to the lighthouse for stunning views of Cape of Good Hope. After seeing the Cape of Good Hope, we visited Cape Point and enjoyed it as well. The tram up to the lighthouse was not running that day so we hiked up. It was worth the burning thighs for sure! Views of Cape of Good Hope, the Atlantic Ocean as it turns toward the Indian Ocean are breathtaking.
The point of 'turn'. Excited to see the point from where the sailors turned in a new direction a found the new worlds. Salute to those who created modern history.

Lots to see rain or shine. Lovely place to spend some time, do some walking and spotting local birds and critters. Penguins, seal lions, baboons, birds-a-plenty and I'm guessing if you're lucky dolphins and whales.

Cape Point Tour with Africa Afrika Cabs and Tours. My Cape Point Tour with Africa Afrika Cabs and Tours was superb. The flowers were amazing, the animals, the Ostrich, the baboons, beath taking scenic views.

Gorgeous!. Spend the day here hiking or viewing the lighthouse or enjoying a meal at one of the restaurants. The coastline is beautiful! Worth the cost to enter the park. If you are interested in hiking, please wear hiking shoes and not flops. Bring a hat, wear sunscreen, come for adventure! Beware of baboons. We saw them jumping on cars. They will get food if they can.

A special place. All the of the cape area is amazing, but this place is special. The baboons are memorable, and there are plenty of places to explore on foot or in a car. Some small cafes and shops are available, as well as a full-service restaurant.

Beware the baboons!. This was a coach tour round the peninsula featuring stops at Cape Point Visitor Centre and the Cape of Good Hope.At the former I was able to see the old lighthouse partially shrouded in mist. No wonder it was so useless that a substitute had to be built at a lower level.The only negative factor was having to beware of the baboons which are always looking for opportunities to steal visitors' food.

Cape Point is done up nicely but don't miss the real Cape. Some park services get it and SA's clearly does. Everything you need is here including a handy funicular to take you to the top, no sweat, and an easy pathway back down to the bottom. Must see if you've come all the way to SA.
Stunning!. Absolutely worth a few hours to take in breathtaking views. A nice shop at the visitor's center makes local, clean restrooms and helpful people. Do not forget your camera (and sunscreen!)
wild and windy. baboons, an a very rare antelope + very inquisitive Ostrich that seemed to be mesmerized by his own reflection in our van's window-very funny
Wonderful scenery. This was an interesting and most enjoyable trip. The winds were very high so the sea was amazing as were the sandstorms around the beaches

Top of the world. The most amazing views and so much to see. The landscape keeps changing. The entrance is pricey for local tourists especially if you go as a family as they charge per person, so make a day of it and pack a picnic.

End of the continent. Stunning drive along much of the way with views accross bays and mountains. At Cape Point not much to see except a lighthouse but again wonderful views and interesting exhibitions

A must - espcially the Penguins on the way there. We did the tour in a minibus with about 5 others. This was good but a bit rushed especially when it came to the Penguins which are beautiful. I could have stayed for much longer. The Cape Point is beautiful and well worth the effort. We left the tour at Simons Town and caught the train to the beach instead and then back to Cape Town.

Day out. Entering from the main gate its a short drive to the restaurant area before climbing up to the Light house that overlooks the whole of the Cape and across to the Falsbay area.What a treat to visit,so you can take the veld route down and walk down to the point.very busy with lot of tourist,be careful as the path is narrow and very steep down into the sea.will surely fall to your death,i feel that this pathway should have a chain to hold on or at-least if possible made wide so 2 humans can walk there.A must visit for locals and tourist's.
Beautiful place. Wild and wonderful location, the colours of the different vegetation were amazing. Well worth a visit
Cape Point, the Rugged Bottom of Africa.. No visit to the Cape Town area would be complete without a visit to Cape Point and its nature reserve. A fabulous place to spend a day
Nature as its most natural. The cliffs, the ocean the views all show nature at its most wild and natural. It can get very windy, but still well worth a visit

Amazing end-of-a-continent experience. Dramatic scenery, the end of a continent which is an unusual experience, and historical significance. It may well be very windy so a hat and in particular sunscreen are strongly advised. The funicular ride to the top was great for kids.
The tip of Africa. This real Southwestern tip of Africa is a great finish or even start of your journey thru Africa. Real Rough Nature!

A Must. WOW what an credible experience!This is a must do for anyone visiting the Cape and indeed South Africa. Stunning and dramatic scenery with a convenient funicular railway to the top for those who don't fancy the inclined walk! There are restaurants, toilets, shops and an overflow car park with complimentary shuttle busses to the main area during busy times.There was a slight delay at the gate of the reserve but it would take a lot to taint this experience.

Stunning views of the ocean, if you manage past the tourist crowd. The place is very trafficked, with cars and buses filling the small parking lot, and crowds lining up to take pictures in front of the sign. But if you make it past that, and venture towards the ocean on uneven rocky terrain, you are in for stunning views of the waves crashing on the rocks.
No need to say why you should go there. Stunning view of two oceans, cliffs and the sea. Lovely hikes. Do not miss the beautiful sandy beaches and the little informative museum by the lighthouse.

Beautiful coastline walk. Wouldn't miss this for the world. Wonderful way to see the coast line and enjoy some of the beauty of the Cape. However, get there early in the am. The line to get into the park was very long. Thanks to our tour guide Take2Tours we were there early but the line when we left was awful.

Please fix the entrance system to this wonderful site!. Other reviewers have eloquently praised the natural beauty of this area. They are right, and a visit here should be at the top of a Cape Town visitor's shortlist along with the Table Mountain and Robben Island.But I was baffled that the Park administration has still not figured out a better system for smooth admission. It should not be necessary to spend 55 minutes in a line of cars moving at snail's pace towards the entrance, all in the blazing sun and emitting tons of exhaust emissions. How about building a few extra lines with cashiers using handheld credit card readers, and a fast lane for pre-paying customers whose tickets could simply be scanned off?

A wonderful experience on the tip of Africa. Although entering the park is not cheap (R125/person) it is well worth it. We entered around 17h00 (the park closes at 19h00). We had a leisurely drive to the southern-most point, climbed the path to spectacular views (in spite of a howling gale-force southeasterly wind!). We then drowve to see one of the "padraos" - large crosses to the memory of Vasco da Gama and Batholomew Diaz - and on to another pristine beach. Along the way we were treated to visitations from a troop of baboons. It was a most enjoyable outing!
sightseeing. Had a wonderful walk up hill, it was so amazing to climb up and joining hundreds up hill, they also have a cable tram to take people up if you are not the adventure's one to walk..

Watch out for the Weather. The drive from Cape Town is spectacular and you pass through a seemingly endless variety of landscapes. However, as the people who built the lighthouse realised, Cape Point has its own micro-climate. I am sure the views are amazing but often they are hidden by the cloud. In a strange way the cloud and rain gave the space atmosphere, but I can't help thinking it would have been better on a sunny day. And, to be clear, it could be a beautiful day in Cape Town and for most of the drive down, that doesn't mean anything.

Peninsula point. It's a nature reserve in the point of the Cape's Peninsula, once the place of storms became the place of "Good Hope". Excellent view and a very important place in the world's history.
Nice drive from Cape Town. Easy to get to from Cape Town. Hire a car and spend make a day of it with a hike and a stop off or two along the way. Great scenery there and along the way.

Average. The Cape Point is an obvious tourist attraction with all visitors. So here's the thing; this is a good place to visit, however, it is not worth the 45 minute trek uphill to reach the light house. Once you reach there, you will have to opportunity to take a picture for a memory at the bottom of the hill, where the latitude and longitude of Cape Point are mentioned. For those who wish to stop here, may do so willingly! For those who wish to go to the top of the hill near the light house, you have two options, either take a mini tram uphill which will cost you around ZAR 50 one way, or you may choose to test your hiking skills. If you are hiking, you will find 4-5 spots which are picturesque for a photo stop. You will find many such places (some even more beautiful) in the Garden Route. So if you wish not to climb it, I suggest, take a photo at the bottom of the hill and head towards Cape of Good Hope.
well preserved. The reserve is taken care off by the people and fines are also imposed on anyone disturbing it. Also there is a st time in the evening by which every tourist must leave the reserve.

Fantastic experience. After having read about the Cape Point at school, this was amazing to explore. You can either walk (10 minutes) to the lighthouse or take the little train (48 rand for one way ticket)
Nature at its best.. Breath taking views all along the cost. A must for nature lovers. Take a day and stroll around the area.

End of the African Continent. Stunning views along the Eastern Seaboard of the Atlantic ocean.
About 2 hours drive from Cape Town central. Lovely beaches - see the Seals and aquatic birds in their natural habitat.
A Beautiful Reserve!. One needs a car, but the views all the way through the reserve, especially along the western ocean-side are just stunning!

Long drive but SO worth it!. Gorgeous views, and so cool that you can literally see the southern most tip of africa at this location. also, there are lots of baboons on the way and they are funny and adorable.
Beautiful!. Seeing the penguins was lovely, but so was the hike to the lighthouse and the gorgeous view of the cliffs and the ocean. Just watch out for baboons!

No food available at Cape town’s premier tourist destination. Visited Cape Point on Christmas day, weather great views fantastic as always. Thought we would get breakfast in the restaurant to our disappointment it was closed. How can this be when it surly must be Cape Town’s premier tourist destination?
Beautiful part of our Cape Peninsula tour.. Beautiful and well worth seeing. Not where the Indian Ocean and the Atlantic meets as everyone thinks it is but still spectacular.

Misty cooling and magnificent. Cape point is again a very busy place and my goodness what a trek to the top! Don't forget water and please remember the view and temperature are totally different at the top. Worth it though

Worth visiting. I have visited this gorgeaus area for four times and can't wait to be back again! The nature is incredible. I especially loved the walk from parkingarea up to the restaurants and shops. You can easily spend there the whole day and just enjoy the surroundings:)
Often forgotten but it's a great place. Not as 'sexy' as table Mountain but the Cape of Good Hope is such an iconic location that it makes it a must see
Fascinating. This ia not to be missed. It is a tiring walk up in the heat of summer so take the funicular up and enjoy the walk down.

The rather obvious must do when in Cape Town. It's quiet a journey to get there but worth visiting. Ideally, you should go rather early in the morning to avoid an hours queue at the park entrance. When there, also visit the Cape of Good Hope which can be easily reached from the main road.

Cape Town not complete without... . You can't visit Cape Town Peninsula without allocating a day to the Cape Point drive. The drive is relaxing and showcase the Cape ecosystem (fynbos). The Cape point itself offers stunning views of the 2nd most Southern tip of Africa where the two oceans come together. Restaurant facilities are also available.

Must do on your trip to Cape Town. The Cape Point Nature Reserve is definitely worth a visit! You can either take one of the numerous tours there or take your own rental car. Make sure you arrive early during main season, because at some point they started to block the road to the lighthouse because it was too full. Luckily we only saw that when we went back.Obviously, the nature is amazing and you will enjoy it! Make sure to take a wind-jacket with you on cold days as the wind there is insane ;)

Highlight is the cliffs at Cape Point. The relatively unspoilt area seems to provide plenty of areas to walk or cycle. We noticed trailers loaded with bicycles that you could hire to ride around in the park.Best bit for us was the spectacular cliffs at Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope. Terrific views, dizzying vertical drops down to the sea. Excellent for watching the cormorants and other birds living on and around the cliffs. Obviously it can get quite windy and stormy, but on a calm and sunny day it's memorable.Quite smelly up around the old lighthouse, but necessary to get to the top to enjoy the stunning views.

A nice ride from Cape Town to Cape Point. Read about Cape of Good Hope since I was young. It felt fantastic to be able to see and be at Cape of Good Hope and Cape Point. Absolutely recommend it. Place is kept so clean. Extremely well maintained.

Well worth the drive. Be there early to beat the crowds, otherwise you will wait a very long time to enter the park. We waited in a traffic jam outside the entry gates for over an hour, because we were there at prime time around 11 am. It might be extremely windy. Bring a jacket.

Nature at it's best. Well, Cape Point Nature Reserve has always been a favourite of mine since I was aged 6 up until now.I always recommend this to all my friends visiting Cape Town from abroad. You will require a full day to experience the full nature reserve, lots of wild animals up close and beaches all round with the most spectacular views available.If you are into nature and hiking, fishing, swimming or just a family braai for the day, this is the place to do it...with the most soft sands to slide down on.There is just too much to cover in one day, so try for a few...Very enjoyable and highly recommended

Breathtaking views!. I have been to Cape Point twice in the past three months with foreign friends and both times have been amazing. We spotted zebra's, ostriches, dassies, whales(in Oct). Even though we had to wait quite some time to get in, it was well worth it. Beautiful walks! Absolutely stunning!

Very nice. This is a good spot to visit if you enjoy natural scenery. If you go there during tourism peak season then I advise that you get there by 9h00am at the latest because after that the queue at the gate (which is very slow) becomes unbearable.

Fantastic view. We took a tour that took us to Cape Point. It was fun seeing baboons along the way, although you are told to keep your distant from them. They are very mean and destructive. The views from the top are just beautiful

amazing to be at almost the southernmost point of Africa. it was amazing to see almost tot eh southernmost end of Africa, beautiful scenery, nice trails altho some would be very tough in the wind, many different views to take in, lovely beaches and lighthouses

Well woth the trip. Guide was very obliging and kew where to take us. The scenery was excellent.
The party was small and we got some choice of where we went

On top of the world . We had a wonderful experience at Cape point. We walked out as far as the trail went and the view was breathtaking every step of the way. The park was spotless and we had a wonderful breakfast afterwards at the Two oceans restaurant. Luckily, we headed to the park early. When we left the park at 10 o'clock there was a queue at the gate for nearly a kilometre.

One of the best landmarks on Africa. Cape point is simply stunning, taking the Flying Dutchman Funicular railway for about 10 minutes that's you about half way there, it has a Capacity of 40 passengers per car and 450 persons per hour, and then there is a good walk uphill to the top. There is a steep walk up the cliff to the main viewing point area. After the a funicular we start the steps, so wear some comfortable shoes especially the narrow path towards the far end of the peninsula. There beautiful Atlantic and Indian Oceans meet, Who would have thought we would ever be so lucky?. I had a breather on the way up(they are quite steep) but it was definitely worth the effort. After the usual photo's it the top there is only one way and that's down, also it's a good idea to wear a hat of the sun.Be careful when near the baboons. They are not pets and can not be played with or touched. They can be aggressive. Please don't feed them. Half way down is nice tourist and souvenir shop, at the bottom near the car park is reasonable catering and clean toilets. To stand at the tip of a continent and look out towards Antarctica is something special. When then went to the cape of good hope and famous sign which informs you that the south - western point of the African continent, You are constantly on your watch to capture thatone shot of the camera. Words cant explain the beauty of nature.

Cape Point - nerve tip where Indian and Atlantic oceans converge. Visited Diaz Beach : beautiful stretch of pristine white sand beach with enticing waves for surfers. A place to feel the wind in one's hair and the exhilaration of the crashing waves. The local baboons are filled with curiosity, but for our visit, simply explored and innocently investigated.
breathtaking. a must see place. a great walk and picture perfect location. i would say a wonder of the world. take cameras, good walking shoes.

not so good dec 2015. We love this reserve and have visited several times, especially like to walk behind diaz beach. Had a bad visit this year as 1. the traffic entering was horrific, queues of 30-60 mins just to get in. Cape Town is dreadfully busy between Xmas and New Year so if you visit then , go as early as possible in the day and 2. There has been a massive fire, lightening strike and the vegetation is severely damaged now so not nearly as pretty as on previous visits. Did, however , see 2 groups of bonteboks which felt very special.
Surprising. The park has more to offer than meets the eye initially.Go as early as possible to make the most of it. Many people visit , it can become rather busy at the entrance.

Make a day of it. Cape Point is hard to reach as a tourist, as there's no transport there. You'll need a car or a tour group, and it's a whole day trip from the city. Make the effort, it's a wonderful day out. It's absolutely exquisite, the cliffs and the ocean and the abundance of fynbos are very special to Cape Town. And it's a worthwhile day trip. Travel over Chapmans Peak, and stop for a drink in Kalk Bay on the way home. This is one of my favourite areas of Cape Town.

Incredible view. Wear walking shoes and remember the suntan lotion and hats - it was baking hot in December. We climbed the path and steps to the old light house and then on the way down took the path to the point for the most incredible panoramic view. Look out for the black lizards who pose for photographs. Our local and international crowd, consisting of adults and the children of mixed ages, loved the day. We bought pizzas from the shop next to the restaurant which were small but tasty. Take your own water if possible as it is expensive to purchase from the shop.
The End of the World (almost). A good place to experience the nature and beauty of the cape. The possibility to see some wildlife. Get there early to avoid the queues.

Absolute bliss. Cape Point nature reserve is a bit of everything...historical, beauty, peacefull and simply adored by the whole family. Pleasent spots of 'private' beach, lots of shells to admire and views all around that blows the mind!
Amazing views and walks. Take a picnic and walk down to a secluded cove for a perfect half day out. Funicular to the top for amazing views.
Stunning!. Keep your eyes peeled for ostrich, antelope, tortoises, and more. Beautiful setting at the tip of Africa.

View depending on weather. I found this an expensive visit and ended up being a bit of a waste of money due to the weather on the day, which means we could hardly see anything in terms of a view being the highlight. I saw spectacular reviews of this being highly recommended, but found it quite crowded at the top lighthouse with nothing to do other than stand next to a post for a picture (if you get a chance) You can buy a ticket for the ride up but we took the walk. Lots of stairs to burn off holiday calories!

Wonderful. A most amazing attraction. Beautiful views all around and many interesting walks to take. Standing at the lighthouse offers wonderful panoramic views of the ocean and shoreline. Possibility of seeing baboons, but keep doors and windows closed at all times.

Incredible views! Well worth the drive from Cape Town!. Traveled from Cape Town for the day to visit Cape of Good Hope National Park. We got there early afternoon - made a few stops along the way for pictures - and the staff told us the parking lots for Cape Point were full, so they were letting one car in, for every car out. We thought we were going to have to wait forever, but it only took about 15 minutes to get in to the park. After park entrance, you drive another 10 minutes or so to get to parking for Cape Point. There is an incline car to take visitors to the top of the mountain for a fee, but we chose to walk up, stopping along the way at certain points to take photos. The walk up was a bit challenging, so make sure you have proper footwear, as well as sunscreen if you're there on a sunny, hot day! We were also there during the "table mountain cloud," so once we got to the top, the visibility was very poor, as you are IN THE CLOUDS :) We were initially very disappointed, but if you just wait a few minutes- we did about 15 minutes - the clouds pass and you'll the incredible views. You can walk to the top and see views from the lighthouse, but we really recommend doing the lighthouse keepers walk to get to the southern most point- those are the most incredible views. Staff says to beware of baboons, but we actually didn't see any.MUST SEE if in Cape Town!

Beauty around each turn. No matter how many times we take the trip down to Cape Point, one never tires from the scenic beauty. Visiting during different seasons makes you appreciate the changes in the natural environment. If can avoid the summer rush do visit around October, November. There hasn't been much annual rains so whilst it isn't as green as usual it's a worthwhile trip. Smokers are encouraged to be cautious about where they discard cigarette butts and matches because the vegetation is highly flammable.

CAPE TOWN'S GEM. When visiting Cape Town, Cape Point Nature Reserve has to be on the list of things to do! Blue skies, panoramic views, hiking trails, scenic walks, wild life ie. baboons, ostrich, beautiful beaches, beautiful drives. An absolutely magical day out. You can either pack your own lunch as there are numerous spots to picnic or braai/barbacue or Cape Point does offer a restaurant which in my opinion is very touristy and I prefer to bring lunch with as a local!
Beautiful views. Went to the top. Saw the penguins. No baboons but supposedly they are thugs and worth watching out for unless you want your bags stolen (they look for food).
Stunning Natural Beauty. Fantastic afternoon out surrounded by nature and awesome views. Will definitely visit again and spend more time visiting other areas of the nature reserve.
Beautiful. Make sure you go all the way to the end and hike to the lighthouse. If you stop before you miss the best views.

A must see when staying in Cape Town. Just over an hour's drive south of Cape Town via one of the most scenic (Chapman's peak) drives in the world, Cape Point is nothing short of spectacular. Come at the right time of year (July - November) & see whales in the bay & the views across the ocean are just superb! All in all, a great day out which you can combine with the penguins at Boulders just north of Simon's town.
Natural beauty.. This destination is super windy and can be chilly, then hot! Bring layers so you are always comfortable, and shoes for hiking to make sure that you can properly enjoy everything.

Fantastic Place. Brilliant place to go for the day, lots of different walks around Cape point with some lasting an hour an half, best to get a car out and spend the day there, you also have Cape of good hope to visit

Good view. As we were a bit short in time, we decided to take the funicular, which represents a nice experience.Once arrived, you still have a couple of stairs to climb before you reach the highest viewpoint.The view over south landscape is splendid, a big electric pole avoids nice photo towards north splendid landscape.

Windy but worth it!. Cape Point, once thought to be the most Southern tip of Africa, is well worth a visit. The curio shops at pretty good, coffee is average, but the views from the lighthouse are spectacular. It can be very windy, so dress warmly.

Beautiful . You dont get to see beautiful views every time. But when you get you must enjoy it. The meeting point of two oceans , the directions of different places just beautiful. Words cant explain the beauty of nature

Lovely place to visit from Cape Town. We took a circular ride from Cape Town to Cape Point Nature Reserve. The views are spectacular, small towns are interesting along the way, and the lighthouse is a great attraction in the park. Be sure to look for the baboons.
Spot the animal. What a nice way to spot birds and animals. You are constantly on your watch to capture that one shot of the camera.

Beautiful views. Cape Point is an easy drive from Cape Town and worth a visit. We passed a family of ostriches on the road which was really lovely, the views are great and it's a lovely place to walk around and take in the fresh breezy sea air.

Stunning Scenery. There are a number of companies in Cape Town that will drive you there and back - and to other interesting places en route. It's certainly well worth the money and generally they get you there early so any queue to enter the park is minimised. The scenery is stunning in the sun but must be bleak in winter and when the wind blows. Take your time wandering along the footpaths to appreciate the views and the wildlife.

A Must See When in Cape Town!. Cape Town has so many beautiful places to visit but Cape Point was definitely a must see!We arrived as soon as the Nature Reserve opened as to avoid traffic. The line can get pretty backed up entering the park. We started off with grabbing a bite to eat at the restaurant on site. Luckily, we didn't have a long wait but was told its common. Its a hefty walk to get to the actual point of the two oceans so pace yourself! The walk is full of beautiful views of mountains and the ocean; absolutely gorgeous! We casually strolled the whole way and ended up spending half the day there when it was all said and done. I'd definitely suggest consulting with the weather before going. Also, be on the lookout for baboons! We saw a bunch when leaving the park.

Fantastic view - A must visit. The drive, the scenary and the road to the cape point reserve is awesome. It is worth the drive all the way from the city, There is also a take out area, a very good restaurant and a gift shop. Parking is available .Beware of the Baboons...

Heaven on Earth.................. A place of natural beauty. A must when visiting Cape Town, ZA. Lovely beaches, Baboons, Mountains, a Lookut accessed by Funicular Train and the Cape Of Good Hope for the holiday must photo......

An afternoon well spent. The two points - Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope are a must but keep enough time to wander and explore the other areas and around there. the baboons provided a lot of entertainment as well!!

Very jam to get in but still worth it.. This park is very strange because there are no trees. It's a mountain range with greenery and a lot of rocks. This is supposedly because there is so much wind that the vegetation cannot grow. There is a fence around the park because there are a lot of animals like ostrich, zebra etc in the park. Unfortunately on the day we came, we couldn't see any animals at all.  We arrived at 11.30am and the way to enter the park was amazingly long! Traffic was bumper to bumper. One has to enter the park to get into the Cape of Good Hope. They say the queue is only during this time of the year at the height of the tourist season. We were very disappointed because at the end of the queue we realized that there was no electricity in the park and we couldn't have lunch even though we had the reservation and the funicular was not working. Some of the views in the park were amazing. The reason is because of the different blueness of the ocean. Also there are these distant mountains with the clouds on the mountains. Natural views like these are priceless.

fantastic view - must see. The Cape Point park is an amazing experience as the view from the lighthouse is just stunning. You better come with hiking shoes and take the advice from locals. You can easily queue for 1-2 hours in high season around noon if you want to enter the park but if you show up early it is 15 minutes. The photo at cape of good hope is nice but the walk around the cape point lighthouse and the cliffs is breathtaking. Actually the monkeys were a real threat in the past but this year we have not even seen one.

Overnight hike to Cape Point. So instead of driving, we decided to hike the overnight trail staying in the huts. So after being dropped off and dropping off our bags to be portered ( well worth the expense) we set out on the well marked trail. We had made arrangements to stay in the cabins well before. Lovely views and well maintained trail the entire way. Lots of elevation. Some confusion when we got to the cabins as it seemed the place was a bit deserted. Abandoned buildings concerned us but we did find the right place after wandering around a bit. And our bags were there. 3 separately locked rooms, bathroom, bunkroom. Wed dropped our packs and set out for the point. The trail on the map was not so easy to find and was quite rugged but we made it. Opted to take the funicular to the top and then walked to Diaz point, beautiful. At this point we had hiked over 14 miles and maybe 3k feet of elevation gain so we thought walking down the road might be best. Which it was and a lot shorter it seemed. By luck we were met by the people who maintain the huts who were just checking up on us. They showed us how to operate the hot water which was lovely to shower in. We braiied up some meat and had a very sound sleep. Next day the trail took us by the ocean which was gorgeous. Lots of elevation in the last kilometer so be prepared. Finally done, picked up our bags which were waiting and were on our way. All in all an outstanding trek.

A great days outing. To really enjoy Cape Point takes a few hours. The drives and the scenery are well worth the visit. Drive down to Cape Point itself and go on the Funicular is an experience itself, The views are spectacular. There is also a take out area, a very good restaurant and a gift shop. Parking is available .Beware of the Baboons and do NOT feed them. They are dangerous.

Really stunning!. This is a beautiful park and you should really take your time. There is so much to see. Plan to spend there a whole day and my advice is to be there when the gates open. If you can - walk the numerous routes, especially down to the beach. Take plenty of water and use UV protection! Apart from your camera, I would highly recommend also taking binoculars.
Beautiful scenic drive and fantastic view. Really enjoyed the drive to Cape Point. The waves were spectacular, and the views were stunning at the end...I'll forever remember this place!
Stunning. Very special place. Imagine the ships battling to round the cape of storms. If yiu are lucky you will able to spot whales.

Breathtaking views, crashing waves. Well worth a trip. If you are a hiker, you can spend days here. If you have limited time you can take the Flying Dutchman cable car to the top (for the lazy or infirm) and wander down from there. There is an excellent restaurant where you can make the most of the views as well.

Worth the trip. The sights are worth the trip. Surprising to us was how good the food was at the crowded tourist restaurant. Great shrimp, langoustines and bisque. good wine selection. Really good service.Don't let the crowds of tourist cause you not to go there.

Great views, do your research before driving. This drive is beautiful but there is so much that is missed if you just drive in, get to the point, then turn around and go home. Research all the small beaches and game areas and leave lots of time so you aren't rushed.
Unforgettable beauty. One should be a writer to describe feeling that touches you when you "Mountains above, Earth's, Ocean's plain below".

Fantastic. If you're in Cape Town, either hire a car or book yourself on a tour of the Cape Point peninsula, for it's absolutely fantastic. From Cape Point to Boulders beach and Simon's Town, on a nice day, which in summer seems to be the norm in Cape Town, you'll be treated to amazing sceneries throughout the trip.

Great views. We drove through the park to the point at the end where we parked. You can get the cableway up the hill or walk (about 10 minutes). Good views from the top. There was a fast food restaurant and a dining restaurant.

Experience the Cape of Good Hope and maybe even see some wildlife!. It's a bit of a drive from Cape Town, but the landscape and the views are stupendous. At the old lighthouse look for the walking trail that extends another 30 minutes to nearly the very tip and overlooks the new lighthouse at the lower elevation. We saw baboons and two ostrich in the reserve, but I also spotted seals or sea lions diving in the breakers below the lighthouse.

Breathless: 2 Trips yet could not get enough of it. Cape Point (and not the Cape of Good Hope) is THE attraction in CapeTown. I made two trips, once in a cab and the other Self-driving. Self-driving is highly RECOMMENDED. For one, car rentals are cheaper in CapeTown. One can get a car in R800 for the day, cabs costs 1100R upwards.Coming to CapePoint: The drive can take you via multiple routes and so can the return. The Best route is to go via the drive over Muzinberg, onto Simon's Town (stopover at Boulder Beach for the Penguins) and then onto CapePoint. Return should be via the other side of the Cape, and DEFINITELY via Chapman's Peak into CapeTown. We crossed Chapman's peak when the clouds had set in and its wonderful (the drive has a small toll - 40R). When Entering the Cape Point Park: The first stop can be the Cape of Good Hope. Its nothing spectacular, just the signage that you are at the Southern-Westernest Point in Africa. The real deal is Capepoint, 10 minutes ahead. Capepoint has 3 main things to do: (a) The light house on top (b) The Trail going being the light house onto the tip of the point and (c) another trail going down the greenish beach type area. Unfortunately on both my trips, I could not do (c), as it got late. I would plan to go early and be at cape point max by 11 AM and spend the entire day. If you have a car, there are so many nice "small roads" leadning upto virgin beaches once you are inside the park (Park fee is 125R, per head btw). I strongly recommend (a) Self Driving (b) Spending a good 4-5 hours and (c) Returning via Chapman's Peak. And a decent GPS navigator and co-driver :-) Enjoy the ride !!
Majestic. A great place for a family outing, For locals it's quite pricey.. but then again most places seem to placed outside the reach of the average local man..

Variety in one spot!. My friend and I arrived at the Cape of Good Hope gate hoping to catch sunrise. Unfortunately the gates only open at 6am. Once in the park we made our way to the main visitor's centre car park where we then headed off on the Cape of Good Hope trail. We spent the better part of the morning on this trail and looped back to the visitor's centre and lighthouse via the overnight hut trail. Quite a climb but so worth it for the views (take lots of water and wear hiking boots as this trail is quite technical). After the hike we took the funicular up to the lighthouse and explored the top of the hill - this is a great activity for all ages. Finally the heat won and we made our way down to Dias Beach for the afternoon. This secluded beach was fantastic, and we were the only one's there - the stairs deterring most from taking advantage of this natural beauty. We enjoyed watching a seal swim along the waves before heading back to the car. A very pleasant day out in natural beauty that I would recommend to all visiting the Cape.

Spectacular views. Good to get out of the city and an easy drive. Great for couples or friends. The views are truly spectacular and the walk is not too far after taking the tram up.. The restaurant there is great as well

On of the most beautiful spots in the world. Cape Point is a must for every visitor to CPT. If you want your peace go there in the early morning by Car, before the Coaches with the tourists arrive. You can easy spend a day in there. there are also some nice hiking tracks. Beware of the baboons, they can become dangerous they are not shy anymore, because they know Tourist --> Food :-) The Cape Point reserve is also full of Wildflowers and some Ostriches.

It is a must but very Nikon spot.. You would like to visit once in your lifetime Cape Point.But it is very crowdy. The park is nice. We saw the "other"zebraBut take the circle road. So go enjoy the Cape Point and take some time to spot the zebra

I guess you have to go there. Although it's not the sothernmost point of Africa it is a great viewing spot, although quite a drive, try and combine it with Hout Bay, Chapmans Peak drive & Boulder Beach (penguins), stop off for a late lunch at the Brass Bell.

South African roadtrip . You must visit here.about an hour and half drive from capetown. The fee is very reasonable. It's very easy to do yourself. We parked up by the gift shop and restaurant and walked 3 hrs return to the cape but you can drive directly upto it. Be warned it can get busy and if you get there when a tour bus pulls up get ready to use your elbows.PS the walk is moderate but we'll worth it with views over the beach.
Nature how it should be lovely. You will need a car to do this. Or strong legs if you cycle.Just BEAUTIFUL. Can't say more,only make it a MUST SEE on your list

Just Beautiful. After paying the entrance fee, we drove along a wonderfully scenic road, constantly looking for roving animals, saw ostrich and bok of some kind. The walks were lovely up to the lighthouse, although it does get quite busy with what seemed like coaches of Japanese trying to take a picture of anything.Could have spent alot longer there but so'much to see, other little roads to pools, scenery was stunning.

incredible vista. we were lucky on a day with now wind and clear blue skies
terrific. No many people as out of season. Always and again worth going

Two great nights in a cottage.... We booked one of the 3 cottages for 2 nights and enjoyed staying over. We did our own catering...took our own food and drink. It's an easy drive to Cape Point and Good Hope from within the park and in each case we were able to beat the crowds by being on site early.The cottage is pleasantly furnished and well worth a stay. So...don't just visit the place and go back the same day. Take a cool box and book a cottage and enjoy the experience.

nature is spectacular. Amazing the Symbiose of the MotherCity, the Nature as close as it can get to a City. I have never seen it that impressive and it's great to go for a trail run or just a hike, take a basket with a bottle of reddish and enjoy the views

Beautiful beaches and relaxing day in nature. Come on a sunshine day, skip the restaurant at the lighthouse that is overpriced, and pack some sunscreen and picnic goodies. Lots of braai facilities off the tourist route that is at the waters' edge. Bring own wood.
Beautiful feeling at the end of the world. This place is absolutely amazing, The view as you get on the top is breathtaking - You can either walk or take the cable - but walking is lot more fun.
Great view in Africa's land's end.... The Cape Point area is so very impressive . It is truly nature at its best. The view is wonderful and if try hard enough you can imagine seeing Antarctica...

An Historic Landmark. We drove to Cape Point and took one of the well-signed walking paths over to the Cape of Good Hope. The walk (about 3kms) was interesting through native fynbos and the view from the heights of the Cape of Good Hope was impressive. We walked back and then drove down to the Cape of Good Hope along the seaside road to take our photos against the sign. There is more spectacular scenery along the coast but this place has a particular historical significance. so we wanted to follow in the steps of the early explorers. There is an interesting interpretive centre a few kilometers from Cape Point which gives interesting information on the local flora and fauna.

Plenty to see and do. The V&A never disappoints. Always a flurry of activity, even during non-tourist times. Jam packed with restaurants and gorgeous harbour and mountain views. Try a boat ride, the wheel or a visit to the aquarium. Of course there are plenty of shopping opportunities, high end shops to craft and curios. The V&A has ample parking available. An excellent way to spend a few hours.
Spectacular Scenery. Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope are truly beautiful. The views and beaches are stunning. Ostriches on the sea shore and baboons mad it even more special

The most stunning ocean views!. Cape point is simply stunning. The drive to Cape Point through the mountains is so scenic and you will see amazing rock / mountain formations, beautiful flora and then of course the most beautiful ocean views and you can see huge kelp beds in the clear blue water. There is a lovely walk to a viewing area at the top of the Cape, or there is a trolly you can take if you aren't up for the walk. If you love the ocean visiting Cape Point is a must do!

Fantastic flowers and other wildlife. The primary attraction is the Cape itself, which involves driving through the park to the southern end and then taking a funicular railway for about 10 minutes - and then there is a walk uphill to the viewpoint. Alternatively if you want to walk out to the lighthouse, which is lower down, you take a different path but I never found out which one. Make sure you investigate this thoroughly before you start. There are plenty of side roads in the park which take you through areas of vegetation and some of them go down to the sea. You have good chances of seeing antelope and ostriches, and we saw an elephant seal at Oliphants Bay. It should have been in the Falkland Islands, we think. So don't expect to see one - although it's not the first time one has been seen there.

An amazing sight to see. There is a beautiful drive from the gates,and if you are lucky you wil see some animals. There is ample parking where you can either walk or take the cable car up to the top. Where there is the most magnificent view from all angels.

Well worth your time and effort!. We went here early in the morning, and it's possibly the best time to go. There is a steep walk up the cliff to the main viewpoint area, so wear comfortable shoes. There is an electric cart for taking people up the mountain, but the walk is part of the adventure. Prepare to spend at least 2 hours here, and certainly make sure you take the small walking routes around the mountain area, especially the narrow path towards the far end of the peninsula. And be prepared to take lots of pictures. It''s extremely popular, but never becomes so crowded that you would not go there; it is really time worth spending.

Nice view across the sea. Firstly it's very expensive for South Africans to enter the park people at the gate not to friendly, watch out for the baboons do not feed them they are big, take the tram up to the top and have a nice view of Cape point a must do
Take the tram. I did not know there was a tram, and yiu save yourself some time and energy especially if you're going to walk to the end. It's definitely worth it. Great gift shop.

Better sign posts needed. After spending the night at the fantastic Scarborough beach i paid at the Cape NR gates its a long ish nice quiet drive to the point shops where you get the train to the top of the hill 'lighthouse' i never saw the train going up everyone walked up the hillThe best bit for me was the right hand turning to the cape of good hope point and beach very nice

One of the Best Landmarks in Africa!. I have visited this park twice in 30 years and have noticed the traffic has increased to be sure. But the entire peninsula is very interesting historically, and especially for photographers. I hiked the trails to the Cape Point Lighthouse and enjoyed every turn of the trail and view of the beautiful Atlantic/Indian Ocean even when it was overcast. A true must see!

Well worth doing. This is a must do visit if in Cape Town and of course most people do it. The views of the ocean and the cliffs are stunning. We took the funicular up to the top and walked down. There are also paths along the coastline/cliffs towards Cape of Good Hope that you can walk if you have someone to pick you up there.

The most romantic point in Cape. The view will mesmerize you and you would never want to come back. Ensure you have your shoes on because you have to walk up to the point. The wind at times can be strong. The mist from the ocean will make you speechless and just admire nature's beauty.

Wonderful walk and views. The walk up to Cape Point followed by the walk to the Cape of Good Hope is just great and I thoroughly recommend it.To stand at the tip of a continent and look out towards Antarctica is something special. it is not arduous therefore suits both young and old.

Heavenly views of ocean and mountain, a little pricey though. We visit Cape Town every year, however this was the first time we visited Cape Point as we have always felt that it was pricey.
