It's R125 pp to enter and another R58 to use the Funicular. If you enjoy beautiful ocean and mountain views and especially photography then it is definitely worth the price. There are several routes you can drive through to get to different points. Visit the Lighthouse and the most south west point in Africa. I didnt'spot any marine life so that was a little disappointing but beautiful none the less.They have a beautiful restaurant (Two Oceans) which is a must if you're visiting. Also pricey but worth the experience.
Worth It. Stunning ocean views along the road to the Cape and worth the hike to the top near the lighthouse. Baboons everywhere. The Two Seas restaurant highly recommended with a reservation.

Go TouchDown took us to Cape Point and our restaurant was INCREDIBLE TOO!!. This was just one of the numerous highlights of our amazing trip with Go TouchDown tours, they thought of everything!!! Thank you!!
Beatiful views. We had beatiful and clear weather. Go there early in the morning as later in the day many busses visit Cape point and Cape of Good Hope..
Natural vistas. Don't miss one of nature's finest. You need about three or four hours if you want to do it justice. Beware of the baboons!

another highlight. Cape Point. Iconic! We took all day to travel here from Cape town and it was worth it. It was not so far from Cape town but we were fortunate to be in a private minibus and stopped at several places on the way to enjoy the experience.It was to be an amazing sight as we walked to the lighthouse and looked out over the meeting of the Indian and Atlantic Oceans. Who would have thought we would ever be so lucky?

Point of interest. This beautiul reserve offers a fynbos kingdom where one can hike, cycle or drive to enjoy the vistas. A supeb restaurant will quench your thirst and hunger. Or pack a picnic basket to ejoy at one of the beaches - weather pemitting of course.Ideal for those who love nature.

Another must-do. You can spend an entire day exploring or just make a quick 90 minute stop. I went twice in my 3 month stay in Cape Town and I could have gone many more times. I never got sick of standing on Cape Point and looking at nothing but ocean. Don't skip it, its a great experience to feel like you are at the edge of the world.

Just gorgeous. When choosing to visit South Africa, I expected to see Lions, Elephants, Giraffes etc. But on the drive to Cape Point from Cape Town, I saw penguins, whales, sea lions, and amazing birds--no safari needed! Awesome.

Amazing experience. A must visit to Cape Town. The view is stunning and the experience is amazing. Visitors should be aware that there is an entrance fees to the park and additional charges to use the furnicular train. The only complaint or room for improvement is for the National Park to consider waiving the entrance fees of cab drivers, who are doing them a favour by bringing the visitors.
Do it!. You cannot come to Cape Town and not do this visit end off! You see so much and to be in the Cape of Good Hope is one of the reasons anyone would come here!

Not what it seems. Of course it's not. The Point is not the Cape and the Cape is not where the two oceans meet. That's Cape Agulhas! Still worth a visit but tends to get packed with coach loads of tourists. Stunning cliff views and seabirds from the right viewpoints.
Unmissable. One of the place to tick off the bucket list. Unspoilt and scenic. Several point to view the scenery.
Stunning!. We did a bustour ariound the mountains and coast. Stopped at beautifull places, the highlights cape of good hope. Pinguins, lunch, all was well organized and worth while!

Special views, allow 5 hours. Cape Point should be a scenic highlight on any holiday itinerary. The nature reserve itself is beautiful with plenty of photo opportunities. Take your time. Take a picnic and enjoy it on one of the beaches. It gets very windy at times, but the weather never ruins the feeling of standing at a tip of the continent. On the slow drive back, consider stopping in Simonstown for the penguins and in Kalk Bay for a meal (Harbour House, Cafe Olympia). Best to make a long lazy day of it.

Beautiful scenery. We hired a driver to take us to this area. We stopped at Boulder park to see the Penguins (great!) then onto the Reserve for great walks at the lighthouse and down to the cape of good hope. It was Very windy, knocked us off the walkway at some points! Then a drive to the waterfront. A bit touristy, but great views. Worth a visit.

Nice outing for a day. Lovely views from the lighthouse. Do drive down to the carpark at the Cape of Good Hope. While going or returning, must take the Chapman Peak Drive, which is divine. Hout Bay, and the penguins at Simon Town (Boulders) are worth stopping at.
Beautiful! . Wow, beautiful place, view, very recommended. We walked till the edge and the view amazing! Have to go in a good weather day.
Cape of Goof Hope. The visit to the Cape Point is a must to see the joining of 2 oceans. The views are spectacular and a photographers dream. A must visit!

Its a long drive but worth it to say you've been !!. Its a long drive out to the Cape :Point. There were hundreds of bus tours there too. The usual souviner shops. There are places to get a drink and something to eat.

Highlight of trip to Cape Town. During a short 4-day trip to Cape Town, the visit to Cape Point Nature Reserve was the highlight for me. We had a hire car and so were able to arrive at Cape Point early, in fact we were first there. We walked up to the lighthouse and had the place to ourselves to take photos. On our return to the car park we had a lovely breakfast on the outside patio of the restaurant, the food was great and very reasonably priced. With the rental car we were able to take all the side roads and visit all the beaches and points of interest in the park. On an orgainzed tour, some of the side roads are not visited. We spent all day in the park. It;s a fantastic area for hiking, beaches, wildlife viewing etc. Definitely a place not to be missed on a trip to the western cape.

Not really a big deal if missed it. This was probably the most touristy spot we went to and also not that great.Taking a walk out to the old lighthouse was the best part. Great views and a place to get away from all the tourists as most do not venture out to it. I am glad I went but it was not as much of a experience as I thought it would be.

head for heights. Enjoyed the walk to the light house, reasonably strenuous but take your time and it is breathtaking. Great views all round. Very touristy. Drive in from the paid entrance was beautiful, with diverse flora and the odd animal. Get your camera out.
Beautiful!. Although crowded, Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope are a must see when travelling to Cape Town! Spectacular views and nice trails to walk around
Stunning views. Bottom of the African continent! We had a car, so we were able to come and go as we wanted. Spent a few hours near the lighthouse (pretty crowded!)

One of those places that is at every person's bucket list. I have always wanted to visit Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope. Therefore, it was a wish of a lifetime granted when I had the opportunity to visit the place. It is scenic in a way I cannot describe. I enjoyed the trail to the new Lighthouse especially at the place where it narrows just directly in front of the old Lighthouse. You could hear the Atlantic Ocean's stormy waters knocking on the cliffs below and the on the other side, a silent and pacific False Bay. It was a contrasting feature and gave me an understanding why Bartholomew Diaz and the rest called the place the Cape of Good Hope. Quite idyllic and ideal for any one. There is a cable car that carries those that are not physically capable of making the trek to the old Lighthouse and the entrance fees not prohibitory.

A wonderful reserve at the tip of the Cape Peninsula. Friends, family and I have visited the CPNR many times and each time it has been a positive and relaxing experience. We typically go bird-spotting, but have also experienced the restaurant which has supplied great breakfasts and fine-dining lunches. Also a lot of history to learn about the area in the nicely designed visitor center. Well worth a visit!
Stunning. Great day trip with stunning views. Very interesting trip to drive around the Cape and see the different communities and nature.
The bottom of Africa!. A long drive but well worth it. Great walks and views from the lighthouse. Wear appropriate footwear to go on the paths and beware cheeky birds who try to steal your food.

Breathe Takingly Awesome!!. What a Majestic, Ethereal , Avatar moment!! the park is spectacularly beautiful, the baboons are crazy and WILL snatch your goodies!!.... the Scenery is the most unreal, breathing...until we did a safari 3 days later!! the Cormmorants look like a scene from Avatar, soaring from the crags in the cliffside over the water and crashing waves below....mezmorizing!! Wow!! Not to be missed!! Dramatically Spectacularly....Nature!!! and we met a beautiful ostrich roadside while leaving.... posed like the Supermodel that he was for us, by the sea! What a glorious day!

BEAUTIFUL!!!! A must see if you are going to the Capetown area!. This was a serious highlight of my trip. Not only the drive down from Capetown to Cape Point, but the natural beauty within the national park. From the first moment I arrived and pulled my car to the side of the road, I started spotting whales from the hilltop. What a beautiful, natural beauty. I can't wait to return.

Well worth the journey - spectacular views. Even though we had to queue for a long time to get into the reserve, it was really worth the wait. We walked up the light house first, then along the route that takes you much further out along the point. It was quite busy at those sites, but the walk to the Cape of Good Hope was quieter and just as beautiful. If you like walking then I recommend doing a full day trip rather than cramming this in on a rushed tour.

secluded beaches!. Cape point is a great place to drive to! Yes, you must see the cape of good hope and take a touristy pic with the sign and if you want the funicular to the lighthouse but, don't miss out on the secluded and beautiful beaches and the sea water pools!

Beaufiful scenery and flora. Amidst the beaufiful scenery and flora were long queues to gain access to the Reserve and also hordes at the main points of interest. Quite simply a victim of its own success.

A meeting of two oceans. Stunning scenery and a dramatic finish at Cape Point with the seas crashing into the shore. The area is a national park and is home to many plants found nowhere else in the world. Definitely worth a visit.

Majestic Setting, Stunning Scenery. We thoroughly enjoyed our trip to Cape Point Nature Reserve. The coastal scenery in simply stunning and the views are excellent. The visit to the lighthouse enables you to gain a good perspective of the area. We were lucky to enjoy a late spring day, which was sunny and clear. A worthwhile inclusion on any itinerary to Cape Town.Thanks for your vote if you found this review helpful.

Dip your toes in the water here!. The drive from Capetown was gorgeous and well worth it, if you can do it. We took the Funicolar train up to the cafe and walked the rest of the way to the old lighthouse. The walk is worth it, as the views are amazing. Then we took the side road which took us to the exact point of the Cape of Good Hope. A very short drive away was a beach where we parked so I could say I actually dipped my toe in the water of the the Cape of Good Hope. The drive through the park was very comfortable with almost no cars, so it was leisurely and we could stop to take pictures whenever we wanted. I'd say rent a car and take the drive yourself. It wasn't a hard drive, and you get a whole lot more independence thatway.

Stunning. Please do the lighthouse first then the cape point and search for seals on the shores of cape point. It was chilli but also rather packed so photos are taken in turns at the base area that is why i suggest the lighthouse for a stunning view of all things.
Stunning scenery. The scenery and the countryside are well worth the drive. Be warned: in summer there are apparently long queues to get in.

Good Day Out. It rained the whole time we were here but it did not stop the enjoyment. We walked through the nature reserve, not recommended if your fitness level is low. You see so many plants and animals that would probably be missed and the views are great.

Worth the visit even if it isn't where oceans collide. It's not the furthest-south tip of Africa, not is it actually where the Indian and Atlantic Oceans meet (which varies depending upon weather & currents). But it is a spectacularly-scenic place and the faux romanticism does add something to it.

Dramatic scenery. Cape Point is filled with dramatic scenery, fantastic hiking trails, deserted beaches and reach-for-your-camera views. There's some great bird watching, and in spring you might catch a glimpse of a whale close to shore

Must see!. We were hear on a clear, sunny, warm day and it was just stunning. Watch out for the baboons, though! It is worth hiking down to the beach and watching the giant waves crash ashore. I wish we'd had more time - We had ~2 hours at the park and that wasn't enough.

It should be on your list of locations to visit while in Cape town. It's on a national park, its a lighthouse and visitor centre which can be accessed by a funicular railway or for the more athleticly inclined, you can walk.Not really too much to do there other than look out to sea where the Atlantic meets the Indian ocean. Often windy, avoid if very windy as it can knock you off your feet!! Pricing is a bit expensive but OK if its on your bucket list and as a one off.

Fantastic View and Beach. The Cape Point has an extremely interesting vegetation and wonderful views on landscape and marine area. It is great for hiking or enjoying a bit the seaside with a high probabiliy in November still to see wales. Recommended to take some food and drinking as the restos are quite overcrowded and expensive.

Nice views. It's a nice walk up to the lighthouse and the views are great. I must admit that I thought the difference between the two Oceans would be a bit more spectacular. I might be biased, but Byron Bay leaves it for dead :-)
A must see.excursion.. This park offer great views and also a nature experience. Cape of Good Hope the most south western point of Africa.Cape Point lighthouse.
Spectacular at cliff walk. The vistas at the Southern edge of the world were incredible . The wind and rain made it even more interesting

Beautiful. The landscape is beautiful. 360° view, once you get to the lighthouse.The hiking trail between Cape Of Good Hope and Cape Point is a must.You see so many biodiversity ... Super scenic views.

Nice views . Fantastic views. Well worth a walk around. The funicular railway is nice or alternatively it is a 10 minute walk to the point. Very windy so take a jacket with you. There are nice gift shops on site and worth a visit to the cape of good hope.

A must do if in Cape Town but beware of baboons. to be at the most southern point of Africa is an excellent experience and a beautiful sight but beware at the eating area there are a lot of Baboons and they will come after you for food so if your hungry eat in the restaurant

Must see.. Great ocean views. Wonderful animal sightings- sea lions, penguins, even whales breaching. The whole trip from Cape Town gives a sense of the breadth of the area, its people and the flora and fauna.

Just enjoy the nature. We spent about 4 hours in the park. While there does not appear to be a lot to do, if you just enjoy the environment you will see many different types of plants and animals. A great day out from Cape Town. Well worth the drive.
Must Do!. We loved our trip down to Cape Point - amazing views, beautiful beaches, a really fantastic day trip whilst visiting Cape Town.

Darn the fog!!. Such a unique opportunity to experience the spot where two oceans meet. Unfortunately, the day of our visit was so foggy, we could see little over 20 feet up so we were not able to take the cable car or see the extent of the vistas. We went as a part of a day tour so the trip from Cape Town was interesting. Lots of tour buses and vans on the road and at the attractions which detracted somewhat. No baboons for us on our visit. Guess they don't like the fog either. Curiously, the fog was concentrated at the actual cape park and the rest of the trip was sunny so it seems it might be difficult to predict what you might be riding into in advance.
Not to be missed. A trip to Cape Point & nature reserve is a must for visitors to Capetown. it offers wonderful views over a wide ranging area and a picturesque climb to the summit and back.
A must see when you are there. great nature and daunting waves, you might catch some wildlife too. Entrance is cheap and the views are formidable
Views, nature at its best. Not to be missed. This is why S. Africa is so special. If you are lucky like we were you may even see baboons!!
Like on another planet. The scenic drive there is just breathtaking. Strange flowers, ostriches and baboons on the street, birds all over and the deep blue sea. Just amazing and a must go definitely!

Worth a visit for the views and the unique part of Africa. A must do in Cape Town. Special experience to see the tip of the peninsula. Not much wildlife, unless you are very lucky. Comfortable roads and very safe, but not a "safari"

Fun to see an historic place one has heard of since elementary school. A lovely spot full of history. I enjoyed views, hikes, birds and wildlife. Went with a birding group to search out some endemics to the area.

Beautifull nature and exceptional views. Beautiful; nature and indeed exeptional views on the landmarks Cape Point and Cape of good hope. You can go up with the cable car for the steep last mile for R58.Absolutely worth going all the way for the spectacular views.Before going into the cable car you'll find a restaurant and pizza/sandwich bar close to where you can park your car.

Stunning. This beautiful reserve is simply stunning, the area is covered in colourful shrubs and the views are breathtaking. There is a choice of walking the last leg to Cape Point or taking a funicular. The pathway gets quite congested and it is very crowded at the top. The Reserve is well maintained with good roads and is a must for anyone visiting the Cape.

NOT the most southern point in Africa. Expensive to visit and inaccurate. This area claims to be the most southern point in Africa and is commonly mistaken for the point where two oceans meet (Indian and Atlantic). However, the most southern point of the continent AND where the oceans meet is Cape Agulas. Would recommend visiting Cape Agulas as it is not full of tourists and is FREE! Still, we enjoyed our visit to Cape Point and the surrounding areas i.e Cape of Good Hope.
A must visit spot. Stunning views, breathtaking area. We were ust amazed by what was on offer, will definitely visit again.

Tourist Checklist to tick. The views are amazing here but it is merely something to tick off your list. Grab your passports as you can get it stamped at the visitors desk there. Go early to avoid loooong queues. If you go all the way to the top of the lighthouse, watch out for tiny mosquitos or bugs. There are thousands and they stick to you and refuse to move. Keep your mouth closed I would say.

The top of the bottom of the continent. Take the funicular and then climb to the lighthouse. You see both the Atlantic and Indian Oceans at once! Very unique. Very exciting. Can be very windy and cold. Lots of baboons around too.

great place. Amazing historical place that is a must see.very windy and in winter also cold. Views from the lighthouse are amazing. Take the tram up and have a leisurely walk down . Be careful of the baboons, very aggressive and not afraid. The gif shop at the top has some really good selections and good process too
Great sceenary. fantastic view, pristine landscapes, wildlife and plants, nice walk and relaxing environment - worth to visit!

On the edge of the Earth. The title actually says it all. The feeling of standing at the edge of the Earth, looking down on the ocean waves crashing into the rocks cannot be described with words. It is some mind blowing mixture of "i finally made it" and "look at all that overwhelming power of nature" and "just imagine - there is only Antarctic somewhere in front"... This cocktail, called Cape Point is best sipped slowly enjoying every last drop, because you will never forget it, I promise!

Wild! (Plus Ostriches). A great drive, passing families of baboons and then,,.. traffic jam as we all slowed down to gawp at a full on family of ostriches strolling on the road. Eh?
Oh, the Cape was ok.

Hanging off the end of Africa. One of my favourite places on earth. Go early to avoid the tourist coaches; there are some roads to which they are not allowed access. Visit those and be wowed by the scenery: the beauty of sea, sand and sky. Choose to walk the trails or take a picnic and a book and find a secluded spot. Be sure to take your camera! Several sets of toilets for the call of nature. Look out for Baboons, Eland, Tortoises etc. Take a towel so you can paddle'; swimming is not for the faint-hearted snd check those currents. There's a reason cshops got wrecked here
Amazing!!!. One cannot imagine visiting cape town and not going to the cape point nature reserve. A true wonder...so well maintained and protected.

Great Day Trip from Cape Town. Beautifully rugged scenery is not to be missed. Penguins at Boulders Beach are also a must see stop. Time permitting, hike up to the light house and survey the shoreline below.

More time required. Waited in line for the funicular ride up to the lighthouse to speed things up.This in itself took a while as the attraction was busy.At the top there was still steps to climb to the highest point.The views were very good and could be seen from vantage points lower down.Would have loved to walk down but didn't have enough time.Shop at lower level with good choice of gifts to purchase.

Well worth the trip.. The trip to Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope (located close to each other) was a great experience. We saw seals, African penguins, baboons, ostriches and a terrapin (all in their natural habitat). The scenery is beautiful (even though the weather deteriorated during our visit) and we were very happy that we had booked the trip. On arrival at Cape Point, you can either walk up the lighthouse and great view point or you can opt to use the funicular which costs approx. R70 per person return. There is a restaurant and a gift shop on the location.

Not to miss. We rented a car to drive first to Simons Town to see the Penguins and then down to Cape Point. No need to take guide as path is well marked. Went first to cape of good hope. Beautiful hike up to over point. Saw baboons, ostrich, Dorris, tortoise and plenty of lizards.Entrance fee quite high but worth it on this one of a king journey

Rugged Location. The nature reserve offers hiking trails and stunning views of the raging seas off the coast. The landscape is quite unique and you will not be swamped by people if you hike a bit around the area.
Gorgeous. Seriously lovely. Such amazing views all around. Great wildlife spotting opportunity when we were there as well - Ostrich with a bunch of babies!

great views great coastline. We drove to the entrance of the reserve where you pay the entrance fee. As they only had one credit card machine paying took a long time.It is quite a long drive through the reserve to get to the point car park. We parked easily and walked to the funicular to take us to the point.It is possible to walk but it take about 90 minutes return and we did not have the time.Interestingly The Cape of Good Hope is not the most southerly point, Cape point is.The views are stunning.

Beautiful - Restaurants over priced.. We enjoyed the views and scenery, it was a beautiful experience seeing the different colours of the ocean. People get the wrong impression that Cape Point is where the two oceans meet which is not true. They should know that it is Cape Aguilas. However the staff working there try there best to give you the best service. The only down fall is that the food is really overpriced we had a pizza and for the price it was at we thought we would of got a decent size for two, we however got a pizza which was enough for a child. I would suggest that if you going to this beautiful nature reserve make sure you pack some sandwiches so you dont get hungry.

A true world wonder. I recently visited Cape Point after about 15 years and it is still and even more amazing. We had a good lunch at the restaurant, went up the cable car, put our feet in the sea, saw buck, baboons and monkeys. What a wonderful day. I was exhausted when I got home.

A must go place for anyone visiting Cape Town. The Cape Point Nature Reserve is an absolutely spectacular place. Whether you want to hike around, visit the Cape of Good Hope, see madmen surfing waves, or just sit in the Two Ocean's restaurant for some sushi, everyone visiting Cape Town should make it a point of going to this place!!

Breathtaking views on the southern tip of Africa. This is one of those must-do places for anyone who visits Cape Town - over and over again. It's remote, unspoiled, utterly beautiful and the views are astonishing. Take a camera and an open mind, and just soak it in.

Southern Points. We combined a trip to the point with a visit to the Cape of good Hope. It is a huge national park which you can tour around by car, stopping and starting wherever you wish. We had fine weather so like all parts of this area we had spectacular views all round. The plants were many and varied but as it was spring they were not flowering in all their glory.
Beauty at it's Best. Wonderful and majestic views of the two oceans - Atlantic and Indian Ocean. Some historical perspectives too.

Amazing. I saw the whales, baboons, ostrich, turtles and seals on the way to cape point. I don't need to say more than if you have a few days in Cape Town it is definitely worth taking a day going down to cape point!

Don’t ever miss this beautiful place on earth….. The Drive from Camps Bay to Cape Point is via the Chapman’s Hill Climb, a mountainous climb with many bends and fantastic views. At the time we started, in the Morning, it was shrouded in the Mist. But later it cleared. In the trip, you can stop by at a semi-precious stone factory and by some souvenirs, which are relatively cheap.Cape Point is the extreme southwestern tip of the African continent in the Republic of South Africa. But southernmost point in Africa is Cape Agulhas, approximately 150 kilometers in the East. The entrance fee is quite high, and then you will have to spend again for the funicular and your refreshments. So keep some Rands handy!! Once in the car park, you see the first peak, the peak that has the old lighthouse on the top. You can take the walk up or take The Flying Dutchman Funicular train. Then you can go to the Old light house. If you are more adventurous like me , then you can take the long trek along the seemingly dangerous cliff edges to the new light house , which is at a lower peak. Don’t worry, even me, with my considerable fear of height could make that trip, and believe me, it was worth the while. ( felt a little breathless on the way up. But OK if you take it slowly )Views from the two light houses and the trek to the new light house are out of this world and a MUST for any nature lover/ Photographer. It seems so remote and utterly beautiful and the best I have seen in SA. Make sure you have enough batteries as you will feel like clicking and clicking.. I don’t advice the trek to the new lighthouse if there is a mist.There are many souvenir shops and restaurants. We decided to go to the best, the Two Oceans. Cape Point is a place on this planet, so full of indescribably magnificent and unbelievably beautiful scenes that I will never forget till the last day of my life…..DONT MISS IT

Away from the world. I remember visiting as a child. When I returned last year, very little had changed. Maybe a few more seating areas and better ablution, but still well cared for and natural.The trip to the point was thrilling! The walk, the ride to the top, the view, the history. I was in my element. So much history was put into perspective, and my appreciation for nature increased exponentially! The crosses, the flora and fauna. Unspoilt.
Good way to Spend A Day While Visiting Cape Town. Take full day tour. I used African Eagle Tours. Price was $62 U.S. for full day tour. Most other touring companies charge at least double the amount.

A gem in the Western Cape. It was our second time here and it was as beautiful as the first. We went up to the lighthouse via the funicular and walked back down on foot. It was quite a misty day but the endless view of the South Atlantic ocean made up for an otherwise grey afternoon. There were lots of baboons and a few ignorant tourists who kept on giving food to the animals. The shops were well stocked with some beautifully crafted items, the price were good and didn't feel that it was a rip off which is often the case in souvenir shops in tourist spots. We had lunch at the Two Oceans but it was a hit and miss, we definitely had better food when we went there the first time for breakfast. If you have time and the weather is nice do a detour and head down to the Cape of Good Hope, close to Diaz beach for a walk and picnic.

Great for the sights, even better if you love gale-force winds!. The Cape of Good Hope and Cape Point is a Must destination for anyone traveling to Cape Town and the Western Cape area. The drive past Hout Bay is reasonably short and well worth the time. The baboons had just routed the restaurant at Cape Point and were a major nuisance before we arrived, but they were nowhere to be seen 20 minutes later when we got there. The walk up to the lighthouse was doable (holding onto the rails both ways), but, man, the gale force winds at 80mph, with gusts in excess of 100mph, were amazing. I am normally well planted to the ground (at 240 lbs), but the winds really knocked me around, so much so that I had to hold onto a rail with one hand to take a picture with my camera in the other.

The more the wind blows the more spectacular. Our group visited on a nice clear windy day.No animals sighted to and from the point but the ride to the top and back was easy and no waiting. The views from the top of the 2 oceans spectacular and for foreigners being able to see their home town distance on the map a great tourist attraction.
Southern most tip of africa. A nice place to visit, next stop is the Antarctic Ice. Photo opportunity and good views of landscape.
Absolutely beautiful. A Visit to The Cape Point is a must. Most beautiful views, restaurant, walkways, fishing, swimming etc. Good value for money.

Stunning. Awesome place. Entrance fees and food is a bit pricy. Cable car or walk up is both enjoyable. Amazing views and perfect for picture opportunities. Try to go in good weather to fully appreciate the place.
Worth the trip. It's a ways from Cape Town, but worth the trip to see the "end of the Africa." Gorgeous landscape. You either have to drive or take a tour, but it's worth it.

Cape point is awesome. I live in cape town but i must say this is truly an amazing part of the world! There should be tour guides at the point (included in the entrance fee) to tell visitors about the histroy and fauna and flora. Oh the retrurants and shops are so old and cliche. Surley it could be more relevant and world class?But worth visiting for sure.
Great views. Went there on a fabulous sunny and windy day. A must do if you are visiting the cape as the views are excellent

Wonderful scenery. We had a great time at the Cape... spectacular ocean scenery, beautiful small mountains, and a number of pretty coves. The park is well organized and maintained. We even saw a family of ostriches on the side of one of the roads! The funicular is pleasant, if you are not in the mood to hike.

Amazing South Africa. Some of the most amazing scenery in the world. Prepare for some wind, it always seems to be windy...likely the close proximity between the warm water Indian Ocean and the cold water Atlantic. Word of advice, as cute as the penguins are, don't pet them, they peck hard! LOL

The Oceans. Was a dreary and very windy day but it was also very interesting watching the waves crash against the rocks. Walked part way up to the light house and enjoyed all the flora along the way. Also saw several baboons while driving away. Interesting to note this is where the Indian and Atlantic Oceans meet. Not something you see everyday.

Out Of The Way But Worth It. You must take a car or private tour to get here but by all means, do just that. Here you will find true beauty at its finest. To some this is the place that the Atlantic Ocean meets up from both sides of the world. What you will see is plenty of scenery, ostrich's and mountains. A mile away is the famous lighthouse worth the trip up. You won't spend much time here so the lighthouse tour is part of the excursion to come. Enjoy!

Beautiful!. Definitely an interesting experience, though it's ridiculously packed during high season. Don't go expecting anything mind-blowing. Hiking through the beatiful scenery and the spectacular view of the sea is what makes the trip worth it! If you're a feeling a bit on the adventurous side, you could also go for a swim down at the beach near the point and get bragging rights for swimming at the Cape of Good Hope. Though if you do, beware of the sea. There are waves and currents, and the water's very cold.
Where Two Oceans Meat. This is the point where Indian and Atlantic ocean merge. The view from the top of the old light house is beautiful. It is a must see

Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope - see them both. There are 2 points of interest - The Cape of Good Hope and Cape Point, so try to see both and they are actually pretty close to each other inside the Reserve (Cape of Good Hope is on a turnoff from the road leading to Cape Point.)There is an overpriced restaurant at the Cape Point near the car park. I dont suggest to go there, but the views looking back to the Peninsula are fantastic. Go grab a coffee and sit on the deck outside for views of the coastline.The access to the Cape Point is up a hill so be prepared to climb. I did the walk up and down but there is a funicular available. At the top of the hill is one of the two lighthouses which guard the point. The look out point has panoramic views (and even on a bad weather day, it is quite a dramatic view). There is a walkway which leads to the second lighthouse (the one closest to the end of the Peninsula). The path is steep and uneven so do take your time if you intend to go all the way!

Bucket list worthy experience. Visiting Cape Point is definitely a must see when in Cape Town. The Nature Reserve is well-kept and it does my heart good to see that SANPARKS does such a good job of maintaining our National parks.The views from the Lighthouse is breathtaking (be careful of the win). I would recommend taking he Flying Dutchman as it saves you a great deal of time and protects you from the elements.The Cape of Good Hope provides great entertainment as the waves smash onto the cliffs.An ideal day outing!
Not the real lands end. A busy an inspiring view and definitely worth a visit but this isn't the lowest part of Africa as we found out that cape Guysal (or similar) was

Breathtaking views. This is a must-see for any traveler visiting Cape Town! Cape Point has incredible views of the coastline, and it's an amazing feeling to stand on the southern most part of the continent. Also, probably the only place you can find ostriches next to an ocean!
Worth the Trip. Was unsure about making the time to get down there, but glad we did. The scenery is dramatic, see everything and expect to stay all day if the weather is good.

Beautiful, on a clear day do the scenic walk from the lighthouse to the old Lighthouse keeper's house. It's a 15 - 20 min hike from the lighthouse to the former lighthouse keeper's house and another 15 - 20 min back. Yes, you can make it in 20 back & forth , but don't you want to take in the beauty that surrounds you? It's a very scenic walk, that you should not miss. The views from the path over the bay are just breathtaking , depending on the time of year you will find many beautiful flowers on your way. I just loved loved loved this part of the visit. I saws whales surfacing from the water right below me and had a perfect birds eye view in crystal clear water. There were not too many people walking this path. Many got sort of 'stuck' up at the lighthouse, very crowded, so this was a nice relief to get away from the crowds. Must do if the weather is good!!!

Stunning views - Must do while in Cape Town or nearby. Cape Point is an amazing roadtrip while on a vacation to Cape Town. The views from the nature reserve are just amazing. Also you get an opportunity to get a picture with a wooden plaque mentioning that you are at Cape Point which is the South-western most point of continental Africa.There is also a lighthouse at the top which presents spectacular views of the ocean. It can be a bit tiring though if you decide to walk up. So take the funicular train instead - it is not very costly. You can also choose to walk down if you are the adventurous types.If you are lucky enough, you might see wild ostriches near the coast which is an amazing view.
The views are to die for. Beautiful scenery , and parking is next door, i you are in Cape Town than this is also a must.Be safe and enjoy your trip

Nice view. if you are going to cape town, you must go there. Better by car because you will be able to have a pleasant view of the sea shore, driving the nice roads of South African beaches. to get into the reserve you have to pay, it is not free, but I think it worths the price. The view is really amazing.
Visit the "Howling 40s". Beautiful and unique biological terrain, great birding, and a chance to see just what mariners face when trying to navigate through the Cape.

Beautiful and perfect place to see. This place is a MUST!!! A worth trip and see the flora scene, museum, sea, baboons, lighthouse and many more. Don't go there on high season, never enjoy with too many people. Full parking, crowded and annoyed. It'll be much nice if it go there on low season.
Must do!. Amazing on a clear day great for taking pictures and views were spectacular, make sure you wear sutable shoes and the climbs is very safe but not a flip flop affair

Loved the penguins!. There was a long walk from the parking lot to the nature reserve; but it was worth it. The penguins didn't seem as excited to see us as we were to see them. (They need to get to know us better.) The shops near the entrance yielded lots of good deals. Our group was very pleased.

Not to be missed. Take the all day your only if the weather is good. Beautiful scenic costal drive through Chapman Pass. Saw deer, baboon , ostrich and Zebra. Take binoculars. Most southern point of africa.
Great views not to miss. A day trip down the cape is a must if you are in Capetown. The views from the lighthouse and the cape are spectacular.
wonderful. Wonderful beautiful place,with great views,we did not see one baboon but told they are a problem there..breathtaking place but very busy

Stunning Scenic drive, delicious fun lunch with the natty birds and a nature lovers walk, perfect day. The best drive and the most wonderful walk and views - do not miss this!!! We travelled all the way from Capetown to cape point. The cape of good hope, boulders bay, Clifton, the whole circular drive ( just google cape point drive and spend the whole day on this) Wow, trip of a life time. The most incredible drive ( felt I was in one if those car adverts!! ) make sure you stop every one and then to appreciate the views. When you get to the park, you must do the walk between the two points and also dine at the Two Oceans restaurant. Get a front deck seat outside if you can. The birds will try and steal your food, but the waitresses will gently spray then with water to keep them at bay. Lovely meal, not expensive, sea the light housek see the sea!! Enjoy the walk, nature lover, walkers and photographers paradise - ps look out for the baboons and ostriches!! enjoy :-)

Excellent views and short walks.. Well worth the visit to the Cape. Walk to the lighthouse and beyond for fantastic views and sheer cliffs. Get the tram up and walk down if you are short on time or fitness. Watch out for the baboons and don't carry food.
Wonderful waves and beautiful scenery. We visited in July , their winter so was windy and cold but beautiful clear blue skies. Stunning views from all angles. Beautiful place, well worth a visit

Such a lovely place. First time to cape point and unfortunately it was a rainy day. The views were limited and it was a bit miserable getting so wet. That being said it was absolutely amazing. The scenery and some of the animals we came across were stunning. I recommend everyone to take a trip here but leave yourself enough time to go up the railway to the top

The place you learnt about at school. This is a fantastic spot. Read about Vasco Da Gama and Batholomew Diaz and see for yourself where they rounded the Cape in search of the East Indies. A unique spot in the world. Take the ride up the Funicular, great fun and saves you a few steps! great views of the two oceans from the top.

Worth the effort to go. It was a long way to go and a very desolate place, but worth the effort. The waves were amazing the day we went. We spent ages watching the sea birds landing on their nests. There is a little train to tak you from the car park to the point, we walked.
Peninsula tour . Loved it! The guide was so good and talked alot about everything we passed by. Interesting and fun the whole day.

A view.... Its quite a travel getting there and then the view ... its epic! The two oceans meet and the ocean view just goes on... one can get pictures of both the east & west coasts. Wear comfortable trail shoes and take a good camera with.

Worth a Visit. Slow to get into the nature reserve but once through the payment stage good roadway through to the cape. The funicular is a good feature to the top, but it should be made clearer there is still a way to climb once you get off it!! The views on all sides are a must to see!

Not worth the long queues. Yes, yes... it's where the two oceans meet, etc... but really?...
I've been here a couple of times and it never impressed me. :(
Where two oceans meet!. Beautiful spot, lovely being here. It is a short walk from the car park, so easily acessable with a timber walk way and great signs explaining the area.

Worth the visit. This is somewhere you have to visit, do not miss it. We hired a car online before arriving in Cape Town, which was very reasonable. By doing this it gives you the freedom to stop off at some beautiful sites on your route, stunning.

Long way to go, but worth it. We made a day out of the long trip south to Cape Point and did Boulders beach on the way to see the penguins.Cape Point is a great day to spend getting out of the city.Be mindful, you pay for entry into the national park, also pay for the cable car to get up top the lighthouse if you dont want to walk 55R return and 110R per person to get into the park.The views are amazing! Would recommend trying to get there as early as possible so as not to get stuck in the line trying to get up to the lighthouse, also trying to park close to entry.If you're lucky like us, you'll see plenty of Baboons in the park, coming onto the road. And we got out of the car to pat 2 turtles who came out of the bush onto the road also.

Must do. Cape Point is immaculate. The scenery is unmatchable. It provides some of the best views you will ever get in the Cape, with great hiking trails along the mountain that will leave you in awe.Seeing the old buildings and the history behind them is interesting, all while surrounded by the unique Cape Floral fynbos. I'll be visiting again without a doubt.Warning though: the wind is incredibly strong here. Find out what the wind will be like before taking old people or small children.
Amazing. Cape point is a great place to relax by the ocean and take in the wonderful scenery around this brilliant part of the country.

Lifetime experience. You need to visit at least once in your life! Words and pictures do very little justice to the experience of seeing this natural wonder of the world. Watch out for baboons, they are not scared of you if they see you have food.

The tip of South Africa. Where 2 oceans meet.. This is a very famous nature reserve with a number of unique flora species. For the energetic traveller you can walk to the very end of the land where it is claimed that 2 oceans meet. It is not the most southern point in South Africa, but it is considered as such by many who go to Cape Point. Watch out for baboons if they are in the parking lot at Cape Point. They can be cheeky.
Great place to get out of the city. Definitely set aside time to check out the cape region outside of Cape Town. Many people don't get out of the city and it's well worth it.

If you like dramatic shorelines this is a must. Should definitely fit this into your travel plans. Beautiful wilderness with dramatic ocean views. Don't miss Neptune's Dairy Beach. The walk up to the light house opens up wonderful views. Just be ready for gale force winds up on top. We saw ostriches, baboons and elands during our visit.
The end of Africa. An experience not to be missed. Beautiful scenery and so much to enjoy. The little train is a eat experience and the views are wonderful

Amazing!. We went to see where to oceans meet and what a splendid sight it was. The climb was hard and I wished I would've taken the shuttle. Still, the scenery was great and worth it. It was foggy when we arrived but the fog cleared after few minutes and we managed to see clearly. The reserve is supposed to house wild animals but we didn't see any. We also had to pay entrance fee for the taxi driver despite the fact that he did not climb to see the Cape. Otherwise, we would have had to walk 5 kilometers from the Reserve gate to the cape. The view is quite differet on the two sides of the Cape and there is a beautiful variety of wild flowers. There is a small museum at the top and a crafts shop at prices comparable to those in the town.

Amazing. We got for the 3th times overthere and it's allways so exiting to that people of Capetown and the lovely food. For just 8 till 10 Euro you can eat 'n briljant dinner with also the drinks incluse p.p.Seefood is the best in Capetown you could ever thought!

Stunning Views. After four visits to this attraction, I am still not sure if this is where the Atlantic and Indian oceans meet or at Agulhas. Different guides tell you different stories. I have not had the chance to read up on it personally. One thing is certain, it is not the southern most part of Africa. That is at Agulhas. However, there is a very scenic point where you can take pictures of being on one side or the other. For me the most interesting part was reading the history of the shipwrecks up at the top, next to the shop. Great photo spots at the top. Ride up to the top in the funicular was interesting experience. I also enjoyed visiting the monuments to Vasco da Gama and Bartholomew Dias. It is a trip well worth taking so long you combine it with other activities like visting the penguin sanctuary in Simonstown.

The views were amazing. With views of the ocean stretching for miles and some incredible wildlife this was such a great experience. The views at the top were amazing. I would say it is worth it to rather walk up than take the funicular. The viewpoints on the way up are crazy good. We saw a whale, 2 ostriches with their 8 babies, an Eland and some very wide variety of birdlife. Really worth the drive.

Enjoy the Flying Dutchman but watch out for the tour buses.. Great place to see some stunning views of the Atlantic and Indian Oceans. Lots of tourist buses and pushy visitors from the east. Well worth the walk to the top.

Picturesque views and brisk breezes. To welcome our KZN cousins to the Fairest Cape , we enjoyed a family outing to view the natural beauty and animal life of Cape Point. Of course, we had to remind them that the real 'Two Oceans' is not here, but at Cape Agulhas..which became another fun outing.

Good Experience give yourself plenty of time. We did a day trip and spent around 5 hours travelling around the Reserve we managed to see plenty of animals including Ostrich and Kudu. Also we called a quiet place and took a small hike to the rocks as we sat down 2 whales surfaced directly below us and kept us entertained for at least 30 mins. We also travelled down the Chapmans Peak drive a must for views and experience. We also incorporated a stop at Boulders Beach for the penguins and Hout Bay for the Seals. If travelling these are experiences you need to do and a full day is required.

Mrs Sihlangu . Magnificent views of cape Town beaches, though it's bit pricey but it's value for money. u can take a half day or full day visit in one of minibus guided by experienced tour guide. next time you visit cape Town please make sure you go to cape point.

Excellent day trip, we spent 8 and a half hours here, and saw some wonderful sights.. I would say that this was one of our best days out, we saw also the Cape of Good Hope, many and I say many types of birds, Zebra, Antelopes, Ostriches and many more! Would highly recommend that you take all the trails and not just go only for the end view!
Nice. Really nice experience. Professionally maintained and a highlight in the South African Parks Board experience

Penguins. We had a hire car and did this trip ( about an hour from Cape Town) and signposted just past Simonstown.This is a brilliant trip to view the Penguins close up via a boardwalk down to the beach.
Great place to experience. The culmination of a great drive around the Peninsular. Great views on clear days and a very historic and geographically significant location.
Views. Wonderful views, pretty windy though and wildlife around. Very peaceful mist of the time, charge for entrance also closes at sunset.

not on the list of highlights. this was a bit barren and we did not see any animals . The lighthouse was fine but it is a lighthouse. the shops were the best but the café was run upside down so we walked out as there was no system
beautiful. Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope were fantastic. Great views. Lighthouse hike is easy and were able to see whales in the distance. Stop at Boulder beach on the route to see Penguins.

Great outing on a rainy day. Really nice to visit. Amazing walks and views. Climb all the way up to the lighthouse, it is worth the sore calves the next day! Friendly staff and very clean. We even shared the road with an ostrich.

Nice view of the cliffs. A must visit while being in Cape Town. Nice park with beautifull views of the lighthouse and cliffs. Did see some wildlife as well and on our way out we passed a big family of baboons crossing the road. The trip with "The Vliegende Hollander" was fun but the hicking trip to the top is less crowded. We tried to hike down to the southern lighthouse but the trail was closed and it looked to me that the trail was closed for a while.

Time well spent!. It was a lovely leisurely drive through the game reserve. We saw some game but not as much as we would have liked. The Fynbos was absolutely beautiful and lots of it. The array of types and colours was fascinating. The spectacular view of the Atlantic Ocean was a real treat!

One of Unusual Places in the World, where two seas meet. My husband loves geography and to visit the Cape of Good Hope/Cape Point Reserve was a real high point for him. Beautiful views driving to and from as well.

Beautiful landscape and insightful information at the visitors centre. Great walks and views - doesn't really matter about the weather. Look out for the zebra and other animals as you wander - as well as the falcons near the lighthouse. Well worth a visit and the information centre is really good and informative.A number of tours to the Cape have a cycling element to them which is really enjoyable and not too challenging - a great way to see the area.
Beautiful place, even on a cloudy day. Went there with a tour to Cape Point, and was a cool ride. We had bikes to go along some part within the reserve, and the views are really nice!

Beautiful but go to Cape Agulhas instead.. The cape point was special and beautiful although we really enjoyed much more Cape Agulhas (the true southern tip of Africa).A bit disappointing because there were so many tourists there.

A not-to-be- missed visit. Cape Point nature reserve is as stark as it is beautiful. You could visit every day and you would see it differently as weather conditions can change dramatically from hour to hour. Spectacular views of False Bay and mountain range beyond. Looking down from the point at the crashing sea below you can understand how difficult it is to navigate and why so many vessels have sunk - it is not called the Cape of Storms for nothing.

Should Be on Any Cape Town Visitors' List. I visited the reserve twice - once on my own and once with my husband. It's really a must-see for anyone visiting the western Cape, both for the native plant life and for the historical significance. Word of warning - it is NOT where the Atlantic and Indian Oceans merge! It is, however, the famous Cape of Good Hope, the site of many a ship wreck, including the Flying Dutchman. The native flora is especially beautiful in early spring when it is in bloom. You may be lucky enough to see some wildlife as well (beware the baboons!)...

Should NOT BE MISSED. You have to work to get there or pay for the tour. Make the effort and go. Vistas are outstanding and the drive is very much the same. Impressive views and shoreline and some wildlife. Just go I don't think you will be disappointed.
Fabulous. You can't travel to Cape Town without going that little bit further to the Nature Reserve . Fascinating day out, views and wildlife intrigueing

Must See,the southern most tip of Africa!. One of the places I always wanted to visit. This is the point where Indian Ocean & Atlantic Meet. This is the historical route taken by ancient mariners including Vasco da Gama used for visiting India. Loved the place! Seaw waves were also fascinating.
Must visit. Must visit site to get a feel of the southern tip of Africa and also dive into history. Good infrastructure

Must visit sight. The Cape Point is the southern most point of Africa and is awe inspiring. There is a funicular to the lighthouse but we didn't have the time to go up. The profusion of protea flowers was fascinating.

Beautiful!. It is very special visiting the Cape of Good Hope. The authorities seem to have resolved the baboon problem at the main restaurant and funicular area, but they are still to be seen in the park on the way to Cape Point.

Beautiful Experience. We drove through the preserve and saw lots of bird species, ostrich and the hard to spot Eland. There were also baboons at the point. The lighthouse view is amazing. Highly recommended especially if the weather is decent.
Penguins!. We took a boat first to see the seals then to Cape Point to see the Penguins. Lots and lots of both. Beautiful beach.

Good not great but on the must do list. I've always wanted to come here and liked it very much, though I expected it to be less touristy and more rugged and challenging. The biggest challenge was getting pictures without other people getting in the way - just do it back, they'll remember you were there too then!

Worth doing but weather impacts it. The day we went it was very cloudy at Cape Point (but can drive to Cape Hope area which is at sea level and can see a bit more). Still worth the doing. Saw some dolphins in the sea at one point!

Lovely vegetation, springflowers and pincushions in bloom. This reserve is called Table Mountain National Park; Cape of good Hope. We have been here many times but never at spring time. It was lovely to see the springflowers in the fullest bloom and also many different types of pin cushions were out.
Great place to visit near Cape Town. We enjoyed our tip to Cape Point Nature reserve and the scenery is stunning.We saw Ostrich wild and enjoyed the wide open spaces

REALLY? Standing at the tip of the country - well almost!. It's rugged but so emotinal to be standing there at the tip of the country, and then to be able to pop over to the óther'tip - Cape of Good Hope. I felt like I was standing in history.

Amazing Photo opportunities. If its dramatic landscapes that you're after with amazing photo opportunities, then a visit to Cape point is a must! Incorporate it into a daytrip around the Cape Peninsula including Hout Bay, Chapman's Peak, Noordhoek and Boulders in your itinerary. Set aside several hours to wander around the lighthouse and lookout point and view the dramatic cliffs below, and also visit the Two Oceans meeting point for a great photo.

Stunning Views and Beautiful Hikes!. Beautiful nature reserve with stunning views. Take your time walking up the stairs to the lookout point (it is quite a climb, but manageable for everybody). From the top of the lookout point you can see a line in the ocean which makes it look as though the Atlantic and Indian Oceans merge at this point. This is however not the case, but it still is a very impressive sight! Keep an eye out for whales, as they are often spotted here. When you walk back down, try to find the restaurant which is fairly decent, and has stunning views!!! Take care as there are often cheeky, wild baboons wandering around the parking lot trying to steal food from the visitors - DO NOT FEED THEM - they might bite you!!! They are however very entertaining to watch from the safety of your car. It is also possible to hike through the nature reserve and admire the amazing flora and fauna and the many amazing views.

breathe taking. Definitely worth a sunday morning drive out of the city. You can also put on your trainers and go for long walks experience the beautiful fynbos in the area.
Awesome place to destress after a long week of work.

Beautiful natural excursion outside Cape Town. We opted to drive to Cape Point and explore the area prior. Upon arriving, we were amazed by the lovely sights. We decided to trek to the lighthouse, and see the almost pristine 360 view. Afterwards. We headed to the restaurant for some sushi, bubbly and more views! It was truly breathtaking!

Bad roads Bad prices Just Bad.. After paying a ridiculous amount of money at the gate you get to drive on a smooth piece of road for about 1 km then its just pot holes all the way. This is just a money making racket and you would be better off avoiding it.

Great Drive Even if the Weather at Cape Point isn't the Best. Staying in Cape Town, we drove down to The Cape to enjoy the views and to see where the warm Indian Ocean currents meet those of the icy cold Atlantic Ocean. The drive took us down some fairly spectacular coastline - we were able to enjoy the beauty of clouds rolling along the dramatic coastline mountains.Unfortunately for us, the clouds actually meant fog, so when we arrived at Cape Point it was completely fogged in. We climbed up the lighthouse & looked out anyway however we could not see the water at all. But that allowed us to concentrate on our senses, and we could feel a marked temperature differential between the warmer air coming from the (nearby) Indian Ocean and the chilly winds on the Atlantic City ocean just by moving from one side of the lookout to the other. If you can't work it out, the basking geckos will show you where they know it to be warmer!Definitely worth going, but if you've got the luxury of selecting between several days of your experience, check and see what the visibility is before you set off!NB: Technically the two oceans meet at Cape Agulhas, which is over 250Km away ... but the warm air/seas currents that originated in the Indian Ocean meet the cold/icy air & sea currents of the Atlantic here.

Poor service but spectacular views make up for it. We visited this place on 8 September 2015. I would never have expected to receive such appalling service at such a beautiful place. From the person who seated us at the restaurant right up to the people who work with Flying Dutchman, the staff on this reserve need to be trained on how to treat all customers equally, especially their fellow South Africans - our money is just as good as the next person's. The only nice person that works in this place is the lady who greets you at the entrance of the park. We went on the Flying Dutchman at about 2:30pm and the lady who sells the ticket must really be trained on customer service and her product. When we were coming down just after 3:15pm, the lady sitting in the section at the top was having a personal conversation with coworkers about her mother/ mother-in-law swearing so loudly using the F word. I mean really, you shouldn't be speaking like that at work. What kind of impression does that give of people in this country. We Thankfully this place has views that more than makeup for this awful service experience, service that spoilt what otherwise would have been a magical day. But you decide when you get there.

Wander where you will.. This reserve has so many different habitats it's a fascinating place and the scenery so varied. You can watch the seabirds from near the lighthouse. get your photo taken at Cape Point ( the flyby's of the Cape Cormorants are quite spectacular there) and look for animals and birds as you wander around the various routes. You can get a meal, buy a souvenir but watch those Baboons!
Amazing views . Amazing views over the Cape. If we had more time would have loved to explore more. Enjoyed the drive through the reserve to Cape Point. It's a must see

Unparalleled geography lesson!. Don't miss this. You will remember for the rest of your life this glorious spot where two mighty oceans meet. Even on a blustery day the spot was magic! Must be the magnetic pull! And the baboons provide entertainment!

Has to be done. We made a quick stop here on our full day Cape Town tour and we wish we had more time to spend here. It's a splendid scenic drive and the views once you are there are magnificent - the lighthouse, the walkways, the whole trip getting there - just thoroughly enjoyable. The wind was brutal, and that made the climb to the lighthouse a bit difficult but that much more fun, too.
Good Day Drive out. Dont expect too much, especially when it is windy. The walk to the top is fun but can be tiresome. Not too much to see though.

You just can't miss it. Take your long lenses, and try to capture some of the sea-birds struggling in the wind.
Incredibly romantic
A must see!. We went during SA's 's winter, so crowds were small; my wife and I very much enjoyed the views and also the restaurant.

End Of The World. As a retired naval officer, I was excited to see a nautical landmark that I'd only read about. Unfortunately, the weather (fog) set in while I was up at the lighthouse, so I was not able to actually see the Atlantic and the Indian Oceans meet but I sure could hear them. I hopr to return when the weather is better and more completely explore the Reserve.

Make time for a visit to Cape Point. Cape Point has some of the most amazing views I've seen. We enjoyed the drive there as well as exploring Cape Point. We saw a lot of wild life, especially monkeys on the drive there. I highly recommend driving yourself, but I am not a fan of tours, I prefer to explore on my own with no time constraints.
Absolute beauty spot. Beautiful scenery very natural, and not many people around. The walking was not too far a couple of hours and you get to see two oceans.

Great place - allow yourself some time. I visited Cape Point as part of a day tour from Cape Town. The tour was great and I really enjoyed Cape Point, but I really wish I had got there under my own steam (hire car) so that I could have had more time and flexibility to explore.The day tour was a great way to get a flavour for the area and some of the attractions but next time I would definitely get my own transport and do things at my own speed.

Nice and organised. Rent a car and drive around. It's very easy and stress-free (even if you've not driven on the left side of the road before). I wouldn't bother with the packaged tours and the hike if you're just sightseeing in town for a few days. The car can drive and park right up to Cape Point. Cape Point just because it's iconic. Sure it's just a rocky beach on a windy shore with a corny marker! We appreciate it for a sense of history! If driving, allot only a couple of hours here and enjoy the other attractions going to and from if staying in Cape Town.

A must see if time permits on a trip to Cape Town. If time permits, a trip to the Cape Town Nature Reserve is worth the investment of a day's time. Consider incorporating the visit to a day long trip around the Cape which is one of the most scenic places in the world.
Cape Of Good Hope. Leave your self time for this one. A wonderful view point to sea Cape of Good Hope. The two oceans restaurant is also a good stop for lunch.

More authentic than the cable car. The real deal if you want to experience the overwhelming power of the Cape of Storms, its vast beauty and brutal winds. Take a wind breaker and glasses for the sea glare. Don't take food. This is the formal 'sight seeing' bit between the Chapman's Peak drive, and a stroll and bite to eat in Kalk Bay. Head back to the city on the highway or wind your way through Tokai and Constantia to dinner on one of the wine estates. Take a hairbrush and proper shoes along if so.

Beautiful place at the end of the continent. Saw cape point with a tour guide, who took us to several places to see wildlife and scenery, and the requisite "end of the earth" sign and lighthouse. Spectacular park. I'm amazed that SA has had the wisdom and foresight to preserve such a beautiful place and not allow development.

Absoloutly breathtaking and so much to explore. Worth traveling to from anywhere in Cape Town. Please do not miss out on this absolute gem! So much wildlife to spot and every corner has a different stunning view. We drove all the way to the cape point cable cars although didn't go up in one. We took lots of photos - we were there around sunset and it was beautiful, there was lots of mist over the sea which was illuminated by the sun. Brilliant day out for families, couples and groups of friends. You will be charged at the gate and given a map but from there you are free to decide where you go. You can spend an hour here or an entire day - we wish we had more time to explore!

Beautiful route to drive from Cape Town . We drove ourselves to cape point and the route itself was already a beautiful experience. We had a lovely lunch with a beautiful view and saw lots of baboons and ostrich.
Windy!!!. This was a part of the Cape Town-Cape Point guided tour which included far more than the reserve. Easy to walk around and explore the flora and fauna
Great day Out. This was a great day trip from Cape Town, the coastal road drive down was beautiful and the park itself was stunning, it was amazing to climb the point and see both oceans at once
Wonderful landmark with great views. Wonderful remote feeling location at the tip of Africa. Watch out for baboons. They will steal your lunch in a flash!
Cape of Good Hope. Must do. One of the most important things to do. The view is awesome and stunning.It is the point where two oceans meet.

At the end of a continent. I loved the whole atmosphere, openness, freedom to move about and scenery.The restaurant has very good food, we had the hamburgers and chips - very good chips. View from here excellent!Impatient tourists - I disliked, nature is to be savored not rushed through.

Cape Point, South Africa. It is amazing to stand at the Point and to look out over the wide expanse of the ocean and think of those adventurous sailors who take on the unpredictable water. Watch out for those baboons and keep your car windows completely up and the doors locked!

One for the Bucket List. Beautiful -- from the drive to get there (from Cape Town itself) to the location itself. We had lunch at the Two Oceans Restaurant and it was a memorable day. Bring your camera -- and good hiking shoes. Baboons will be plentiful, but be careful as they are not afraid of humans.

Went to Cape Point Nature Reserve during a breakaway weekend. Beautiful views of sea and mountains.. If you are in Cape Town, you must go to Cape Point Nature Reserve. It is an awesome experience. We saw Eland, Ostrich and also penguins. The colour of the sea was breathtaking. I would really recommend going there.
Another must see in Cape Town. It wouldn't be a trip to Cape Town without a trip to Cape Point. Just watch out for the monkeys and ostriches on the way!

Excellent views, nature at its best. A few things to keep in mind when visiting Cape Point: 1) The entrance to the park is R100 per adult. 2) The ride up in the funicular is R55 per person, round trip. 3) The food at the little shop is overpriced.Apart from the above, this is a must visit on your trip to Cape Town. The views are stunning, the drive through park is really beautiful. We spent a good few hours in the park admiring Cape Point, Cape of Good hope. If you want to make the most, get their early, take your hiking gear, charge your camera batteries, pack some food and water (take your litter out when you leave) and walk around and enjoy nature at its best.Truly a stunning place to visit.

VISIT TO CAPE AND LIGHTHOUSE.. Amazing weather to view the Cape of Good Hope, and many people queued (or jumped the queue) to have their photo taken with the sign. Also drove to the Lighthouse and stunning views from both spots. Many wildflowers despite the rugged and rocky landscape. Baboons also at the Cape of Good Hope, and should not be fed.
Naturalis spot full of naval history. Nice Naturalis spot full of (naval) history, Rugged landscape, saw Some baboons, ostriches, eland antilopes
Must Go. Spectacular views of the most southern tip of South Africa. It's busy but for a reason. Great place to take pictures
Cool. It was awesome to be able to have this experience! It is a tourist trap but its a tourist trap for a reason! Go make the line and take that amazing picture.

So much to do . We love going to Cape Point the views are spectacular, it is so beautiful here and you have both the mountains and sea there are lovely walking paths and the restraurant serves the most wonderful selection of seafood
nice. what a great day we had exploring Cape point. We say a number of animals and enjoyed the views. go on a clear day if possible.
Stunning. Fantastic, dramatic scenery. Be careful if you walk up to the lighthouse, a lot of steep steps, but when you get there the views are fantastic, if a little windy!
A Sight to Behold. To be in this reserve was so tranquil and beautiful. Then to drive to the top of the Cape and see the split of the Atlantic and Indian Ocean is just mesmerizing.

Outdoors beauty at the tip of Africa. Cape point has a good deal of natural beauty, some interesting native animals and birds, and a fair bit of history. For people who don't mind some short hikes, this was a great way to see the Atlantic and Indian oceans meet and get a better understanding of the Cape area. Occasionally tour busses will overwhelm the so called Cape of Good Hope, but there are lots of other areas to see that are not so crowded.

Spectacular views.. If you visit Cape Town, make sure to book a tour to Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope. On the trip, you will see African penguins and incredible views. The Cape Point park requires a vigorous but safe hike to the top. The views are breathtaking. After Cape Point, it is a short trip to the Cape of Good Hope. On the way, you will likely see baboons and ostriches.

Beautiful and Wild. A great find. Not only is the scenery stunning but there was an unexpected abundance of wildlife. While at Cape Point, we saw ostrich, eland, and baboons in addition to numerous bird species. Other than being windy, it was a great experience.

Definitely not where the oceans meet. Wonderful place. The drive to get there alone is worth doing. Once there you can either walk or take the funicular. The view is awesome but don't believe the nonsense of two oceans meeting here or it being the southernmost tip of africa for that matter. That is in fact cape aghulus some 150 ks away. I assure you the oceans are unaware of the fact that they are Indian or Atlantic and definitely do not have a line separating them.The view anyway is outstanding and it's a good day trip highly enjoyable

Beautiful landscape. Stunning drive and then hiking at the park. There are several places where you can go for hikes among the rocks and find really spectacular views. It was a great way to spend half a day. Along the way you can also visit the penguins.
Floral paradise. Great for cycling, hiking and hanging out. Watch out for the baboons. The short walk to the viewing point is worth it
See the oceans join. Fantastic exploration of this floral kingdom. Wide open spaces filled with Fynbos, historical monuments, wildlife and the stunning walk to Le Cap.

Fantastic in every way ! . We loved this place so much ! Great views with very little fees to enter . My kids loved being there . They are 10 years old and enjoyed every minute of it ! We would like to do again some day in our life

History Field Trip. Having heard many tales of the "Capo da Boa Esperanca" when I was a kid, I absolutely loved visiting the real thing. The weather was temperamental and strong winds and gusts of rain caught is, but I reckon it actually gave as a good glimpse of the old caravels experience! We got to see a few baboons on the road too. That was nice. :)

Windy Overlook. First of all, the drive there from Cape Town is very scenic. We visited on a day when the rain was on and off in the winter. We took the funicular to the top and back down to save time. You can also hike if you want. When we got to the very top, the rain started again! Wind was blowing strongly and the rain drops hit pretty hard. I didn’t really enjoy the harsh weather, but because of the rain we saw a couple of rainbows. Still a beautiful view and it was fun to be at the most southwestern tip of Africa.

Awesome!. This is a must see when visiting CapeTown.Be sure to climb the steps to the lighthouse for great view. We took our time so we wouldn't get out of breath. We really enjoyed seeing Ostriches roaming around the rocks at the Oceans edge.

Visit the southernmost point on the continent of Africa. Beautiful drive through the peninsula. Stopped to watch the baboons along the roadside. Soooo cute. Also stopped at the Penguins. Walked along the boardwalks photographing cute little birds.
Well worth the drive.. We had an excellent day in and around the nature reserve. It was well worth the drive for the great range of birds, plant and mammal life. Fantastic scenery too!

Time out. Always pleasant to travel down to Cape Point and get away from town life. One should just be aware that the wind could be unpleasant so take something warm with. Make the effort to go to the top and have a look from the lookout point worth the effort. for the more adventurous take a walk down to Diaz beach.
Incredible view. Drove through as part of our drive along the peninsula - the geography and views are breathtaking! It was winter and the wind was howling, but it was worth the visit.

Stunning Cape of Good Hope // Cape Point. If you are visiting South Africa you should most definitely take the time to visit the Cape of Good Hope / Cape Point.....the whole Nature Reserve is absolutely stunning........ensure you go all the way down to Cape Point and walk around all thru the area.....plus, take the tram car up to top----unforgettable

Not really where they merge but close enough. Cape Point, like most natural wonders in Cape Town, is beautiful. It important to take in the sights from the lighthouse to the point. There is a lot of history there, and something about the fresh air (even per Cecil John Rhodes) brings life and peace.

Don't miss the views from here!. Lots of hiking opportunities so budget time to take advantage of the trails and the sights, especially interesting flora and even some fauna like rock dassies. Expect high winds and dress warmly. A funicular tram is available if you don't want to walk to the lighthouse. Toilets were clean and well maintained.
View from the southern most end of the african continent. The ambience was niceSpecialy the cable car ride, good place to buy collectables, wonderful scenarios

Good day out.. A lovely day out to the Cape Point Nature Reserve.
Well worth a visit - you may see ostriches and for sure baboons.

Ostriches at the Cape of Good Hope. How could we not visit Cape Hope. It didn't take long--just a photo op and a bit of a hike. Ostriches were wandering near the sign and made a great picture. Driving here was a great day trip from Cape Town.

Fabulous and just SO beautiful. Such a beautiful place to be - just been revisiting it via my 'photo-book' and stunned once again by the natural beauty. Do watch out for the local birds (a type of starling) that make a good go of taking your picnic....

Tranquil and serene. This is a quiet, serene place to walk and enjoy the surroundings. You could easily spend a half or full day here. Walking around the light house and seeing the Ostriches and other animals at leisure is a bonus. Entrance fee is minimal, and considering how clean and well cared for the reserve is the fee is worth it.

Fun on the Funicular. Wonderful experience. Short or long walks and beautiful scenery.
Take the Flying Dutchman Funicular or take the walk. Whatever you do, make sure you go to the lighthouse and have your camera ready...
Interesting. A lovely location and conceptually interesting place to to visit. Unless you are planning however to hike around, it is a bit pricey just to go look and leave.

Great day trip. Cape Point Nature reserve has so much to offer, from an easy walk to two lighthouses, to secluded beaches, hikes and easy mountain bike trails. There is a restaurant for meals, but a picnic by the sea is so much better!

Still one of the best views in the world. As a resident of Cape Town, it had a been a number of years since I last visited Cape Point. Having family visiting from overseas in October 2015, gave me reason to visit here and I felt "proudly South African". From the entrance (fee payable here) to the "point" itself, the reserve is maintained in an excellent and clean condition (including toilet facilities). A fantastic meal can be enjoyed at the restaurant with the most gorgeous views you'll see anywhere (priced for tourists). A lovely souvenir shop can be found as you enter/exit the Funicular - that can be used (at an additional cost) to take you to the "point".
