Alternatively, put on your hiking shoes and enjoy the amazing walk to the "point" (suggested only for the reasonably fit amongst us). Once at the Cape Point, whip out your camera to record your memories. Enjoy seeing the Indian Ocean on one side and the Atlantic Ocean on the other.... and how they "meet". You may be lucky enough to spot dolphins frolicking through the surf, while whales breach the surface of the ocean as they slow dance their way to/from Hermanus. Look back/behind you to bask in the view of the Table Mountain National Park stretching its long arms out - before you slowly make your way back home - possibly stopping at Boulders Beach (in Simonstown) to enjoy the Cape's famous Penquins. Don't forget to stop off in Simonstown and explore the myriad of interesting shops here and the amazing home made ice cream with all its different flavour choices, at the pink café (to be found along the main road). A fun filled, FULL day, excursion that will bring you home exhausted, but pleased with yourself.

June 2015. A memorable place. This though is not the most southern tip of Africa it's around 200 odd Kim's from here. However all in all a great place to visit. You can walk up as well however you should take a funicular. Views are awesome, be mindful to hold your cap as it really gets windy. Great photo place. You will see the two oceans meet.

Stunning. One the most beautiful places in Africa and where the Cape of Good Hope is. The place is a bit over 1 hour drive from Cape Town City Center. The drive through Ou Kaapse Weg or Chapman's peak drive is very scenic.The tickets are ZAR 100 per person ($10)To get the most beautiful views, take the Flying Dutchman Funicular which takes you up to the lighthouse in a few minutes. Otherwise, you can hike up there.On the way down, turn left towards the Cape of Good Hope sign. If you have a hour to spare, take the Cape of Good Hope scenic walkway.

Wonderful Place to Visit!. This is an absolutely beautiful place to visit. I had a great time. The landscape is gorgeous and there are good stops to make here and there on your way. Definitely worth your time. Be mindful of the baboons.
Like being in Switserland. An amazing experience. So professional in every way. Very much like I experienced overseas. Proud to be a South African when we can deliver this kind of service.
Beautiful sights. Driving cape point is an awesome way to spend an afternoon. There are many very pretty sights of the ocean and landscape. Just be careful with the baboons

Awe inspiring. Although this is not the Southernmost point in Southern Africa, it is worth driving through the nature reserve to view. It is a unique feeling knowing that the next piece of land is Antarctica. If you're lucky, you might even see whales.

Feels like you have reached the end of the world. On a cold (14 degrees) and windy winter day in July, we went to Cape Point Nature Reserve. The good thing about going on a winter day is that there are not many people lining up to enter the park, the bad thing is that once you reach the very end of Cape Point, it can be very cold. Cape Point is a great experience and although there are more southern points in South Africa, once you are standing there next to the lighthouse at the very end of Cape Point, it feels like you are at the end of the world. Please be careful not to eat outside the local restaurant. If not careful baboons are literally grasping the food but also bags from your hands.
A mind blowing experience. One of my best memories was standing near the lighthouse and seeing pods of Southern Right Whales swimming Southwards on both sides of the point.
Worth a visit!. Worth a visit to the South Western tip of Africa.However, to visit the southern most tip of Africa you have to travel 3 hours from Cape Point to go to Cape Agulhas.
Stunning views. We were lucky enough to spot a whale on our trip to Cape Point, also got up pretty close with a couple opf Ostrich. Again heights were an issue for me, but it was managaeble

beautiful land, beautiful views. We loved our visit to the nature reserve. The whole ride down one coast and lunch there and the ride back along the other coast made for a fantastic day of sightseeing.

Brilliant. Firstly its a wonderful drive getting there, walk up to the Lighthouse, and the views of False Bay are Brilliant!There are many hiking trails, Great to spend the entire day.The baboons sometimes try to get too friendly, be careful
Beautiful views. Great that there is now a cable car to take you to the summit at Cape Point. Beautiful views from here all the way back up the Peninsula

stunning. we visited in the middle of winter so it was windy and cold but just stunning. A visit to both Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope is recommended - they are so close. Cape Point has more facilities including restaurant and shop and a trip up the Funicular is fun. Climb to the top of the lighthouse for incredible views - nothing between you and Antarctica! The babboons dont seem too scary - if you don't have food. Spotted ostriches on the road out to Cape of Good Hope and seals out in the bay - a nice drive from Cape town and worth every minute
Visit to Cape Point. Very nice views you pay to go in when you get to Cape Point you will find a nice place to eat and transport to get up to the Point or clime if you wish.

Cape Point and nature reserve. A lovely place to visit. Cape Point is wild and unspoilt. We came across several ostrich down by the ocean. There is also an excellent restaurant where you can enjoy a gourmet meal overlooking the ocean. Also a shop with interesting African crafts for sale.
Truly unspoiled. Beautiful hikes and walks - be careful of the baboons (no food visible) and the South Easter ;-) Otherwise enjoy this absolutely awe-inspiring landscape.

2 Oceans Meet. Where two oceans meet. This beautiful reserve is rich in wild life and flora. You feel like there should be hustle and bustle at such a significant spot on the earth, but its nature at her best. Views of the world you've never imagined. So worth the trip.

Family day out. Activities for all...Hiking for the teensFishing for adultsSwimming for the children braai areas available So if you planning a family day i would advice Cape Point. The point where the two oceans meet is a talking point for all youngest (primary school) that is when they make it up to the point. Showing them the walk up is a sense of achievement as well.

Nice drive, hike and views from the Light House. The drive to the light house is quite enjoyable (and even exciting if you drive Chapman's Peak road on the return to Cape Town!). Although there is a cable car that takes you to the top, we opted for the hike. There are several stairs to reach the light house, but the views were worth it. Although not technically the southernmost point of Africa, it is worth the drive and hike for the views. We also drove to the Cape of Good Hope and saw 4 whales in the distance. Enjoyable afternoon!

A must..... Stunning scenery an absolute must when visiting Capetown. I would recommend wearing sensible shoes I saw a woman wearing very high heeled boots, in all fairness she did manage to climb to the top, but it was incredibly windy.....rather her then me!!
Must find time to do this!. Make time to visit Cape Point and to walk down the wooden walkway to the point! Somewhat scary, but well worth the effort.
Nature. Great view but it was june and very bad weather there try it in a good weather amazing nature (9/10)

A very pleasant experience. We did a day tour of Cape Ppoint and thoroughly enjoyed it. The coast line is spectacular, there is ample opportunity to see animals (not lions and elephants!) and to take in some of the history of the area.
Unmissable. This is another must-see tour while in Cape Town. It is very cute and fun. The view is breathtaking and should not be missed.We really enjoyed!
Beautiful scenery. The views are amazing and a must see if at Cape Point. You can sit there for hours just taking in the beauty.

Great day trip. How can you go to Capetown and not see the Cape of Good Hope? Had a very pleasant day trip from Capetown with great scenery. A very pleasant stroll up to the lighthouse with phenomenal views on a clear day. Don't miss it...

Beautiful scenery. This place is just stunning and we enjoyed exploring and taking a walk down to the lighthouse and up the rocks by the cape of good hope. The coastline is very rugged and beautiful. Saw wild ostrich & antelope too which was a nice surprise as we thought we had finished our time on safari :)

Love Love Love this Reserve.. So much to do here. Absolutely a must. Get your wild card - super cheap from kirtsenbosch and go as often as you like and take friends with you. Great hikes and surfing and views. You have to do the 36km 2 day hike and stay over in the huts. Best experience ever!!!

Just an hour's drive away from Cape Town lies a natural wonder. If you have 5-6 hours to spend at Cape Town, make a trip down to the Cape of Good Hope & Cape Point. If it is a clear day, you will get to see vast expanses of blue and green. The light house itself is 231 m high and was visible to ships 67 km away. Unfortunately, it was often covered with clouds and hence proved to be less than useful. But as a place to enjoy the natural beauty of the beach, the ocean & the hills, it is perfect.

A great bit of scenery. We drove down to the Cape of Good Hope via the western coast of the Cape through the charming fishing village of Hout Bay and over the historic Chapman's Peak Drive. After visiting the obligatory Cape of Good Hope, we then visited Cape Point - the most southern part of South Africa and where the Atlantic and Indian Oceans meet. It is a good exercising walk up to the lighthouse or it can be reached by the "Flying Dutchman" funicular railway to the pinnacle. It was very windy and a bit cold so make sure that you have a jacket. The views are spectacular and we are told that whales can be seen at times (we didn't see any). The facilities are well maintained. The trip to the Cape (and return via Simon's Town) is a great day out.

Enjoyed the Sights Here. This was a fun little trip that we took on the weekend. We wanted to go see the tip, and look out over the Indian and Atlantic oceans. It was pretty chilly and windy when we were there, but I think that helped with all the steps we climbed to get to the lighthouse. There is also a tram that goes to the lighthouse for about $4 US or 20 Rand. It's worth the trip.
Beautiful must visit. Really stunning scenery! Not too far from Cape Town so makes a good day trip. If you're lucky you may even see Mr Ostrich :)
Well maintained. Visiting this spot after many years was great and recommended for all who enjoys nature. Facilities are well maintained.

Worth the drive. You are NOT visiting the Southern most tip of Africa - that is Cape Agulhas, 3 hours South where the Atlantic and Indian Oceans meet, BUT still Cape Point is beautiful and worth the hours drive from Cape Town. pristine beauty, unique flora and fauna and a well run funicular to the top viewing point.

Enjoyed the views. Basically there are two areas to go to once you are in the park. Cape of Good Hope and Cape Point Lighthouse. The Cape of Good Hope route has lovely views of the coast. Once you are there you can take photos of coast/sea and the sign stating that you are at the most southwestern point of the Africa. You can also hike up a small cliff.  The lighthouse is about a 4-5km drive from the Cape of Good Hope and it has a restaurant, gift shop and a cable car that takes you up to the old lighthouse. The ride cost (R55 Rand) so we walked up even with a small baby on a cool day. The views are awesome!  TIMEYou need about 3 hours to do the Good Hope and Lighthouse, if you plan to hike some of the trails and eat at the restaurant you will need more. COSTR110 per adult to enter the parkR55 per adult to ride up in the cable carThe prices at the restaurant are bump up a bit.

Beautiful Cape Point. This is really a beautiful place, we saw ostriches, antelope and whales! The view is astounding and even though it was busy it was never crowded and other travelers are pleasant. We really enjoyed it.
Gorgeous. I saw baboons on my way in and on my way out. The walk up to the lighthouse is steep and well worth the effort. Spend a whole day here as there is a lot to see if you drive around.

Cape of Storms. An invisible barrier prevents the mixing of the cold Atlantic and the warm Indian ocean. Watch from up high but be careful for crosswinds over the connecting walk way to the outpost. Unrivalled views of the Cape of Storms

Two Oceans. An absolutely stunning area to take a stroll (Just beware of the baboons) and so fascinating to see the Atlantic and Pacific oceans meet. There's a lovely restaurant there too that makes a mean seafood Potjie! Highly recommended!

Incredible views. The reason we traveled to Cape Town on our return to the states after living in Africa...to visit Cape Point. The views are spectacular, the walks are wonderful, and the historical displays are fascinating. Well worth the trip south of Cape Town.
Beautiful day . A very nice place to visit in the Western Cape. The views are amazing and worth every penny. The funicular is also a good experience. Great day out for a family

Mind the baboons!. We begin with a fright as a baboon leapt into the car the steal the children's biscuits. Once we calmed down the hysterical, frightened children we had a lovely lunch before we took the train to the top, took lots of photos, then walked down.

A must see!. Well preserved and looked after reserve. A must see - take the finicular to the top and take in the views and then grab a photo opportunity at the most South-Western point in SA and where two seas meet.

Stunning scenery and well worth the beautiful drive down.. Loved the nature reserve. The drive down was spectacular and there is a cable car to take you to the view point where the two oceans merge.
We returned to our car to find ostriches standing beside it which was fun. We walked on deserted beaches and jumped the freezing cold waves with the kids.
Loved every minute.

Most Southern Point of African Continent. The reason that the Cape Point is a nature reserve in addition to a tourist attraction is the fact that the land around the point is semi desert with fynbos and other varieties of plant life as well as wild ostriches, seals, waterbuck and other antelopes, goats, etc. We even stopped our car so that a turtle could cross the road without injury. The Reserve has a small museum and gift shop as well as tramway to the lighthouse located at the highest peak on the point. There is a sign at the end of the point giving you the latitude and longitude of the tip of Cape Point.

A Must for Any Vistor to the Cape. An absolute must for anyone visiting Cape Town. The scenery is just breath taking and there is just so much to see with some really good stops. Can work out a bit pricey and could be crowded in summer. We however had a marvelous time and an experience of a life time. The reserve could maintain some roads a bit better - saw a few potholes.
don't underestimate time needed. this is far from cape town and you need at least 2 hours while inside. go to diaz beach - one of the best in the world
Fabulous place. full of memories. We've done the walk there and have been to cape point. Meet peoples from around the world. Excited moment and peacefully place.

Awesome natural beauty. Do take the time to travel out of Cape Town down to Cape Point. The drive is quite beautiful as also the natural beauty of the Cape Peninsula. Please budget for about 2-3 hours at the Cape Peninsula.

The journey there is the best thing. The journet to the cape point is the nicest thing if you visit the cape point. The cape point itself is great too, but its like the nature around it, so there is nothing nwe and amazing in the end of the peninsula
Animal Sightings & Gorgeous Views. Saw baboons and ostrich while out driving to and from the point. Very cool. Be sure to climb to the top of the Point. The view is well worth it.

Two Oceans Breathtaking. We had taken the drive down the Cape peninsula and stopped along the way as the sites were amazing and had to snap a few pics. Once we arrived at the Nature Reserve, the drive itself inside is very easy - the roads were wide, paved and well maintained. At some point - some baboons were crossing the street and a few of the babies even jumped onto the car (lock your doors!). We had lunch at Two Oceans (do not eat there unless you just want bland food with a great view). The actual scene up at the lighthouse of the "two oceans" (Atlantic and Indian) is very cool - it kind of reminded me of a a scene in Game of Thrones. If you have a full or half day, go for it. The drive down the peninsula itself is worth it and the nature reserve is pretty nice itself.

Beautiful. Nothing beats Cape Point nature reserve. Often very busy in school holidays but if you aren't right at the point, the reserve is really big and you can find a lovely spot on a secluded beach for the kids to play. There are many rock and tidal pools as well. You can walk up to the Lighthouse at the point or take the tram. People of average fitnesses should manage the walk with little effort.
Cape Point lighthouse. Beautiful day to look off the end of the world. Hike up to the lighthouse not bad at all but there is also a cable car for the less athletic.

Beautiful and worth a visit.. Very close to Cape Town, and a pretty drive. Not a lot to do other than drive there and take in the view, but what a view. If you are able, climb up the hill and get even better views, but watch the wind.
the tip of africa. the place is where two oceans meet and the view is one of the best in cape town. this is one of the top 10 things to do in cape town

A favourite place of mine. Cape Point deserves time. The lighthouse at the end of the road is a must for first time visitors, but it is usually very busy. Take a side road. I love Olifontsbos. There is a small beautiful bay near the car park with plenty of bird life. We usually see Bontebok antelope when we visit. Take a walk to Tommy Tuckers wreck. The sign says it is a 2 hour circular walk but you can walk to the wreck and back along the beach in 40 mins. The beach is spectacular. You'll see Olifontsbos cottage which can be rented for the night. I love staying there. It's such a privilege to know that you have the park almost to yourself. If you are very lucky you'll see Zebra coming down to the watering hole near the cottage at dusk.

View of cape point . Make sure you go on a clear day . The mist will spoil your view . The walk up can be a bit of a challenge but the cable car makes it easy . The view is spectacular . Worth the effort and drive
Quiet easy drive. Liked the views and enjoyed the penguins en route. Small amount of construction in park was not a hindrance.

At the southern tip of Africa.. We drove our hired car along the coast from Muizenburg ( a surfers paradise) through Kalk Bay ( a quirky village with excellent restaurants) and on to picturesque Fish Hoek ( with million dollar houses on the mountainside ) , then stopped at the Victorian Naval seaport of Simonstown ( visited the penguins ). The latter part of the drive to Cape Point hugged the cliffs and seaviews with the odd Baboon sitting along the way.The Cape Point Nature Reserve is so natural and had great history in the age of Portuguese explorers discovering the sea route from Europe to India.It is a must to visit the Lighthouse at the top of The Point either a long walk or a cable tram will get you there.Afterwards take some time to explore the various other parts of the reserve , either by car or hike. Overnight hikers accomodation is available - book in advance.

Lighthouse visit. As a family a visit to Danger Point lighthouse near Gansbaai sparked an interest in lighthouses and a visit to the Cape Point nature reserve was a must as it houses 2 lighthouses at the point. It certainly an experience and of special interest was, besides the view, the signage that pointed to lighthouses locally and globally including their distances from that point. Also the walk amongst the baboons is exciting.

not quite the tip of africa but close.... and where the nature reserve / park is located... head up the funicular to experience spectacular views and climb the lighthouse: white sand beaches. ocean vistas. then drive out to the tip and yes, have your photo taken!

Day Trip around Cape Point. Grabbed our driver and three of us took off for a day long excursion around Cape Point. It was a lovely clear day so there was lots to see especially when we arrived here. Large animals on the roadside and Cape Sugerbirds in the bushes.We went onto the lower car park and watched the oceans swell, seals basking in the sunshine between the rocks and hundreds of cormorants drying their wings. Later we journeyed up to the main car park and walked up to the top where there is a lighthouse, for those of you that don't fancy the numerous steps there is a lift which will take you almost to the top where there is a small museum. Should you wish to have a drink and something to eat there is somewhere you can enjoy the scenary while you eat. If you enjoy watching the waves, wildlife and walking this place is great, Our only regret was we didn't come across any baboons during out time here.

Don't forget the camera 👍👍👍👍👍. This a full day out.,we took an excursion by coach from Cape town . Great relaxed tour with plenty to see along the way. When you reach the nature reserve you will not be disappointed.The view of the two oceans is breathtaking. The two waters coming together you won't believe your eyes. Lots of time and effort has been ploughed into this nature reserve. Again don't forget the camera. We spent over 3 hours here. A must while your in Cape town .
A must see.. A wonderful place to go and see while in Cape Town. It is a very beautiful scenic drive to get there and when you arrive it is breathtaking.
Well maintained Nature Reserve. I was very impressed on how well maintained the Cape Point Nature Reserve was. You can really see that they making an effort to keep this spot beautiful

Great day out.. The place to see when in Cape Town. The view of the two oceans meet is unbelievable. You can seen the color of the water getting together. Be prepared to spend some time there. You will not be disappointed. I love the view from the light house.This is a must see.

Where two oceans meet. Enjoyable visit. Allow a half day to drive around the nature reserve.Diaz column to commemorate the Portuguese explorers.We are pensioners, and had no difficulty walking the 240 steps up to the old lighthouse - about 45 minutes up and down and time for photos.

Experience for sure. On our last day we decided to visit this popular destination and I'm very happy we did. Restaurant was good, had sushi and cocktails. Views are amazing and although the line was quite long getting in, it's worth it.

FABULOUS DAY OUT. Cape Point a great drive, reasonable entrance fee. Lots of opportunities to find picnic spots. Beware of baboons ostrich on the together seem to think that they have priority must go tothe beacon uphill but easy walk and also down to coast to sign 'most south westerly point in Africa's. Also worth exploring side roads. Great day out for all ages.
Excellent views!. This is a fantastic place to really experience the spectacular coastal scenery of the region. Plenty of parking but not too much in the way of explanatory signage.

Where the Indian Ocean meets The Atlantic. Beautiful view and an amazing place where The Indian Ocean meets The Atlantic - and it is nearly the southernmost point of the African Continent. A must to visit
Ugh.. Soooo much potential to make this a great venue but the captive diners I think have made the management lackadaisical.

A must visit to Cape Point Nature Reserve.. The view in this Nature Reserve is spectacular. Watching the sunrise from high up on the mountain is awesome. There are a few game and flora to see. some beautiful beaches. Just be aware of the baboons they can be troublesome around food. It can become windy.

Wow!. South Africa has not disappointed with the awesome natural beauty that abounds here. Everywhere you look. Is jaw dropping. The park is so beautiful and very well kept so that tourists and locals alike can enjoy

Appreciate the “Beauty” of Creation...!!!. Cape Town has put a lot of effort into Nature Conservation, and it is very unfortunate that some disasters are man-made and result in huge loss of Fauna & Flora. Thank goodness these replenish over long periods of time. It is however worth the money spent to visit Cape Point and the Reserve to appreciate the “Beauty” of creation.

Great day trip. I've visited many times at different times of the year and it's always a great experience. It's great in winter when it's misty and rainy over the big open plains, and in summer, the magnificent skies over the sea with budding wild flowers offers a different experience. Spotting buck or ostrich occasionally is a highlight. The ride up the point is great too. You can do this trip in half a day.

Lovely area to visit. This is a Lovely area to visit with lots of diversity in plants and animals. We spent a day driving throughout the reserve and saw many kinds of Antelopes, wild Ostriches, Penguins, birds, and monkeys. We were blown away with the vistas and coastal areas, took tons of pictures and did a bit of shopping as well. Besides our Safari in Kruger, this was a highlight of our trip to Africa. Do take the time to stop into Kirstenbosch which looked like a lovely town although we did not stop there and only drove through.
Spectacular. Great place to go and sample the Cape Of Good Hope but beware peak season crowding and watch the weather.

Solitary, wild nature at its best. This relatively short trip from civilized Cape Town, presents the traveller with broad expanses of fields, scrub, and mountains, along with the opportunity to see wildlife such as the cheeky baboons, ostriches, antelope, hyrax, and other species in their natural habitat. There is also the famous Boulders Beach in Simons Town, where there is a colony of penguins in residence, right on the wild and beautiful coast. At the tip, the Cape of Good Hope, there is a lighthouse worth trekking to ( or be lazy and take the cable car up to near the top). There are souvenir shops and a place to eat something. The waves crashing against the rocky shores is hypnotic, and you can even swim in the sheltered cove near the cable car. Be very careful never to leave your car with windows ajar, or else it could literally be destroyed by the native baboons. Remember, this is their home, and you are merely a visitor here. Enjoy this amazing wild place, it is awe inspiring.and a place to contemplate what we value about or home planet.

Good views, nice day trip. We had lots of fun on our day trip to cape point. Make sure to check out every nook and cranny. A good place to rent a car is Around About Cars. It was right by our backpackers and had tiny cars for about 129 rand a day. Be careful of the monkeys and be ready for rain.

A bit of nostalgia. Although many people think it is the most southern tip of Africa they are a bit out (well with almost 300 kms!).A very nice (and easy) day trip from Cape Town. The drive through the national park (there is an entrance fee at the gate) is beautiful and the walk up to the lighthouse is amazing. There is a funicular for the less adventurous - but then again stopping to catch your breath is the ideal time to experience the beauty. Fun for the whole family.

A question to debate. Depending on who you ask - the question of where two oceans meet is open for discussion. Oceanographers and marine biologists do differ on this, however from a lay mans point of view it is a significant place to visit. To look out over the ocean from the top is great especially when you see the force of the sea and wonder how people survived this intrepid journey.

BEAUTIFUL. My girlfriend and I went to Cape Point in October 2014 and where blown away literally and figuratively haha. We walked up the stairway to get to the lighthouse at the top and then walked on the hiking path to get just that much closer to the point. We also couldn't help but buy a few souvenirs. We really had a great time here! Definitely worth a visit if you are a tourist, or even a local for that matter!!!

You wouldn't miss it would you?. Don't miss the trip to the bottom of Africa, the wlaks and view are definately worth it. I spent my 50th birthday looking out to Antarctica and could think of a better place to be. Lots to see on the way to and from Cape Town as well, Simonstown etc- don't miss the penguins, had a great hour swimming with them.

Awesome and breath taking. View from the tip of the southern most part of Africa is breath taking. The beaches are clean and the sea animals are definitely in a habitat of its own. Even the wild animals in the park are a pleasure to watch. Enjoy our stay very much. will return again and again.

The tip of Africa. This is always excellent we go here very often as it is another experience you cannot miss when visiting the Cape. When you on the time and looking down there is a little private beach which is so romantic. If you can get the chance and permission go down to that beach and you will think that you are in a movie. I love Cape Point nature at its best. Don't have space to put some pictures for this one.
Awesome place. Very Beautiful. Coastal views everywhere. DO some hiking in the area especially to the farther lighthouse.

Not the most Southerly point in Africa. It is an interesting drive from Cape Town out to Cape Point - if you have time it is worth stopping in either Muizenberg or Simonstown. They both have interesting little shops and sights to see.Everybody thinks that Cape Point is the the most southerly point in Africa and it is where the Indian and Atlantic Oceans join - it is not, both of those facts belong further along the coast at Cape Agullahs. When you arrive at the Cape you have a choice - you can either walk up to the top or take the funicular. Both are worth doing - one is cheaper than the other. The views looking out from the top of the Cape are spectacular and the sea has its own special color. Not only should you walk up to the main lighthouse you should also walk out to the much smaller white lighthouse at the end of the point - this is not so highly signposted and is really worth doing.The restaurant at the point also provides good food and a good view of life and it's myriad visitors. A trip to Cape Point would not be complete without also driving down to the Cape of Good Hope - here you can stand on the rocks close to the sea and be captivated by the waves crashing against the rocks.
Funny thing, it was just like Scotland. I could have been driving up through the Scottish Highlands, it was bizarre. Instead of seeing Deer at the roadside, it was Baboons! Fantastic!

Beautiful nature and great scenic drive. If you're in Cape Town you should also take advantage of all the nature it has to offer. After all, it's the greenest city in Africa! So get a car and get to one of the most scenic drives alongside the cliff side overlooking the bays on one side and green slopes on the other. Make sure you plan in a whole day to visit everything! Visit the lighthouse at the Cape of Good Hope, the Boulders Beach with the penguins and keep away from the gibbons (they are very naughty). There is an entrance fee, but it is worth it.

One of my favourites. Always try to go here when in Western Cape take a half day visit and drive round and see everything and have lunch in the restaurant which is really good food and no longer just tourist crap. My sister actually ate vegetarian sushi which looked beautiful Yes you pay to go into the reserve but it helps support SAN parks throughout South Africa. You will spot duikers if you are lucky loads of seabirds and maybe even a whale off the Point
Pure beauty. Nature and views from the top and the serenity of the place was out of this world. Cable car looked safe and worked well. Nothing to complain about.

The more scenic southern tip of South Africa!. I loved the whole experience of walking up to the lighthouse at cape point, climbing 126 steps up in the last stretch to the highest point to get the view and then coming back in the tram, more. The tram more popularly known as the Flying Dutchman Funicular has an interesting history behind it’s name. Also in the picture below you can see flags from multiple countries, this was an interesting fact. Though I did not get a chance to clarify this.

Lovely family outting. If you are local, do yourself a favour and buy your My Green card before going to Cape Point or boulders etc. Its a fraction of the cost!! Beware of the baboons. The funicular is fun for the kids,
Close to nature. It is always beautiful to visit Cape Point nature reserve. Specifically on a sunshiny day. You feel so close to nature

Disappointing. We toured Cape Point in May 2015 but was disappointed that the two oceans does not meet there as advertised. If you want to see where the two oceans meet then you need to travel to Cape Agulus. The view is amazing.

This is just the real wild nature!!!. This is definitely a must to visit when going on holiday to the Cape.nature is beautiful, and especially in spring when all the bright colours from all the Fynbos shows.one should know, after all, the Fairest Cape is known to have the best collection of Fynbos in the world.No matter if the weather is bad with rain or wind. Its still as beautiful. and after all... also known as the cape of storms

Beautiful Views. Great scenery and views of the Atlantic and Indian Oceans. Didn't get to spend much time here, but the views along the water are spectacular. The lighthouse at the Cape was interesting and there are lots of great photo ops along the way.
Natural Reserve - Cape Point. Beautiful place, so peaceful. It's great to go and spend the day (within the allowed time). From animals to vegetation, and the view .... no words!!!

Beautiful and interesting. We saw ostrich, bontebok, springbok and baboons on our journey and had our photographs taken at Cape Point where the surf was impressive. We also went on the Flying Dutchman funicular railway up to the lookout. The views are stunning.
Wet, Wet, Wet. We happened to have a very wet day and although this did not take away from the beauty of Cape point it did deter sightings of any wild life other than a family of very wet ostrich.

Surreal. When I was growing up I learned about the Cape of Good Hope and its significance on the history of the world. It was simply amazing to stand over those rocks and see both oceans, the Atlantic and the Indian collide. The trip up to the light house is well worth it. Don't bother with the restaurant there unless you are very hungry and can't wait to go somewhere else.

Just okay. Not much to do here except to take pics next to the board that displays the coordinates. And climb a hill. And a bunch of rocks. Good just to say you have been there. Not much fun otherwise. Makes for decent pics too.
Must Go. Once in Cape town and not be at this place is better don’t go. Its amazing be up and see 2 oceans, one from each side….the green color and the blue color mixing where the met each other.

A fantastic place for a visit. Outstanding scenery, the meeting point of two oceans and if you are in the area you must visit it. Driving through the park the main wildlife you will see are Baboons, dont be tempted to feed them as if you are caught you will be in trouble. The views from around the light house are epic. I used the Flying Dutchman to get to the top and took a walk back. Even at the end of the South African Autumn the sun was strong and once you were out of the wind still warm Didnt eat or drink there, but the shops on site seem reasonable considering it is a tourist trap. Well worth a visit.

STUNNING. This is a must on anyone's itinerary. We were so lucky to go on such a beautiful day and it was fantastic! Would highly recommend both Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope. Ignore the signs saying it's a 1.5hour walk to the second, newer lighthouse at cape Point - it's about 15/20 and definitely worth doing. The scenery is spectacular and it was much quieter than the older lighthouse where all the (other) tourists seem to stay.

Breathtaking!!!. one of the most beautiful places I have ever seen. I was told that usually it is cloudy over there, but when I was there the weather was perfect, and I saw how clouds were forming, It was sooo beautiful

Fantastic Day trip. An incredible day trip. We hired a car in Cape Town for the day, and with a GPS, it was an easy drive of just under 2 hours with some roadworks. The drive down the west coast from Cape Town was one of the most spectacular we have done. There was a manned toll booth for this road so have some cash handy. The views on arrival were gobsmacking. We stopped in Simons Town for a coffee on the way down - restaurants, galleries, and a penguin colony. We wished we had a night or two to stay and explore further.

Most spectacular views. The most southern tip on the Cape Peninsula offers mind-boggling 360-degree views, dramatic scenery, fantastic hiking trails, deserted beaches and a sprinkling of big game in the reserve, some great bird watching, and in spring you might catch a glimpse of a whale close to shore.The restaurant is fabulous and if you don't want to walk up, there's the fun funicular ride. This World heritage site offers visitors everything they could dream of, including some great gifts from the shop to take home to family and friends back home. Just watch out for the baboons - don't feed them under any circumstances and keep your car windows closed - they're known little thieves that will love to relieve you of your possessions or snacks :)
View to the End of the World. Don't just take pictures at the bottom, climb up, look out, breather deep and think that the Next continent is AntarcticaJust Do It!

How Could You Not Go to Gape Point?. After travelling zillions of miles (for many of us) it would be criminal to not visit Cape Point. We all know the history and the geography but you have to see it. Highly recommended.

Baboon alert!. Great family outing. Beautiful scenic drive especially if you travel via Chapman's Peak (if open). Baboons tried to "rob" us in the parking area, but that was part of the fun. Great place to hike.
cape point. This is a magnificent place to visit ,the environment is beautiful ,it is like heaven on earth and a must see site.

Incredible views. We hired a driver Lesley Cox for the day whom we had worked with 2 years ago and spent the day at the coast and touring vineyards. We were greeted by ostrich walking down the road, what a graceful giant! The area by the ocean had incredible parking and a easy walk down to view the water. Beautiful way to spend a day.

High Priority Site!. Rent a car and spend a day cruising from Muizenberg to Cape Point through Kalk's Bay, Simonstown, Boulder Beach. Spend a few hours exploring the Cape Point area. Make your return trip up through Scarborough, Camp's Bay and Clifton via Chapman's Peak Drive. You'll never regret this day!
Cape Point resturant. At the Cape Point, only have a restaurant - Two Ocean. The food is nice but not much to choose. The price is middle to high.
Where two oceans meet. Gorgeous scenery, unspoilt beauty. It was really difficult to find anything wrong with this locality. So want to go back..

Beautiful Road Trip!. Plan a few hours to travel to Cape Point to see the nature reserve and experience the views, the lighthouse and all there is to see and do. We were a bit rushed for time but it was so worth it. We even saw some wild ostrich and baboons! We even had one climb on our car!

Good idea for a day excursion from Cape Town. Excursion going by Houtbay / Simon's Town / Cape Point.This is an excursion to do for a day.If you have a rental car you can go on your own, if you do not, Baz Bus propose one with very good guide!

A must see. Cape Point is definetely one of the most attractive feature Cape Town has to offer. The drive alone is really magnificent and if offers views to die for and when you reach the point you will understand why. Watch out for the baboons on the road and remember not to leave your car windows open when you stop to see them because they can be dangerous. If you want to you can walk to the top of the light out and see the view of the place the 2 oceans meet (The Atlantic and Indian) believe me when I say this, it is an amazing view.
Spectacular. how could you not fall in love with the beauty of the cape point! the views are spectacular and it's such an experience to go to the southern most tip of africa. totally worth visiting!
Gorgeous scenery. Beautiful views, easy drive from Cape Town. While not the exact meeting point between the Indian and Atlantic oceans, it was pretty close for us from North America!

A great day out!. Bit of a drive from Cape Town but well worth a visit. Lots of lovely walks and trails and the scenery is stunning. Can get a bit windy and cold just wrap up! Thought we might visit the restaurant for lunch but found it overpriced, they must be catering for the overseas visitors. Difficult to eat/picnic outside the restaurants in any of the parking/seating areas as they have a baboon issue, sadly made worse by visitors giving them food!
Awesome views. The scenery and views were awesome. The roads reasonably good. Birdlife plentiful if you take the time to look. Great walking trails and spectacular views

A white beach , the breath of the Ocean and . .... Una spiaggia bianca, l'oceano che urla, solo tre creature .... It has been a great idea to rent a car and drive all down to Cape Point. Although a little scared - being alone - I did the right choice. This has revealed as one of the unforgettable day in my life. The Nature of Cape og Good Hope is incredible: hthe highest cliffs, owesome desert white beaches , soap wawes, wind and nobody..... will never forget the emotion of such incredible natural wonder. It is safe, it is incredible.... Do NOT go with big buses , go with your own car and stop by where you want ... means every two kilometers... take yoyur time and enjoy!!!

Stunning views on a grand scale. Worth taking the drive out from CT or a tour, were from the UK so found the scale of the scenery much more dramatic than at home.We're not big walkers but I can imagine you could spend a full day in the national park on foot.Highly recommended must do whilst in SA

Disappointing. What a disappointment, driving all the way to Cape Point only to discover not much on the other side of the world. We wanted to go to the restaurant but it was jam packed full and had a looooong que waiting to be seated. It was also overpriced. Fortunately I'm a nature lover and took my camera along, so it saved the day... but I would probably only go once - for the experience.There is a shipwreck walk that I have heard is outstanding; so before I'm too harsh in my review, let me add this titbit!

Views & more. Part of our day trip was this - there is a place to eat, funicular railcar to take you nearly to the top - we were not physically able to climb to the lighthouse at the top but the views were magnificent - joining of both oceans - excellent artefact shops

Excellent day out. I booked a tour with one of the many operators (can't remember which one, sorry) in February 2009. Going to the Cape of Good Hope is one of the things to do when already in Cape Town and you'll see a lot of the peninsula while driving. Take a boat tour to penguin rocks from Hout Bay for example on the way there. You can get the Cableway to get up to the restaurant at the top to have lunch and then walk down - great view of the cliffs and the ocean foaming below you. Have fun while at the Cape!

Very nice reserve, ocean views, excellent food. Be there early so you can beat the busses, bring sunscreen and a wind breaker, as you weill be exposed to the sun, and on a windy day it can get cold. Get your food not from the fast food take out but the real restaurant. Top food with excellent flavors, and reasonable priced. Exceptionally friendly staff and wonderful ocean views. We had no baboons in sight even though the nature reserve is notoriously famous for them. Do not feed them, lock your car, don't carry food in your bags.

Something special. This was a great way to spend a lazy Sunday afternoon. A couple of us rented a car and drove through to Cape Point reserve and loved the different vistas and especially the ostriches who tried to eat my hand. Beautiful, but the cable car was a bit crowded with long cues. Prices were on the high end.

Beautiful scenery, Breathtaking views. The nature reserve has Mountains views, ocean views , blooming flowers, abundant plant life ,Cape of good hope, historic lighthouse, hiking trails (steps to the lighthouse). They day we were there it was not as windy as I heard it could be which was very nice.

Fantastic!. The scenery was very varied and magnificent. The views from Cape Point lighthouse were spectacular. We did not see a lot of wildlife, just some baboons and ostriches, but the reserve is very large, so antelopes have a wide area to roam. TheAtlantic Ocean was very cold!
Gorgeous Scenery. Love the babboons with their little tricks, excellent place to walk around and take in the beauty of the two oceans, well looked after nature reserve

One of the major sights in the world. Spectacular views - walk up to the old lighthouse. This is one of the most dramatic places on earth. Not quite as good as the Kauai coast, but you don't need a helicopter tour to see it. It is worth the trip just for this - add it to your bucket list. But allow for bad weather - you need a clear day.
You have to go to say you have.. A good day out with stops en-route. Limited food availability at the Cape but good overall day trip.

Gorgeous. I like going to places where two large bodies of water connect and Cape Point is one of the more dramatic I've seen. Excellent photo opportunities and in general it's a good place to relax and enjoy the spray of salt water. Not too many animals spotted but overall a wonderful day.

Gorgeous scenery, wild animals and the iconic Cape of Good Hope. The point area is beautiful. The sea crystal clear and the mountains craggy but the drive there and back is just as lovely. Stop for seafood lunch at one of the many picturesque little towns along the way

Gorgeous Views and Great Hikes.. Takes about an hour to get out to Cape Point but it is so worth it. We by passed the tram up to the top of the point and it was worth it. We walked to all the look out points, great views of the cliffs. we hiked up tot he light house and took pictures of the cliffs. We then walked down to the farthest point of Cape Point. They say that it takes 1.5 hours to get there but thats so not true maybe takes 30 mins.
WOW....almost the tip of Africa. Yes....a must see location as is tough to get any further south then here. A walk up the million steps to the lighthouse is also a must.

Bucket list adventure. I initially wanted my guide to just take me to the Cape of Good Hope sign for obligatory photos and views of the Atlantic, but he talked me into going up to the lighthouse as well. I had just had lunch, and it was a 20 minute,incredibly tedious hike up. Man. I am so glad I went despite the ferocious wind and chilly weather that day. The views are unrivaled and absolutely breathtaking. My best photos from my visit to Cape Town are from Cape Point. Do not pass this up!

Impressive Land Head at Cape Point. Compared to the unimpressive Cape of Good Hope nearby, this IS impressive. Wildly beautiful with with a lighthouse on the cliff 200 meters above the Ocean. Walk up to the lighthouse or take the funicular, your choice, round trip or ride up and walk down. The views are spectacular, the winds can be fierce and the cold penetrating.
Awesome appreciation of nature. Worth a trip and make sure you have enough time to to appreciate the majestic and relaxing environment, really awesome.

A must-have!. anyone should visit the cape - the park is beautiful and one can see that wind is a major player in this area - only low Fynbos vegetation. Weather is unpredictable but being on the cape is unforgettable

Amazing Vistas. When in Cape Town, you just have to go the cape itself as well. And the views at Cape Point (way better than the ones at Cape of Good hope) were spectacular indeed. However, what we liked even more were the views you got when driving back to Cape Town along the Western route along the Coleman's pass. Incredible when the sun is setting!

Wild, windy & wonderful. We were here on a very windy day, so be aware that if you hike to the top for the views, you might get blown about a lot. The path is steep & rocky in many parts, although there are steps & walkways on other parts. On a good day you might spot whales, ostriches and baboons.

The highlight of our Cape Peninsula day trip. Cape Point was, in my opinion, the best experience of all on our various road trip adventures outside of the city. The drive from Cape Town to the peninsula tip itself is fascinating with some of the most beautiful views and landscape I've ever seen along the west coast. I've read some reviews saying that not much happens there but clearly they are not fans of tranquil, natural habitats. The reserve is well protected leaving it fairly untouched, particularly noticeable when heading off the main road on one the many walking trails. The views up at the lighthouse give a panoramic view of endless oceans to south, across the bay to the mountainous east and over the Atlantic and up the peninsula coast to the west. Perfect scenes to meditate on the vastness of our world or simply stand in awe of the diversity of mother nature's greatness.
Brilliant. Standiing at the end of the continent was a super feeling.. lovely drive from Cape Town and clear skies and water made it surrealwill go again

Fantastic!!. The views are amazing!! Unfortunately I was too hungry to wait for a table at the fancy restaurant which supposedly has great food (think I saw a 4 + rating from tripadvisor), but in case you're not that starving I would recommend to have lunch there as a part of your visit. Watch out for the baboons, they are dangerous and will snatch food and whatever else they fee like right out of your hand, don't try to hold on to it if this happens. They do have park rangers who tries to keep them away from people. Cape of good hope truly takes your breath away!

See the fairest Cape in all the world.. Entrance Fee: R 110 for Adults - R 55 for Children If you want to see the fairest Cape in all the world, and learn about the history of South Africa then you have to go to Cape Point.You will experience shree and inspiring beauty. Even my kids were impressed.There was a shop to buy curios at the bottom of the point and one at the top of the point. The road you drive along to get to Cape Point was in excellent condition and well signposted.Much fun was had by all.

A must see and visit, provided you have deep pockets. A fantastic place to visit and experience. Really geared for tourism and this could be the problem. As a local, it becomes an expensive experience. From the entrance fee to the reserve plus the fee for the funicular (unless you are young and fit) to the utter insult of the extortionist prices in the restaurant. A good day and experience spoiled by this fact. Perhaps the restaurant only wants to cater to foreign tourists?

Trip around Cape point. We hired a driver to take us to Cape point. This meant that we could stop wherever we wanted to on the drive to and from the Cape and we could both appreciate the views. The drive is very scenic via chapman's peak.We had already visited camps bay and houts bay on the tourist bus and had seen the penguin colony at Betty's Bay so gave boulders beach a miss. The point is almost the most southerly point on the continent . You can spot the whales from the viewing points.We walked up to the light house and viewing point but there is a funicular. The drive back was via Simons town.

do it only if you have a spare day. Do not expect to see two oceans clash- it really is a nothing event and nothing spectacular. HowEver the drive to get to the reserve is beautiful and the restaurant at Cape Point is certainly excellent. So if you have done and seen everything, take a leisurelydrive here, have lunch and tehn take a leisurely drive back to Cape Town through Simon's town

Do not go to Cape Town without visiting the point. This is a beautiful area that has been kept in excellent condition. Yes, it is a very touristy area but it should not be missed.. I would definately visit the lighthouse, we took the tramway to get to the top..I was glad we ddid because there is another walk to do when you get there which will take you all the way to the end... It's only a 30 minutes walk but it was worthwhile and most of the tourists do not go there, so it gives you a bit of peace and quiet for a short time and it is a great place to visit.
Not worth the cost. The views are good but it is very expensive. The cost is R110 per adult and another R55 to use the tram. Be advised this is where the currents meet and not the two oceans.

Indian and Atlantic Oceans Meet here!. So exciting to see the point where the Indian and Atlantic oceans meet! Our hired driver brought us to the parking lot and we chose to walk the .65 mile/21 minute hike up to the light house rather than pay to ride the funicular. It was a beautiful walk!!! Great photos along the way as well. It is really very romantic as you look down on the Atlantic Ocean. The fog came blowing in while we were there. There is a beautiful light house on the peak that was made after the Portuguese liner Lusitania wrecked here (not to be confused with the Lusitania sunk in WWI by a German sub). The light house was found ineffective due to the fog as well! At this point you are looking literally down at the point where the Atlantic and Indian oceans meet. The fog was blowing in over the Atlantic while we were there and the peak of the cape block and sent the fog high above us so we could see the Indian Ocean very well! Our driver got a sandwich at the shops below while we were hiking and got immediately ill from it--warning! We did pick up a coffee mug at the nice souvenir store up by the light house. It was a wonderful visit and I couldn't imagine coming all this way and not seeing this iconic sight!

Stunning place. If you are based in Cape Town,my advice is to hire a car and drive down one side of the peninsula and return on the other side. You will be rewarded with stunning views and wonderful towns. Wait till you drive Chapmans Peak,it will take your breath away.
Worth the trip. Being able to see both oceans and take in the feeling of history that has occurred here was amazing a it was our first time in South Africa

Fantastic place!. We only had a few hours to spend but it was really worth going! Beatiful mountaineous area, gets very windy in autumn though, prepare for super cold wind especially near the lighthouse. We walked all the way to the lighthouse but you can take the little train too. There are many harder or easier hiking trails available, we walked to cape of good hope (about 1 hour return trip) and visited the stupendous beach on the way. There are also several places where shipwrecks may or may not be visible although one of the main shipwreck trails was closed then due to terrible bushfire a few weeks before. Careful with baboons you can see them feeding on the beach, they can be quite bold there as they are protected - don't feed them!! Just watch at a distance. We also saw a huge antelope, an ostrich and a mongoose on the way!

Beautiful as always but avoid the overpriced restaurant!. I visit Cape Point every few years and it remains one of the Cape Peninsula's most spectacular natural attractions. We always made a point to get there early to have breakfast at the 2 Oceans restaurant which no doubt has some of the most spectacular views in the country. The restaurant has recently undergone a total revamp including an interior redesign and unfortunately the menu has been completely overhauled too. The new menu is now extremely overpriced and will be unaffordable for most Capetonians. The stuffy choices of food options on the new menu are also downright bizarre and simply don't suit the relaxed, touristy Cape Point atmosphere at all. The entrance ticket to the park has also become incredibly expensive and will itself soon make the trip through the park unaffordable for local families, which is a huge pity as the park is such a beautiful place. Hopefully Cape Point will eventually implement a similar system to many other local tourist attractions where lower prices are offered for local citizens with an SA ID/Passport.My only real genuine complaint about the park is the total lack of visitor information. The only effort made to inform the visitor is a basic DL sized flyer handed to visitors upon entering. Any further information gathering is left to the visitor to self-serve at the half-attempt of a visitors centre a short distance inside the park. Improved signage and information offerings dispersed throughout the park could be vastly improved upon and this would seriously improve the visitor's experience.

Cape Point. Love every area of this beautiful part of history, plenty of walks, mountain bike routes, touch and learn area in the info centre, the lighthouse is a must see and the Two Oceans Restaurant serves a fantastic breakfast with lovely staff.
Worth a visit. We weren't going to bother but so pleased we did, the views from Cape Point are amazing. We used Grant Sayers from Go Cape Tours and his knowledge made our trip much more enjoyable.

Second time there and still beautiful. Beautiful location and great for photos. You can ride up or walk up. This is part of an all day tour of this area and is very picturesque. Baboons and other animals along the way

Another beauty must see.. Have been here more than ten tomes over the years to show my friends and family.
Stunning place to see but again I stress that it is out pricing people like me and cannot go as often as I would like.
The main restaurant also too expensive.
But…must see!!!

Breathtaking.. It is a steep walk to Cape Point, but it is definitely a walk to be done to the beautiful view. The most southern point of Africa leaves you humbled and absolutely astounded. Something to add the to-do list, as a couple or a family, as it is family friendly. The drive in is also beautiful, just beware of the baboons hanging around for food.

Beautiful Spot. We visited Cape Point as part of a day tour. If you're visiting Cape Town, you really should check it out. Even the drive there is gorgeous because it is along the coast which is spectacular.
Watch out for baboons. Wonderful scenery, sea, cliffs and beaches but watch for baboons as they will tear the rubber off your windscreen wipers! Keep windows closed.

Amazing to see the oceans meet. I am visiting Cape Town from London, and really loved just visiting Cape Point Nature Reserve! The finebos is amazing! So are the baboons. and it was awesome to see the Atlantic ocean meet the Indian Ocean - I swear I could see the line. Great destination for Nature Lovers and ecotourists.
Stunning. We drove clockwise from Cape Town on the east side and back on the west stopping at chapman's peak for sunset. The drive must be one of the world's best. Highly recommended.

Ostriches, springboks and coastal trails. We drove through the natural reserve while visiting Cape of Good Hope. The area is rich in indigenous animal and plant species and offers beaten walking trails, e.g. one between Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope. Ticket to Cape of Good Hope includes entrance to the park.
Not much to do there, but must see anyway. Spectacular views. Some wildlife to see along the way, both on land and in the sea. You really can't go to Cape Town and not see where the two oceans meet.

Beautiful views of the ocean. We drove from Cape Town to Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope which was an experience in itself. My first time driving on left side of road and it was very winding with mountain passes. If you rent a car, get a GPS or finding your way there would be difficult. We took the funicular to the top; but you can walk as well. It's straight uphill and at the funicular station stop you can still walk up about another 100 ft if you are in shape. Views are fantastic and water is so blue. Watch out for the baboons. They are very aggressive in this area. Don't have any food out as a baboon might try to take it from you.
Great visist to Cape Point. Amazing scenery, lovely drive, great to spot animals too. Not expensive and good to be supporting the nature reserve.

place must to see. Besides table mountain a place to visit while in Cape town. I would recommend if you rented a car to drive via Chapmans road to CP. You will have nice view on the beaches. When you are there i recommend a short hike to the top, where you can get great panorama pictures.

Saturday Visit. We drove through the Cape Point Point Nature Reserve very slowly enjoying the beauty and drinking in the clean air and quietness. It was a restful visit, we did not see any wild life but it did not matter as the time spend there was magical. Expensive to enter but well worth it, breathtaking views of a much loved place.

Awesome. Brilliant place!! If you're in Cape Town, traveler or not, you have to visit this place. We went as a team to explore Cape Town and it was our first time being at Cape Point. The view is AMAZEBALLS!! Not to MISS!

Breath-taking Views!. Cape Point Nature Reserve was just one stop on our day-long tour. The scenery on the way was beautiful, and once there, the views (especially from the lighthouse up top) were breath-taking. While up there, we saw families of baboons and even saw one snatch a bag of chips from a tourist! I highly recommend a visit to the Cape Point Nature Reserve!

was a cool location. My wife and I hired a driver and car for the day and explored the region including some wineries.The national park is cool, but not dis similar to any other park. However the cape point is wow. Climb to the light house for some great photos.

Breath taking. I was in The Cape more than 20 years ago and although the beauty of the place has not changed, i did find that a lot of development has been done around catering for tourists. There are now so many walk ways that if you had the time an energy, you could keep busy for days. The florna and flora is absolutely beautiful, coupled with sandy beaches, cliff faces and aqua blue waters. The highlight is the Cape Point where the two oceans meet (The Atlantic and The Indian Ocean). To get to the point you can either opt to walk up a number of stairs or for a fee catch a Tram ride up. At the top you still will need to walk up some more stairs to the point. The reward at the top is a breath taking 360 degree view of the Atlantic and Indian Oceans. The Cape Point is a far ride out of Cape Town, but if you take the scenic route past Capmans peak, them the ride becomes a journey filled with hidden treasures and look out points. A must see if this is your first time in Cape Town.
Worth the drive. Fantastic scenery along the way to get there and while there especially along the coast. Lots of animals, we saw ostriches, zebra and large families of baboons!

The Photo Destination. if you are a keen photographer then this is for you. The views are good but it is hard to do much. Don't bring your kids for more than an hour because they will get bored. It looks like a photo-shoot destination.

worth it. Just the fact you that you know this is a place where to oceans collide gives you a sense of majesty of the place. As reserve you don't see much in terms of wild animals except baboons and some ostriches but never the less its was worth the long drive through the beautiful Chapman's hill and to stand in a place with such importance

The edge of Africa. I was amazed by the sheer immensity of the Nature Reserve as well as its natural beauty. You can spend hours wandering around it, breathing in the ocean air, admiring the animals (ostriches, baboons, seals) and incredibly rich plant life. The obvious highlight is Cape Point where the Atlantic and Indian Ocean meet. Magical!

Part of One of My Favourite Ocean Drives. We visited the Cape Point Nature Reserve as a part of a bigger day out, driving the coast line. Windy!!! Take a jacket, take your camera. Great views! Cheeky baboons - we saw a few stealing food off unsuspecting people and another hanging off the back of a parked car while chewing the air foil.
brillant views!. you can't visit the Cape and not see Cape Point!! quite a steep walk, but absolutely worth it! just to stand at the cliffs and see the breathtaking views make it all worth while

Nice small towns, dramatic coastal scenery.. A good day out from Cape Town. I arranged a car and driver for the day (Rand1750). Stunning coastal scenery as we headed south from Cape Town through beachside suburbs, fishing towns, about 2 hours to Cape Point area. Worth the walk or the small train up the lighthouse on the point. Amazing views over the Atlantic Ocean (and coastal cliffs and beaches) and across False Bay and Indian Ocean. We drove back through the wine regions (slightly inland)...beautiful.

Bottom of Africa (almost). Great day tour out of Cape Town with so much to see from the penguins at Boulder to Cape Point. The day was packed but enjoyable. Wouldn't be much fun in the rain but we were lucky with superb weather if a little windy which is normal apparently.
Absolutely stunning. A visit is a must for the scenery. On a good day, which we had, this place cannot be beat. I would go early as it gets very busy, at least on weekends.

wear comfy shoes. Cape Point & Cape Of Good Hope are well worth it.... we used a hire car rather than a tour bus and did it at our own pace. Stop at Caulk Bay and or Simons Town on tbe way for breakfast.... (the Meeting Place in Simons Town is my tip)
Well maintained and gorgeous views. We spent one day driving out to this historical venue. Amazingly well maintained. Small fee for entrance was absolutely worth it to maintain this site

Dramatic views. Well worth the trip from Capetown, stop off on the way for coffee in one of the smaller towns.We set out early it took quite a while and traffic can be bad.Well worth the trip, shame about the telecoms mast which spoilt some views but if you love dramatic sea views this is for you. Plenty of walks to do too.
Amazing. Well worth the drive. Enjoyed seeing the scenery, and the dramatic feeling of being at the end of the southern tip of Africa, plus baboons!

Very nice, but there's a lot more to see. Yes, it's a beautiful area, but it's not the best part of the larger picture, which is the Cape Peninsula tour as a whole, a spectacular marine drive, best done in 1 - 2 days, including the beautiful western coastal suburbs of Cape Town, in particular, the beach communities of Clifton and Camps Bay, the Chapmans Peak Drive skirting the mountains and cliffs, the fishing village of Hout Bay and neighboring beach communities like Kommetjie and Llandudno. Only then do you reach the Cape of Good Hope Nature Reserve, which is quite small in area. Some of the animals. like the Bontebok, were introduced from other areas. After a quick visit to blustery Cape Point, it's on through the False Bay side and you pass through more fishing villages and beach resorts, including Boulders Beach with its African penguins, before heading back to central Cape Town. A 2-day trip could include a detour to the neighboring beautuful Constantia valley with its wine estates with their spectacular mountain backdrop - also a great dining area - the Tokai estate, and the pleasant, leafy southern suburbs. One of the world's great motor tours. Unless it's raining, don't miss it.

fabulous view. The walk up to the top is a little hard...lots of steps and uphill...but the view from the top is so worth it! Baboons hang around the parking lot looking for handouts! Very nice gift shop at the top..if you're too tired to walk back there is a cable tram to take you back. A very relaxing and serene atmosphere. the restrooms are very clean !
Windy but beautiful. Great spot, a bit of wildlife (baboons, antelope, ostrich), a fairly steep walk up to the lighthouse, nice to see

Not the meeting of Indian and Atlantic Oceans. The Penguins at Boulder's bay, Simonstown were a joy to behold.The drive is on the verge of too far for a half day trip and our driver was rushing to avoid a fine for staying in the National Park too long and returning home in the daylight so the journey was not the most comfortable

Amazing Experience. Visiting the Cape of Good Hope has been a lifelong dream and certainly the wide vistas and amazing terrain didn't disappoint. Entry to the park is by way of a small fee and the funicular is an additional cost although its just as easy to take a slow walk up the hill to the lighthouse. The one thing or rather things to watch out for are the somewhat unruly baboons which apparently have attacked tourists suspected of hoarding food!Misbehaving wildlife aside the views from the lighthouse include the Cape itself as well as a number of wild ostriches and a couple of antelopes we were not able to identify but they would have been either Kudu or Springbok according to the locals.There is a little museum just before the funicular exit that gives a little more information on the park and the lighthouses in the vicinity that is worth pausing a moment at.Beyond that, guests are required to leave before the park closes each evening or face a ZAR500 fine. If you're driving its around a two to two and a half hour visit but there were also cyclists and motor cyclists. But having ones picture taken at the Cape of Good Hope signboard was the culmination of years of reading about the cape and the many sunken ships and drowned sailors there, a thought made even more vivid while looking at the whirlpool just off the cape!Great place to tick off the bucket list!

Explore and explore some more. Make sure you leave a whole day to spend there and go off the main roads and explore some of the side routes which take you to some great beaches and unexpected finds. We stumbled across a tortoise and some ostrich. The map they provide you with when you pay is great and we drove down every road! The route up to the lighthouse is very busy as is the Cape of Good Hope area as everyone wants their photo taken by the sign.

..not the Southern most tip of the country but the most famous... ..the journey out to the Point was worth it alone..stunning scenery..food and shopping exist..one word of warning..baboons will get in your car and there are plenty of notices warning you about the danger, a real danger!..

The end of the world. This is a great place to see. Take the vernacular to the top at the lighthouse and see where the two oceans meet, and walk down - the views are fabulous. Food here is very expensive so take your own food & drink. Do not feed the baboons they are dangerous and they are no longer afraid of people. Lock your car and close all windows no matter how HOT it is

Great national park. On arrival we were unsure of what the expect as all we intended to do was visit Cape Point not realizing that we had to go through a national park to do so. Once paying to enter the park there were many of there interesting attractions and hikes. paths, rail car and facilities are all world class. Well worth a visit.
Very Beautiful. We took a tour here to be able to enjoy the scenery when driving from Cape Town to the point. This is a must see if you are visiting Cape Town.

worth the trip!. This place offers great views of the ocean and bays and if you are lucky you can see ostrich, baboons( they can be aggressive) and few "game animals". we had a picnic there, and the tour bus stopped also at the cape of good hope.
Third visit. Lovely reserve but try to avoid over mail holiday period as it takes so long to get through the main gates. Some fantastic views from so many different parts of the reserve.

An Adventure!!. I did a tour that went to Boulder's Beach in Simons Town and Seal Island in Hout Bay, then biked down to Cape Point. It was a great tour, we all had a lot of fun. (Myself and other travellers who booked the same tour). The hostel booked it with Day Trippers, which was a great company and great guide!

Stunning. You have to remember that this is basically a visit for people who love beautiful landscapes and do not mind a walk. I would have loved to have done the 90 minute round trip on foot to the Cape of Good Hope but the rest of the party were not keen. If you go there you will be away from the madding crowd and might be able to appreciate the magnificence of the scenery at peace. Quite a big climb to the light house but you can be idle an take the funicular. If you are prepared to walk, you will get the best out of this trip.

Knocked me off my feet, Literally!. Myself and two friends made the long drive here immediately after arriving at the airport to make sure we beat the rush hour traffic in the evening. The entire drive was amazing!!! We climbed mountains and drove through a small town before arriving at the entrance of the park. Unfortunately for us we had no idea that there was a separate entrance fee from the train car we had seen online so that took a chunk out of our cash on hand. We decided to pay the fee nonetheless thinking it quite steep but later seeing that there are a million things you could do after entering park and how you could spend an entire day there, we understood. It was another 6k or so to get to the actual place where you could take the street car or walk it up to the lighthouse. There is free parking in the parking lot which is quite small and also along the sides of the road, which is where we ended up parking. There were two options available. You could go up to the lighthouse or down to the shore. We opted for the lighthouse since it was way shorter, the alternative would have taken us 1 1/2 hours to go and return. My oh my was it windy that day! Or is it like that everyday???? I literally was being blown off my feet and had to steady myself quite a few times. We decided to make the trek up to the lighthouse since to take the street car was R52 which we had already spent in the entrance fee :( It was a fun walk with my girlfriends and we had jokes for days with people encouraging us, "You can make it!" as we struggled to make it to the top. It took us about 20 minutes but it really could have taken us 5 if we hadn't stopped and taken breaks along the way. Oh, and there are plenty of stairs as well, so prepare yourself. We finally made it to the top of the lighthouse and man it was gorgeous! Windy but gorgeous. Had to hold on to my cellphone with both hands while taking pics. I must say parents with small kids should be weary of taking them up there because with all the wind and the altitude our ears were killing us. We saw a mother with a small baby at the top and the child was screaming it's head off. We took a few minutes to peruse the gift shop just to give our ears a break which actually helped as we made our way back down. Definitely a must-see if you are ever in Cape Town!

The best views in Africa. Its another expensive attraction so don't just come for an hour or 2. Rather leave early (over an hours drive from Cape Town) and spend the day. There are some small beaches on side road which you could relax or have a picnic at. Some nice trails to walk, especially the one from the old lighthouse where everyone normally goes to the new lighthouse much lower down and closer to the actual end of the land. he views a retsunning from almost anywhere in the park. I'm not sure if the Oceans do actually meet here as I've never seen the clear difference in water or colours. Its possible that the Oceans meet at Cape Aghulas further South East. But if you look closely may see some greenish water near the beaches on the Atlantic side and greyish water on the India Ocean side.
Must see. It's always on our list when visitors come. It's beautiful and the views are extraordinary. Go onto the beach road and enjoy the troops of baboons, they are always around.

Penguins in Africa?. The rugged terrain of South Africa really culminates as you approach the tip of Cape Point. Truly spectacular. It's hard to believe that the next land that you would come across is the South Pole. It's worth the trip alone to see the Penguins. And then there's the Baboons and Ostriches just wandering around.

Fantastic. Not only it's the most southern point in Africa, you will have the most spectacular views of the ocean and cliffs. Coming there, you'll have, most certain, the oportunity to see many baboons on their natural environment. Do not miss it!

Exceptional Long Day, But Worth Every Hour. We booked a private tour departing our hotel in Cape Town and took the scenic route down to the Cape.On entering the National Park we headed for the lighthouse, parking close to the train. However, if it is busy be prepared for a long walk from where you park to the base station. The lighthouse is many feet above the base station and you can either walk up the hill or take the train.At the top station the view is good, but the lighthouse is still about 100 stairs up. It is a good climb, the stairs are generally in good condition, but the view from the top is spectacular and well worth expending the energy.During our visit the contrast on either side of the Cape was amazing, to the West it was clear as day, but to the East it was completed covered in fog. On completion we headed down to the Cape sign for a photograph and walk along the beach. The water is shallow and crystal clear.Driving back we saw a family of baboons playing by the side of the road.

Magnificent views!. What wonderful scenery. My husband and I walked up to lighthouse and admired the most wonderful views. Very good exercise! It was very busy but not overcrowded. The ocean views go for miles. We had a very tasty lunch at the restaurant afterwards which also had beautiful views. The shops were very well priced and we purchased a lot of gifts.

Wonderful day. We hired a private guide with car to go from Cape Town to the CGH. It was a great trip through a couple of little towns and then down to the point. We went to Boulders and saw the penguins--that was a real treat. We had a nice meal at the restaurant--a bird stole a calamari right off my plate! This is a must side trip from Cape Town.

Great views BUT... Worth a visit for the fantastic views. One thing that was disappointing was the fact that cyclists are charged the same entry as someone entering in a car. This is despite there being a number of signs near the point which highlight concerns about raising carbon emissions!

Be prepared for a bad hair day.. The drive to Cape Point was very scenic. We went with a local tour co. called Thompsons and the guide called Mark was very good.
