He was giving us information all the time on the way there.The scenery was breath-taking. We stopped at Cape-Point and it was extremely windy even though the sun was shining and it was hot. We posed for the obligatory photo at the Cape-Point sign and then we drove on to the Funicular Railway and the lighthouse. Later we had a nice walk through the Kirstenbosch Botanical gardens which was pleasant. I think Cape Point is worth seeing but maybe choose a day not as windy.

Amazing views. Bit tricky if windy so try to earlier in the day on a calm day. Grab a sandwich/salad and sit on one of the tables by the restaurant to get the view. Beware of birds flying into your sandwich to steal food!
Wonderful. Had a great time driving around here. Was much better to do on your own, rent a car you will enjoy it. Also, don't miss going to see the penguins, that was a blast!
Stunning. Another Cape Town must, took private car and driver for day trip, views and scenery couldn't be better.. spectacular.

Enjoyable day out and about. Quite expensive but go with the idea of spending the day. Did a short hike from Cape of Good Hope (where all the tourists take pics at the 'Most South Western Point' in Africa) up towards cape point. Awesome views and daisies and, and.... Also went to the restaurant and up the funicular to the light house. Great day all in all

Longer than you expect. There is a lot to do at this attraction. We rushed there and did the walk to the lighthouse and then had to rush off. There are several walks that you can do there and also you can go to the beach there and so would be a good trip for the entire morning or even day. Just remember that it takes a while to get there!Beautiful spot and we loved it.
a must see. A great day trip that you must do while in Capetown, the trip down is lovely with heaps to see along the way
Day trip. Took a private tour to Cape Point and took in the Penguins at Boulder Beach. A super day out finishing up with wine and cheese tasting

Overpriced.. Took our kids to show them another beautiful part of our country. The scenery and views are awesome, but then so are many other parts of our country. The prices are a rip off, as is their "child" policy- a 12 year old an adult? Really? It's not like they occupy a seat in a plane or anything like that, so it is nothing but an easy way to take money off people. The staff at the entrance and funicular station were unfriendly and arrogant. I wouldn't bother going back, there are enough spectacular settings in this country where I don't have to get fleeced to take in a view. Go early to avoid the tour busses.

They don't call it Cape of Storms for nothing!. Definitely a must do unless it's pouring rain. The winds can be extremely strong but this only adds to the adventure. Make sure to have your picture taken at the iconic sign, ride the funicular to the top and walk up to the lighthouse if weather permits. The day that we were there it was very windy and we saw some parents attempt to take young children up to the lighthouse. Bad idea. The winds pushed them around dangerously and they wisely turned back.

Beautiful area. this is a really beautiful area, go with good weather if you can choose a day with good weather. But be aware good weather in cape town doesn't mean good weather on cape point. Cape point is very susceptible for clouds and it is a pity if you can't see the beautiful area.

Beautiful walks and views. Everything was wonderful. Lovely walks, well-marked trail, beautiful views. One could easily spend an entire day, just sitting and enjoying the views. Recommend bringing a picnic and a book. Not to be missed!

Amazing. We visited on a day when there were not too many other visitors, It was a truly breathtaking experience. The scenery was so beautiful. We walked on beaches observing groups of animals which looked like Antelopes in the distance. Cars were stopped by Baboons and Ostriches in the road! There are fabulous views from the funicular car and even better when you get to the top. Don't miss this.

Great Scenery and wildlife. If your visiting Cape Town it's well worth a trip to Cape Point to experience the great scenery and wildlife, although there was a fire recently it's still worth doing the circle route if you want the chance to see lots of wildlife.

Stunning scenery. We took a drive out here to visit cape point and we are glad we did. The scenery is simply stunning and you feel like you are at approaching the edge of the world. Dress warmly though as it's windy up there!
Tidal pools a hidden secret :). The tidal pools make you feel you are in heaven! It's always good to be in the park, whether for a walk, a swim or a quick 4X4 drive

Must visit. If you are in Cape Town, but you have not been here, surely you have missed something. This will take your breath away and trust me, if you are a good photographer, there are very few beeter place to click in the world

Well worth a visit. You really get a sense of the wildness of the tip of Africa as you gaze out towards Antarctica. Do climb up to the lighthouse at Cape Point, as the views are to die for, although the wind is usually ferocious. Very good shop at the bottom too !

My oh my. wondeful place to visit, the waves where high, the weather was wet, but the sun shone as well, but what waves!! Even the seals were stranded and had to wait till the waves died down, before they moved on, but the view was breaktaking

A lovely place to visit. No trip to Cape Town or that general area should miss out on this. While there isn't an abundance of wildlife (other than sea birds) the drive to it is really nice and the scenery there is superb. You can visit Cape of Good Hope while there as its part of the same reserve
Eat before you go. Overpriced and poor choice of catering options. Not much to see after such a long drive from Cape Town
Beautiful :). I feel very fortunate to be able to live near cape point and visit it when I want to. Spectacular views and an amazing restaurant just makes it an awesome place.
Scenic drive. We had a driver set up to take us through the park, and it was a really pretty day. We saw ostrich and baboons, and took some great pics. Worth the stop.

Southern most tip of africa (georaphical tip is different). beautiful park with a beautiful drive to reach there. We loved the train ride up to the lighthouse and back. clean and accessible with good food at the restaurants within the park.

Best cuppuccino for tired legs. We often cycle into Cape Point Nature Reserve which is always stunningly beautiful and mostly devoid of traffic (especially before 11h00). The highlight though is the cuppuccino made by SoSo at the take-a-way kiosk at the Point car park. It is always hot, consistently delicious and if there are not too many people, you will most likely get a designer face on your cuppuccino foam. This is a not to be missed opportunity if you are a cyclist and a coffee lover.In Winter you may also be lucky to see the large herd of Eland that frequent to grasslands below the high road. For road cyclists the road is a bit bumpy, but definitely worth it with very little traffic, great scenery, wonderful fynbos smells and excellent coffee at the end.

be sure to go around Cape Point. It is an incredible experience to stop along the way and walk from the road to the beach following a path. It is the best way to watch all kinds of plants and flowers and some wild creatures....
Great Views. Go for a couple of hours or for the day. Enjoy the scenery and views. Scenic and a pleasant way to spent the day.
Amazing views. I got the most amazing pictures here. We went up to the Light house and then drove down to the beach and sat on the rocks, it was absolutely serene.

A CIRCULAR WALK, OVER TWO DAYS. We arrived early and gave our box of food to the office staff. We enjoyed our first day of walking though beautiful lowland scenery, watched bontebuck and eland drink from a pool and then headed over to a deserted beach. We were on our own, apart from a family of ostrich. After lunch and a dip we walked on to our hut for the night "Erica" at Cape Point. Great views over both sides of the point, adequate accommodation. The following day we walked back towards the visitor centre, Judas Peak - with wonderful views all the way. We recommend it to anyone who is interested in a two-day walk.
Wild and beautiful. This is a beautiful place to visit to walk or to watch the waves. It was quite windy, but the sun was shining. We did see ostrich and antelope.

Spectacular...Beautiful...Amazing. Great drive and amazing views all around. The view from the lighthouse is to die for. It can get a bit windy. Amazing pics and if you are alone a chance to stare into the vast ocean and be at one with yourself. The Finnicular can be used for a fee if you ar not up for a little trekking. Be sure to carry water and shades, as it can be a bit taxing to climb up those steps.

Great walks through the reserve - baboons & ostrich if you're lucky. A great area for hiking. If you're lucky you might see baboons - but keep well away as they can be vicious! Also ostrich - again, they can be rather defensive of their territory.

Beautiful and awe inspiring . Fantastic visit to this beautiful place. The land literally falls away onto the ocean and you can hear the roar of the breaking waves. I went via a small tour, definitely worth it with limited time but if you can, go for the day and take in some of the amazing walks - one literally takes you to the edge of the world..

Still Beautiful ("after all these months"). It was my 2nd visit, after 14 months of absence. The views are still magnificent, but there were 2 major differences. This time it was much more windier (March vs. January), and there were almost no sea birds to be seen. Kind of a pity, because last time they were such a big and significant part of the scenery. Another matter was the heavy smoke of the recent fires. One of the last ones was still very much in progress a few KM's to the North-West, and helicopters and fire fighters were intensively engaged over there. But luckily there was no impact on the Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope itself. This time we also walked from the Cape Point to the Cape of Good Hope. Except for the strong winds, it was a wonderful walk of less then 30 minutes, depending on stops.
A must see in Cape Town. I always thought Cape Good Hope was the far south point. Even Cape Point isn't but this is as far as one can come. Great experience and fabulous view of course, windy!

Coves, shipwrecks and storms. The windswept point of the peninsula, where most tourists end up, is breathtaking, however I encourage visitors to take a few hours to explore the beaches, shipwrecks and heritage points of the reserve. You wont regret it.

Spectacular. The views you will see from this location are like no other. Knowing that you are staring out to the ocean and the only land mass staring back is Antarctica is incredible. This is a must if traveling to the Western Cape, you will not be disappointed!

FANTASTIC!. A must-see! This was included in a full day's excursion - well worth it. Going on a 'tour' shows you places that you might miss if travelling on your own. Wonderful views-beautiful mountains and fabulous nature reserve. Enjoy!

Great views from the lighthouse. The drive to the reserve from Cape Town is part of the fun in visiting. We travelled via Camps Bay and along Chapman's Peak Drive - a beautiful coastal road right by the rugged shoreline. You pay a fee to enter the reserve and once inside the most popular stopping point is at the bottom of the funicular railway up to the lighthouse on Cape Point. There's a walkway to get right to the end of the coastline, but the view from the lighthouse was good enough for me. I would definitely recommend the funicular as there are still quite a lot of steps once you get up there - it costs about 55rand. You get a good view across the Cape of Good Hope from the lighthouse too. Be wary of snakes and baboons if walking around the reserve. It's also worth visiting nearby Boulders Beach while you are in the area to see the penguins.

The deep end of Africa. Hiking between cape point and cape of good hope is an absolute must. I like it. We didn't like the forest in fire . It was a pitty. Take care of this piece of land, it is unique
Apes !!!!. Beware the Apes otherwize a must do trip.Don't expect anything outstanding but it is a trip one must attempt

Fabulous day out. We hired a driver for the day we went to Boulders Bay first then onto Cape Point, unbelievable scenery and surroundings quite a long journey but well worth the drive, some lovely little villages on the way, lots to see in the park and great Restaurant for lunch with stunning views. Take the cable car to the top great views as well.
Love the sense of history!. Wild coast, baboons, fabulous beaches and the weight of history combine to deliver a stellar experience.

This is a lovely day out,. The road from Cape Town down to the Nature Reserve is spectacular (though be away the Chapmans Peak road is a toll road. Well worth a day out, though very busy at Cape Point. A lovely restaurant there

Breathtaking views!. We could have spent a whole day visiting the area around Cape Point. There are so many gorgeous views, hiking trails, secluded beaches, wildlife and cliffs to explore. We reached Cape Point around noon and the main areas were already crowded. The hike to the first lighthouse took about 10 to 15 minutes. There is also a funicular ride to the top however the day we visited there was a power outage (we were told that power outages are very common in South Africa) so the funicular was shut down. Once your reach the first lighthouse there is a trail to walk to the second lighthouse. That trail says it will take 1.5 hours round trip. The time really depends on how long you enjoy the view at the end of the trail but it only took us about 40 minutes in total. This trail was very quiet since most of the tourists visit the first lighthouse then turn back around. The views from each trail were unique and beautiful. If you have time make sure to explore a few of the trails. If we ever return to Cape Town we will certainly return to Cape Point to explore other hiking trails.

Must Visit place for Nature Lovers. Visiting this place virtually requires entire day. Variety plants and flowers to see. View is just too good. Budget accommodations are available where one can spend days tracking this reserve. Must visit place for nature lovers.

View's are astounding. It has wonderful views, walkways and a shop and toilet facilities. We went as part of a small half-day tour, but were we to return we would hire a car and drive ourselves in order to spend more time in the area.

Worth visiting as much for the dramatic coastal journey as for the Point itself. Visited on a stormy day in mid-winter - all the more dramatic for the sunshine as we arrived. Small flocks of Helmeted Guineafowl and Egyptian Geese on the way, Ostriches and Black Oystercatchers on the beach, apes prowling outside the busy but efficient Two Oceans restaurant, hopeful Cape Buntings in the eaves. The steep climb to the lighthouse worth the effort for views of the wild Atlantic - be prepared for very high winds.

MORE THAN WHAT YOU WOULD EXPECT. Upon entering the reserve, we didn't know what to expect and planned to go to some other attractions nearby during the day.... What a surprise! We stayed the whole day, walking, admiring the beautiful landscape and sea, reading up on history about the Cape, snacking, driving to another breathtaking spot.... When we go again, we'll go earlier to spend even more time in the reserve. (and take extra water for all the walks...) HIGHLY RECOMMENDED
Dodged the fires. Brilliant day trip to the cape. dodged fires on the west of the cape. Iconic place to visit at the foot of The African Continent
Legendary spot. A nice place to visit one of the most known spot in Africa. So many tales have been told about The Cape of Good Hope. Rough terrain but the sea views magnificient around Cape Point!

Fantastic though a bit windy. Spectacular views of coastline and ocean. Two Oceans restaurant a great place to dine, outside table a must if you don't mind the birds trying to scrounge a meal. Steep but manageable climb to lighthouse from the funicular drop off point. Should also make sure you go to the Cape of Good Hope.

Excellent place to visit. Brilliant views - such an amazing place to visit. We were spoilt for a day by a local who decided to take me & my colleague out and about for the day around Cape Town and the surrounding areas.Once place the was on both our minds was Cape Point. It was unfortunate that this was just after the fire had take place so alot of the landscape was charcoal - with the other side still lush & green It didn't detract us from the beautiful surroundings & natural beauty.
Beautiful. Such a beautiful place to go.. The views are spectacular, staff are friendly and the wildlife, whilst not prolific, are there to be seen.. Watch out for the cheeky baboons at the carpark

The furthest point South!. Lovely national park, Eland and baboons and seals amongst the wildlife , the scenery is rugged and beautiful. Well worth a trip down to the point to see the Cape of Good Hope and Cape point. If you eat at the cafe watch out for the baboons - they have a habit of stealing your food!
cape point. had a good morning there some great views see some animals but no baboons very good for windsurfing and when you get to the top there is a lighthouse a very good time there
Another area of outstanding natural beauty. Be prepared for a windy visit as this is where Africa ends. the winds can be fierce but you can't visit South Africa and not go here. A must see.

R110 per adult - bit hefty but okay. This is like table mountain a must see attraction. The entrance at the gate is a bit hefty at R110 per adult.
Take the funicalur up and enjoy the view

Great views and wildlife. bring binoculars if possible. We saw ostriches grazing at a distance and baboons playing in the road. Over 100 steps to lookout to see Indian and Atlantic Oceans. Great photo ops. Restaurant for lunch and funicular to get toward top. Many tour buses with large number of people at once.

Perfect. It came as a bit of shock to see ostriches roaming the sandy shoreline - I expected to see the ubiquitous baboons (which we did) but not these mighty birds and their young. But there they were in all their glory. Although they're fairly relaxed at the sight of us human rubber-neckers in our tin boxes remember they are wild creatures and shouldn't be approached. The park is covered in fynbos, from which I detected a slight honey aroma from the many hundreds of different herbs, grasses and flowers that constitute it. I think that we're all aware of 'everlasting' flowers, the dry, often artificially coloured ones found in flower arrangements, but here in the park they abound in such profusion they appear to make up drifts of white, to the extent it's called, locally, Cape Snow. A word to the wary, remember that puff adders live in this environment. If bitten you've got approximately 2 hours to be treated with anti-venom. But as most snake bites are 'dry' it shouldn't pose too much of a problem if you decide to get out of the car for a wander.Animal life abounds of course; eland, springbok, buck and kudu. Zebra and porcupines are in there somewhere as well but we didn't see any. Bird life is stunning; everything from soaring raptors to red-legged oyster catchers patrolling the rocks along the beaches and enough cormorants to make you become bored with the subject.In short Cape Point Nature Reserve an excellent half day out (at least) and the longer you stay the better it is.

Definitely worth it. There are 2 capes - visit both. Walk to the lighthouse from the top of the funicular at Cape Point for terrific views. We bought good sandwiches there and ate them overlooking the Cape of Good Hope, then we drove round to the Cape of Good Hope and walked up it, admiring the fantastic surf. It's a steep walk but worth the trouble. Some wildlife to see. Sadly a few days before our visit fires destroyed thousands of hectares of vegetation so the drive from Cape Town was often through burnt hills but where it wasn't burnt the fynbos is extraordinary.

A wonderful nature reserve. Unhappily the reserve has been decimated by the last bout of horrendous bush fires that swept across the peninsula two weeks' ago, but it is still majestic and very soon the bush will regrow, more magnificent than ever, and the animals will return.See baboons, all types of ground squirrels, tortoises and other animals and note the amazing variety of fynbos, indigenous trees and shrubs and of course the bird colonies. Wonderful day out.
Stop Reading this AND GO!. It was spiritual. AND worth the walk / ride to the summit as well. There is only one Cape of Good Hope in the World. Don't miss it.

A must do !!!. A must do !! Begin at Muizenberg and then Boulders beach ,cape point and end in Houtbay...cape point is just fantastic and don't forget to go to the beach..blue view..a small street before you enter the cable car section ..nice to take pictures on the beach...don't go to the ocean's restaurant..it's a tourist trap !!!!

#2. it is must, go clockwise, start at Boulders Beach, enter the park and go to Cape point, go walking. there is a trial at the left where you can go as south as possible, it says 1.5hours but is only 15 min each leg

Amazing views from the tip of Africa. The walk up the final stretch to Cape Point and the lighthouse is quite easy and can be done in about 5 minutes though there is a funicular for those not so agile. The views from the top are breathtaking.
What a view of the two oceans. We took the funicular to the top and climbed the steps to the light house. The view from the light house was simply amazing and breath taking.

Stunning rugged landscape with some surprises along the road!. It's quite amazing to even imagine that at one time, not too terribly long ago, developers wanted to put a shopping mall and some condominiums out at Cape Point. I'm so very glad that didn't happen! The incredible unspoiled, wild beauty of this point near where the Atlantic and Indian Oceans meet is awesome. We were enjoying the scenery when an ostrich popped into view along the roadway. We had no idea they were out there. Then we got a family of baboons! So along with the wild crashing oceans and rugged landscape, you get ostrich, baboon, bontebok and more. We enjoyed a fabulous lunch at the Two Oceans restaurant. Great views, fabulous food and not horribly pricy. It may be a long drive but you do not want to miss Cape Point Nature Reserve.

Too expensive. Over priced everything, including the icecreams. But if you turn off the main road and get out your car and walk then it is gorgeous. Turn down to the coast and wander along the little paths. Then you you will get a feel for the Cape fynbos.
Amazing views of Indian and Atlantic Oceans. Not to be missed are the wonderful little penguins! The baboons... not so lovely :) but it is all part of the setting.
Nice but Far. Far from cape town (2 hours) but the thrill of reaching it is nice. Nice restaurant over there also.

Great fun!. Another great day out in Capetown. The drive there is stunning and you get the chance to see some of the wildlife. We were fortunate to see the baboons, ostriches and some buck. Its a different world. The views are breath-taking and its one of the best places to see animals in their natural habitat.
Beautiful. Make sure you visit both the Cape of Good Hope - take the cable car up to the light house, as well as Cape Point.

Awesome. Great fun to drive around Cape Point and look at all the cool views. The bonus was seeing some big buck and ostriches. There is lots of wild life and it is great fun trying to spot things in and around the point.

Get a guide from Table Mountain Treks and Tours. Thank-you for taking the time to contact us and let us know about the sad loss of Silvermine camp. As a result of your timeous information, we were able to adjust our hiking route - and we had a wonderful time! We got Mark Hawthorne to hike with us through Cape Point Nature Reserve. Despite the fires raging in another part of the park at the time, Mark chose safe and spectacular routes for us to discover. His knowledge of the fauna, flora and history of the area was fascinating. Was so much more fun to walk through the reserve than just get out of a car, have something to eat and get back into the car.

A beautiful palace. There are different tours in cape town.one of best palace to see natural field and free amimals is this naturak reserve. I saw a group of Baboons with their children who move as a group. If you like to take memorable photos, this palace let you to do it.
A Must. If you travel this far .... you must go to Cape Point. The hike to the summit is short if strenous. Worth it to get away from the crowds.

A Gem .. overload with breathtaking views, unique and endemic flora and fauna and what history!. Spend a fantastic day in a very special place ... hike .. take a picnic .. you can even "braai" (BBQ)! You will see immense and beautiful seas with their many hazards and everchanging weather ... you will be thrown back in time imagining ships of discovery trying to find a way ... finally rounding the Cape of Good Hope into False Bay and then you imagine the many clippers on the clipper route plying their trades to and from the Indies. From the parking area .. walk right out to the point and lighthouse or hike down to the beautiful Dias Beach. Along the way enjoy the unique flora and fauna endemic to the reserve. You have to drive to the Tip of the Cape, the most South-Western point ... very scenic and the obligatory photo-op! and check out the commemorative crosses erected in memory of explorers Dias and Gama. After all the walking/exploring stop off at Buffels Bay Beach where you can swim, relax .. even cook on the "braais" provided. Great day out!

Nice drive. We had a tour book that took us through the Cape Point Nature Reserve, nice drive, you're given a map which is quite helpful as apparently using a sat nav/gps isn't much good in this area. We saw Baboons and Ostrich and a few other animals while we were driving about. We also went up to the lighthouse, you can walk it but we paid something like R50 to go up, amazing views from up in the clouds.

Unique Nature experience. To be at the South Western most point of Africa is indeed special. The Cape of Good Hope as well as Cape Point are special places with unique flora and to see the oceans meet by the point is special. Be careful of baboons and do not feed animals - they can get too bold and take, steal from an unwary travellor. A very pretty place which has views of ship wrecks, fynbos and one can fish or do walk trails.
There's no sense going to Cape Town if you don't visit Cape Point.. The Light House, Cape of Good Hope, the wildlife, especially Baboons, were terrific. Should not be missed - so beautiful.

At the end of the World!. Amazing day out exploring Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope. It was quite blustery on the day that we were there but didn't spoil the amazing views of the two oceans, and you could easily imagine how sailing ships have have become wrecked in the area! This isn't somewhere for those less steady on their feet as some of the paths are challenging, but it was worth it to experience both of these important landmarks. Well done to the National Parks as the place feels well managed without being touristy. The Two Oceans restaurant provided a welcome lunch (but you need to book) which felt like a substantial meal in a gastro-pub rather than a snack bar, and offered some more amazing views.
Once in a lifetime. Such a feeling standing there on the edge of cape point. We spend a few hours there and got some good pictures as it was a nice dag.
Steep cliffs. Must see if you visit Capetown. Simply worth it to stroll around the lighthouse and the steep cliffs .

A must if you are visiting Cape Town.. Cape Point Nature Reserve is absolutely bursting with healthy Finbos, and there are plenty of animals if you take the time to look carefully and not hurtle to the point as so many visitors do. Plan to spend a few hours and watch as the awe inspiring scenery changes with the weather and time of day.

Excellent view. We went on a sunny day, it was a great view with huge wind. There are two path, one goes to the cape of good hope sign at the bottom of the cape, it will be a short trip with just a sign for tourist to Tak photos. There is path "cape of good hope scenic walk", but it can be accessed from the cape point side. It's a nice view on top of the cape and the walk way was quite okay. The cape point has a funicular to the top light house but you can also choose to climb up. The restaurant there serves fresh seafood, great sushi and delicious food!

Don't miss this. The views and walk at Cape Point are wonderful. Make sure you continue past the lighthouse. The sign warns that it is a 1.5 hour walk, but visitors have scratched the 1, because it really doesn't take much more than 30 minutes and it is worth it!

Great half day Tour. We booked through a company called Cape Point Route and I would recommend this highly. We did the half day tour and the scenes were stunning. Our driver Abe was friendly, informative and chatty. He went out of his way to ensure we had a great experience. The highlight of the tour is the stop at boulders beach on the way back to Cape Town to see the penguins.

Great National park with giid facilities. Caoe point its self is the cimmercial part of the park and is very good but the view and natural wildlife is amazing and well worth spending the time there watch out for the baboons and the Red Starligs!

SPECTACULAR!!. There are few places I have been that truly take my breathe away. Cape Point is one of them. The views were out of this world incredible. No trip to S. Africa is complete without a visit here.

Long way to the end but worth it. The drive to the end of the cape is quite long but it was worth it as the view from the light house was great. We used our feet rather than the funicular railway. This meant that we had the opportunity to see various birds and flowers as we climbed.The pzzas were also exceedingly good value for money considering the location

Worth the fee. Wonderful coastline with a great walk up to the lighthouse (there is a cable car for less able). Saw baboons and there are other animals off the main track which friends were lucky to see. Would have liked more time there to go on the beach.

Windswept, but worth it. The long drive down to Cape Point is worth it. The park is a little barren, and at times the light house is a little overcrowded. Make sure you visit all the turnings and don't just head to the main attraction. Beware the Baboons. They bite!

Absolutely Stunning. The view is absolutely breathtaking. Please arrive early as the walk up the stairs to the light house requires atleast 30 min up, alot of people are taking photos along the way. You can use the cable cart as well. There are many other attractions here so do dedicate a whole day to see most of the nice spots, such as Cape of Good Hope

What an Incredible Place. Quite different to anything expected. This Reserve has miles of walking routes as well as the main attraction of climbing up a steep path/steps or taking the funicular to the top. Once you get off the funicular there are still many steps to reach the top level. From here you can see the meeting of the Oceans - Indian and Atlantic. Beware it is very windy and so even on a hot day can feel a bit chilly.

There's much to do in this national park. Go for it.. Recommended.
Whether you're into sightseeing, hiking, beach combing or rock climbing, this park presents opportunities for all.
Clearly, the majority of visitors come for the sweeping vistas where the Atlantic meets the Indian Ocean.
If you're interested in pix at sundown, keep in mind the park closes at that time.
Enjoy! It's worth the fee and a visit.
Unforgettable!. Saw it on a spectacuar clear day. End Feb/early March is definitely best time for Cape Town. Amazing to see where two massive masses of water meet.

More Than Just Where Oceans Meet. Even if all you do here is take the arial tram up to the lighthouse, this is a world class place to visit - the point where the Indian and Atlantic Oceans meet, where Vasco da Gama and Bartholomeo Diaz sailed, where the vistas are absolutely breathtaking. Once called the depressing Cape of Stones, the name was changed to the more positive Cape of Good Hope. At the most basic level, you can come and take the funicular almost to the top, and then climb the stairs the rest of the way to the light house to see the views. For the more ambitious, there is a trail to the top, where hikers can savor the vistas along the way. But the park has much more to offer. There is the Oliphant Hotel for those who want to spend more than an hour or so, and enjoy the reserve and it's views after the tourists leave or early in the morning. One can also camp there in the open. Either way, there are lots of nature trails and beautiful beaches to explore. The wildlife - flora and fauna - is extensive, and one needs to be prepared to even see ostriches wandering the rocky beaches!Even though there are lots of tourists, the flow in the main areas is good, and there are very few people wandering in the less trafficked areas. Christmas is perhaps the most difficult time to visit, as lines for entry and for the funicular can stretch pretty far back.

Wrap Up and Beware the Baboons !. Vast Nature Reserve access via car /bike/foot. Suggest taking a layer as exceptionally windy. Several walking routes - allow at least 2/3 hours for some. Suggest no taking food in bag as Baboons can take a liking !

Breathtaking views. There are a lot of trail you can take, but you should definitely visit the light house. There is a funicular which takes you to the top, and then a short walk to the light house. The views from the top are really breathtaking. Definitely worth a visit, if you are in Cape town.

Breathtaking. It was a life long desire to visit this part of the world. The views were stunning, the information available about the history of the area was very good. There were plenty of tourists, but the management keeps things running fairly well, and the experience is worth it. There are also plenty of trails to explore on your own (via car and foot).

Great day and drive out. Amazing views at Cape point, stopped to see the Penguins and boulders beach and a coffee in Sioms town. Really great day trip out. Easy I. Your own hire car and well worth the trip
must visit. Drive to cape point is just amazing, hire a car njoy the ride,we saw baboons,ostrich etc. the view is just amazing.

Go Cape Point & Good Hope. Passing through the main gate into the Cape of Good Hope National Park there are a number of drives one can take, but like most we head off for Cape Point & the old lighthouse marking the meeting of the two oceans. Depending on fitness you can either walk or take the "funicular" which is a interesting tram ride to the point. This is then followed by a visit to The actual Cape of Good Hope, the most South - Western point on the African Continent. It was crowded with visitors all wanting the same picture, so have patience there.
Two oceans. Great overlook at the tip of the continent, almost, but we won't tell that the site is a little off. It is still a spectacular view and a very pleasant place.
Gorgeous. We were there at a sunny day and the views are just stunning!! Great trails, where contact with nature is simply wonderful.

Get the Point. Cape Point is an astounding natural landform which takes the breath away. But in addition to that, the surrounding natural beauty elevates this to a very special experience. The facilities are world class and the food in the restaurant is great.

Amazing View. Everyone should take the time to visit this amazing venue at least once a year. Just in case you have forgotten how incredible the ocean is, go back regularly and feast your eyes and senses on the view, smell and sound of surely one of the most beautiful places in the world.

Spectacular scenery. Cape Point was the highlight of our trip to South Africa. The scenery is breathtaking and the area is rich in history. The walking paths are well engineered and provide plenty of vistas of this magical place.

All that beauty was overwhelming. What can I say about this place.
You need a car to wonder around but the beauty of this place is hard to describe, the geographic location makes it very dramatic and diverse and the flora and fauna is totally wild. We saw some ostriches and baboons.
YOU MUST visit this place is AMAZING.

Stunning location but explore the side roads too. Many visitors to Cape Point confine themselves to visiting the lighthouse and restaurant. This should certainly not be missed but the area can be crowded and, if you're eating, you need to watch out for the baboons. You must go further afield. The side road down to the Cape of Good Hope carries fewer cars and coaches, offers access to beaches, seabird colonies and a short climb that reveals great seascapes. There are super views across False Bay from the Rooikrans turning. Picnic on the grass by the sea at Buffels Bay or take the longer Olifantsbos Bay turn where we saw bontebok on the beach. This is a great day out and you can easily find yourself on your own.
Must visit!. That was a great destination that shouldn't be skipped. It had beautiful nature! We enjoyed a lot :)

A must do. Amazing changes in landscape as you move fropm Cape Town in direction of Cape Point. Ostriches, Baboons, flora and fauna, amazing beach and rock views. Day we visited was windy and there was a kite surfing party going on nearby, photo's are amazing but the memories are even better.

The Southernmost Point. This is one of my favourite places to take visitors. There is just so much going for it. From the beautifully scenic drive just to get there, after entering the Reserve, you experience the full beauty of this place. Take the funicular up to the top, walk down towards the lighthouse and then make your way down the stairs, to the beach below. Baboons are problematic and dangerous. But as long as you aware of that, you can survive them. Do not carry packets, do not wave your food around, do not feed them and keep your distance and you'll be fine. Don't braai in the park - It's just not worth it, because baboons spoil it and you just cannot relax as you are permanently looking out for them. Rather spoil yourself at the the wonderful restaurant, overlooking the beautiful bay.

Take some walking shoes. Fantastic location on a sunny day. Thousands of tourists, limited retail and dinning facilities. Use the cable car to go up and walk down. Good local crafts on display for purchase at the entrance to the National Park, a must see.

Where you take the visitors to show them stunning views. We have taken a number of UK friends and relatives here over the past six years and that always get jaw drop and are stunned to silence.
Its a wonder of the world

Nice to have been there. Cape Point it something special. You have to go there so you can say to all your friend back home, and take a Picture ofcourse.
There is a lot of things to say on the way down there too.
great views. Been there many times, always great even when the tram is broken! Many baboon sightings! A naturally beautiful place....

an OK Place..... Visted this reserve in Feb as part of the Cape Peninsula Tour. The Place is large. We stopped at the Cape of good hope for a photo session, then visited the light house right on top, and had lunch below...Good place for some pics of the ocean and great views, but nothing much else to do otherwise...

Cape of Storms - not to be missed. It is a beautiful wild place and well worth a day visit, though exposed to the elements (wind, sun and rain according to the season). The are big drops into the sea, so be careful at the viewing spots. The views in all directions are magnificent, there is game to watch and rich vegetation. A big word of caution from a local however - be very careful with the baboons. They are fascinating and amusing to watch, but on no account feed them or tease them with food. It is better not to picnic even in the designated areas as the baboons can descend rapidly and create havoc.
Bucket List ticked!. Forget visting the cape of good hope.......this is the jewel in the crown of this coastline!Fantastic views, stunning scenery.

Stunning. Plan a day here, there really is so much to see and do and you can sit on the beach, see the famous Cape of Good Hope or drive around seeing wild life. Give yourself time to visit as it is worth a day out!!!

beautiful. I've been through the Reserve driving on a mini-bus. Our guide was an excellent driver and a very expert guide. The place is really something and it's possible to see a lot of wild animals "strolling" around the area. Just be careful not to open the windows of your vehicle when you spot a baboon. They're really dangerous
Great couple of hours. This isn't the largest attraction, but one that you will enjoy. The animals are well cared for and the staff knowledgable.

eye catching beauty. the quietness and the beauty of the surrounding mountians and sea. Please follow the rules and do not get out of your car be careful of our fauna and flora and what ever you take in with you to bring it out eg litter

It is an absolute must ,the Baboons are a huge attraction of course .They are however dangerous and can be found opening. The views,the Baboons pity they are so naughty ,it would be such a pity if they were kept away from the area.
Lovely restaurants to have lunch,beautiful walks,bike rides .
It is kept pristine and clean.
Popular Attraction. Really enjoyed visitng here. But as it's an extremely popular destination, the better option is to get there early to skip out on waiting in lines

More Than Skin Deep. Cape Point is like an exclamation at the southwestern tip of Africa. But don't go there just for that amazing view. The reserve has geat walks, overnight cabins, you can ride a bike (contact Daytrippers), or picnic. The reserve has some fabulous beaches. With some local knowledge, it's worth spending more than just a few hours there.

Very good in early summer. The drive from the main road to the lighthouse is longer than expected, but in early summer the heath type land is a blaze of colour, wild flowers carpet the whole area, well worth a ride out from the city
Cliffs and sea forever. The trek up the stairs is well worth the effort as the views are stunning. The baboons are rather amusing.

Cape Point Fishing. The park is well run and the fishing (whether form the shore or a boat) is awesome. An absolute must for everyone (at least once). I go regularly as I love fishing. Check winguru before you go as the weather at the point can be a significantly different to that of Cape Town central and the suburbs.
A must see!. Do not miss this on your Cape trip you will regret it. Stunning wild nature that simply must be experienced
Don't miss the Venus pool. Cycling in the reserve is superb. But don't miss out on soaking in Venus tidal Pool - it is magical!
Scenic and fabulous park, love the "fynbos" vegatation. Great day out, lovely views and take your time to explore this park about 45 mins drive from Cape Town. South Africa at its best.
Nature at her best. Beautiful scenery. The climbing to view points is not for those with tricky knees but you do not miss anything from ground level.
A good day out.. Excellent day out we went in January and missed the crowds, it can get very busy. disappointed in the lack ok wildlife

Great Day Trip. Very fun day trip out to Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope. Amazing to see where the Indian and the Atlantic oceans meet. There is also the chance to see baboons and maybe even zebra roaming about. The views were incredible and would also recommend a stop at Bolder beach along the way to see the penguins.

Blown away. Well worth the drive for some fantastic views make sure you lookout for the wild life especially the "Dassie" (Rock Hyrax) very timid animals which you can get close to, the kids will love them.Good restaurant "Two Oceans" worth booking in busy times +27 21 7809010. The monuments in park are Da gamma Cross and Diaz Cross celebrating the Portuguese explorers.

Supperb afternoon Car drive with Family and Children. Fantastic Fauna, Great view into the Sea and surrounding Cliffs, allow sufficient time as there are long quewes, much Traffic during the Christmaas Holiday period to get there and back. Wear comfortable Gear if you intend to take walks which should be a must at this place.

Experience of a lifetime!. The nature reserve has a lot of things to explore. Give it at least 4 hours to really explore the whole area as we got there like 2 hours before closing time so all we could visit was Cape of Good Hope and Cape Point. And go there with a rented car or driver as taxis won't wait for u.

enchanting view. It is a great feeling to be at the southernmost tip and see the oceans from a height.View is simply enchanting .It is windy at the height .We had taken the funicular to the top though climbing will be very enjoyable.A lifetime experience to be there!
Breathtaking. The scenery and the vibe of this place - the wind was hauling and people had so much fun - definitely Cape of storms-

Must seen place on every CPT trip. Been there on a very windy day to go to the Cape Point where "the two oceans meet". First I couldn't go to the Cape Point itself, because the wind was just to heavy and I could harldy hold my camera in my hands. So we just went up to the light house and took a picture of the cape. Second I've got taught, that it is just a legend, that the two oceans (Indian and Atlantic) meet at the Cape point... all water you see is the Atlantic Ocean. But anyway, the trip is worth to go there.

cycling to Cape Point. We hired bikes form Downhill Adventures (would recommend a company with better bikes, they had zero maintenance, but that's for a different review). We then drove to the park with said bikes in boot, parked up and drove to Cape of good Hope and then Cape point, total distance 31KMs. It was quite windy but a great way to see the park. We were the only ones on bikes that day.

Amazing views and vast expanse. Great choice for a perfect day out. Excellent place. Great to drive. The Cape of good hope and the light house located within the national park. Breath taking views of the Ocean.

Must See!. Get a good guide and take a day to see the entire peninsula. The views are extraordinary and there is a variety of wildlife, including ostriches, baboons, and others. The towns along the east side of False Bay are charming, historical, and have a relaxed vibe to them. The towns on the west side (Atlantic), a little less so.
Well worth the trip. The trip down from Cape Town is breath-taking, and the nature reserve is amazing. You must stop off and see the penguins too, we couldn't believe penguins in Africa !!
Another windy day. We had a wonder day in the Reserve. We of course went right to the end of the Point. It was very, very windy. We also drove around the Reserve.

Very good. The service is amazing friendly the food is not to bad a little over priced but the location is out of this world, great range of seafood , menu could have more imagination to it but overal very nice
Lovely. We saw wildlife including ostriches and birds of prey, and lovely plants. Very scenic and good photos to be had!
Enjoy the ride!. Great landscapes to enjoy and taking fotos - specially during sun set and the streets are in such a good shape.

Lovely cycle, lovely walks, beautiful hidden beach.. What a lovely walk to the top, skip the funicular, I could spend the whole day here. Take a picnic basket. Watch for baboons and ostriches though. Swim on the beautiful beach below. Just enjoy this piece of paradise

S Africa 2015. The drive out there from Cape Town along Chapman's Peak is stunning with great views of Hout Bay. It can be quite busy within the park if coach tours are there, but the scenery from all of the vantage points is amazing even with crowds. Take the fernicular upto the old lighthouse and walk down for the lazy way to take in the best views. It's also worth taking the detour to Cape of Good Hope.
Its a must do. Worth the time and effort to get their. If your in Cape Town then leave about 07:30 and you will be a head of the crowds

nice but just to check a box. Let's be clear the peninsula is awesome and the natural park breathtaking but the cape as such and the lighthouse are just boxes to check for the tourist mass. You can be cooler than this and hike all the way to the cape really living the experience

Amazing Beauty. Wow wow it was magical seeing the point where the two Oceans meet the Atlantic and. Indian Ocean. One is warm and the other is cold, you can see the distinct line where they meet what a beautiful sight, visit the lighthouse to view from it is quite a hike so would recommend the train for older people or small kids. Great Restaurant and the prices are pretty reasonable. The views just go on forever and it is fantastic to say the least.

Windy Adventure. The wind was pretty intense which reduced the pleasure of the scenic views. The baboons were a bit too close for comfort ...something that tourists aren't regularly in contact with and they are aggressive, especially when the tourist is carrying food.

It looked so peaceful. Driving through the nature reserve to Cape Point lighthouse was relaxing. Arriving at the point we took the funicular up. The sight was lovely. The sea was so calm, hiding its menace and the destruction.

Best day out. Give yourself a day or at least a few hours to enjoy this special place. Take time to walk on some of the beaches on both sides of the peninsula to appreciate the variety of the ecosystem. The funicular or walk up the hill, views and experience are wonderful. If you can - walk down the path below the old lighthouse - it is steep in parts.

Beautiful, stunning, a must. We drove to Cape Point from our hotel in Cape Town, the drive to the Point was just breath-taking and thats before we even got to the Nature Reserve. Each and every turn you take in the car is better than the last, on arrival at the point you are given the option of the train or walk up to the point, we chose the train, as it allowed us to get to the place we wanted to be and spend more time there and wow we were not disappointed, breath-taking and magical, to be at this very special place, should be on everyone's bucket list, it had been on mine for some time and it was no disappointment. After the point we went to the Cape of Good Hope the most south westerly point on the African continent, again, just stunning, you have to do the journey to experience the wonderment of this very special place, do it you won't be disappointed we weren't.

Lighthouse Furthest Point South. The hike to the Lighthouse was fun even though I had a cold and wasn't feeling well for the steep climb. We saw our first wild ostriches on this trip. Watch out for the baboons! Do not feed them. Do not open your car window. Baboons are much faster than you can roll them up!!!

If visiting South Africa, this is a must do!!. The Cape Point Nature Reserve is at the Southerrn most part of the Cape Peninsula. It is part of the Table Mountain National Park, and can be entered with a Wild/Green Card. There are several bus tours into the Reserve, or you can go on a privately guided tour. Enquire at your nearest Tourism Bureau when in the Western Cape for more information. There is a scenic drive through the reserve where you may encounter many different animals, including Zebra, Ostrich, Baboons, and different Species of buck. There is a large diversity of Fynbos species, depending on the time of year, and you can enjoy the beautiful Proteas, Erica's, Leucodendrons, Pincushions, Everlastings and many different Species of Restio' (natural, hardy reeds). You may be lucky to spot a number of different bird species, including Seagulls, Black Harrier, Black Shouldered Kite, Yellow-Billed Kite, Steppe Buzzards, Orange Breasted and Malachite Sunbirds,Cape Robin Chat and Protea Canary, to name but a few.The drive will take you right down to the Cape Point, where there is a lovely restaurant, where you can enjoy lunch, and sample some of the local wines. There is a also a tram which goes to the huge Cape Point Lighthouse, where you can breathe in the fresh sea air, and enjoy the beautiful 360 degree views. Be careful not to feed the baboons, they are wild animals and become a nuisance, if you try and feed them.All in all, it is a wonderful day's outing to be enjoyed by young and old, and definately worth a visit if you are a visitor to the area....enjoy it!! :)

Fantastic Day. My husband and I drove to the Cape Point Nature Reserve from Cape Town, and we had a spectacular day. We drove through Chapman's Peak (a nail-biting yet scenic drive), and also passed several cute towns along the way. We arrived at the Nature Reserve around noon, and there were no lines to get in. We walked up to Cape Point instead of taking the funicular. The walk definitely got our blood pumping, and we had a few baboons surprise us during the walk. The view from the top was spectacular and well worth the journey.We also took the obligatory picture at the Cape of Good Hope sign. Please watch out for ostriches in the road on the way - they are stubborn and will not move out of the way. Afterwards, we stopped by Boulders Beach to see the adorable penguins and drove through charming Simon's Town. It was such a lovely day, and I'm glad we did the drive on our own instead of booking a tour.
Views plus baboons. Great place to visit, the light house was something to see even in the mist. Maybe better in the mist. Great views.

Great day out. We visited from Cape Town stopping at Houts Bay Bird and Monkey Reserve on the way and Boulders Penguins at Simons Town which broke up the journey. I noticed so e people had a long queue to get into the reserve, we didn't queue at all and went mid jan, so must have been very lucky (we did go mid week, not sure if that helps?)The park is huge and to make it worthwhile, I'd recommend spending a few hours driving around. We only managed Cape Point due to time restrictions. There was a bit if a queue for the Funicular Railway, so we decided to walk up, it's not something for the elderly or unfit, but not too demanding and a great way to slowly see the views before you get to the top.
Beautiful scenery. Beautiful, beautiful coastline and scenery. Very windy on the day we went but spectacular scenery made up for that!

Around the Cape of Good Hope!. Wrong time of year (1 hour wait to get into the park) but an awesome experience once inside. Visited both Capes and took lots of photos. Even managed a spot of geocaching and grabbed a Travel Bug at Cape Point. The dassies were also cute.

A must visit place. If you are in the Cape Town area a trip to Cape Point is a must. The views are amazing. Be sure to bring a camera. Lovely walks. Nice food. An experience you will not forget. Come back to Cape Town via Chapman's Peak for more stunning scenery.

A Fantastic Day Trip. A fantastic day trip which you will need a full day to do as its about a 2 hour drive from Cape Town. You can also stop off at the little towns on the way such as Simon's Town for the Penguins. Entry to the park is 110R and the main attraction is Cape Point which offers excellent views. There is a small funicular train - "Flying Dutchman" that takes you up to the first lighthouse at Cape Point, but its an easy walk up if you are relatively fit. From there make sure you take the walking trail that leads down to the actual "point" which is the southerly most tip (only Cape Agulhus is more southerly). When I went it was quite windy which made the scenery quite dramatic with large waves crashing in against the point. After taking in the Cape Point you can have lunch at the restaurant or snack shop after which you can hike to the Cape of Good Hope. This takes a couple of hours and takes you away from the crowds but you need to be relatively fit as at points you need to clamber over rocks. Along the trail you can also visit Dias beach although there are lots of steps to tackle both down and up but well worth it as when I went there were only 2 other people on the beach, although its not safe to swim. Its also possible to drive to the Cape of Good Hope but you end up at the car park at the bottom of the cliff, but hiking you get the views from the top! The hike is also a lovely opportunity to take in the wildlife and during my hike I came across a couple of Eland and a Dassie. Whist driving through the park you may be lucky to see Ostrich and Baboon's too!In summary a fantastic day with some lovely walking trails, beautiful scenery and wildlife.

beautiful place. We arrived just before last car was allowed inside the area. All park operated concessions and funicular were closed. We drove all the way in and hike tools lighthouse. It is gorgeous!

Stunning views. Beautiful reserve. Lots of paths to walk around that are not at all difficult; if you're lucky you may see some of the local fauna. The plants and flowers are so different from the rest of the world, but be careful of the snakes. A few shipwrecks and a lot of history- so reading up or walking with a guide (as we did) will certainly help.

Views galore !. The reserve is a nice 90 min drive from the Central district of Cape Town. The ride is picturesque with tons of excellent view points. The Cape Point itself is historic & tends to get tons of tourist buses, so its best to land here before lunch for some peaceful moments.
Simply incredible. Absolutely brilliant, loved the nature drive, and the visit to the cape of good hope. Taking the railway up to the lighthouse was also great!

Awesome views. Standing here on a wonderful sunny days, its marvellous to think that th next stop south is Antartica! There were plenty of seals and cormorants about. The little funicular railway was good but there is still quite a climb to the best viewpoints but we were lucky - it was a clear day and we could see across False Bay. A memorable trip as on the way there we saw baboons and on the way back visited a penguin colony.

Beautiful Surroundings but run badly!. The park is stunning and the nature is unparalleled, all the views are magnificent! Unfortunately the staff have an attitude and are quite rude, also we were looking forward to hiking on some of the trails, after paying to enter the park (which I don't mind), I thought they could at least have given us the map pamphlet (which was literally an folded A4 page and which map was virtually no help!) for free instead of asking money for it. Also the hiking trails were marked, by which I mean there was the first marker and after that no other markers and a disappearing trail which coupled with the useless map meant we had to decipher and make our own trail. Besides this, the scenery and views are incredible and it is such a shame that it i not managed better!

Spectacular drive. Made a loop drive from Cape Town, all he way down to Cape Point. The drive itself was amazing, but the park is something else.
Leave yourself plenty of time to explore and take it in. So much to see and take in. Drive slow and watch out for the baboons.

Great trip. We took a trip with Hylton Ross.and are so glad that we did.Our guide IGGY picked us up from our hotel and could not have been more helpful in making the half day so enjoyable and well planned.We would not have enjoyed driving ourselves on this route. The roads were winding with spectacular views that could only be appreciated as a passenger.IGGY gave just the right amount of information as we passed through different areas and have just the right amount of time at Cape point and Boulder beach with the penguins.

loved it.. I really enjoyed going up on the train which was faster than you think. the views were great from the top you could have a nice walk up to the light house and see more. very nice to have a day out to the area, and the food shop was nice. they did have a restaurant but the food in shop was great sandwiches and pizza. yummy.

A Must if you are in Capetown & don't miss the Two Oceans Restaurant. Cape Point is in a nature reserve and home to many animals, including the giant Ostrich that had cars stopped while it walked down the road. The point is interesting and there is plenty of room to walk around the beach and small hills. A real highlight was the Two Oceans restaurant which is a short drive from the actual point. Don't miss the restaurant! The food is absolutely unbelievable! This is not a snack place but a full service restaurant with fresh seafood, sushi, salads, gourmet soups, awesome desserts and it is surrounded by friendly baboons.
Stunning views. I went on a tour and was glad to have a guide as there is so much to see, the views from the lighthouse are breathtaking. with plenty of wildlife to see on the way up as well.

A Must Go. This was one of the high lights of our trip to South Africa. It is a long ride from Cape Town, but well worth the drive. I would suggest booking a trip so that someone else can drive you and point out other sights alone the way.

So much to see and do.... Walk along the beaches, climb the stairs up to the light house or go for a hike along one of the many trails in the reserve - you can choose your own adventure. Along with the spectacular views in just about any direction you also get a chance to see some of the amazing wildlife roaming the park. We saw tiny tortoises making their way through the rocks, baboons, buck and ostrich walking along the rocky outcrops or sandy dunes.There are a few designated picnic areas at some of the beaches, but you still have to watch out for baboons as they are quite brave and used to the presence of people, so have no problem approaching you to steal some food.Definitely worth a visit, but you have to make a plan for the entire day! During holiday periods you also need to get to the gate early to beat the rush, otherwise you might spend too much time in the queue.

Not to be missed. This is, of course, the place you have to visit 'at the end of Africa', though it's neither the southernmost point nor, really, the meeting point of the 2 oceans. All the same it's well worth a visit for the sense of place, views and both the land and seascape.It sounds as if the place can get very crowded but we had no problems early in November and arriving not long before midday... no queue to get in and lots of places to stop for a little while or to park, and hardly any cars along many of the roads within the park.Of course, there were lots of people around the visitor centre and the cape itself, though, despite a short 'queue' to take pictures, we almost managed a photo of the Cape of Good Hope sign with no-one else in it. The wind meant there were pretty good waves too.The wind was such that we didn't take the trip (walk or funicular) to the lighthouse, but spent time wandering near Cape Point and stopping off along the roads for a closer look at the plants. Saw (well, almost met) an ostrich and chicks - it was determined to check if we had food in the car - and a couple of the relatively rare Cape (or Mountain) Zebra.One tip is to get into the 2 Oceans Restaurant there earlyish (even to book) as it fills up pretty rapidly from about 12:15/12:30 - relatively expensive but very good

Not to be missed. A trip to Cape Point / Cape of Good Hope is a must if you are coming to Cape Town. We went on a sunny but very windy day, and I think it added to the experience - it cooled the temperature, but most importantly made the sea spectacular. I suspect there are a lot of windy days there :)We were annoyed that the main restaurant at Cape Point was lunch only, no drinks, and quite limited - it was empty for the entire time we were there. BUT... the little fast food canteen next door actually had excellent baguettes, and the coffee was pretty good.We did the walk between Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope - we would very much recommend it! It is not for the faint hearted or unfit, and is possibly the windiest walk we have ever done, but the views were spectacular! Lots of wild life as well. The middle of the walk is well done with a wooden track - but the Cape of Good Hope end is quite rocky.
Great Views and drive. Its a fab drive up to cape point go slow baboons cross the road so drive slow. get there before 5 or you will have to walk as cart closes
Breathtaking views. The second most awe inspiring views I have ever seen after the Grand Canyon. If Grand Canyon is God's playground, Cape Point is where he goes for a pint.

Great Location and very nice scenery, although there really isn't that much to see. This is a location you have to go to. However, keep your expectations low since there really isn't that much to see at the point.

Breathtaking scenery. The drive to Cape point takes you through absolutely stunning landscapes. Winding roads and baboons wandering across the roads with their babies on their backs. We went down to the cape point sign and had the obligatory photos, but did not make it up to the lighthouse as it was very windy and our guide did not recommend going up. A must to see

Beautiful relaxed place to spend time, but get there early!. Beautiful expansive vistas and some interesting rock formations. I gave it five stars but we got there early by car (about 10 am). By the time we were leaving there were queues of cars to get into the park, and once inside looking for parking. I imagine if I had arrived later it wouldnt have been as enjoyable because of this and I would have rated it lower. We walked up to the old lighthouse which was steepish walk but on a good path (you can take the mini train but it costs more and you can't stop to look at the views on the way up). From there you can do a further walk along the actual point. It says it takes about 1.5 hours for the loop but actually it was about 30 minutes. Overall, a must do stop as part of a longer trip around the peninsula. Best in sunny weather otherwise you probably won't see much!

A must !. To visit Cape Point Nature Reserve is an absolute must. Try to get of the straight road to the cape. On the side roads you get a real sense of this majestic piece of land; you might bump into some wildlife - pristine, often completely empty beaches at the end of these. We keep coming back ;-)
Full day cape tour. A long drive, but worth the effort to see the beautiful Cape Town coast, Cape of Good Hope and other attractions en route.

Beautiful views. Wonderful scenic drive to the point where you can park your car and take a walk or catch a ride on the Flying Dutchman to the upper lighthouse.Spectacular views and some lovely places to enjoy a picnic and get some fresh air. There are warnings about baboons posted everywhere but, we didn't see any. Be sure to keep your food securely tucked out of sight until you reach a demarcated picnic spot.The sandwiches sold from the little take away cafe next to the restaurant are out of this world!We arrived early on the last day of our holiday. The queues were relatively short (approx 5-6 cars in front of us) but they moved quite slowly. On our way out of the reserve at about lunchtime, the queues were backed up all the way to the road.

If you have time - put on the tour. I enjoyed the trip as I am interested in all thing maritime and the Cape of Good Hope was something I did not want to miss. Normally Cape Point is included in a tour - rather than specifically travelling to the Point which is about an hours drive out of CapeTown. Make sure you visit the lighthouse and take the funicular as you get great views on a sunny day. Don't do if it is raining or misty as it is a waste of time

Fun Day!. A great escape out of Cape Town to explore the coast down to Cape Point. Get there early as there is a long line of cars to get in. The restaurant has excellent food, and a nice way to end the day. Be sure to hike out past the Lighthouse, it is a nice 20 minute walk and has amazing views. We also went down to the beach, the one with the white sand dunes. There were springboks grazing there and it was quiet and lovely.
Worth a visit for Two Oceans. We had a really great lunch at Two Oceans restaurant, some of the best sushi we've had. The views from the restaurant are incredible.
Excellent. It was great to revisit and still very impressive. Although less baboons an ostriches. Try some if the beaches

windy but interesting. Unusual plants (including beautiful blooming proteas), animals (bontebok, grysbok, eland, fur seals, baboons) and birds (cormorants, ostriches, gannets, albatrosses), wonderful views over the Cape and the water. It's important to get there early or there's a long line to get in; and the parking lot fills up. On a windy day it's hardly possible to stand up. But a place like no other!

Amazing drive and views. Cape Point was the highlight of our day drive around the Cape Peninsular. We arrived in the late afternoon, so missed the crowds. The drive through the Cape Point Nature Reserves, gives you a number of view points to stop at before you get to Cape Point, so stop off and take in the other views. Along the way you will spot a number of species, such as Zebra, Eland etc. Beware of the Baboons as they have become accustomed to being fed and can become aggressive. At Cape Point we took the funicular to the Light House, due mainly to the time we had. The views are spectacular back toward Cape Town and over to the Cape of Good Hope, which is another place to stop on your tour around. Well worth the visit, although next time we will get there earlier in order to do some of the walks along the cliff paths to Cape Point.
Remote and stunning. You really feel like you're in the middle of nowhere, if you want to find yourself this is your place.

Interesting and picturesque. Worth visiting for at least a few hours...best to go early as gets busy around the cafe area and where the two oceans meet...if you want pictures be prepared to queue!! There are animals, we spotted zebra and various antelopes but you are pretty likely to see ostriches and baboons,,, watch out for the latter near the carpark! Lots of lovely walks and areas to sit, and worth walking up to the lighthouse for more lovely views
Nature. Great place and easy to go to. The restaurant was also very good. The trip there was in itself a great one with beautiful views!

Gorgeous experience. We visited Cape Point with a tour company and had a wonderful experience. The wind was very high that day, and the morning started out a little raining, but by the end of the day, the sun was out and the skies were clear. The hike up to Cape Point was enjoyable although there is also a funicular which can take you up to a higher point. The hike goes along the ridge so you can see beautiful views for both sides of the Cape and see the differences between the Indian and the Atlantic Oceans.
A must see. You just have to go to the Cape of Good Hope on a visit to Cape Town, the walk out to the lighthouse and the views are sensational

most southern point. this is a small yet very interesting national park, it is quiet a drive from cape town please bear that in mind, a beautiful drive and well worth the effort, make sure to be early enough as it closes at sunset and opens at sun rise, look at the map you get at the entrance as it has all the attractions in the park on it, it is more for a historical trip than for wild life as there is not as much game as in other parks, the historical sites are majestic in their own right make sure to have enough time to see it all and take the walks available.

a bit rushed. we went on an organised tour from the hotel in the afternoon wonderful guide but not enough time at each stop we recommend you use your on transport and take a whole day to do it, to get the full picture

Stunning Scenery. This is a beautiful part of South Africa. The flora, fauna, walking tracks and scenery are wonderful. The views from the lighthouse are spectacular and on the day we visited we witnessed two jets on a training run which circled the lighthouse many times. The walk to the top of the lighthouse is quite strenuous. The beaches are popular as are the walking tracks. The nature reserve has something for everyone and I'm sure you won't be disappointed when you visit.

Cape of Good Hope. After all those history lessons about Vasco da Gama and Bartholomew Dias it was such a thrill to stand at the Edge of Africa and see the two oceans meet. Glad I'm not a 15th century sailor.

enjoyable walk and scenic view. On the drive up there is wildlife on each side including ostriches. We walked to the lighthouse and enjoyed the scenic views from the top. It was a relaxing afternoon. Then we went to one of the beaches and walked beside the water as the sun was setting and the light was beautiful on the sandunes. We also saw some monkeys playing around near a tree.
Nice. Nothing special. If your there than go see but ita not to special. Next time i wont go there. To big and booring

Great day. We spend the entire day in this park, first climbed the point and walked to the lighthouse, then had lunch at the restaurant at the foot of the hill, great restaurant with great service ! The rest of the afternoon we spend at Buffalo bay here they have made a pool in the see, toilets and shower are there. Also a nice sandy beach.

'''superb'''. Cape point is a must visit place, it is awesome. We went up the cape point and we viewed Cape of Good hope and the entire cape town from there. The place is fantastic. When you climb up high it is fun though tiring a bit. We saw where the 2 oceans join, Atlantic and Indian ocean, the scene is wonderful and spectacular. When we arrived at the top we saw an instrument written the distances of various places like New York, Paris, Berlin etc. The place is SUPERB'''''''''''''
something for everyone. lighthouses, walks, drives, animals, birds, museums, flora, cable car (not like table mountain much shorter, and not so exposed - good for those who are afraid of heights)

Majestic. the cape point is so beautiful from you drive up the mountain you have wild life and nature on your sides.During our visit it was full we didnt even have a parking and we had to wait more than an hour on the que to get into the flying dutchman to get us on top of the mountain.when we got ontop the view is so spectacular you can the cape of Good hope,Cape point and if lucky you can see whales and next time i will go during the off peak season.It was worth every cent i spect

Enjoying cycling trip here. The must do thing in Cape Point is follow a cycling tour and enjoy your cycling trip along the ocean. This is the place where you will see deep blue sea and deep blue sky, it will take your breath away..!!The highlight of Cape Point is the Cape of Good Hope which I have read in history book during school days and the feeling is great when I can see it with my own eyes. The beautiful lighthouse at the cliff is also another highlight here.

Southernmost tip of Africa. One of the top three tourist musts for Cape Town. We had a rental car so we could take our own time to go there & back, however, there are bus tours. You can view the Cape of Good Hope from the observatory on Cape Point. Views of the oceans are spectacular. There is a very pleasant short hike from Cape Point Lighthouse & worth taking. You need to be reasonably fit. There is a restaurant & of course souvenir shops. There is a short cog railway from the parking area, saves uphill climb, but walking back down is easy.

Brilliant. We drove there, spent the whole day on the peninsula. Very scenic. We saw zebras, ostriches, baboons. If you are not up for a short hike to the light house you cab get a train ride to the top. Make sure you drove to the Cape of Good Hope where there is dramatic coastline as well as a sign informing you that you are at the most Southern tip of Africa - a good but popular photo spot.

Stunning. Well worth the drive to visit Point Cape reserve and its right next to the Cape of Good Hope which is the most southern tip of the African Continent. It's rugged and well preserve with an abundance of flora and fauna. Nature lovers with be impressed!

Trek, sea, beaches, hills, flora and wild life all at one place . This place something from everyone ... Small trek to cape point is amazing and very refreshing with exotic breathtaking views... Ppl can go one way by cog wheel train and take stairs while coming back. There is great history to this place regarding light house, dragon island new light house and swimmers who cross this island ...small guided tour is recommended if u have interest in exploring that ... The place also has most southern tip to africa continent known as Cape of good hope. Excellent to visit with picture taking moment. One can also explore different species of flora and fauna and some quite beaches.
Tip of africa. Must do if you are in the western cape. Beautiful, with South African heritage. Expect alot of walking but it is worth it!

One of the Most Beautiful Places on Earth. What an amazing place! The Cape is a short ride from Cape Town (1 to 1.5 hours) along a spectacular coastline. The park itself is a mix of terrain. The views of the sea are amazing, a living orchestra of rhythm and majestic hues of blue and green. White sand beaches receive and calm crashing waves. Everywhere your turn you get a post card view. We were fortunate to see baboons, ostriches, a dolphin, and overheard others speak of seeing whales. The hikes take less time than the posted sign suggest. If you are in the Cape Town area you must make this a priority stop.

A must!. We drove from Camps Bay along the coastline and it was magnificent! Cape Point itself is breathtaking if you have the heart and strength to climb all the way up. Do not miss Cape of Good Hope or to have a nice lunch with a dramatic view at Two Oceans restaurant!

Allow plenty of time to see everything. Saw wild animals as we drove through the Reserve. We first stopped at the sign Cape of Good Hope where we jostled to have the "must have " photo. Spent several minutes at sea level watching the sea and bird life. Then drove to cable car which takes you to top of hill. Wonderful views from top, sharing it with the baboons. We went with a tour so were very rushed. Would have liked more time to explore the area.

Superb Walks. A favourite walking /hiking spot. You have to pay to go in to the Reserve. There are picnic spots, different walks and hikes. A restaurant on the edge of a cliff overlooking the sea. A little takeaway shop and a little curio shop.One has to take care with regard to food and Baboons. DO NOT FEED THEM! Really a beautiful spot not to be missed and well worth a visit.

Attractive countryside and a bracing uphill walk. We visited Cape Point briefly on a four-country tour of southern Africa. The drive out to the point takes you through some wild countryside, and you'll probably see baboons.
