A detour to the Cape of Good Hope is not really worth it, unless you want a photo of your partner next to the sign, but the short additional distance to Cape Point is well worth the effort. You can then take the funicular up to the Cape Point lighthouse, but that would be a pity if you are up to the delightful and well-maintained walk up to the viewpoints, with spectacular sea views on both sides of the headland. And there is one of Cape Town's better restaurants right next to the lower funicular station (see separate Two Oceans review).

Arrive early . Cape point nature reserve is very popular and my advice is arrive early . Entrance is R110 per person . This will allow you to visit attractions like Cape Point and the South West tip of Africa , Cape of Good Hope . The two oceans DO NOT meet at this reserve . If you are lucky you may see a variety of animals and beware of the baboons as they will steal your food and can be aggressive . From a botanical point of view the reserve is very important and very species diverse with over 1500 species of plants within the reserve . This reserve is a must visit if you are in the area .

Amazing views!. Great experience driving through the Cape Point reserve - seeing the mountains, the sea, the fynbos, and the baboons! They were coming out of the fynbos, walking along the road, carrying babies, and even one riding on the bonnet of a minivan looking inside the windscreen!The funicular ride up to the lighthouse was very scenic. Great views from the lighthouse platform. Nice leisurely walk down from the lighthouse gave even better views so make sure you only do the one-way funicular ride if you are able to do the walk-not stressful just a few steps and mostly a well paved path.Also stop over at the Cape of Good Hope to see the beach and rocks with the surf pounding. You can see various markers from ancient shipwrecks. The most south-western point of Africa.Well worth the trip - make sure you stop by the penguin colony at Boulders in Simonstown on the way.
Simply beautiful!. One of the most beautiful areas we visited on our trip. Stunning coastal drives to get there, beautiful beaches. It gets very windy, and beware the babboons!

Our favourite destination in Cape Town. Cape point is the ultimate destination in Cape Town if you want views and more views. Venus pool is a hidden gem, but go very early to beat the fishermen. Gifkommetjie is a beautiful drive and the views are amazing.

Breathtaking Beauty. The scenery is exceptionally beautiful and the trip up the Lighthouse is definitely worth the effort. Did not enjoy standing in the queue for 30 minutes while the cashiers sorted them selves out. Long queues in the take away café are also very annoying. The natural beauty of the place makes it all worthwhile. GO EARLY!!!

Beautifully desolate. We were here this December, and fearing holiday queues, we were ready at the gates by 7 a.m. We drove up to the lighthouse and were literally the first ones to arrive and were pretty much alone. It was stunning... and so peaceful! On our scenic drive around towards cape point we encountered two families of baboons, ostrich, saw cape fur seals basking in the rocks just off the shore, and enjoyed the diverse birdlife along the beach while on the Thomas T Tucker shipwreck hike that starts at Olifantsbos. Quite an experience! we were leaving towards 11 and as we passed the gates a long queue of cars and tourbusses was waiting to get in! The early arrival was well worth it!

Amazing. Ostriches, Eland, georgeous flowers and plants, great views. Don't miss it! This is a very strange pavement type wilderness, very special and unusual. It is well worth the climb to the top of the lighthouse.

Don't go when it is near a public holiday. We made the mistake of going on NewYear's Eve, we didn't get to the Cape itself, too much traffic BUT we did go down the smaller roads to several lovely beaches and coves. The wildlife was brilliant, birdlife, bontebok, eland, and a close encounter with a mother ostrich and young, (can't call it a chick it was taller than me). In the end an excellent day.
Amazing. An eyecatching view from the top....Will love to go once more..was amazed tho see the point where the oceans meet
Can't get enough!. A worthwhile visit each time. We go down at least twice a year and we love every scene of Cape Point.Still looking forward to a major renovation of the rest rooms...

Great coastal scenery. Visited Cape of Good Hope first for the obligatory photo of the sign post then on to Cape Point. There is choice of the steep walk on foot or with the furnicular then steps up from the shop level up to the old lighthouse on the summit. Worth the climb!

So moving...!!. We took a FD excursion to Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope. The excursion was really good and we did not miss anything... Our guide was so nice (Lucia Casali) - she met us at the hotel and our first stop was to take a boat to the seal island. Then stright to Cape Point, which saved a long queue! Excellent visit of the Cape and then to the pinguin beach. Nice lunch in a restaurant overlooking the beach. Final stop was at the Gardens. Thanks to Lucia for everything!!

Far but worth a drive. This park is very far from CT central, but is well worth it. Cape Point is gorgeous - beware the climb! - but the views are incredible and so are the pics one can get. Wear appropriate climbing shoes and clothes for the climb up and down, and charge your camera batteries. Easily spend a day here if you take your time, or half a day including the hike to the lighthouse, so plan accordingly.
Wonderful View, Wonderfully Kept Up. Traffic controlled, beautiful drive in, easy parking, lovely walks and perches high above the ocean, fun funicular.
Tip of African Continent. Cape Point is a good place to visit to brag that you visited the southern most point of African continent. A cool place
Unique. Cape view is a geographic and historical mark all together. I just loved to be there, being able to experience what I learned when I was a child. The Atlantic meets the Indic Ocean. WOW!

Two Oceans Restaurant a must while visiting the Cape.. Talk about a meal with a view. The restaurant is perched at the top of a short cable car to the top. The meals we had all around were truly outstanding and reasonably priced. Capped off with a glass of South African wine and it was perfect. And every table has a view of the Cape.
Cape Point beautiful. But go there early, especially if you stop in Simonstown on the way to watch the penguins and if you want to skip the shuttle.
a must visit. If you come to Cape Town, you have to visit the cape point. Awesome landscaep, awesome view.... the only bad thing are the masses of tourists..

A "must go" place to visit. We considered Cape Point a "must go" place to visit in South Africa! It has so much history envolved! You can take a walk to the old light house, which will provide you with a great sight and pretty pictures. The restaurante is also great!

Wild ostriches and baboons by the roadside. We hadn't expected to see wild animals outside the national parks and forests. So we were surprised on the first day of the trip to see chacma baboons sitting in the bushes by the roadside eating figs. Next up was 3 ostriches standing by the roadside. We could get down and take pictures from a safe distance (about 40 feet). The Cape of Good Hope was also spectacular with huge waves crashing into the cliff-side. The entry fee is 110ZAR. A funicular is available at extra fee to go up the mountain for vantage views but since it was raining we skipped it. There were well maintained restrooms and a small souvenir cum snack shop.
Spend a day. We enjoyed the park but didn't arrive until after lunch and to really see the park you need a day particularly if you are going to visit the light houses etc

Amazing place to visit. great place to visit, you can spend a full day at Cape point, so get there early. The restaurant is nice, but bringing your own food could be nice, as the restaurant gets very crowded.You can hike to diaz beach, and go to cape of good hope (I went by car, not hike).Going to cape point is a visit you must make while being in cape town.
Stunning. Worth the trip. Cape Point Ostrich Farm worth a visit (if not going to Oudtshoorn Ostrich Farm) and Stanborough great wide beaches and waves.

Watch out for the monkeys. Very dramatic scenery. The steps up to the lighthouse are hard work especially if it is windy, as it was when we went, there are few hand rails and they are quite exposed, but it was worth the climb. Food in the restaurant was very good but it was a bit like a fast food joint.

The point is ... nothing beats Cape Point!. This is indeed one of my favourite outings in our country! Nothing beats the beauty of this area, and the Diaz Beach MUST be one of the BEST BEACHES in the world. Quiet, secluded, safe, beautiful - and not many people visit it - as you need some exercise with a hike down to it! Most people just enjoy the view from the point itself. Wonderful historic information available here too! A MUST if you are in SOUTH AFRICA as a tourist - an outing you will never forget! A restaurant is available - but we took our own picnic basket. Overnight stay is available and this will be wonderful - we only visited for a day! It can also be part of a hike of a few days - starting here and ending at Table Mountain - or the other way round. Only an hour's drive from Cape Town!

Amazing place!. We have spent most of the day at the Cape Point. it is worth arriving there early in the morning as it gets packed with tourists very quickly and they can be very irritating. Also, it is worth bringing your own food as restaurant and a take-away get extremely busy and there is a pure chaos. Views are breathtaking!!!

STUNNING views …. If you're staying in Cape Town, the drive down to Cape Point is well worth it …. not least because it takes you through some very pretty laid back seaside towns - such as Kalk Bay and Simonstown. The drive will take you about an hour.When you arrive the parking is easy. There are loos and a good cafe …. There's also a 'white table cloth' restaurant which we didn't use. We had v good pizzas at the cafe…. I'm not sure whether someone in a wheelchair would be able to get to the very top - but they would be able to get onto the vernacular train and then appreciate the views from the first 'viewing area' You travel up to the rocky Point by vernacular railway …. and at the top the views are truly stunning. You will get some stunning shots…..

amazing, but 4 stars for lack of info. The reserve is an incredible place, but until we arrived and even after, I found info on their trails and experiences available to be sparse. We did the amazing ship wreck trail and we were the only people on it for more than 2 hours. I'm certain this is because the trail brochure, which was 5 rand, was labelled Trail #5, or something that nondescript. If people knew how much there was to offer and see I think more people would plan to spend the whole day there, but most come in and go to the point and leave. Watch out for baboons!!

Beyond words. We visited on a very windy day and I thought my camera would be ripped from my hands. The views however were beyond words. You can take the car up to the top of Cape Point and then look down at the ocean. The view makes your heart stop. We spent 30 minutes just looking down at the ocean, marvelling at the natural beauty. Cape Point is actually far more impressive than the Cape of Good Hope.

Beautiful views. Cape point has wonderful views with fynbos and sea and is really beautiful .You can hike up or take funicular .If you decide to hike up please note that if you tired to return it is more costly to go down than just go and up and down,a R10 difference .

TheSouthAfrican review. Surrounded by the majestic Table Mountain fynbos this is a place you don't wanna miss you visit Cape Town. The picturesque scenery and the array of over 200 flowering species will keep you snapping away as you move through the park.

Enjoyable. While the views are rather good, it is a long drive to get there from Cape Town. The whole experience does not last very long, ending in a good view of Cape Point at the lighthouse. Would not be my first pick of what to do in Cape Town

Scenic beauty amongst the cliffs. I always love visiting Cape Point when I am in Cape Town. it is a lovely drive to Cape Point pass Simons Town. After entering the nature reserve , you can experience this floral paradise with natural fynbos and indigenous plants. I enjoy the walk up the cliffs where you can view the oceans. it is great being at the Jagged piece that you see on the maps. I enjoy taking the side roads in the reserve towards the beaches where you can take lovely photos.
Beautiful!. Enjoyed visiting Cape Point. We enjoyed the hike to the lookout point - paved but lots of steps. The views are gorgeous.

Awesome beach and views. Nice reserve with Fynbos galore, as well as great views at Cape point. We had the kids with so opted to take the funicular car up the mountain. Great photo opportunities at this place.

Fantastic wonder of nature, and unique in the world. This is a fantastic site to visit while in Cape Town, being the most southern point of Africa, and the point where two oceans meet. The attraction is neat and well run. The views and nature of the reserve are spectacular. The Cape Point attraction is located in the nature reserve, and is not far from the entrance to the reserve. The Cape Point attraction includes viewing areas and pathways to the end of the Cape Point. There is also a nice restaurant with amazing views. Definitely a must see while in Cape Town.
take time. We were there on a very windy day but there are great walks. Either take the cable car up or have a very easy walk up
Light house. A must go place, the wind is very strong by cape point. Amazing views
Cape point a nice place to be. The walk to the tower very nice and refreshing. can walk or use the train. The road to the tower is smooth and tarmacked

Worth the money to see the Penguin.. It is worth the money to get a close view of the penguins. If you do the free walk along the walk way you can not get close enough to the penguin to really experience them. We saw Penguins sitting on eggs. Penguins taking nesting material from other nests while the resident penguin was swimming. The baby penguins look particularly funny with their fur coats in varying degrees of shedding. Well worth the visit.

Beautiful views. This is a must visit for Cape Town. The scenery is stark and it is windy. There is a small tram to take you to the top of the rock if you do not want to walk (extra fee). Just outside the entrance are some of the ubiquitous craft sellers. Their prices were much cheaper than you will find in Cape Town and they seem to need the business. If you are driving take the west coast road back to Cape Town for more spectacular scenery and cliff hanging roads.

Well worth the trip. Fantastic views from Cape point. Really unspoilt landscape. As well as the walk to the point there is a great walk off to the right past stunning beaches & to another headland peak. Well worth the drive down there & stunning scenery from cape town on the way. The restaurant also serves decent food for lunch. Many other beaches also to explore.

In the wake of portuguese navigators. If you would like to feel a bit of taste of what the portuguese navigators saw and felt when saiing these seas do not miss the tour to Cape Point Reserve. We enjoyed the views, the nature, the wilderness.

Forget the cable car! Turn right and discover the most beautiful beach on earth. Everything they say about this place being stunningly gorgeous is true and insufficient....it's the most beautiful and breathtaking place I've ever seen in my life. Skip the cable car up to cape point and take the little hike to the actual peninsula and then the stairs down to the secluded and most beautiful beach ever. Be careful around the waters edge though, I can't guarantee you'll survive a dip in this ocean at this beach. This is a must do bucket list item for sure!!
Do not even think of missing this place!. This is a must visit. There are no words to adequately describe the experience. We were there on a great sunny day and it was an amazing experience.
Wild nature. This is as fare you nearly can go in Africa. Beautiful and dramatic wild nature. Take the Atlantic coast way if you have the time for it.
Cool place. Go there. Great scenery and vistas and possible baboon sightings. Just remember to drive on the left side. And drive down there is pretty interesting as well,

It's not the southernmost tip of Africa but it's still pretty impressive. When travelling down from Cape Town don't miss the bay (as we did) where the penguins are. Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope alongside each other. There are some interesting birds, lizards and flowers here and a lovely sandy beach if you want to take a stroll to reach it. Interesting information is displayed about the climate and weather predictions from the meteorology station based at Cape Point. We also came across an ostrich crossing the road in front of us. There are spectacular views and you've got to visit there and take a stroll around

Great views. We visited here as part of a day's guided tour and were really glad we made the trip from the centre of Cape Town. We drove through some amazing countryside with stunning views and were not disappointed when we finally reached Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope. The only problem was that they were having one of the power 'outages' when we arrived so had to walk up the steep hill instead of using the lift. The views were still very worthwhile.
Worth more than a day trip. We based ourselves in Simonstown and spent two full days in this park, which is vast and diverse. There are nice walks you can take, and lots of wildlife to see.

Super!. Don't forget to go to the Cape of Good Hope! Lot of people only go to Cape Point. The drive down to Cape Point, via Houts Bay, Chapmans Peak is breathtaking. On the way back, don't forget to see the Penguins at Boulder Point (near Simonstown)- Lot of fun watching them.

A windy visit to Cape Point Nature Reserve.. Cape Point is in the Table Mountain National Park. The restaurant, "The Two Oceans " was good. We walked up to the lighthouse instead of taking the funicular. The wind was howling ; the feeling was of being on the edge of Africa. The cormorants took the thermals and with their legs hanging down ready to alight onto their crag-like cliffs in the adverse wind. The area is in one of the six Floral Kingdoms of the world where unusual species of plants known as fynbos ( fine bush) have survived the howling gales. Here you can see Eland, Zebra, baboons and gemsbok. There are mountain trails, swimming beaches and one can either be part of the tourist scene with restaurant and souvenir shops or you can explore unspoiled terrain, protected from the ravages of time. There is a good information centre. The ablution blocks and all the buildings are designed to blend into the natural scenery, and are of mountain stone with roof gardens. You can either walk to the lighthouse or take the funicular. There is an entrance fee into the park, but when one considers the privilege one has of being able to experience this sensitive area of incredible beauty, more or less 10 $ is a small price to pay. Just be aware of the baboons and do not walk around with food.

Worth a visit. We saw ostrich near the ocean, such a lovely surprise! Also a family of baboons along the side of the road, cute to look at but understand they are quite dangerous so stay clear! A nice drive through great rock scenery, wonderful colors in the rocks. Quite congested and noisy at the tip of the cape, lots of cars and tour coaches, the road through the Reserve was not busy.

Beautiful Water and Wildlife!. Another must see landmark! Take the cable car up to the lighthouse and hike the ~30 min path (there and back) to the left of the lighthouse that takes you all the way to the southern most point. This view is breathtaking and its wonderful to experience where the two oceans meet. Plus, the wildlife (baboons, ostrich...) on the way to the point is a great bonus.
Cape of good Hope. Impressive scenery and plantlife, funicular railway to point a great idea for older travellers like me with osteoarthritic hips

Great place. Well organised - handed a brochure with map and full information at the gate which is actually quite a long way away from the actual point. Well signposted and plenty of parking and toilets. Like all National Parks there is an entry fee of 40R. Good value and good to know that money is going to preserve the area.

Incredible experience. This trip is definitely worth the effort! Take a full day and drive down via Simons Town-do boulders beach with the penguins. Stop at one of the other bays for lunch. Chapmans Peak Drive (the route there from Cape Town) was the most beautiful views we saw our whole time driving the garden route. From experience for the actual Cape Point itself bring sensible walking shoes-I did it in flip flops but wasn't ideal!! And also bring a waterproof/ cardigan as it is blowy!!! Beautiful walks and lovely experience! 100% recommend planning to spend a day of your time in Cape Town here
Wild. The sea was amazing such force of the ocean and wild life keep your eyes open and be surprised.The plant life was very diverse and the rocks very colourful.

Well worth the effort. Take a car and give yourself plenty of time, there are walks everywhere.take good shoes, sunscreen ,water ,hat and a jacket the weather can change very quickly.remember your camera, scenery is as good as you can get
you feel like at the end of the world. a must do if you travel to Cape townbring a rain coat, wind breaker since the ocean is very cold so the air + the wind could be cold.DON T FEED THE BABOONS :P

Hold on to your hat. Not sure what everyone is raving about. It is a well maintained site with decent rather than spectacular views. The views pale into insignificance compared with those from table mountain.The walk up to the lighthouse was a welcome bit of exercise but the area around the lighthouse was rather cramped with limited viewing space. It was also very windy. One can walk the extra to the Cape itself but there seems little point doing that except for the fact that it is the Cape (and it's not as though the Cape is Africa's Southernmost point!)It was a pleasant enough drive to get to the Cape but it is very much a fair weather trip.

Surreal. Fantastic, wild beautiful.....but what was more weird/amazing? The bull seal lying on the beach about 10 feet away from us and eyeing us warily, or the families of ostriches (including chicks) running along the beach, wings and necks wobbling precariously?What a fantastic experience for kids and adults alike! A must-visit destination.

Crowded at the point, peacefull aroung. Main attraction: everybody to the point !! And the lighthouse ....Great view indeed but so crowded ...Some people think that climbing over the walls and standing on that edgy rock for a smartphone picture makes them ... immortal. Might be wright if a gust of wind would help them a little bit: CRAZY !!Once you leave this 'attraction' it is worth taking a tour to the two coastal shores: small roads leading you to places where ... nobody comes ??!!Strange but magnificent: you can wander along the two ocean-shores and probably see nobody else then the company you are with: fantastic.Water is icy cold in January, but who cares ?And if you are lucky you can see a small portion of the African wildlife .... because it still is a nature reserve to start with.
Amazing. It is worth going there, to see Cape Point, where the 2 Oceans meet. A point that mankind had to sail in history. Truly an amazing experience.
Cape Point beauty. This visit was my 1st time and am glad to make it - the area is well preserved and well done too - as the area has been ravaged by fire and modernisation
Garden. Theses gardens were superb. There were millions of different species of flowers that I didn't know excited.

Beautiful nature and view. Went with the family. Beautiful nature and views. Perfect for pictures. Went during the week. Had a nice lunch in the restaurant , and thought it would be more tourists but it was perfect . Good food and very good service . Go here with no stress.

A taste of wild Africa. This is like a toe in the water of the real wild Africa. Remote, empty roads, amazing views out into the ocean. We saw a tortoise, zebra, baboons and ostrich. Cape Point itself was a bit like a theme park with the funicular railway bringing in crowds of people, but the Cape of Good Hope was fabulous - just a car park and the wild rugged rocks of the shore, a clifftop walk, and raging seas.

Good weather day trip. Cape Point Nature Reserve is a good weather day trip. If you are driving yourself ... take time to search the flora for birds and animals hidden sometimes. There are hikes that you can do. Take a walk as close to the point as possible, up to the lighthouse and down to have photos taken at the Cape of Good Hope. The restaurant serves lovely food but if you are here in peak period it's good to make a reservation. If the wind is blowing ... it isn't pleasant to visit.

The Tail of African Continent. Cape Point on the Western Cape Peninsula is a breathtaking scenery rich in flora and fauna. To reach the lighthouses, you have to hike through the cliff, hills and valleys. After the last lighthouse, there is no land surface leading to the South Pole

Feels Like I Stood on the Tip of Africa!. It is something to stand on the edge of a continent. The views are breathtaking and its even possible to see Antarctica from South Africa. From the baboons to the ostrich farm, there is something for everyone. Of course, the Cape of Good Hope and lighthouse are the highlights of this Reserve and an absolute must for your visit to Cape Town!
A Real jewel in a tour to Cape Town. The serenity and the beauty of the place is simply fabulous. Of course, one has to be prepared for a very pricey restaurant and very pricey fernicular ride.
Awesome photo spots. Take Cape Convoy tours there as Rob is th best in the business for personal small tour groups going there, I use him exclusivly for this,

amazing. very well organized, unbeatable view from the lighthouse!! words arent enough to describe what you will feel by visiting this place. be careful of the baboons, you will see many on the way. dont forget to visit the restaurant!! very good sea food and very good wine list. GO ...

Must see place. Me and my wife heve choosen Cape Point Route cc for a full day tour. We were totally satisfied with the kindness of the guide, the quality of the bus, the variety of the program. It is not cheep but worth the price.
Once in a lifetime experience. It was a privilege to be at the Cape and experience the fantastic views. Please take the time to climb up to the lighthouse and see the marvellous view.
a must do if staying in capetown. Great scenery and plenty of things to do on a visit to Cape point. Rough weather can make it more dramatic but on a clear day the views are spectacular.
lovely drive. Drove through the Nature reserve to get to Cape Point. Lovely drive and scenic, Saw ostriche. Baboons,

A must!. It's a must visit place..views are great..we took a cable car to go to the top. on the way to cape point, the southern most tip of the African continent, we saw Ostriches and lots of proteas...at least 6 different species!

A slow drive is most rewarding. Cape Point Nature Reserve is a must for any visit to Cape Town. Head south past Sea Point, Camps Bay and Hout Bay to enjoy the stunning Chapman's Peak Drive, and then through Kommetjie and the usually misty Misty Cliffs to reach the entrance. Once in the park, take it slow. You could easily spend four hours meandering along the side roads before getting to the 'Point'. These side trips offer stunning floral scenery in winter and spring, as well as opportunities to see baboon, bontebok, zebra, eland, ostrich and more. Look out for tortoises on the road - if you see one, you're likely to see several. There are many hikes along the coastline, and if your preference is to avoid the bustle of tourists pouring out of the busses at the 'main attraction', you can expect plenty of peace and quiet on these trails. The shipwreck trail is well worth doing, and look out for dolphins if you venture out to Venus pool.
Great Photo Op. Visited Cape of Good Hope and Cape Point Nature Reserve in November, 2014. Great place for photos and the lighthouse was beautiful.

Beautiful Drive!. The drive itself from Cape Town to Cape Point is worth it! Beautiful scenery and great roads! The Nature Reserve Park is well kept, beautiful sights and all facilities work well. Watch out for some baboons along the drive!

Great get-away from CT Central. Just had a few spare hours near the end of a business trip to Cape Town. We decided to take the rental car and head out for one of the tourist hot-spots around CT, Cape Point. An easy, but very worthwhile and scenic drive through Camps Bay, Hout Bay, Kommetjie a.o.Spectacular views and easy walks. We had so little time that we could not make it up to the lighthouse or even to the point itself. That did not matter, it feels good being there, a powerful force of nature and 'feeling the presence of oceans coming together'. Due to time constraints, we also did not visit the Nature Reserve. Will certainly get back another time.On the way back to Hout Bay (via Simons's Town, Constanza), we got stuck in traffic at several occasions, specifically around traffic lights that were not functioning (power load shedding?). Be careful if your are on a tight schedule to get your flight from Cape Town International Airport!

Seems like the end of the earth. Wonderful drive through remarkable scenery to get down to Cape Point and then walk through to Cape of Good Hope. Care around the baboons that line the road in parts; enjoy the ostriches and in particular the flora, which is outstanding. Pleasing little pizza-café at Cape Point. Nothing at all to dislike - an essential visit to a stunning place.

Was hoping to see more.. A little disappointed once arrived at Cape Point, not a great deal to see, didn't bother to take the Funicular to the top of the mountaain but that was more due to time restraint as we were on a tour.

Our tour was with Ilios travel,it was a perfect day ,. WE enjoyed a full 8 hours where we travelled along the beautiful scenic Chapmans Drive to Cape Point,where we climbed the hill to the lighthouse ,it was very winy ,great views ,we also saw Baboons Ostriches,zebras and African Penguins

Wild landscape dramatic coastline. We drove down from Cape Town through the wild landscape on a sunny but very windy day. Not much wildlife to see (our guide said they were sheltering from the wind on the Indian Ocean side of the land) - just a couple of baboons on the road, and two more in a bush eating berries. At Cape Point we took the funicular up to the top and then the short walk to the "first" lighthouse and the great views from there. Then back down to near the top funicular station before taking the 1.5 mile path to view the second (newest) lighthouse and Cape Point itself. So dramatic and wild, really not to be missed. Warning, you need to watch out for the wind on parts of the path on the day we were there, but we didn't feel in danger. Also, there are long slopes and steps down on the way so it's quite a climb back up, but nothing too wearisome to worry about.We then went to the Cape of Good Hope, a long walk from Cape Point, or a road connection a little way from the car park. Tremendous waves, huge spray, rocky coast, seals on the rocks. Well worth the visit.

Not Actually the Southern-Most Point of Africa. The truth is it's not the southern-most point in Africa. (A bit of a fraud). Still worth it for the classic photo at the sign and a quick mini "hike" up the hill.

Beautiful place. Nature at its best, take some time to discover the whole park, by bike or foot! We were there in november and it was super windy, the way up to the Lighthouse to look down to 'ze' cape point looks worse then it is and even seriously unfit people can make it in windy weather, wearing heels ;) there's a cable car for fans of those of course not included in the park entrance fee.
Fantastic Views. This is a must. We walked but there is a cable car for those unable to walk or in a wheel chair. Wonderful and a must.

Fantastic landscapes and some nice wildlife. I enjoyed the views most but was also very pleased with the small amount of wildlife we saw (baboons, ostriches, butterflies, 3 zebra and lots of birds). Well worth a visit.
Cape Point. The views of the ocean and whales. There is a very nice restaurant at the Point. We also saw wild baboons on the drive in.

A wild and rocky view of the end of the Cape.. The car-park is now mercifully baboon free, they had begun to take over. And why not, they were there first?!? Sadly the human element destroyed that relationship and made it unsafe to be in the same space together.Spectacular views, good walks down to the neighbouring bays and a funicular railway to take you up to the lighthouse if your legs are dodgy. The Nature Reserve is huge, but most people just visit the little bit at the end to have their pic. taken by the sign. It's worth exploring by bike or car, as there is game roaming around, beautiful wild scenery and a remoteness hard to find these days if you're from the city.
Blown away!. Great to go down to the end of the continent. It is very windy at the top by Cape Point lighthouse, so hang onto your hat!

Awesome. Make sure you take enough time to see and hike around. The restaurant is comfy and nice views. Take a jacket it can get windy. You will have a good time. there are cottages for rent if you do it well in advance.
where two oceans meat. Scenic ride and hike to the lookout of cape point - Atlantic on one side and Indian on the other side of the park.

Unbelievable!. the beauty and wind at this lookout post is incredible-also amazing was the food in the cafeteria--the best sandwich of our entire trip-chicken salad and avocado--totally amazing after a busy morning of sightseeing--

Not where the oceans meet but friends meet!. As a descendent of the Original Inhabitants of this area, I am proud to take all family, friends and overseas guests to Cape Point. Although most of the reserve prohibits fishing or removing anything from the sea, it still remains an extremely popular place for local families of all social strata. Many still dive for crayfish (lobster) and do fishing from the rocks but before you do so check out the rules with a park official because permits are required.The 'Flying Dutchman' train ride is a must fit elderly or disabled and the cost is very reasonable. The fit normally walk up the steep hill at no cost except for some stiff joints the following day.The big restaurant is ALWAYS packed to the rafters so I'd you don't want to be disappointed, then you must make a telephonic booking before you go. The food as always been great and affordable which probably explains why it is packed.Watch out for baboons... DO NOT WALK ABOUT WITH ANY PLASTIC SHOPPING BAGS IN YOUR HAND. They can be a pests and should not be viewed as cute and harmless. They will grab your bag and attack you if you don't let go because they expect to find food inside!Other than that there are literally hundreds of photo opportunities so take your digital camera along to record this beautiful part of Cape Town.

What a rip off. The internet prices are half what the actual prices are, the place needs a good clean up as something was dead at the point and so flies were everywhere! Toilets are a disgrase, even though people hanging around they fail to do their job. Very disapointed as it is a popular location.
Cape Point. Face to Face with Nature lots of scenic spots and beautiful view of the so called "2 oceans meeting"

Must do when in Cape Town!. This is a must do experience when in Cape Town. Try to hire a car and self drive through the reserve. Give yourself the whole day for this attraction. This will give you plenty of time to stop and take in the scenery or go for a walk. Take a walk up to the lighthouse, have lunch at the Two Oceans restaurant. Make an early start to avoid the coach tours.
Definitely worth a visit. If you're in Cape Town and have an opportunity, definitely try to visit the Cape Point nature reserve and the Cape of Good Hope.

Gotta visit this!. This is part of the Cape Town Peninsula tour and a must to see. Lots of the protea family trees in bloom during certain parts of the year and also lots of flowers in season. Do not expect too much animals but look out for the Bontebok and ostriches. The Cape of Good Hope point is very busy with people taking pictures but well worth it. Take a hike up to the light house and experience the grand view from there. Just be on the lookout for the baboons at the restaurant, they steal your food, even from your hands. Good place
A must see. Perfect. The landscape, the animals and the feeling. To know that the next stop would be Antarctica is just amazing. If you go to SA, this place is a must see.

A Cape Town must. If you can, hire a car for the day, and give yourself the whole day. We didn't have enough time when we went and were not able to explore and walk around the point or explore the nature reserve. A spectacular piece of coastline.

A wonderfull site where you can enjoy both the Atlantic and indian oceans. A great site to visit! You can walk up to the top of the hill where the lighthouse is. Scenic view to both Oceans, and you also have ostriches and baboons.
amazing place. Beautiful view from the top of the Cape Point and then a walk to the Good Hope. Stunning views of the beach and the sea.
cape point light house. to drive with the flying dutchman is recommended. save time and energy for climbing the steps to the light house

A unique ecological gem. The high point of a visit to Cape Town, seeing Cape Point leaves you in awe of the explorers who first came here, and the beauty of nature. It is obviously a huge tourist draw so I'd recommend a) coming very early - as close to 8am as you can avoid the hordes of coaches b) getting a guide to take you on some walks on some of the many trails around the point and along the coast in the nature reserve.We did a couple of 2 hour walks and although quite hard work, it was well worth the views, and seeing all the incredible unique plants and animals close up. We saw whales, seals, elan, turtles, geckos, ostrich, and lots of birds. If you can get to the botanical gardens before coming that's even better because then you have a sense of the different endemic plants and why they have evolved as they have, and what's important about them. But just wander about and enjoy the incredible beauty of the scenery, the flowers, and the stupendous cliffs. It's awesome!

Worth it. The wildlife, the vegetation, the rocks and the point with some awesome views of both oceans. There is a lot of hiking opportunities. There is a beach that would be good to hike to. Of course you hike up to the light house and it is all steps.
Wow. Cape point is unreal even though the wind was blowing a treat. Make sure you do the hikes up the peak. Not many seem to but the view is fabulous.
Food. Food acceptable with so many visitors at one point in time. The Que was pretty long but we were helped pretty fast.

Wonderful views. The views were wonderful. We didn't get a chance to go to the beach nor the light keepers trail because it was and organized tour. I would recommend if you like hiking go on your own to be able to really experience the cape.
So worth going to. So worth going to. Lovely wild scenery and naughty wild baboons. Stop off at Boundry Beach on the way back and see the penguins

The end of the world (almost). Standing at Cape Point or Cape of Good Hope is weird knowing that this is (almost) the end of the world, beyond the sea pretty much nothing by water and ice.Brilliant view from the two lighthouses, much more than the actual Cape of Good Hope, which is more of a sign.The drive is pleasant through the reserve, and we encountered a few baboons on the road. The drive from Cape Town is just 1-2 hours with plenty of picturesque 'Kodak' moments along the way.

Historic landmark and spectacular views. Very shortly: you have to go there if you are in the area. And as you drive there you can spend the day arpund that coastline to explore the penguins, nice villages and more.
Well worth a visit. The views are fabulous and well worth a trip out, there is ample safe parking and a good restaurant and sandwich outlet if required.

Spectacular scenery. We went there as part of an all day peninsula tour, the whole area is steeped in history and has breath-taking views from every vantage point so would recommend as a "must do" for every traveller.

Wonderful place but a smile at the gate would help. Cape Point is a wonderful place for me to take my International Tourists. The views are spectacular and combined with some history of the Cape makes for a visit to remember. Sadly the cashiers at the gate have an attitude and could really do with a course on how to smile and treat their customers !

Wonderful excursion to the Tip of the Continent. The journey to the Cape was wonderful ride down the coast with the ultimate views of the joining of two oceans. The views were memorable especially from the lighthouse. The ride back through small fishing and artist villages made the day's journey most enjoyable.

Fantastic view. I was part of a tour that took me to the cape. The day had 50-75 KM/H winds making it a real challenge to walk up to the lighthouse. You had to hold onto something otherwise you might "fly" away. The view is spectacular well worth the trip. I really enjoyed my self. On the way down we encountered playful Baboons (although a bit dangerous).

Almost surreal and haunting. The landscape is hauntingly beautiful, the finboss flowers are everywhere and make the hills look lovely, the occassional ostrichs and other animals add a safari like touch, and the Cape of Good Hope adds history and scenery.
Nature at the end of the world. Great views with, if you are lucky, sightings of wild antelope or unlucky rampaging baboons. Good walk up to the lighthouse
Cape of Good Hope. Breathtaking views at Southern Africa's south western most point.Got to see it to believe it in the mother city.
Stunning views. Stunning views of the ocean on a clear day. I went on a super windy & foggy day which was a tad disappointing,but it was still beautiful.

Wind and wind and a lot of beauty. What a beautiful but windy place! There are 2 places to go, to Cape of Good Hope and pose by the sign which says you are way South, then over to Cape Point with the funicular railway to the top and the lighthouse. It's worth going to the top as the views around 360 are incredible. But it's windy!!

stunning. def worth the 2 hour drive down from Cape Town - scenic views and lovely walks although very windy on the day went so a bit scary on the rocks. Take walking shoes food and water and rain wear and have a romp around. You can park and just walk up to the lighthouse or do longer trails to the most southerly tip. Great views take your camera.

Rugged and beautiful. Obviously a trip here is very dependent on the weather conditions but catch it right and it is well worth doing. The coast line is stunning and a visit up to the lighthouse offers a rewarding view of the most southerly point in Africa. There is a funicular railway but this gets very busy with long queues. If you are fit and heathly then walk is much better as there are other viewpoints on route.
Nice day tour. A rather long drive but worth it. Choose a good travel company and avoid tourist buses, rather take mini vans or private tour.

End of Africa. This is a must do -- If possible rent a car to drive from Cape Town -- much better than a bus / Tour -- The walk to the top was pretty easy and would recommend - the decent was a breeze

Beautiful view. We came to Cape Point via Baz Bus tours and it was a really good day and a very good way to take in as much of the area around Cape Town as possible in a weekend stay. The walk is quite strenuous but on a pathway with stopping areas. The view is beautiful and well worth the walk. There is a cable car to the top, but if you can do the walk it is worth the exercise :-)

For nature and wild flower enthusiasts. Enjoyed the ocean view and nature reserve drive from Cape Town to Cape Point.It was the right time for Protea and many other fascinating blooms. Stopped several times to admire them up close. Beautiful views of the ocean with easy hike, no need for the Funicular even if you are nit fit. Take your time .

You cannot believe you are really there. After studying the discoveries at school and reading Camões' "Lusiadas" epic book, as soon as you arrive in Cape Point you start looking for the monster "Adamastor" that sinked so many ships back in the days ;)You cannot believe you are really in the same place these explorers were so many centuries ago.You have not trully been in Cape Town if you did not go to the Cape of Good Hope to see and feel the place that forever be part of our evolution, oh! and wresttled to take a picture behind the sign...

Poor service from Restaurant. The park is absolutely fantastic and the infrastructure well maintained. We did however have a bad experience in the Restaurant itself. We were asked to leave the restaurant because we only wanted to have some cake & coffee and they were serving lunch. It was a horrible, rainy and icy cold day and all we wanted to do was have coffee/ hot chocolate and some cake. The waiter refused to serve us telling us to go to the neighboring canteen to get our drinks there. When we complained to the manager he said the same thing. We had to sit outside, in the cold and rain and have our beverages in the end. There was no shelter and I really thought that was just in bad taste.

Speechless. Walked up to the point, it was so worth the walk. It is beautifully breathtaking watching the blue waves crash against the point. the baboons are an added bonus of entertainment. Just don't take food out in front of them!
Hike from Cape Point to Cape of Good Hope. HIKE AGAIN: Yes! Wonderful walk from Cape Point to Cape of Good Hope, mostly on a boardwalk. You can even take the steps down to the beautiful beach.

Must Visit. After studying so many years in high school geography about the Cape of Good Hope it was a must visit in our itinerary. It's very interesting and the views are magnificent, and in the way you can stop in Boulder Beach to see the Penguins.
great hike. we had a fantastic walk. it was very long but it was worth it as the views were spectacular. we took a lunch and enjoyed the views.
Wild and spectacular scenery. Breathtaking scenery, wildlife everywhere from lizards to Ostrichs. Great walks and informative visitor centre.

EXTRAORDINARY. Driving around with a guide is time saving. But anywhere and anytime in this spectacular country is highly recommended travel. It's global rating can never be anything less than a must-do.However be warned about the Babboons, though the Extra ordinary view from the vehicle is none the less exhilarating.Ostriches on the beach and the strong wind adds to its charm which is unforgettable.

A place not to be missed. Starting from the drive from Cape Town through Chapman's Peak with its high cliffs and the road cut on the cliff side, the entire view to Cape Point is fantastic with the green and turquoise waters of the Atlantic Ocean splashing across the coastline. After entering the national park ostriches and deers can be seen along the way. Cape of Good Hope is at the foothill and to see Cape Point, either one can climb the steps (not for elderly and with medical conditions) or take the funicular to reach to the top of the original lighthouse. From there the view of the Cape at which two oceans meet is breathtaking. We were lucky to be there on a sunny day and without too much wind. On the return trip, it is recommended to take the route via the Indian Ocean shoreline and visit the African Penguin habitat. Take a coach tour to avoid driving and soak in the beautiful scenes along the entire trip. Plan for a day trip.

A journey worth making. The weather was pretty atrocious whilst we were there, but the trip is still worth doing. How many people can say they have stood at the Cape of Good Hope and had their photograph taken at the sign.
Just Fantastic. Do not miss this wonderful place. So many neat things to see, this should not be missed. Best be seen from a rented car. It's an easy drive.

Very special. The park is really nice to visit.the cape is amazing to be at.wind was strong but the view on the beach with rocks and water splashing is amazing.We went inside only at 16 so we didn't have much time.we saw baboons as well and ostriches.

Lovely. A wonderful place to visit, where the two oceans meet. It is a bit of a drive from Cape Town but well worth the visit. Make it a part of your trip to see the African Penguins. Most highly recommended!
Experience. It is an experience to visit this place, the views are awesome despite the howlling wind. Just watch out for the baboons, they like to steal ice cream.

Ostriches on the beach, beautiful views.. I enjoyed the drive. The point and the animals. Natural flora. Spent about half an hour taking pictures of a male and a female ostrich on the beach. Who would have thought to go to the ocean to see ostriches. A nice herd of Blas boks. No baboons but I am told they are usually there.
A must do. It was amazing to stand in the point where to two oceans meet. It was a foggy day when we arrived but it cleared soon after and it was spectacular!

Fantastic Scenery. Looks are deceiving - seeing Cape Point on a map does not allow one to realise how big it really is. So many places to see and just chill out from Bordiesdrift to the lighthouse.The drive from Simon's town is about 23km to the parking at the light house. The walk from the parking to the lighthouse can be a slog, but for those not up for the challenge, the funicular takes one up in style. Just sitting and hearing all the accents and languages makes one realize, how well visited this place is - from Dutch to Portuguese to Turkish to German to Japanese - a really well visited site.Several hikes can be done, but one needs to spend more time to be able to enjoy that. There is a nice walk to the bottom, that that takes about 45 minutes and longer. Several ostriches can be seen from time to time. A great variety of birds can be seen.The restaurant and take away's section has quite an assorted menu and there are a souvenir shop as well.
trip around the cape peninsula. Stunning views and beautiful nature , truly amazing, we drove around the peninsula and walked up to Cape Point. Worth a visit !

cape point two day visit,. I went to cape point on my second day in cape town. and the best way to see it is by car once you have paid your entrance fee you get to explore all by yourself for the whole day.there is some amazing views and then there is the animals from snakes birds and tortoises to name a few. It was so good that after a hole day there we decided to make our last day in cape town back at cape point.so go by car and take something to eat as cafes and shop are expensive and limited.

Crowded and Poorly maintained. I have visited this reserve many times but have not actually been the the Point itself and caught the funicular up to the old Lighthouse for many years.There was a large crowd of tourists there and although the funicular service worked well, the viewpoint at the top was very grubby and full of graffiti , it was also covered in small flies or midges emanating from the garbage can there , not very pleasant for such a major and most beautiful attraction.

A unexpected beautiful experience!. This was a truly beautiful unexpected experience! We went to Cape Point/Cape of good Hope to see the most Southern point of South Africa and probably a Lighthouse :-). Well both were true but it offered a lot more we enjoyed a few amazing but very dueable hikes (BTW going to the Lighthouse top is a nice climb but they offer a great Cablecar on rails which they call "Funicular") and being in the top at a windy day the speed of the cloudes racing around and over the Lighthouse are more then impressive plus you have a great hike around the Lighthoyse hill and on the little Rocky hill on Cape of good Hope and of course everybody wants to make a picture with the signs! On top of that you can have a very nice drive through the entire nature reserve and see some amazing beaches and other sites! In other words don't think thst you will see all in an hour :-) actually you can spend easily an entire Day at this reserve!

Beautiful!. The dive from Cape Town to Cape Point is amazing, i highly recommend you plan some extra time to stop and check out the sights along the way. Lots of pictures to be taken. Cape Point nature reserve is definitely worth the trip. It is a beautiful spot. I recommend walking down from the top to the bottom. I's about a 45min walk down, well worth it.
a beautiful spot worth seeing. we had a foggy day but it was still lovely to see.everything about cape Town is beautiful.we had a tour.
The end of the world!. Not too 'touristy', but a must to do. Nice little souvenier shop with similar prices to other places.
fantastic nature scenes. Watch flowers and plants native to this place only. Could possibly see some small lizards and baboons as well.

Windy, but worth it. We drove to Cape Point, doing a circular tour from Cape Town. The roads were fine with no issues. We took the Funicular railway up to the lighthouse (you can walk if feeling energetic). It was very windy at times , but great views. There is a formal restaurant and café, which were both busy, so we went to the smaller stop on the way in/out which was fine. Headed to the Cape of Good Hope as well.

Great way to spend a half-day while in Cape Town. We took a half day tour starting in Cape Town down the west coast by Camps Bay, Houts Bay. Some great views along the way. Also went by Boulders Beach to check out the fun penguins. But the Cape Point area was definitely a highlight. Amazing to think the next closest land mass is Antarctica! It was a little foggy, but even so, the views were impressive. Beware of the baboons - keep your snacks hidden. We only had 45 minutes there - I definitely could have spent a couple of hours at least.

Fabulous place to visit. Loved it here, so much birdlife, stunning views, ostriches on the beach, lighthouse, mist rolling over the top of the mountains, you can see forever. You must definitely go if you visit Cape Town.
Beautiful site!!. We had a lunch at the Seaforth restaurant. A little expensive but a nice road trip. Cape point road trip from city center is a must do!!!

Cape of Good Hope and Cape Point. I recommend going to this attraction. Southern most tip of Africa with picturesque views of South Atlantic Ocean. Funnicular railway recommended, if you are short of time. Trek up the mountain is also recommended. It is 2 hours drive from Capetown via a coastal route down M6 via Clifton, Houts Bays, Camps Bay, across to Simons Town and down to Cape Point.Good beaches to stop at Houts Bay and Camps Bay.

Defintely worth your time and money. This is a beautiful park only 1,5 hours drive from Cape Town. You can walk up and down or go by cable car or make a combination of both. It can be quite windy up there (when I was there, I could barely breathe) so bring a warm wind jacket. Along the way from the entrance of the park to the southern point, you see protea flowers everywhere which are currently in full bloom. The different colors (yellow, red) are amazing. Make a short stop to take a photo. On the way back, take the first road left and drive on. You will see some austriches walking around eating. You will enjoy this park.

Nearly the most Southern Point in Africa. You can dine in the restaurant or just have coffee and cake. Take the funicular up and enjoy the view. There are excellent hiking trails and you can also mountain bike in the reserve.
Oustanding scenery and quality attractions.. Take the Hout Bay route and go around Chapmans Peak Cliff Drive and eventually you'll get to the reserve which will leave you gobsmacked with it's beauty.

A great day out. One of the must visits of the Cape Peninsula. Its best on a day without wind. This place offers so much to do, from staying over in incredible tented houses, to walking on a beach with ostriches.The park has beautiful wildlife and incredible beaches. I would recommend to buy a Wildcard if you are going to visit more than one south african national park or SAN park, with this card entrance is free, and you can buy it per person, couple or family.you can bring your own wood and make lunch on one of the fireplaces next to the beach, or you can have an amazing meal at the two oceans restaurant with breathtaking views. Also make sure to visit the Lighthouse. There is a small cable way but the walk is not to bad. Also try to visit all the beaches and walk around. (no lions) Enjoy

Most scenic place I have ever been. This has to be one of if not the most scenic places I have ever been, the drive from Cape Town is simply amazing, the park itself offers great scenery and great photo opps! We had lunch in the only restaurant in the park and it was beautiful! We walked on deserted beaches, deserted by people that is as we did come across a baboon and an ostrich walking side by side! This really is a remarkable place

Beautiful!. What a beautiful place. We got there early and saw the old lighthouse and took photos before the many tourbuses arrived. The tour buses seem to stick to the two main attractions of the reserve so the rest is not crowded. It is incredibly windy at the lighthouse, and there is a lot of walking and stairs to climb so dress accordingly. We tried to walk towards the actual point from the lighthouse but a HUGE baboon was in the way and us two small women backed off. Next time I will be going with my big husband :) We saw a few other animals, including ostrich with babies and a small tortoise which was my favourite sighting of the day. There is a fancy restaurant and a small cafe that sells pizza and sandwiches. We shared a footlong baguette with chicken avocado and watercress. It was good, all the ingredients were very fresh. I have gluten issues but it was worth the suffering for that sandwich! Unfortunately had time constraints and had to rush our visit, it deserves a full day of your time. Pricey, but that keeps the masses out which in turn keeps the bush intact and litter down. Hope to go back soon and make use of the braai (bbq) area.

A must!!!. Unfortunately I was on an organised tour so only had 1 hour at the reserve. Manage to walk to the top (you can take a cable car) and the views from each angle were just spectacular. Extremely windy though so watch out for crazy hair in your pics. I didn't not see any baboons but they are around and apparently dangerous. Please do not feed them as they become even more aggressive and need to be put down. The entrance to the park is 110 local currency. Toilets are available and free.

Impressive Cape Point Nature Reserve. Not far from the Cape of Good Hope is the Cape Point. One could walk all the way to the top of the hill where the light house is (15-20 minutes) or take the Funicular for a fee. The vista as one goes up to the light house is magnificent. The Cape of Good Hope is visible in the distance, and the trail is line with pretty flowers in bloom. From the light house, one can have stunning views of the Atlantic ocean. Without pressure to get back to the tour bus in one hour, one can spend a lot more time in this location. A good time well spent.
Scenic picnic spots. This is a beautiful part of Cape Town. The reserve provides braai and picnic spots as well as safe areas for swimming. Not great on a windy day, but otherwise a fun experience.

Don't miss it. If you are in a reasonable shape, I would highly recommend you do the walk between the Cape of Good Hope and the Cape Point. It's not overly difficult and has wooden boardwalks, but it's steep in places. Park your car at the Cape of Good Hope, head up towards Cape Point. Make sure to walk down to Dias Beach on the right, it's stunning, then come back up and continue. At Cape Point you'll find restrooms, food (Two Oceans restaurant is quite good), and a tram up to the lighthouse (if you feel like it, you can just walk up). Watch for baboons around Cape Point, both at the station and on the hike, they are there most of the time. You can also take a walk to the new lighthouse.It's very windy most of the time here and light rain can come at any minute, so bring a windbreaker. The previous time I was there it was quite nice, but this time the wind was so strong it was uncomfortable.When you drive around the park, watch for antelopes. We saw several ostriches near Cape of Good Hope and also a bunch of them near the sand dunes, make sure to stop by there. That should take you about a day. If you have more time, there are plenty more walks around this beautiful nature reserve.

Especially wonderful on a stormy day. We went to Cape Point as part of our Road Scholar Tour during the winter on a day that was expected to be very stormy and we were not disappointed. The prior name of the Cape of Good Hope was Cape of Storms and the day we visited it lived up to that title. Rather than detracting from the experience, the stormy weather (including hail) enhanced the wonderful experience. Remember that this is an old sailing location and many ships have gone down in the area ... so experiencing it that way makes for a wonderful time. You really need to be part of a tour or have a car to do this trip. It is not far from Cape Town but the point is part of an national park and driving around is well worth it with different vistas and experiences wherever you go. Perhaps the least important (except for the photographic opportunity) aspect is the actual place of the Cape of Good Hope (with signs in two of South Africa's 11 official languages -- English and Afrikans). And, if you are interested in such stuff (and I am) be sure to check out the online disputes as to whether the place where the Indian Ocean and Atlantic Ocean meet is actually here or at Cape Agulhas. (Short answer: Cape Agulhas is where the oceans official meet and is the southernmost point on the African continent; Cape of Good Hope is the southwesternmost point on the continent and where its supporters claim the Indian and Atlantic ocean currents meet -- although the Agulhas people claim the currents move up and down the coast a lot depending on the season. However this is no way affects the picturesque aspect of Cape Point.)Right near the cape is a lighthouse which you get to by going up a steep road, parking in a big parking lot, and then taking a funicular up and finally climbing some steps up to the lighthouse itself and the surrounding area. It is not difficult but does take some climbing. On a windy stormy day it can really blow you around when climbing (about the only thing in my experience I can equate it to is nearly being blown off of Palmer and Goudier Islands on the Antarctic peninsula). But the views are magnificent and well worth it. If you don't want to climb the final steps, there is a building you are in when exiting the funicular.One issue that I know only by being told. There are a lot of baboons at the lighthouse area and they are quite aggressive. They have been known to have grabbed backpacks off people if there is food in them and they can be dangerous. Of course, the added advantage of being there on a windy stormy day was that the baboons were nowhere to be seen -- having more sense to be out of the storm than we had.

Beautiful. Beautiful place, the sea is incredible. Make sure that you take the cable car up to Cape Point and the lighthouse, and then head down to the Cape of Good Hope where you can stand by the sea and might see some ostriches.

Bike it if you can. We bikes here with Bike and Saddle and really enjoyed the chance to ride on what is generally flat roads among a number of [nonlethal] game animals. The sights are spectacular as well.

Ostriches on the beach .... Need I say more?. Visit the Cape Point Nature Preserve and be sure to walk to the lighthouse and also down to the Cape ofGood Hope. It is very busy but is too beautiful to pass up.
the end of the worlkd. Some of the most striking sights woldwide. A must do day trip from Cape Town. Fantastic motorcycle or scooter ride
More than expected. How do you describe one of the most beautiful places on earth? A definite must-see for every tourist. Highly recommended!
Integral Part of any Cape Town visit. Flora, fauna and views to die for. Ostriches, baboons and zebras run wild through stunning landscapes. A must!
Fantastic landmark!. A must see for visitors to Cape Town. The only downside is it is a very steep climb for the elderly or unfit! I made it but next time I will take the cable train!

Gorgeous scenery, great walks. I love the fynbos, the beaches, the walks which range from easy to a bit challenging. The views are wonderful, especially from the lighthouse. Take the funicular and then walk the steps all the way to the top. Even on windy day (and there are lots of those) its breathtakingly beautiful and wildly exciting out there. If you picnic just be careful of baboons who will raid your picnic very quickly and they can be dangerous.
Great views. Loved watching the baboons. The views were fabulous. Glad we took the funicular to the top as it would have been a fair climb.

What a view!. We were surprised by the great view we had from cape point. Great!So many birds. And the colour of the sea is magnificent.The hike to Cape point and cape of good hope is well indicated. We saw nice animals and flowers.

Amazing Wilderness. We visited Cape Point Nature Reserve after Simon's Town penguin colony, which breaks the drive down to the Point. It's an amazing drive through wilderness, with ostriches wandering around & monkeys (if you stop keep your windows closed ... We saw a monkey 'raid' on a car which had stopped for piccies; it was hilarious!). Both Cape of Good Hope & Cape Point are worth visiting, the views are absolutely stunning, with good walks. We drove back via Chapman's Peak which also has amazing views. This part of South Africa is awesome.
Fantastic park. Lovely park, iconic, animals, nice to go for a long walk. Spend a day enjoying nature and the seaviews.
Very good. The tour was quite good. Got to see some ostriches from very close.But one needs to check for good weather before making the trip to ensure they enjoy all the views.

Best braai ever. Made a braai in the designated area, and I must say with such a sublime view and tranquil setting it' will always remain with me as one of the most picturesque venues ever. The whole nature reserve is just so amazing, from viewing the cape dassie to the flora and fauna, and the drive to get there is equally sublime via Simons town etc...There is accommodation available and it's well worth a booking to spend a night or two to absurd this sublime setting at the tip of Africa.

Blown away. We visited on an extremely windy day but totally worth the visit. The actual Cape of Good Hope was marked with a sign so good for the photo opportunity and maybe a walk, but people quickly left making room for the next groups. The big car parks, restaurant and lookouts were at Cape Point so removing the pressure of crowds away from the actual Cape. Well organised. The national park is a must do in Cape Town.
Great Site for the Holiday Maker. Unbelievable ocean views, good food in their restaurant, a must for holiday makers, especially for the overseas visitor,...

"Wonderful views". We drove down to Cape Point from Capetown, spending most of one day doing so. On the way, stop off at Boulders beach to see lots of very close African penguins. Cape point is a bit of an uphill walk, but is ok. Dramatic, panoramic views of the Cape of Good Hope right round to False Bay. You can also drive down to the Cape of Good Hope should you wish. Lots of wildlife to be seen. We saw at least ten different Southern Right Whales in False Bay. Ostriches were close to road. Baboons were present, apparently they can be aggressive!

Cape point. God's land for sure.The veld and it's glorious flora is breathtaking.The waves on the shores menacing and majestic as. The dramatic mountain drops.Wild ostriches skirting the winding roads fearless and brazenly posing for cameras was a sight to behold as well as the many daissies or South African rabbits foraging for food around us.And of course being at the Tip of the Cape - a sense of almost achievement.
Watch out for the baboons. We booked a bus tour with a small company which took as to see Penguins at Boulders beach as well as Cape Point itself.
Great Trip. One to put on your list of to do's.A long day but such fun, try to do a private trip, cost's a bit more but is worth every penny

Top attraction. One of the must sees when touristing in Cape Town. Must set aside at least 3-4 hours if you want to give it justice and do the walk to the lighthouse. Don't forget to also take the drive down to Cape of Good Hope.
Where the two oceans meet. Under spoilt nature at its best . Walk to the lighthouse for a view of the ocean , can be a tad windy

Nice day trip!. In a day trip we went from Stellenbosch back to Cape Town. We visited Cape Point Nature Reserve and did the Chapmans Peak drive. If you have the time, do this!At Cape point, walk up to the lighthouse, it's worth the walk! (Watch our for monkeys, since they try to steel your food!)
Good with guide. I nature experince to go by car to the point. We werw two nights in Simonstown and can recommend a meeting with the pinguins.

End of the continent. Great to see the most south westerly point of africa, and the penguins that live amongst the rugged shoreline. Great views and a great trip, well worth the drive down from Cape Town.

I was really here!. This was one of those moments that will really stick in the memory; standing by the Cape of Good Hope sign. Stunning scenery throughout the park and I could have stayed for most of the day. Just glorious, but go on a good weather day to really experience it!
Worth the drive. Take a car - you will see more than in a bus. Explore the side roads. As always the unexpected is what is remembered

Took a Full Day Cape Point Tour with Thompsons- Fantastic!. We booked a full day Cape Point Tour out of Cape Town and were lucky enough to get one of the best guides we've ever had- Mark from Thompson Tours. We drove down to the Cape with a running commentary on everything from vegetation and animals to geography, history and architecture. At the Cape of Good Hope, we felt like explorers- the sun was out; it was raining; there were wild winds; and then it would repeat- in about five minutes! The funicular up to the lighthouse was easy, and the view from the lighthouse was fantastic. Mark had told us to not have any food anywhere on us including in purses. The baboons will get it no matter what. If they come for you, just give them whatever they want. We did not have food on us, so we were fine. On the way back, we stopped at Boulder Beach to see the Penguin colony. They were a delight. We had a wonderful tour of Kirstenbosch National Botanical Gardens again led by Mark who really knew his plants and trees! I love photography, and the whole day tour was one wonderful photograph after another. I'd highly recommend setting aside one day for this trip.

Entrance pricey but worth it. After table mountain I would rate this as my nr 2 attraction in Cape Town. Awesome views if you go to the top. If you are not keen on walking you can take the cable car to the top.

Great spot to get to. Worth a day trip out of the city to this area. Was incredibly windy the day we were there. Now pay attention. The baboons mean business. Don't try to bring any food. They were grabbing bags from people all over the place. Ran through the porch at the restaurant. Seriously people. Don't try to sneak in food. You won't trick them!
Beautiful. The drive to Cape Point is so worth it. The ocean views and drive is spectacular and there are many quaint places to stop. Boulder beach and the penguins are a must see.
Memorable. The place for the traditional picture at the Southerner point of Africa. The sea, the sky, the sun, the forces of the elements.

Whales Whales. enjoyed our drive to the Cape, fantastic views of the ocean. Amusing to watch the Baboons checking out people with food or water bottles. Spent sometime watching the Southern Right Whales lazing in the shallows around the cape cliffs.
Great Nature Area with Lots of unique Vegetation.. It was a nice drive with many native plants, and we spotted some Safari style wildlife. Road is in great shape - well worth the drive.

Beautiful. Wonderful place and spectacular scenery at the point and all the way there on both coasts. It is quite a climb on foot at the end up to the Lighthouse ( there is a funicular too ) but worth it! Would definitely recommend going round to the Cape of Good Hope too - beautiful - and that is where we encountered the Ostriches and Baboons on the road! The drive back up to Cape Town on the west coast is spectacular with lots of deserted beaches and bays. The drive through Chapmans Peak to Hout Bay is truly stunning.
A lovely drive down the coast .... This was at the end of our drive down the coast and it was a lovely spot to see. I would recommend you visit this area.

Cape Point. Be prepared for strong winds up there. The view is amazing, its totally worth it to climb it walking and not by electrical car. It is a challenge and the things you see while walking are perfect. Never in my life I saw clouds moving so fast :D
Nature at its best. had a history and biology book on the park...makes the visit more interesting and intriguing...especially when you ry to identify all he plants.

Stay as long as you can. What a fantastic place! Most people come by coach and o the tourist bits of the lighthouse and the old lighthouse, but if you can, take time to walk to the Cape of Good Hope - the vegetation, birdlife and scenery is just wonderful and you can soon get away from the crowds.

Beautiful nature - baboons quite scary. We visited in April and enjoyed our day having a picnic next to the beach, walking some of the hiking trails. Saw a proposal in the distance in a beautiful nature setting.I must say we had a bad experience with baboons - we were very cautious, but in a split second two massive baboons took over our picnic and they were not intimidated. We threw everything in the car and took off - only to see the guards laughing where we stopped to repack the car - not cool. Not sure what one is to do about this as it is nature, but also not nice having to constantly look over your shoulder.It is also funny to see all the tourists take a photo at the name board cape point at the start of the one hiking trail. Was shocking to see how rude they were - bus loads stopped and wouldn't move and let other tourists in to take photos, people yelling and pushing. If you're a visitor you also need to be nice and friendly

Worth a visit. Quite a long drive brings you to Cape of Good Hope along with Cape Point nature reserve. Along the way you may see animals such as Zebra and Elland, we did. At the Cape of Good Hope there are thousands of birds including Artic Tern and Cormarants. There was also a large colony of seals. The lighthouse at Cape Point is built at the top of a promitory and is so high that it is invariably fogged in and so another had to be built lower down. There is a funicular railway to take you to the top, cost 55 rand, or you can walk up and down. From here we visited the Penguins at Boulder Beach and watched these long mated critters waddling around. Again worth a visit. Simondstown a former UK Naval Base and now manned by the South African Navy is on the return road to Cape Town.

A Great way to spend a day. We drove to the nature reserve after a delicious breakfast and slow start to the day. The concierge gave us a printed sheet with suggestions en route which was very handy. The drive along the coast was fabulous and views from Cape Point great. While we were looking out from the lighthouse area we spotted a Southern Right Whale lolling about in the sea below us and that made our day! Penguin bay on the way back was also excellent for a stop.

Boyhood dream. Ever since I read about the early European explorers as a kid, I wanted to stand at Cape Point. So glad we visited this beautiful spot. You can go for an hour or spend a week exploring the trails, walking the beautiful beach, and taking photos of the zebras and ostriches. A must see.

Beautifull nature, spectacular views. Go there if you want to enjoy the magnificent nature of the cape, you also get to see ostriches and babboons. We can recommend the restaurant in the park, the food was very nice.

Cape point. A remarkable place. We were there on a very windy day but it made things more interesting. The ocean was wild. Try to plan an afternoon there are lots of trails. You can ride the cog rail to the top and walk down or ride both ways. The sandwiches in the quick take away by the ticket booth are great v
The end of the world. It was amazing with spectacular views and wonderful scenery. Its worth taking the walk to the lighthouse and then going on further.

Beautiful, Beautiful Scenery. If you've come to Cape Town, do not miss taking a day to tour the Cape Peninsula, all the way to Cape Point, the southernmost spot on the African continent. You'll find a sign there for a memorable photo. The scenery is vast and beautiful, with changing looks as mist and clouds change the view. You'll also have the fun of seeing ostriches and baboons along the way! There's a good restaurant available at the base of the lighthouse, food quality was very good. On the way out to Cape Point, before entering the park, we stopped at Kalk Village. It has a touristy side with interesting art galleries and nice boutiques, but Kalk is also a commercial fishing port. Walk out on the pier and see the fishing fleet up close. You're also likely to see some large seals that are swimming close to the pier, as well as several that have climbed up on to the pier itself and are enjoying a bit of sunbathing. Good photo op!

Plenty to do. This isn't just a trip to the end of Cape Point, there are numerous other places to visit in the reserve so leave yourself plenty of time to explore the different beaches and lookouts. Beautiful views and well worth a visit.

Great visit to the Cape Point Reserve. Excellent views, but give yourself time to look around, which we did not - schedule a full day trip not 1/2 day. Take a picnic basket, the cafe on location is fine but not great.

Dramatic views!. A great way to spend the day! The drive along the coast is spectacular and the park stops are well marked and kept.
