With dramatic views and wildlife encounters this is a popular attraction and day activity. Recommend going early or later in the afternoon to avoid the tour buses. Can't imagine what this area looks like in the height of tourist season ...

Do not miss it!. We visited it as part of a Peninsula tour and it was a great stop. I wish the famous sign was less packed with tourist, because when we stopped by it we had to take pictures with other, but the presence of tourists cannot be predicted or limited. Beautiful scenery that I would absolutely recommend for anyone staying in the Cape area. Do not miss the lighthouse.

Pricey fee but worth it.. We were initially surprised at the cost of driving into this area having been to quite a few other parks on our travels at much lower prices but it's worth it. The Cape Point is a sight not to be missed. We were lucky to have very fine weather after a miserable morning so the views were spectacular. The roads and paths we went on were all well maintained and there was plenty of parking at the lighthouse point where you can go up on a little funicular or walk the steep but short path. We even watched some whales from the lighthouse viewpoint.

Don't miss Cape of Good Hope. Bypass the ride to the top with mobs of people and hike up instead, it's well worth it. The views are extraordinary and how many of your friends can say they were at the southern tip of Africa?

stunning views. A beautiful park with stunning views of the rugged coast line. There are lots of walking trails for different vantage points to the coast line. A cable car to run you to the top where there is an info & curio shop & below is a quick take away or you can sit in the restaurant to enjoy a lovely meal & ocean views with a possible sighting of whales. The restaurant meals are a bit pricey but what the hec.

Spectacular drive to the reserve, one of the best in the world. Lots of zig-zag to the road, but totally worth it. At each turn, there is a beautiful vista. The only road that would come close to matching it is the road to Serrento, Italy. The reserve is supposed to have a lot of wildlife, but we didn't see any, except at an ostrich farm. Take your time in getting there and enjoy the views from the top.

Round the Cape. We took an organised day trip down the Cape Peninsula which included a boat trip to Seal Island and time to visit the penguins further south. From the top of the fenicular at Cape Point the views were amazing. In all, a good day out with the chance to see combine several new experiences into one trip.
nice walks. Thety said it is a must do, so we did.Nice hikings and Diazbeach/Cape good hope itself is just for the picture with te board.

Well worth a visit. You have some pretty amazing scenery on route to Cape Point and if your lucky you might even see some wildlife, we actually saw some ostrich just yards from the main road. If you have any mobility issues you might find it difficult to walk all the way to Cape Point lighthouse as there are a lot of steps. The views are amazing. You can take the coastal path to the Cape of Good Hope. It does get busy here as coach loads of people come and they all want their photo's taken at the landmark sign. At the right time of year you can see Whales from here but also look out for baboons as they are in this area.

Quite crowded but a must do. It is a must do while in Cape Town, but many tourists. It is worth it going there early in the morning for the sunrise. The wind is quite strong up there and be aware of the baboons. While you are driving to Cape Point or the Cape of Good Hope, zebras, ostriches and antelopes such as bontebock or eland might cross the road. It is definitely worth it going to the very end of the trail out on the peninsula.

a good walk. If you are thinking where to visit when you are in Cape Town, this is one of the trip worth making for.The walk up the light house is enjoyable and can be exhausting for the ones that are less fit. I think the authority has done a good job of keeping baboons at bay. I didnt encounter one when I was there. Up at the light house, you can see the two sea merging clearly...the Indian ocean and the Atlantic ocean. Overall, an enjoyable trip.

Worth including in your trip. The dramatic location ending in the lighthouse is worth the drive and the little railway makes it accessible for those not so fit. After the viewing you can get refreshments at a little cafe and sit outside to eat BUT be warned the birds will have your sandwiches even when they are in your hands. The baboons too can make some clever raids but it's the birds who are the cheeky thieves.

Day well spent. As one of Cape Town's most popular attractions we thought it would be nice to try it out, and we weren't disappointed. The nature is beautiful and so is the walk up to the lighthouse. If you aren't sure what to do with yourself in Cape Town, this is a great idea!!
Natures best. Beautiful park for hikers of all ages. Take a drive to Cape Point. No waterpoints so make sure to stay hydrated

Really Enjoyed our day here. Visiting this primarily for the Cape of Good Hope ect we were pleasantly surprised by how much wildlife there is. We saw numerous ostrich, as well as red haartbest, elan, bushbok and baboons.A word of caution re the baboons. The baboons here are the larger, and more aggressive chacma baboons. We had been very careful to look our car doors every time except for one occasion when we forgot. Having stopped to watch and photograph two male ostrich fighting I saw a large male approach from behind, before we knew it he had opened the rear passenger, got in and was sat on the back seat. Luckily we were so surprised that neither of us panicked. I tried to get my rucksack from the footwell behind me, as there were pears in it and I thought I would throw them out, but he wanted my bag and having shown me his teeth and growled I had no intention of arguing with him. He took the bag and sat beside the car, this gave us the opportunity to close and lock the doors. After he had searched the bag and distracted by bananas that someone behind threw out we managed to retrieve my bag and contents! After this we carried a small bag of fruit to throw out of the car if the same thing happened again.

Wild & wonderful place. This is a wild and wonderful place to visit. We met a couple of wild ostriches on the shore and baboons near the restaurant area. Unfortunately the restaurant was fully booked out for bus tours and the alternative food shop had a very limited selection. The wild flowers were beautiful and the crashing waves provided excellent photographs.

Cape point. Travelling from Cape Town suggest you go via Chapmans Peak, the views are outstanding lovely coast line, try stopping at one of the small town along the coast to get a feel for life there.Cape point should be visited. On a sunny day as the winds can be quite strong. So check the weather before you leave. The plant life has to be seen so varied and unusual. Walk upto the lighthouse, worth the exercise.

Nice area. One of the most beautiful reserves. Keep your eyes open for the antelopes(?), zebras, ostriches, baboons, dassies and lizards! Only disappointment of my visit was the two busses of tourists that arrived at the Cape of Good Hope which made it impossible to make nice photos. (don't forget to check out Olifantsbos. It's a distant beach you'd skip easily, but it's really peaceful)
Allow yourself lots of time !. Don't just drive up to the lighthouse, take the funicular up then leave ! Take some of the side roads and take the time to walk around a bit and enjoy. It's worth it!
Beautiful scenery. We loved the scenery, the vegetation (fynboos), the ocean, the views. It definitely is worth visiting, if you love nature and beautiful scenery.
experience on high level. Beautiful flowers, nice beast which are very rare in nature! Especially the walk next to the beach is very nice!
beauty!. what can be said about the beauty that abounds here? It's everywhere you look, from the ocean, to the mountains. Plenty of wildlife!

Stunning. A fascinating day trip where you can not only see the point itself, but imagine what it must have been like for sailing ships to make this voyage. Along the way, there are ostriches, baboons and antelope along with gorgeous coastal scenery. On your way back to Capetown, take the route past Boulders Beach and see the penguin colony there, then have lunch in the picturesque village.

The views!!. I really enjoyed this trip. views and all. One cannot miss doing this when one is in Cape Town. We took the elevator up to the light house and walked back....walking up is only for the very fit!

worth a visit. great that they have kept this natural as possible. lots of parking at the point, quick trip up to the point and stunning views. bonus of seeing some whales whilst we were having lunch too.
Beautiful. Stunning scenery, breathtaking views, we saw ostriches by the beach, and a few types of antelopes and baboons. A must if visiting Cape Town area.
Standard tourist thing to do, but lovely anyway. Stunning views. Wild nature. Caters for all types and ages wanting to see the South West point of the Cape. Just love the fynbos.

The Most Breath-taking views and Full-day activities...... We reached Cape Point Nature Reserve late afternoon.There is a fee at the gate and we drove the long main road to the Parking Lot at the end....Along the way there are other sights to see that are well-marked...They are points at the coast where one can swim, surf,scuba- dive or fly kites amongst other things to do. There are shops and a Restaurant just next to the Parking Lot.Our intention was to walk up to the lighthouse overlooking the sea and the best breath-(aking views.The very strong wind was a challenge but we got as far as the ascent before the steps to the light house....At that level we could take photo's and take in the unique sights.The fitter members of our group did reach the highest point to take photo's and the sights.Another option is to buy a ticket on the Funicular to the area below the lighthouse. We did not shop or eat at the establishments on this occasion but on previous visits I found prices on the expensive side for a local but probably Okay for tourists and a large variety of souvenirs..... You can make a day of visiting Cape Point for a unique experience that will be long-remembered.....
Worth a visit. Very wild with beautiful views and animal sightings. Bring comfortable shoes and warm clothes. There is a very good gift shop to buy local craft .
Great views. The drive to Cape Point is spectacular but when you get to the nature park the views are even better. The sea was quite rough which just added to the beauty!

Spectacular Cape Point. It is worth the drive here via spectacular Chapmans Peak and Houtt BayWalk up to the lighthouse and take warm clothing unless it is summerWatch the aerial dexterity of the cormorants landing in their nesting place below the lighthouseIf you can, walk on the path and Boardwalk past Dias Beach to the headland (about 45 mins)Later, drive down to the beachIf you are lucky you will see baboons and occasionally ostrich and some buck

Holiday. What a wonderful part of the beautiful country of South Africa this truly is. Southern most tip though some dispute this the scenery here is truly amazing. The only down side if you can call it this is the walk to the top of the hill when you come of the fennicular but if your fit this is not a problem. Beautiful scenery which is very calming and to think the next continent is Antartica is weird. Well worth a day trip and picnic or eat at the lovely restaurants here.

Stunning and awe inspiring. Good path to walk to the top or reasonable funicular, we got the tram up and walked back in less than 10 mmins. Take note of the baboon troop warning re food. The views are stunning and there are longer trail walks. We grabbed a drink and snack but those in the group who had food said it was very good

What a great day out. Went here as part of a day long Cape Penisula Tour. Saw mountain zebra, wild ostrich, bontebok and of course the baboons. The scenery at the Cape is breathtaking. Seeing the Atlantic and Indian oceans meet, is quite something. Had wild birds eating from my hand. Great day

The end of South Africa. Loved the majesty of the tip of South Africa. However, filled with tourists in buses anxious to get photos around the signs. Difficult walking on slippery rocks but the view was magnificent
Amazing. Was in full flower! Saw whales, seals and numerous sea birds. The contrasts of the steep cliffs, green slopes and white beaches makes it a special place

Nature at it best. While it is a long drive from Cape Town CBD it is worth the drive. great views from cape point light house. You must take the side roads and explore. Try to make a day of it and travel early in the morning to fill the day. if not you will miss a number of site seeing opportunities

Wonderful scenery. I am a keen gardener and grow a lot of Proteas so for me to see the huge numbers of Proteas in flower in their natural environment was a real treat. The seascapes were second to none and round every corner was another wonderful vista. The down side of course were all the other cars following the same route.

Not to be missed. Visited as part of a Cape tour. We saw 3 Cape Mountain zebra on the way through the reserve. They blended in so well with the scenery so we were very lucky to spot them. Unless you are quite fit I would suggest taking the funicular to the top of Cape Point where there are stunning views and then walk back down. Watch out for the Baboon families!!! and it can also be very windy. There is a very nice restaurant if you wish to enjoy lunch. Well worth the visit.

Watch out for baboons!. Cape Point Nature Reserve was spectacular. One of the most beautiful places on this earth. There are tons of trails and breath-taking views. Please don't miss! And watch out for the baboons... they are everywhere!

breathtaking. The walk up is not for the faint of heart. There is a cable car that you can also take. Do not take any kind of purse or bag. The baboons can be aggressive if they see a bag. You will not win that tag-of-war. Still worth the visit and the climb up. The restaurant at the base served excellent food.

A must do in Cape Town. Don't try to do this trip as a half day. It takes a full day to see it all. There is lots to see starting off with a tour of the West side of Capetown and the twelve apostles. There is an optional seal island tour which is well worth the short visit. The road has some incredible terrain and it is best done by a tour guide and not in a rental car. The nature reserve is where the light house and Cape of Good Hope is. To maximize your time there, I suggest you bring snacks or a lunch with you. The restaurant is crowded and your time is better spent touring and enjoying the grounds. There is a snack shop there and an outdoor eating facility. The last stop on the tour is the Kirstenbosch National Botanical Gardens and it by itself is an entire day to see and tour. Our guide with Thompson tours was an encyclopedia of knowledge and it one of the few times I over tipped on purpose.

Good views of two oceans. You can climb up to the lighthouse or take the funicular for 100 rand return. we did the latter and if it's hot is the best way to go. You could always pay 50 rand and walk back down. Thee's a restaurant at the bottom but the food is mostly fast food style and there's often a queue.
So beautiful!!. The drive to Cape Poibt is stunningly beautiful!! And stop and visit the African penguins on the ways!!
Photography Paradise. Amazing! Simply amazing! The views are phenomenal and the wildlife is a bonus! Plan for constant changes in the weather!

Views and Nature!!!. I've been here a couple of times. No matter what the weather, it is amazing!!!If it is a nice sunny day, you would want to get there early, before the tourists arrive. ;)Take the hike from Cape Point to Cape of Good Hope.If it is rainy and windy... Just enjoy the awesome power of the Cape of Storms!I love it!!!
You need to be fit!. We loved the views from the top of Cape Point. The climb up is quite strenuous but worth it. Of course the view is breathtaking.
The most south western point. A great hour drive from Cape Town but completely worth it. On the way you can see beautiful towns, beaches and penguins

Blustery visit. We had hired a car for our fortnight in SA. The drive to the reserve was easy. Once on the reserve it was a little confusing trying to find ones way around despite the free map they gave us. Nevertheless we saw what we wanted to with not too much difficulty. We climbed up the rocks at Cape Point and found that it was very windy at the top. Not many others had attempted the climb which was not difficult and was worth the view. We took the funicular to the light house which was a delightful short trip. We read on other reviews to get there early but as we were out of season it was not busy even by early afternoon.

A must see. If you had only one day to stay in Cape and to choose the best place to visit, it is the Cape point Nature Reserve. Especially if you go there with the "DAY TRIPPERS". The trip with the company consists of hiking, biking, seal viewing and going to the cape poing through the Nature Reserve, where you will be able to see the flora surrounding the mountains. I recommend highly more than any other place to be the high priority if one is visiting cape town.

Wow. Make sure you allow yourself at least 4-5 hours here to really take it in. Lunch at the restaurant between walks is a good idea. We took the funicular up to the light house to experience it and walked down. Do all the walks. It is great. Bring binoculars so you can do whale spotting.

Great day out. I could easily have spent much more time here, as well as the actual Cape Point attraction with it's magnificent cliffs and views, there are many miles of walking tracks, plenty of wildlife to spot
Loved it!. Hike up to lighthouse and then hike out to the southern most point- Beautiful! Try to go near sunset for best views.

beautiful view, but beware of the baboons!. It's quite a drive to Cape Point and you have to pay an entrance fee. The view of the two oceans meeting point is very impressive, and the walk there easy. We also walked toward Cape of Good Hope and went down to Dias beach-lovely. Coming back the carpark was fairly empty, except for baboons trying to pull out bits of rubber, windscreenwipers, aerials....they can also open car doors! So beware!!

Must go!. If You have only a couple days to be at Cape Town, here You must come! First to top of Cape Point with funicular, then to Cape of Good Hope to see the great roar of the sea. Then a top quality food at Two Oceans Reastaurant. What a wonderful day to spend!

Enjoy nature. We had a lovely time walking through different parts of the reserve, each offering an unique view and experience. In some areas we walked through fields of pink and purple flowers, with the mountain on the one side and the sea on the other. A great day.The only drawback- some of the hiking trails are not marked well, confusing.

amazing scenery with strong wind. stunning coastal views and breathtaking scenery, a lot of wildlife (beware of the baboons!) - just a beautiful place!!! Even so we started in Cape Town with very warm and sunny weather, at the Cape was a very strong wind, so take a jacket with u!!!

cape point. what a wonderful experience...cape town has go so much to offer and its right on our doorstep...make sure you go on day that its not raining though can get very miserable...otherwise a must for anybody visiting cape town
Be prepared for wind. Wonderful views wherever you look! But be prepared for the strong winds up at the lighthouse - it was hard to even hold my camera still.

travel with ilios. Our driver for the day was so helpful and knew just where to take us to see ostrich, eiland, baboon and zebra in the wild, how lucky we were to see them on the first day. After our trip through the park and to cape point we also got to see cape fur seals, African penguins and a whale in a harbour that was not on the tour, but our guide stopped to allow pictures. The only problem were the group of 4 people who had their own timetable so left us with less time than expected when we got to kirstenbosch gardens. What an amazing day to see all those animals wild instead of a zoo. Don't miss it

Lots to see. To fully explore this park you need at lest half a day. There is lots to see especially if you like walking. Take the path to the lighthouse And you can walk on further to the headland. It says it takes 90 minutes but that would be a very leisurely pace!

fantastic views. On a sunny spring day but with ferocious winds, four of us battled to the lighthouse to look around at the most amazing views. We had driven through the park that was just a couple of weeks off being perfect with a ll the flowers, shrubs etc, close to perfection.
Spectacular !. The south West Point of Africa, crashing waves and whales on the way home! The experience of the funicular up to the lighthouse was fun and saved a walk......
Nature and mistic. Amazed for such a beautiful clifts, beaches and views. You may find several animal species, as well as a very rich Flora. Worthy to visit

Brilliant Cycle & Hike. Loved Cape Point! Such dramatic scenery and beautiful ocean views. I've done an overnight hike here and a cycling day trip, both of which were awesome! It was peaceful and the flora and fauna really interesting. Looking forward to going again soon.
Breath taking. I highly recommend going to Cape Point. The scenery was amazing, the history was fabulous. Just make sure you go with a tour guide who knows the history.

Standing at the tip of Africa. The drive from Cape Town was easy and beautiful. Standing at the top of Africa was really special and memorable. The lighthouse is an easy walk from the parking area/gift shop.
Lovely place. The view is fantastic, just check befor u go if there is any national free charge day for the local people... The place is so full of people it's hard to move and get good pics...
A stunning day out. Stunning coastal views everywhere, Ostriches, penguins and a drive which left us gasping. What a wonderful place.

Beautiful views, lots of animals. Spend a delightful day touring the Cape. Saw multiple wildlife (some farmed, some wild) and had good weather. The coast is beautiful with blue seas and mountains. Enjoyed seeing the penguins in the wild.

Beautiful, Rugged Scenery. Plan a full day and leave the driving to someone else so you can enjoy the views on the way and snap photos of wildlife, beautiful beaches and rugged sea cliffs.. Sweeping views from the lighthouse and take a selfie at "The most south-western point of the African continent". Several tours stop at the Kistenbosch National Botanical Gardens on the return trip to Cape Town. Highly recommended.

Great views. Beautiful views around the cape - the scenery is not to be missed with Ocean views all around. Very windswept and rugged. Wrap up warm! We saw a few animals en route too - kudu and ostrich so there is something for all.
Beautiful spot. After going to the cape of good hope, we went up to cape point. Great views and a really good restaurant overlooking the Atlantic, Indian oceans.l

Phenomenal Views Loaded With History. Awesome views alone make this a worthwhile excursion. The tram to the top plus rock and concrete paths make this a friendly and easy trip to the top of the mountain and lighthouse. The small booth at the top of the hill provides more than enough information and history about Cape Point.
wow. After a childhood spent daydreaming about the Cape of Good Hope, finally a chance to visit this area. Scenic, windswept, all I dreamt about.
Must do. Simple drive from cape town and some beautiful scenery on the way to see the penguins and visit Cape Point.
Wonders of the world. Very big place to see South Africa's own floral Kingdom. Such diversity with such a windy reserve. Even saw Ostrich
Cape Point (2 Oceans). The long way up (Walking) is definitely worth it as well as the sore muscles the next morning!Beautiful ...

Worth the day trip. Don't miss this drive to the Cape as long as you have a good weather day. It is so scenic all along the sea to the Cape. Plan a whole day to see it from Cape Town, it takes longer than you think. You can do Boulders beach and the penguins on the way back. There is a 1+hr walk from one parking lot at the Cape to the other over the top with killer views and a gorgeous isolated sandy beach that you can walk down to . If you have a driver have them let you off at one side and pick you up later on the other side. Wear shoes with a good tread/grip.
Well worth the effort. It's a long drive but worth it for the fabulous view once you get there. And the restaurant serves an apple crisp to die for.

Loads to see. Beautiful scenery, lots of wildlife (just be a bit wary of the baboons)and well marked pathways. Restaurant food was excellent and the staff all very friendly and helpful. One of those places where you could go a dozen times and see something different each time. I love it.
Beautiful location at the tip of Africa. Travel that far, you have to see it. Trip down is also part of the experience. Just beautiful place.

Barren but beautiful. We enjoyed our visit to Cape Point and being able to climb up to the lighthouse and see the meeting of the Atlantic and Indian Oceans. The view was stunning, and we could almost see the ships struggling to get around it in the rough waters. It was hailing and very cold when we went, but it was still worth it. The ride in was very spacious and barren, and we would not want to get stuck out there alone! The down side was that the ride up on the funicular was one way, and we were not told that it was closing and that we would have no way back down! Fortunately, a van came to pick up the workers and they squeezed together to fit us in. Thanks again for that! Watch out for the baboons also, as they will try to grab whatever you have in your hands!
Gorgeous area. The nature reserve is characterized by such beautiful nature. Additionally the roads have quite a high standard, so there is no problem getting around.
Cape Point Tour. We did a private tour with Ellios travel, outstanding. Our guide knew all the places to go for great pics and views.
Breathtaking Views. Long walk but worth the view. Cable car up available. Watch out for baboons. The roaring surf up against the green mountains is spectacular.

Wild country.. Good day trip if you visit penguins at Boulders beach on route. Cape of good hope interesting visit. you pay to enter park and then again to go up furnicular to lighthouse. Busy at point but rest of area attractive.

Efficient and beautiful. This is such a beautiful part of our country. Truly stunning. For a family this would be a very expensive outing. SA Tourism should look at encouraging the locals to visit our beautiful heritage by offering cheaper rates. Everything is efficiently run and the staff are friendly. Sad about the graffiti at the view point. The flora is stunning. Just wish we could have gone a week later and we would have seen all the Protea's in full bloom.
Must see it. One of best places there .very nice to dtand and see the view of water and enjoy with weather there.u must go there.

Easy drive and great views. Drive yourself down to the Cape. The drive is quiet shortage and it enables you to stop and see a lot of interesting places along the way. Once there, wildlife is plentiful throughout the park. The crowing glory are the views from the Cape. Some great picture opportunities. Take the drive home through Simons Town for some great lunch or afternoon tea.

Amazing exprience!. Cannot be missed! It is amazing! I walked to the top of the moutain, admired the lighthouse and the grand sea. I experienced that I was at the edge of the world. It was very windy, the sea looked magnificant. At that moment, I had a picture in my mind, lots of people were transitted from here to America or Europe hundreds years ago. They might die in a marine perils, or went to a different world to face a different miserable destiny.
must visit in Cape town. everybody visiting cape town should visit.at the end of the reserve you get to the beach were pacific ocean and indian ocean meets.must visit placs,

A must visit!!. Great drive around and saw ostriches and their family literally just had the car window to separate us! They were so elegant and it was great observing them. The experience was just simply amazing.

What a place!. Lizards, ostriches, whales... but we didn't see any if the famous baboons. Penguins at Simonstown on the way down and the lovely walking and amazing views from the lighthouse make this a brilliant day's outing from Cape Town.

Good Hope. Cape of Good Hope it was once believed to be the dividing point between the Atlantic and Indian Oceans. The currents of the two oceans meet at the point where the warm-water Agulhas current meets the cold water Benguela current and turns back on itself.
Magnificent. The location is superb. The views are stunning. The reserve is very well maintained. We walked up to the light houses and the experience is just wonderful.
Lovely. It was busy, probably always is but I really liked it. Nice 15min walk up to the viewing platform with great views, don't go if it not a clear day.

Bottom end of Africa. Such a beautiful, wild place. Many flowers and animals big and small, as well as the lighthouses which have been and still are very necessary. Not for nothing is it called the Cape of Storms!

A day out. Lots to do and see if a nature lover. Nice beaches to relax on. Going up to the point allows you to take in beautiful views and scenery. Take something warm to wear, wind can get very cold. Restaurant a little on the expensive side as a local, but the food well worth it.

The tip of the iceberg (so to speak). As a visitor to our country or as a local.. this is a must see!The ocean seems to go on forever - pick a clear day and you will get the most incredible photo's to take home. You do need to have money on you - there is an entrance fee.. you will enjoy this visit but it can be a little expensive for large families/groups. There is plenty of parking and there are plenty of security persons around. Look out for baboons - don't feed them please!You have the option to walk up to the entrance or take the fenicular (which is a great experience and kids LOVE it).It can get intensely windy so expect a 'bad hair day' (lol). This is definitely worth the visit and for photographs - perfect!! There are amazing views, plants.. the lighthouse, the fenicular, the people all make for stunning photo's.For wheelchairs/strollers - there is access to a point as the fenicular will take you up where you can see the views but then there are stairs going all the way up to the lighthouse for an all-round view.

Cape Point. Views for ever, good but steep walking exercise. Classy restaurant with fantastic views over False Bay. But expensive to get in - worth buying a Wild card in advance of a visit as it gets you free entrance to the park I believe.

Beautiful place. It's well worth the visit here if you're in South Africa. The drive into the park goes over large plains then reaches the coast. You can either climb to the top of the hill (where the best view is seen) or take a cable car/mini train. We took the train, which was not full up at all and got us to the top quickly. The layout of the pathways at the top is done really nicely so to allow people to walk to different points on the edge of the cliffs and catch different views. The view itself is incredible and what's even better is you can see all round (360 degrees). There is also good for sale in a restraint which is cheap and tasty, but watch out for the birds there - one tried to take food right out of my hand haha...also, the baboons are mischievous (we saw two trying to open a car door), but not harmful as long as you're careful. It's a great place worth visiting - it would be a shame to miss this spot out.
baboons. Beautiful ride in and the view from all around. Lots of baboons and people getting to close to them for comfort. They are not teddies.
Where the Two Oceans meet. Excellent RestaurantRugged terrain and some wild life - baboons and ostrich.Excellent views from old lighthouse.Da Gama memorial spike.
A little taste of Africa. See babe where 2 oceans meet, mingle with the baboons, take a long walk in the reserve and enjoy nature at its finest
A must do. Top spot. Great views from the lighthouse. We took the funicular. Watch the baboons...can't eat outside....

Scenery Galore.... I read a review of someone saying there was a lack of scenery. I don't know if they were at the right place then :)We always make this a day trip and never get sick of it. As soon as you enter the gates you will see almost the entire False Bay on your left. You can see as far as Rooi Els on the other side of the False Bay. There are many animals too be seen here if you look closely and drive slowly.There are a few roads that leads to the ocean where you can have a picnic or relax. Buffels Bay being one of them.Drive all the way to the end where you will find the lighthouse and restaurant area. If you are on a self drive mission be sure to lock your car when you leave, the baboons are very clever and know how to open car doors ;)..you can either walk up to the lighthouse or take a tram. I prefer walking because I need the exercise. Many people just go to the lighthouse (the old white one at the very top) but never walk down the other side to the one lower down.If you are really lucky and stay a while you might see schools of dolphins swimming close to the coast line. Not too far from the lighthouse you will also find where the Indian and Atlantic Oceans meet. There are still people that believe Cape Point is the Southern most tip of Africa, which is not true. That will be Cape Agulhas.Be aware that the wind can really get out of hand here so always bring something warm just for in case. This really is a MUST SEE when visiting Cape Town.

Well worth the climb. The earlier you get there , the nearer you will be able to park! this was our second visit here and we thoroughly enjoyed our day. There is a restaurant snack bar near the car park with clean toilets. The climb to the top didn't take as long as predicted and we were soon walking out to the top viewing point to see where the two oceans met. There were plenty of opportunities to have Asti down on the way up, and the going under foot was easy. A thoroughly enjoyable trip from Capetown
360deg view. Lions head a favored place for launching paragliders into the sunset, has a magnificent 360 deg view of the city the ocean as well as the mountain. Don't miss out its worth the climb

Wonderful!!!. An absolute must!Road through Silvermine to get here from Cape town is really scenic as well.The park is great affording some bird, whale and game viewing as well as very nice views of the ocean. Try walking from cape of good hope to the lighthouse if you have the time. You will be walking on the edge of a cliff and meeting some wild ostriches. Very nice.Try driving back through Simon's town which is also a really scenic road.

Expensive for the Quality. I was disappointed in the lack of scenery and the number of tourists at this place. It is cool to be at the point of South Africa, but there really are many more beautiful places to explore in the country. The drive there was nice, and we did eventually find a beautiful, non-touristy beach, but over all, there are much prettier places that don't cost R100 to see!

WONDERFUL. You move by 200 meters and the coast changes. It is an amazing series of wonderful panoramas. I have never seen something so fascinating. You can also see lamas, whales, baboons and other animals. Wind can be amazing: be prepared but nonetheless GO!

Brillant trip to the point/nature reserve. Brilliant trip to the point/nature reserve. We walked up to the lighthouse and saw many birds. We enjoyed a nice picnic at the Cape of Good Hope and saw bontebok and ostrich.

Great reserve for viewing, hiking. Numerous spots to relax. Either close to the beach or high up on the cliffs looking down on the point. Quite a drive to get there from the city centre but worth the drive
Wonderful point of view!. This is a really beautiful area with several chances of trails to be hiked. It is wild and also full of random animals.

the most SW tip of Africa. some say "where two oceans meet' quite dramatic but then so is this beautiful place. Aproximately 90minutes drive from the city set aside at least half a day to explore the various paths and bays. Stunning views from the cliff top. It can be cool so take a jacket. Take the funicular up and walk down. Ther is a fast food and restaurant option both close fairly early so don't leave eating too late.
A must for any traveler. If you do visit, it is worth walkind to the actual cape, which is a bit of a hike but well worth it.

It was a joy to revisit this again. I was able to share this with my niece and it never fails to inspire! A very windy day but the us did shine but where oh where were the baboons? The views as ever are awe inspiring and we visited the lighthouse as well as the Cape of Good Hope, where we saw male and female ostrich. My niece loved the spectacular views. We also drove Chapmans Peak Drive, whic on my fourth visit to Cape Town was actually open.The drive along to Cape Point and back to Cape Town is a must for all.

Amazing!. Amazing cliffs go onto the Atlantic, meddling baboons and royal ostrich. This Park is really wonderful. Cape Point and Cape of Gode Hope have the best sigth. The first one has also restaurants and a cableway to reach easily the lighthouse.If you arrive from Cape Town, drive through the scenic Victoria Road on the Atlantic side and do not forget to visit the african penguins at Boulder's beach in Simon's Town.Just pay attention to closure time: to get late from a Park is a criminal act in South Africa, you may receive a written notice to appear in the Court of Simon's Town, pay 500 rand and become a criminal for all legal purposes.More info on sanparks.org/parks/table_mountain
Cape of Good Hope. Great to go to the extremities of any country, especially one you have studied as a child at school. A Funicular to take you to the lookout.

Fabled Meeting of Two Oceans. Spend the extra $50-$100 to hire a personal driver. We were able to choose what to see and how much time to devote to each area/attraction. Do bring SA currency because you'll have to pay to enter the reserve. We went in the winter month and was informed that in the summer tourists line up for hours in order to get into the reserve. We experienced up close view of animals, plants, and the sea. Do take the time to walk all the way to the point lighthouse and use the funicular to go up; then walk down.
Amazing View. IF your in Capetown you have to go to Cape Point it is breath taking and so amazing, a must see location if your visiting form over seas, but make sure its a clear sunny day.

Spectacular views of the ocean with the added bonus of baboons and ostriches. Plenty of opportunity to walk or drive. Watch out for those baboons. They try to get in your car and are aggressive. Trippy to see an ostrich grazing by the seashore!

Good exercise. But if your ears are sensitive to wind, make sure you take something to protect them-it's windy up there! Hurts the ears. It's a bit of a letdown once you get to the top, but if you enjoy exercise, the walk up to the top-and down-is well worth it. There's a road before you get to the Funicular that leads to a bird colony, try it. It's lovely!
rugby team tour. we traveled this on our coach then taking the vertical tram to the top. Beautiful to look at with a wide range of animals. Worth the visit

Well worth visiting. We visited Cape Point as part of a day trip from Cape Town and it was well worth it, the weather was lovely which definitely helped but scenery still would have been stunning anyway. Definitely worth visiting if you appreciate stunning scenery

History class comes to life. Portuguese explorer Bartholomew Dias was tasked to find a sea route to India from Europe. He was the first European explorer to round the cape and aptly called it the Cape of Storms. Now called the Cape Point or Cape of Good Hope its magical... History for real!

Worth the journey. This was definitely one of the highlights of our trip to South Africa. We made the Cape into a day's outing and were delighted that we did so. It was, however, incredibly windy that day so if you are quite light do take care when climbing up to the viewpoint so that you don't get blown off as there is very little to hang on to!! Our only bugbear was that, in comparison to many other things in South Africa, it was very expensive, having to pay to go onto the route, pay to go into the reserve and then pay some more to go up on the furnicular. Other than that, fantastic

Not where the Indian and Atlantic meet. Loved the walk, the scenery but the baboons were everywhere, so watch your belongins. They even climb onto the cars!
And this is not the point where the Indian and Atlantic oceans meet :(

Not much too see. Really quite tedious terrain, although the point itself is worth going to as it is relatively dramatic. Makes a nice day out from Cape Town with Chapman's Peak Drive and penguins as Simonstown.

gorgeous walk with wildlife. Loved this walk from the most south westerly point in Africa to the top. Beautiful walk up along coastline with gorgeous scenery and ostriches and baboons to see along the way. Not too difficult and a great short hike

A MUST!. Not only is this area historic and ruggedly beautiful, but also has some interesting wildlife. We saw eland, springbok, and (of course) babboons. You can take the smal rail car up to the top, and then walk from there, or walk all the way down toward the lighthouse. Fantastic scenery. Don't forget to go over to Cape of Good Hope - just a matter of minutes. It's the southwestern tip of Africa!
Nature in the rough. We spent a few hours here climbing to the light house and riding the funicular to the top. Saw quite a bit of wild life while having a nice lunch at the restaurant.

Don't miss. The drive around the Cape Peninsula is awesome and you are not let down when entering the Cape Point Nature Reserve. The crashing waves all around, the buck and baboons all add to a great experience. We were there during the height of winter and it was very busy so I should imagine that it could be quite unpleasant in the summer holiday period. As it was, we couldn't get into the restaurant so strongly recommend that if you want to eat there you should pre-book. The views all around are breathtaking and whether the seas meet there or not, it is a certainly a must on the visitor's list.

Awesome must visit. This is a magical place with stunning mountainous landscape and sea views mixed into one . I love visiting this pristine part of Cape Town . Its very rare to find this type of remoteness so close to a city. It has a veriety of wild life that adds to the experience. I highly recommend this national park

NATURE LOVER. We visited Aug 20014. Amazing views and lots of trails to walk. If you would like to just sit and enjoy nature there is plenty of quiet spots to do so. This is a day outing, pack your picnic basket and enjoy!!

Great way to spend a day in Cape Town. Highly recommended. And end the day with a mean in The Two Oceans, at the bottom of the cable car. The food was amazing and you get to shoot the birds that try steal your food with a water gun! It was fun!

Meeting of oceans. Wonderful views & scenery, didnt see any baboons but well worth a visit.A pleasant climb to the top, ( if your not very able there is a tram/train that takes you most of the way up.) The food @ the cafe was pretty good & very well priced. A very pleasant day out. If you have time there are also historic shipwrecks you can see.

Don't miss out!. Visited September 2011.
A wonderful part of Cape Town with just the most amazing views all around. I could literally sit and stare for hours and hours.
Various wildlife can be seen here at various times of the year and day. I saw ostriches, lots of naughty baboons (be careful!) and whales.
Cannot wait to return next year!

Awesome experience!. Beautiful nature! I have seen a lot of animals, driving with our own car. It is a big park, so you should go there early.
You should also visit the Ostrich Farm, which is only 2 minutes away from Cape Point!
Wow. We just couldn't believe where we were The Cape of Good Hope was amazing. The waves crashing to shore were breathtaking. Loved seeing ostrich, antelope, and baboons. Really neat.

The Most Southern Point In South Africa. Definitely worth a trip to see the spectacular views from this point. The animals in the area are so much fn to see and photograph; the baboons and ostriches were so great to watch. The shoreline is very picturesque.
Wild and Beautiful. We saw some lovely antelope and the whole park is wild and beautiful. Amazing scenery. Visit the lighthouse and have enough time to go to Cape of Good Hope too.
Blustery visit. Great visit. Winter and teaming down with rain and blowing a gale but still great. So enjoyed it. It was busy enough can't imagine what it's like in summer.
I can't believe I waited so long to see such beauty!. Born and raised in Cape Town I had never been to Cape Point, but I have to say it was worth the wait. One worn.... Breathtaking!

bit blowy!. Amazing place to visit, incredible drive there, must-see experience. You can park near to the point, and it's not a hard stroll up to the top. Great scenery for photographs from the lighthouse, although the view from the nearby cove is probably better for capturing the ferocity of the confluence of 2 oceans.

Great day trip from Capetown. We rented a car to explore the surrounding areas of Capetown. This is an easy day drive around the peninsula. Before entering that national park, we stopped along the way at Boulder's Beach to check out the Jackass Penguins-hundreds of them! You pass through Simon's Town-which is quite small and quaint. http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/03/16/penguins-penguins-penguin_n_4912079.htmlWe then continued on to Capepoint where you can walk up LOTS of stairs or take a tram up to the lighthouse for epic views. We circled back stopping at Capepoint Vineyards in Noordhoek-the view and the cheese plate are incredible!That put us on Chapman's Peak Drive which was just stunning-you can see why it is used so often in car commercials. You then hit Hout Bay and head into Capetown. Capetown was much smaller than we anticipated so this was a great day trip.
Breathtaking!. Gorgeous sights! We were with a private tour guide so we were able to weave quickly around to the great spots to see the south western most point in Africa.

Really Nice. This place is really nicely presented. There is an excellent train to the top where the lighthouse is which is doable for anyone minimally in shape. The light house has pretty views and the people going up are very friendly. The facilities there are also well taken care of and the gift shop is worth a peak and fairly priced for a tourist shop. Food is also available

Beautiful Setting, no baboons..!. Definitely worth the trip out for the views and scenery. Steep climb to the lighthouse if on foot. No baboons there, but saw plenty on the way home to Cape Town by the side of the roads.
Loved it!. A must do trip! Don't miss the light house and cape of good hope. Take in the views as you get there, we saw whales and ostriches along the way!
Come on...You gotta do this!. Visiting the Cape area without going to the Point would be a crime. Our family of 19 thoroughly enjoyed the experience, and you will too. Don't miss it. Enough said.

Breathtaking area - best to go with a guide if unfamiliar with road. Spent around 3 - 4 hours in this area (including lunch). The view is just. so. breathtaking. And it keeps getting better the higher you go! Just when you think it can't get any better, it does!!!! Cape of Good Hope itself isn't suitable for older people or those with trouble climbing stairs. Although there is a cable car service that takes you up, nothing beats walking up those steps and looking at the view. Very crowded at all times.Cape point itself is less remarkable, but for the braver ones there's a cliff you could climb up to via some steep stairs to get a tourist pic :)During winter the flora and fauna is limited. But we did encounter alpacas, springbucks, ostriches and a few very endagered African oystercatchers! Definitely worth a visit :)

Its good but not exquisite views like Table Mountain.. I find the Table mountain better than Cape Point and Cape of Good hope.I had studied in in school about these two so I did not want to miss these both attractions.Though this is 2-3 hrs drive from Cape town towards Simon town. But it take half of the day to go and come back.Well as it is said main attractions should not be missed when you go on outdoor so we did visit here but when I see the GoogleMaps makes me feel good that I was at the tip and at the end point of Africa Continent.
Scenic, powerful, great views. Fantastic light, sea views. Accessible. Popular place but seems to be able to absorb the masses. Didn't feel overwhelmed by the others.
Really enjoyable. Loved the scenery and wildlife. Even with Baboon poop thrown at the car and lots of rain it was a great day out.

awestruck !. no words to express how beautiful the world around looks from top the cape point. Amazingly beautiful ! very good camera,good walking shoes,warm clothes,no loose clothes are must.we took the flying-dutchman-funicular to reach Cape Point Light house. Breathtaking views awaiting on top so hurry... a must must visit in lifetime !
Superb. So glad we made the drive down to Cape Point. It's an amazing spot on earth. Gorgeous scenery, spectacular sea views and of course the Cape of Good Hope.

Don't miss the Shipwreck Trail. Obviously, the main attraction at the reserve is the Cape Point Lighthouse and Cape of Good Hope. This is noticeable by the crowds of people at these locations. However, make sure you also include a visit to the Shipwreck Trail on a visit to the reserve. This is off the beaten path and well worth the visit. Take a scenic hike along the beach (1.5 hr return) from OlifantBos and you will see some amazing shipwrecks on the beach. Very scenic and surreal.
Windy but wonderful. Great natural beauty, even though the gift inevitable shop has to rear it's ugly head. Take the short downhill hike to the Cape of Good Hope- you might see a rock dossie!

A great escape from the city!. The drive to the Reserve is lovely and the park itself is breath taking. Make sure that you have enough time to really explore the area. This is a place to slow down and relax!

Unforgettable views. Views from the lighthouse, the drama of high seas, a profusion of sunbirds, cormorants and Cape seals make this a don't miss location, where hiking in good weather as opposed to our heavily overcast day must be a joy.Agree entirely with other reviewers about the high quality of the restaurant at the base of the lighthouse, but describe the pathetic cable car to the top in a review of Table Mountain National Park.

A must for every visitor to Cape Town. The Cape Point Natural Reserve should be on every visitor's itinerary...yes, it is touristy, but not overly crowded. The natural surroundings are stunning and well worth the travel, preferably with a rented car.

Cape Point - the point of two oceans - Atlantic & Indian. the view is spectacular, awesome that the point can be so specific. The buffeting of the two oceans is memorable. Sense of freedom, and history, and ships that must have passed this way.... the sea breeze is refreshing. A must go, a must do... though arm yourself with hat, sunglasses, block out, water bottle, walking shoes.

nice morning out. If you looking for a good day out and good food and beautiful nature!?!! Then Cape Point is for you. my favorite restaurant in Cape Town is located in the reserve. life just couldn't be sweeter with some beautiful paths to walk on. my mum is in a wheel chair and even she gets the chance to feel apart of the group at cape point. having gone with children i would do CP all day as they tend not to enjoy the go slow feel. a must do in CPT!
Wonderful vistas!. Wonderful views. Saw a herd of eland grazing. Wish I had had the 1-1/2 hrs to hike all the way out to the point.

Excellent experience!. Despite the rain we decided to drive to the nature reserve and visit Cape Point and The Cape of Good Hope. We were not disappointed. The views were spectacular. The immense power of the two oceans as they meet is testament to the bravery of the sea farers of times gone past. Beware of the baboons! We actually witnessed a huge baboon climb into an open door of a vehicle and steal a bag of food! Awesome!

Spectacular. I had come earlier in the week on a guided bus tour while my husband was at a conference and knew he couldn't leave Cape Town without seeing the area so we took a long detour to Cape Point on our way from Cape Town to Hermanus. While the weather wasn't as good as the day of the bus tour it was still spectacular - maybe more so as the ocean was quite wild. We managed our timing fairly well to go down to the actual Cape of Good Hope and up to the lighthouse without getting too wet. Saw lots of baboons - some stealing people's lunch bags (not a good thing for the baboons). We had lunch at the restaurant and it was very good. I would recommend going on a guided tour as you will get more information and enlightenment than driving down on your own.

gorgeous. A trip to Cape Point is not to be missed. I went with Daytrippers. Penguins on the beach, animals in the reserve, hiking on the rocks on Cape Point, a visit to the lighthouse. All worth it. The view and the ocean are just stunning.
A meeting at the crossroads. Spectacular views...A must photo op. You will always cherish this experience. Take the walk to the top to marvel at the views

Good but not priced for locals. We did a complete drive around and walked up to the lighthouse and also to the other point near the new lighthouse. Great trip and worth it for scenery.We did find it expensive though - probably OK if paying in dollars but the food was all completely overpriced for locals as was the tram up to the lighthouse. Oh well, at least it made sure I walked and got some exercise as I wasn't paying that for 4 of us!

Must see. Great drive to the Point, it is not too expensive to get a ticket to the nature reserve about 100 Rand, but worth it. Take the people mover to the top where the light house is and enjpoy the views. Good restaurant there as well. Be on the lookout for baboons.

Beautiful Views and a great restaurant for lunch. The drive to Cape Point was beautiful. Had lunch at the park service restaurant concession which has a lovely view. We had the seared tuna salad and the prawn salad. Delicious.

Don't go without visiting. Take a day tour to this area because it is truly spectacular in its wild beauty, the colours and textures of the mountains and sea are just wonderful. As a bonus, you can spot orang-utans in the middle of the road, free ostriches and many other local birds. Cape Point and the lighthouse area is a touristy place and full of people. That doesn't rest beauty to the place, which is stunning in its rusticity and wilderness, or makes the colours of the rocks, vegetation and the ocean less stunning, or shuts down the sound of the ocean battering against the rocks. The way the area has been transformed to allow visitors to enjoy the surrounding area is remarkable, with plenty of curvaceous stony balconies and stairs that follow the natural shape of the mountain and allow you to have amazing views of almost every corner. The ascend and/or descend to the lighthouse can be done by foot (which is what I recommend), and takes about 10-15 minutes, or by the on-site funicular, which comes handy if you have little time or some mobility problems.The lighthouse itself is a historical piece with some informative panels around. The views from the top are spectacular. The whole wall at the lookout area is covered by graffiti! and the place is full of people wanting to take photos of themselves and pushing other people out to take their photos. I never like that, but the views are just stunning. If you drive, get there early morning, because it is mayhem at around midday, when most tour operators get there. There are two food places, a fast food one, and a normal restaurant. I tried the first and it was nothing remarkable, but the food came out quickly and it was fuel for my stomach.The funicular costs 40 Rands one way. If you are short of time, take the funicular to go up and come down by foot. MINDMind the orang-utans, they are wild and can be aggressive if you are carrying food. Have your food before starting the ascend to the lighthouse. Some of the blackbirds around (from the crow family) can be also annoying if they see you eating outside.
Beautiful!. Beautiful scenery, could stand and stare out to sea all day. Worth a visit. Lots of tourists but for me this didn't take away from the experience.
breath-taking. I once stood at the point where two oceans meet. the view is just incredible and you should definitely visit here AT LEAST once in a life time.

Overcrowded place. Even though the site and views are beautiful, there are dozens of buses and cars unloading tourists from all over the world. The tip of Africa is swamped with people making it hard to find a quiet spot and, in some locations, even to access the view.

Simply amazing,. I had the opportunity to go to this amazing place, is one of the most beautiful places I had the chance to go. Is just 1 hour and 30 minutes from Cape Town. Do not miss this chance. (The fare is 60dls, including the tour to a penguins reserve)

Too little time. Been promising to go to Cape Point for a long time. Always said later. Now we've been, was so much to see and absorb. Was made even more special by the revelation from our friend, who accompanied us, that his grand-father was one of the lighthouse keepers, in fact the second lighthouse keeper there!!We had a fantastic meal at the two Oceans restaurant, which capped off a great day out.Next trip to Cape Town - one full day in the park - booked!!
Amazing.. To be at the edge of Africa, where to oceans meet was an amazing experience. Beware of babbons and wind. All the rest is worth enjoying.

Awesome Wonder. You need to take the time and visit the end of the African continent. Ride the funicular to the top to see some of the Mose spectacular views. If you have the time, walk to the very end of Cape point...about 1.5 hours round trip. Dress with many layers and gloves. Prepare for rain at any time as the weather changes quickly.,don't set anything down for a moment as baboons will steal it away. They also know how to open unlocked car doors.

the end of the world... What better to do on a crystal clear day, than drive down the east side of the Cape along False Bay and through all the seaside towns to Cape Point; then take the fenicular up and finish walking to the lighthouse at the top. Come down the stairs and grab a take away lunch from the restaurant and start back to the Cape of Good Hope along the beaches on the western side and have a picnic lunch. Be careful not to go where there are baboons.
Amazing experience. A beautiful scenic drive along the coast will take you to this amazing Nature Reserve, This is a must for every visitor to South Africa.
Always a treat. Visiting Cape Point is always a great experience, no matter how many times you go! Well done to National Parks Board for keeping it in such a great shape!

Take a tour group. We booked a tour in a small bus holding about 8-10 people with a bike trailer in tow. We stopped at various places including seeing the Penguins in Simontown. We biked in the Cape Point Nature Reserve. I think our tour was with Point Four. Rick and Bianca were great guides.
Amazing Scenery. Absolutely beautiful scenery. The wind was whipping all around us even though the weather was quite warm. Seals, Penquins, and Monkies, what more could you ask for?
We saw a few animals. We enjoyed the views of the Cape Horn. We loved getting to see some animals in their natural habitat. It was very windy while there.

Beautiful Park!. We travelled here on a private tour with my husband and my parents. We saw so much wildlife (ostrich, zebra, baboons, etc.) as well as incredible views. Very nice area and well worth visiting.
Worth a stop. The most south point of Africa. Beautiful nature . Great views. You can climb all the way up to observation or use the cable card(about $5). Recommend to visit.

Wild animals, awesome views. We had a tour bus take us, so if you only have less than an hour, take the cable car, because the walk up to the lighthouse is brutal. But the views from there are spectacular! You can see where the two oceans meet. The surf is incredible just to look at, alone. On the way out, we saw ostriches grazing with the high Atlantic surf in the background. We saw elands and other antelope. Even in the dead of winter, it's not cold. Cool, but not cold. Well worth the long drive.

a day trip to remember. this park is well kept and hardly visited because everybody ride to get to the lighthouse and cable cart .so do u want a park to yourself...come here. 4 routs takes u to different private beach .i did not see a lot of wildlife here but a great number of birds

A must see if staying in Cape Town. This is my second visit and the first for my wife. I visited about 4 years ago while on a business trip and liked Cape Town and the Cape Point area that I wanted to bring my wife back to enjoy the fantastic scenery. We had a hire car and visited Fish Hoek on the way and the Cape of Good Hope and Simons Town on our return. A wonderful day with some stunning scenery.

Frequent visitor. I visit the nature reserve as often as i can (Wild card holder) and each time I enjoy the wide open spaces that allows the mind a chance to let go of city life. This is great getaway right in our city!

A Cape Town Must See. Stunning scenery and a mandatory stop if you are in the Cape Town area. Cape Point itself is incredibly beautiful with excellent views of the Atlantic and False Bay coasts. Don't overlook the amazing biodiversity. If this is your first time in the fynbos you'll be surprised at how rich a habitat it is when you look (and smell) up close. Give yourself lots of time and look around other parts of the reserve, not just Cape Point.

A lovely day-trip. This is a great day trip from Cape Town - combining a nice drive and some lovely topography before ending at the Cape Point Lighthouse for photo-shoot and views. Then a small detour to teh Cape of Good Hope. Must stop-over at the Simon's Town for that old world charm and sea-food.
Beautiful!!. Panoramic views. Witness the majesty of the ocean. Crowded at holiday times. You can either walk or take the tram to the top. Food available before you go up.

Down to the bottom of the world. A windswept and cold place, but a visit to Cape Town would be incomplete without a visit. Very limited food outlets; basically choice of a stylish restaurant or takeaway pizza.

Gorgeous!. First of all, getting to Cape Point is a joy, with scenic views, vineyards, and quaint towns en route. The Point itself has numerous seaside hikes, expansive views of the Atlantic and Indian Oceans, and tons of baboons. Great seacoast restaurants, too.

Stunning scenery. But too many tourists taking endless photos - move on and let other people have the opportunity. The reserve is also a great place consider trekking and The route up from Cape Town is spectacular
A great day trip from Cape Town. I love it - as always! Great landscape and a visit to the tow ocean restaurant with view over False Bay is always a treat.

ok...... Pleasant enough place but touristy as you would expect. We had a hire car and there are lots of touch buses here. Nice walk to the summit and some nice views. Watch for the baboons....oh and the ostriches as you drive in
Amazing views. This is a super spot to check out if your in Cape Town for a week or so. If its a clear day you will see some amazing views. Be careful of the wind and baboons.

Majestic. What a place to see the Oceans meet, marvel at the local wildlife and sheer beauty that the Fairest Cape has to offer.
Great walks of all levels and certainly a top tourist attraction.

Wonderful Place!. The nature preserve is just gorgeous, and the diversity of the plant life is amazing. While we were driving through we saw two groups of Elands. Our destination was the Cape Point Lighthouse. We rode the tram up as far as it went, and then got plenty of exercise walking the steps to get up to the lighthouse. There are also several really nice-looking trails to walk, all of which have spectacular views. There is a nice gift shop up there, as well. I would love to be able to spend time exploring the paths around the lighthouse and just checking out the plant life in the park. The area around the lighthouse is not for people who are seriously afraid of heights or who are mobility impaired. Oh, did I mention that the views are absolutely spectacular? Well worth a visit.

Beautiful beautiful beautiful!. Look carefully for the ostriches and baboons which are aplenty in this very unique nature reserve I like tseeing the baboons eating seeds in the middle-of-the-road, right after noting the sign that says don't feed the baboons
Very pretty but very pricey. We enjoyed our drive around and walked up all the stiars. It was a lovely day out, but we felt it was very pricey.

Where Two Oceans meet. Growing up I was told that this is the place where the two oceans, Indian and Atlantic meet - must admit could not see that from the shore where I was standing, but was told by guides that you can when you are on a boat ..... Pity would have loved to see that for myself. Great look out point, the park also has some wild life, fauna and flora - must see when visiting Cape Town

Astonishing. Cape Point is, without exaggeration, one of the most naturally beautiful places I've ever seen. I recommend taking your own car there instead of opting for a tourist bus experience. Part of the joy is being able to drive the smaller roads-less-travelled within the nature reserve and arriving at amazing beaches, coves and viewpoints all along the way. Some incredible sights and photograph opportunities, and just astonishing natural scenery.We've driven along California's Pacific Route One, and as much as I enjoyed it, dare I say that I found the drive to (and through) Cape Point Nature Reserve to be superior.It is a must-see sight for tourists and residents of Cape Town, and I cannot recommend it highly enough.

Remarkablely beautiful. . After doing a safari, wine tour, table mountain, helicopter ride etc Which were the main elements to our tour of South Africa, we slotted in trip to Cape point and the nature reserve. We all thoroughly enjoyed our visit here, it was probably one of the most enjoyable days of our trip. It was a great drive through the reserve spotting baboons and antelope. Then the views from the top of Cape point were amazing.Driving down and to the beaches of the peninsula you get even more beautiful views of rugged rocks with waves splashing. Its a stunning place, and one to take your time exploring.

So much, so little time. If you love nature and walking, come here!There are so many hiking routes, ship wrecks and off course the Cape of Good Hope as well. Really love this spot, it is a bit pricey, but pack a picnic or have something at the Buffelsfontein visitor center (call in advance) or there is always the Food Shop and Two Oceans Restaurant at Cape Point itself. Enjoy the views and remember the sunscreen, water and comfortable shoes!

Just Amazing. A beautiful and scenic drive up to the Point. Saw some baboons on the way. Always quite a climb up to the actual point, but well worth it. The lighthouse is still well maintained, for some good photographs. It always amazes us as to how clear the meeting of the Indian Ocean and Atlantic Oceans is. Another one of nature's wonders. It is well worth the drive and the walk.

Perfect day out into nature. This nature reserve boasts some of the most beautiful plant life on earth. The abundant Protea trees and Fynbos is a delight it behold. Add to that the backdrop of the Atlantic Ocean with the dramatic views and you have the perfect opportunity for a hike/picnic combo. The park is pristine and quiet with abundant birdlife for those looking carefully. The sunbirds are especially beautiful and look out for ostriches and tortoises! Make time for a hike. There are short easy hikes as well as slightly longer hikes of about three hours. They will reward you with the most breathtaking views you can imagine, and will allow you to feel a very special connection with nature. More often than not you will be completely alone with no other hikers present. As it is a national park with restricted entry, it is perfectly safe to wander all over enjoying the views and the vegetation. Please remember to take water and refreshments and remember to leave only your footprints when you go.

Penguins in South Africa. This was pretty cool to see the penguins on the guarded beach area and watch them so closely. It was pretty interesting to see how they interact with their mates and how guarded they are on the eggs that are close to hatching.

A real treat. One of Cape Town's hidden gems I believe. A true wildlife experience thats as natural as you can find. Probably still the same as it was 300 years ago. Getting around in the park is a pleasure with good signage. But do stop often and walk around. Take the walk down to Diaz strand, which is to enjoy.

Beautiful Cape of Good Hope. Stunning vies from the view site at top of hill. Take the Flying Dutchman funicular to the top or walk up the steep hill. It is worth the effort to get to the top.Lots of other beaches and picnic areas in the reserve to explore

Where to 2 Oceans meet ...... I have mixed feelings about this venue. Some might say it's just because the wind swept me off my feet. Or that the discontent which we experienced with both the tram and restaurant staff might have affected my outlook. Nevertheless, it's beautiful. Probably more so in the head than in reality (the thought of knowing that you're at the point where 2 might oceans meet is quite appealing). Go early. This is another one of those Cape Town "must do's" that's HORRENDOUS if the tourist busses come flooding in!!!
wonderful sights to cherish. again, I was there in 08, but I have great memories of this place. Nice little resturant too.amazing to see baboons running with their babies.

get your camera ready for a great view.. a point where the Atlantic and the Indian oceans meet, the nature of every thing there is spectacular. the colour of the water, the rocks, the trees and plants, all merge together forming a view that you will never forget all your life. although you have to wait for some time for the funicular, but getting there is an experience that you should Not miss.

Truly Spectacular!. Beautiful scenery and interesting trails to follow. This is the spot where two oceans meet. We rode the funicular up, then it broke down and we had to walk back down to the bottom. Be forewarned as it apparently happens a lot. On the plus side, they refunded our tickets.;-)
Be sure to include this stop!
Nice spot. Even if it is not the most Southern spot nor the point where to oceans meet it is quite spectacular! Recomended in a tour with a guide.

Beautiful. Nicely kept with a nice walking trail to the actual tips of both cape point and cape of good hope. Just beware this is NOT the southernmost point of the African continent, that is in Cape Agulhas. Loads of tourists mistakenly think this is the southernmost point and push and shove to take a picture at a sign that clearly indicates 'South-Western Point'.

Where two oceans meet. What an amazing place. The beaches we visited were pristine and picnic areas clean. We rode up to the lighthouse and all the staff were courteous. All the toilets were clean and as always an amazing place to visit.

amazing. Just beautiful. The ocean is hammering away at the rocks you really feel you are almost at the end of the world, really stunning. You can stay close to the car or walk around and climb up the hill.

The southest side of the world. you will face with an amazing wind there. You climb by cable car to the hill and see the two ocean are meeting there. You will see this natural beauty and absolutely admire.

Lovely place. A very nice and lovely place of Cape Town area.Fortunately I saw 2 baboons and 4 zebras when I visited there. I'd like to appreciate South Africa's nature and protection plan. Cape Point nature Reserve is must see place in Cape Town.It's definitely lovely place.
#LoveCapeTown. Always a pleasure to visit with it's breathtaking views and scenery! A must to walk or take the funicular up to take in views and people watch♡

Wish I could stay longer. On my Cape Town day tour we where just driving through this area to get to the Cape Point. I wish we had more time to enjoy the reserve more and to be able to see some animals. The place is beautiful and is definitly worth a visit and not just a drive through.

Truly beautiful. A very peaceful place just to drive through. We could see many diff. kind of animals as well which was making the whole experience even more nice. The mountain looked fantastic and majestic.
Nice walk. Walked up to the lighthouse and out to the point...little jaunt but worth the view! Very busy with tour buses but still plenty of room.

Not the Southern most tip of Africa, but you will think you are there!. This is an absolute must! The drive out there is an adventure on itself, but then taking the funicular (or for the more fit ones amongst us!) to walk all the way up to the lighthouse - absolutely magnificent! Breathtaking views!

Get out of your car and walk. You cannot visit Cape Town and NOT go to Cape Point. If you're short of time or lack the brainpower to plan/ think for yourself, a bus tour from the city would probably suffice, but you really are just limiting yourself to the lighthouse viewpoint, the Cape of Good Hope sign photo and a tour of the gift shop. Having said that, the bus tours are popular and there are LOTS AND LOTS AND LOTS of buses at the lighthouse carpark.The walk up to the lighthouse is beautiful (but steep) and the scenery is stunning. If you're short of time or unable to manage the walk, the funicular is really good and wasnt expensive at all. Whilst up at the (old) lighthouse, it's worth doing the walk to the lower (new) lighthouse - it never takes the 1 hour 30 minutes stated on the sign. Absolutely stunning views down the sheer cliffs. About 20 minutes gets you to the end of the path and having had time for plenty photos along the way. Lots of black agama lizards lying in the sun.In the past few years we've usually seen a few eland grazing in the fynbos near the toilets / lighthouse carpark. The bigger herd of eland is a bit skittish and people-shy.Platboom beach is our favourite. White sands and turquoise water. Bontebok and ostrich usually found there. We've also seen rhebok there, and have been mugged by baboons when one of the party was carrying his sandwich in open view (our own fault, really). The walk to the Thomas T Tucker wreck from Olifantsbos is stunning late afternoon, with fynbos on one side and crashing waves on the other. Not a lot of the wreck left these days. More recently we've done bits of the Sirkelvlei walk from the same carpark and you get some really good views back up the Atlantic coastline.We've seen puffadders twice and hartebees once. Still keep hoping to finally see the zebras, but no such luck in 10 years of regular visits.This is nature at its finest, and we love being out amongst it, taking it slow. Usually we do Cape Point as a half day, combined with a half day at Simons Town and Kalk Bay etc. Sometimes we make a full day of it.If you see people doing illegal things (like loading tortoises into cars), please make a note of their car reg and let the staff at the HQ know - they really do act promptly if they have something to go on.
Must see. A Beautiful, large peaful reserve with Cape Point in.Make sure you go to cape point it self. There you will see some amazing rocks and waves as well.
Walks and scenery. The scale of the park seems huge so near CT and so tranquil - a little difficult to find the walk we wanted to do, but lovely anyway. Find the tidal pool for a dip on a hot day!
mustdo. beautiful scenery in the park, nice hike (also cable available), really worth seeing, can be a bit crowded, many tourists, but still, a must do

HOLY VIEWS!!!. Breath taking views all around!!!! A must visit!! Can't say enough about the views. Water is blue. Wish there was someone or something to help figure out where the two oceans meet, like actually pin point the area b/c it could have been anywhere. Wish we had more time to hike the trails. Did I mention the views were great?!?! The drive to Cape Point had some amazing scenery/views too. I would definitely go there again.

Living history. As a Brazilian you study the portuguese expeditions many times and the Cape of Good Hope is part o many of these expeditions. Being there is an amazing experience. Good infrastructure, well managed park. Must see in CPT.
Stunning Views. A must for every traveller to Cape Town. You feel like you are on the end of the earth with views of two oceans coming together - awsome.

worth a visit for lovely scenery and a few wildlife sightings. There are long queues to get in if you do not arrive early so be sure to get there early in the morning. The roads in the reserve are well maintained and there are some good sightings of wildlife (not the big 5). Also some lovely beaches to sit on (not swim).
Cape Point. Nothing to dislike and another extremely enjoyable visit to yet another spectacular part of the Cape. Our guide was outstanding in every respect on this tour.
Not to be missed. If you go to Cape Town you have to make time to make it down to the Cape of Good Hope. The scenery is spectacular and there is a nice restaurant and gift shop.

End of the earth. When you stand right at the southern tip of the peninsula you will rightly feel like you are standing at the end of the earth. It is a great day out and a breathtaking view over the place where two oceans meet.It has a funicular if you do not feel energetic enough for the walk up the steep steps. It caters for wheelchairs.The gift shop is well-stocked and the restaurant on site will help you replace the lost energy. This is a must visit for any tourist as you will go a long way to see a more beautiful or spectacular site.
Watch out for the baboons. Baboons roam everywhere on Cape Point. Best to be in a vehicle. The view from Cape Point is breathtaking.
Worth the visit. This is such a beautiful area with spectacular views.We saw some interesting birds and a couple of lizards as well as the baboons. We enjoyed every minute.
