Simply beautiful. This is a perfect spot. Loved the funicular, really loved the views, all of which were worth the effort. Watching an amazing turquoise sea pound the rocks, perfect. Although there were a lot of people there it was still easy to find a place away from everyone to simply look and enjoy the views. Roads to get here and signposting was excellent too.
Fantastic. You can tell your friends you have reached the most southern point, you can take a cable car or walk, I walked up, fantastic views, fantastic place, there is a car park, café and shop.

One of many boxes to be ticked in South Africa. It may be a box that has to be ticked, but it's a biggie! The drive into the park is scenic and gets better the closer one gets to the southern tip, and we saw baboons and eland close to the road - our first sight of 'game' in Africa! The park has well marked walks and trails as well as the usual souvenir shops and cafés, and the funicular takes all of the strain out of climbing up to the lighthouse at the Point itself. The views from the lighthouse platform are spectacular and you just have to go on down to the sign at the Cape of Good Hope for THAT holiday photo! More time here would have been nice for strolling and relaxing, but there were so many more boxes yet to be ticked...

Cape Point the Name tells it all..A must see in Capetown. This place cape point is where 2 oceans merge and this is excellent and had an amazing walk tot the tip of Light house and we can get to see Superb views of Cliff rocks and stunning views of the beaches. Definite spot to see when around in Capetown.

Something different. Quite a spectacular drive, but make sure you take a picnic basket and bring some comfortable shoes to make it worth your while. A jacket is also a good idea as most days of the year have a fair amount of wind. Consider renting a bicycle or doing one of the hiking trails that offer over-night facilities.

Full Day Cape tour including Cape Point and Cape of Good Hope.. This was a full day tour for me arranged through Viator.com. It left Cape Town in the early a.m. Drove down the west coast with beautiful sights of land and sea. The Cape Point reserve and Cape of Good Hope were beautiful and our group of 10 stopped to walk and climb to see the sights. Our driver stopped along the road at a beautiful park to use restrooms and see the views. We took a boat to see the seals (an extra fee trip). Though I've seen lots of seals in Oregon these are a different kind and was an interesting side venture. We had lunch at a lovely restaurant with many choices. Then on to see African Penguins at Boulder's Beach. Our last stop was Kirstenbock Gardens which, though not heavily in flower at this time, was beautiful, relaxing and fascinating for those of us interested in plants. This full day trip was well worth it. While the guide provided some interesting insights I found his demeanor to be a bit short and opinionated. I wish he'd shared more history as we went along.

You sort of have to go. It is dramatic once you get there. A fee for the entrance and another for the funicular. As in international traveller, you have to be going to quite a few SANparks to make it worth buying a wild card, but the fees do add up but not enough to buy a card. I did work it out roughly before we left home.The funicular is quick and regular, it was working fine when we were there. Every 3 minutes. If your time is limited its definitely worth it. There are still quite a few steps to climb to get to the lighthouse and it can be a bit crowded up there. The view is great and the ocean crashing below is spectacular. The park it self was a little disappointing as no wildlife was spotted but a lovely drive. Getting there was a nice day, out but mainly for the other sights on the way there and back.The restaurant is on the entrance level not at the top, very good food, very busy, service flaky.

Make a day of it at Cape Point Nature Reserve. Great for the whole family. Maps are useful and well detailed. Pack a picnic as the restaurants are full of tourists who arrive in bus loads. Take the funicular up and walk to the cliff edge for stunning photos if you're fit enough. Lots of historical monuments, so educational as well.

Ulungeletours tours. Hank and his wife Carmelita,owners of Ulungeletours did a wonderful job with airport transfers, driving me to and from locations in Capetown, and taking me on a private tour to Cape point and the Cape of Good hope. They were reliably on time, always kept in touch and always had a pristine vehicle. Hank provided great tips on driving in SA, was always friendly yet professional, and provided positive suggestions that made me comfortable to explore the city on my own. I would definitely recommend Ulungeletours to any woman travelling on her own to the Capetown area.
Endless Nature Reserve. A must visit after the Cape Point outing. There plenty of Ostriches, Zebras and antelope to be seen. Of-course the endless ocean as you are driving through the Reserve.

The edge of beautiful. Just the idea of standing on the edge of Africa was amazing. What more when the 2 oceans are in front of you? Well, almost the 2 oceans but not quite. Breathtaking views of the seascape, waves crashing into the cliffs. Naturally beautiful.

You can't come all this way and not go to Cape Point. It was more expensive to get in than I expected - 105 Rand each. We parked at Cape Point and walked up to the lighthouse (even if we had wanted to take the funicular we wouldn't have been able to as it was broken - this was a real problem for elderly people and those in wheelchairs - not sure how they managed the steps).We also visited the Cape of Good Hope and spotted baboons, ostriches and some sort of antelope. Most visitors did exactly what we did so there were always crowds of people wherever we went, however, the park is enormous and it would be easy to get away from people if that is what you want.

A must see!. When visiting Cape Town this nature reserve is a must see. Beautiful, accessible and free if you have a WILD card it is a great place to mountain bike, have a braai at one of the designated picnic spots and explore the chilly but spectacular beaches.

Beautiful place. Whilst there are many visitors to this site, it never feels crowded. The sea view is awesome, I beleive that that the restaurant is excellent too (reccomended by the family at our accomodation)

Disapointing!. We expected much more than what we found...!Althoug its nice , we found so many places much more outstanding along the drive by the coast to Cape Town...!For us it was not worth visiting it and considering this , the entrance fee was expensive...

Another visit, another great experience. Revisited after a few years and the drive down was as interesting, spotted some baboons and cape zebra in the distance. Although we know that this is not the actual place where the two mighty oceans meet, it is, nonetheless, a fantastic vista.
Must see!. A beautiful wild( and very windy!) place. Make sure you climb or take the funicular to the lighthouse. The view is exceptional!! Spend a few hours and walk the various trails.

Spectacular. A fantastic experience. The views are fantastic and a camera is essential. If you are fit and have the time walk out to the point it is amazing. The car park and the view point around the Light House seem to be infested with Baboons, which will steal anything you are not hanging onto (especially bags) and getting them back is impossible.

This is THE highlight of the Cape Peninsula. The Cape Point area of the Table Mountain National Park is so much more than just the Cape of Good Hope and its lighthouses - although, they are great too.Firstly, this is a national park, so wild-life and landscape are some of the main attractions here. And to really appreciate them, you need to take some time and let it soak in, so give your self 2 days or more (you could do the main parts in 1, so your choice...)The history of the place can be found on your friend Wiki and updates about the Park can be found on the website (http://www.sanparks.org/parks/table_mountain/tourism/attractions.php#goodhope ).Now what to do...Day 1.Starting with the lighthouses: They are at the furthest of the park, so you will need to drive down to Cape Point. There is a walk up to the highest one (or you can take the tram for a fee), and the views are spectacular! But dont stop there...go for a walk to the lower light house as well. On your left hand side, you will most likely see some Cape Fur Seals swimming around in the surf and the views back up to the highest lighthouse are incredible. (NB work is being completed on the walkway to the lower lighthouse, but you can still walk some of the way).Avoid the restaurant, unless you are desperate for food (mainly greasy items like pizza) and bring your own, or drive to the Braai area at Buffels Bay Beach.Now you have 2 options - there is a walking trail to the Cape of Good Hope (highly recommended) or you can drive around there (NB if you walk, you will need to return by the same track). Once there, you can do the obligatory tourist photo with the sign :-), but dont just leave it at that. Let your senses soak in the winds and surrounds of the famous point that was used to lift the morale of sailors in the early days of international shipping.And for something a little different; if you look at the path that leads to Cape Point, you will notice 2 minor paths that lead to the bottom of the cliff face, take the 2nd (that leads "higher") and follow it around the first headland for a great view towards Cape Point and nests of birds in the cliffs, across, above and even underneath you (this path is wide and higher than the waves crash, but does involve some minor stepping over of rocks).Spend the later afternoon at Buffels Bay, doing some minor walks along the False Bay coast, having a swim (not patrolled), or cooking up some early dinner. Stay until about 1630/1700 hrs and some Ostriches usually appear - they are timid and will run away if approached, but are very relaxing to watch at the end of a day.On your way out stop your car alongside the road where you saw people sitting to keep the baboons at bay - the people have gone home, and the baboons come out. From inside your car, you will get to enjoy the little "children" learning to jump on top of their older brothers and sisters, plus the usual stroking of hair of mothers and children and rough-n-tumble of the youth.(NB stay inside your car).Drive back to your accommodation, but stop by Scarborough for a sunset you will not likely forget.Day 2.Check out the wild life (mountain zebra, eland, Cape grysbok, or red hartebeest), wild flowers (Cape Snow, sewejaartjie aree amongst the 1200 in the Cape region) and wild hills as you drive through less less visited part of the Peninsula. Take a walk along the shipwreck coast, on the western side of the park near Olifantsbos. Some of the wrecks are amazing (pieces strewn across broad distances) and one time I nearly stood on a young Cape Fur Seal (1m long) who was sunning itself and enjoying being on the sand (and also oblivious to me). The walk to the Thomas T Tucker is quite easy (about 90 min) and highly recommended, or continue walking along the shipwreck circuit.For the second half of the day, head across to Black Rocks and walk up to the Venus Pool (with its green and orange waters) for a wander along the south western shores of False Bay. Or wander inland to Sirkelsvlei (a largish inland lake) (4 hours).Have a Braai again either in the same area, or return to Buffels Bay to end your stay, knowing that you have experienced the Cape more than most tourists.Please note: Always check with National Parks staff re conditions, closing times of the parks and other safety issues.

Lovely place. Great experience. We went to the lighthouse using the funicular railway, it was amazingly windy up there, but it was a windy day to start with. We saw baboons, (had one on the car at one point), ostriches, bontebok antelope but no zebra. Lovely views.

Not to miss - awesome experience. Don't miss ANY of it, especially if the weather is great, as we had it.Truly dramatic views as you approach the top. If you're in reasonable shape, really no reason to use the funicular, as the drive is quite easy and not that long. Be alert and look for all the little observation points on the way up. There will be lots of sea birds to watch, and if you're lucky, also baboons. Don't miss the extra half an hour walk (both ways to the furthest point, just above the lower and newer light tower. It's all amazingly beautiful.

wonderful natural beauty. Drive down the peninsula through the leafy southern suburbs. Don't miss the walk from cape point to cape of good hope. It takes about 45minutes and it offers fantastic views. Very windy though. You can even walk down the stairs to the ocean beach if you're tough enough. Make sure you stop at boulder beach to see the penguins on the way.

Dramatic Scenery. Dramatic scenery, lots of animals from reptiles to baboons, fantastic hiking trails, great bird watching, pristine deserted beaches and picturesque "camera" views. All in all a very nice trip and honestly as have mentioned in our other reviews of this area a wonderful quite interesting way to spend the day so take water or snacks, sunscreen & a towel if you want to stop at a beach along the cape peninsula drive and enjoy taking in all the sights.

Breath taking. The whole of the Cape point area is another must do on a visit to Cape Town. Game in the reserve is not that easy to spot although the ostriches are not at all bothered by humans. Go down to the vast beaches and have a customary picture taken at the Cape point sign board. Then head up to the departure point for the light house. The restaurant is excellent with a particularly good seafood platter. A funicular runs up to the light house but I recommend the 15 minute walk to stop along the way to enjoy the beautiful scenery. There are any viewing spots around the light house from which you can view South west Africa's southern most point.

Beautiful. The drive down the cape peninsula was beautiful. The scenery and views are spectacular. The creatures we saw along the way or on our walks were also fun. The baboons held up the cars as people stopped to watch and take pictures. The trek across the top of the mountain is quite picturesque.  Take a day and take your time, there is plenty to see. It was quite hot when we were there. Best to go early to avoid too many people and the heat.

The place where dreams come true. Visit this place once and it will stay in your heart forever. I have never experienced the magnitude like this before. You can really feel the Power of Nature in increase your own Power there. Amzing Horizons of your dreams!

Great area to visit. Its a few years since we went down the cape and thoroughly enjoyed the trip again.
Its very busy so set of early to miss the crowds and coaches. The views are stunning.

Visit Cape Point and the Cape of Good Hope. Beautiful views looking down at the end of the Cape Peninsula. Walk up to the lighthouse or take the funicular. Around the corner is the most south westerly point on the continent, the Cape of Good Hope. The nature reserve itself spans most of the peninsula, we saw baboons, ostriches and a tortoise crossing the road.

Not worth a visit. The reason why Cape Point nature reserve is not worth a visit is because the entrance fee isoverpriced - R105.00 per person, so if you have a car (like we did) with 5 persons, you then payover R500 to see bush and only if you are lucky you will see one or two baboons. Once you arein and you want to travel with the sky-train to the very top, you then have to pay a further R52.00 per person or walk uphill for 1 hour. Your only other choice to to eat in the restaurant whichis full with bus tourists. Don't waste your time and money to travel there rather use it for manyof the wonderful places to visit in Cape Town and her surrounding areas.
